webTitle: Burton the new centre of England

fields.headline: Burton the new centre of England
fields.trailText: The England national squad centre will be built at Rangemore near Burton-on-Trent.
fields.body:
The England national squad centre will be built at Rangemore near Burton-on-Trent.

The Football Association has purchased a 360-acre site, formerly part of the Bass brewing family's estate, in order to build the centre close to the geographical heart of the country. It is intended to match and rival the centre the French federation established 15 years ago south of Paris at Clairefontaine.

"We will be making an official announcement about this on Thursday [today]," a spokesman for the FA said yesterday. "Until then I cannot say too much."

George Best left hospital in Belfast yesterday after 10 days of treatment for pneumonia. He will remain in Northern Ireland to convalesce.

Northern Ireland have called up a player from the Irish League: the Linfield striker Glenn Ferguson. The 31-year-old Irish League top scorer has been included in Sammy McIlroy's squad for the friendly against Norway at Windsor Park on February 28. Ferguson, who has scored 24 goals this season, has already won one cap, when he appeared as a substitute in a friendly against Canada in Belfast in April 1999.

The Republic of Ireland coach Mick McCarthy has recalled the central defenders Gary Doherty and Kenny Cunningham and the Feyenoord striker David Connolly to his squad for the friendly with Denmark at Lansdowne Road next Wednesday. - PA

Northern Ireland: Taylor (Fulham), Wright (Bolton); Nolan (Bradford), Hughes (Newcastle), Griffin (Dundee Utd), Williams (Wimbledon), Taggart (Leicester), Murdock (Preston), Kennedy (Watford), Magilton (Ipswich), Jeff Whitley (Man City), Sonner (Birmingham), Johnson (Blackburn), McCarthy (Birmingham), Elliott (Motherwell), Lennon (Celtic), Gray (Oxford), Healy (Preston), Kirk (Hearts), Ferguson (Linfield).

Republic of Ireland: Kelly (Blackburn), Given (Newcastle Utd), Kiely (Charlton); Carr (Tottenham), Staunton (Aston Villa), Harte (Leeds), Breen (Coventry), Dunne (Man City), Cunningham (Wimbledon), Doherty (Tottenham), Roy Keane (Man Utd), Kinsella (Charlton), Carsley (Blackburn), McAteer (Blackburn), Holland (Ipswich), Kilbane (Sunderland), Finnan (Fulham), Delap (Derby), Duff (Blackburn), Quinn (Sunderland), Robbie Keane (Leeds), Connolly (Feyenoord).

webTitle: Bates faces no-confidence vote at FA meeting

fields.headline: Bates faces no-confidence vote at FA meeting
fields.trailText: Opponents of Ken Bates within the FA's hierarchy will today make the first official move to remove the Chelsea chairman at a meeting of the FA board.
fields.body:
Opponents of Ken Bates within the Football Association's hierarchy will today make the first official move to remove the Chelsea chairman at a meeting of the FA board, the 12-man decision-making body.

Bates's reputation at Soho Square has suffered since, in an open letter of resignation from the Wembley stadium project, he was fiercely critical of the FA's involvement.

He claimed the governing body had undermined him and that no one on the board had stood up publicly to defend him or the national stadium project. The FA has so far made no official response to charges in the Bates letter.

Bates will not be at today's meeting because he is on holiday in the Caribbean but a vote of no confidence is anticipated from his fellow board members in his absence.

It appears unlikely that he will be forced out directly on the strength of a no-confidence vote. He is an official representative of the Premier League and technically can be removed only if deselected by the league.

Bates began a three-year term in January 2000 and his future role is next scheduled to be a matter for discussion at the Premier League's agm in June. However, he may be left in a difficult position if the sway of opinion is openly against him.

He has lost friends at Soho Square as a result of the criticism aired in his open letter of resignation to the FA's chief executive Adam Crozier, which also contained the comment that "leaks and spin-doctoring appear to have become a way of life" at FA headquarters, adding that he had "neither trust nor respect" for a number of the people he was working with.

Crozier and the FA chairman Geoff Thompson will attend today's meeting in a non-voting capacity. Among the board members, who are equally divided between the professional and "national" games, Bates is thought to have a particularly strong opponent in David Dein. The Arsenal vice-chairman, like Bates, is one of four Premier League representatives.

Bates, who feels passionately that he was let down over the Wembley project, is not expected to walk away, although it is possible he will be asked to stand down at the FA's summer meeting if he has not gone before then.

If Bates, who chairs the FA's Challenge Cup committee, loses his position on the board he will relinquish his principal seat of power at Soho Square. However, he will remain on the FA council unless deselected in a separate vote.

webTitle: FA Cup countdown: Leicester v Bristol City

fields.headline: Ghost ready to haunt old home
fields.standfirst: Leicester must beware Bristol City and Tony Thorpe, writes  David Foot
fields.trailText: David Foot on why Leicester must beware Bristol City and Tony Thorpe this Saturday.
fields.body:
Tony Thorpe is the striker whose success rate is resented by opposing defences. He simply refuses to play it by the book. The physical presence is insignificant and they can easily miss him altogether.

That, of course, is fatal. He has scored 19 goals this season, his most valuable one - emotionally for the Bristol City fans, financially for the directors - having been the home equaliser with almost the last kick in the previous round of the Cup against Kingstonian.

Defeat would have been a painful embarrassment for a club who under their new manager Danny Wilson had hauled themselves up to the shoulders of the Second Division's leaders, after all the internecine distractions and nondescript football at Ashton Gate.

Thorpe was a £1m buy in 1998 from Fulham after Ray Wilkins was fired and Kevin Keegan appeared to take no more than a perfunctory look. What Thorpe may have seen as a dismissive judgment was not the last he would experience. When he arrived in Bristol, the burdensome price tag resting uneasily on his shoulders, he found there were altogether too many strikers around and he was, no doubt to his surprise, down the list to Ade Akinbiyi and Soren Andersen.

For a long time at Ashton Gate he must have felt he was a superfluous and costly acquisition within a club who were palpably losing their grip and sense of direction. John Ward seemed to have a few reservations about him; so, even more, had Tony Pulis. "I just wasn't his type of player and he didn't want me in the side, said Thorpe. "That was his prerogative."

Progress and the kind of respect he has acquired these days have always had to be earned by him. Leicester is his home town, lending an added piquancy to Saturday's tie. His heart has never strayed far from Filbert Street.

"It's from where all my family come, and my girlfriend's. I return there after a game most weekends. I was a Leicester City player, after all, at schoolboy and apprentice level, and coached by John Gregory. I was still young and the first team eluded me." It did not help when he damaged ankle ligaments. Brian Little decided to release him.

David Pleat took him to Luton, playing him on the left side of midfield and encouraging him to attack. It was Lennie Lawrence who converted him to striker. The goals started coming in profusion. In 1996-97 Thorpe scored 31 times and visiting managers and scouts started driving in convoy to watch him. It was Wilkins who hesitated least and came up with £800,000.

His style and opportunism, at times based on an aptitude for ghosting into the penalty area, has not always blended with that of fellow strikers. "I'm not particularly orthodox," he agrees. "But I like to link play, using brains and technique rather than relying on any bish-bash approach, knocking four people over or smashing my shot over the top."

This season, after being reassured by Wilson that he would definitely be in the team, he has worked up creative partnerships and patterns with Lee Peacock and Peter Beadle in turn.

Thorpe, 26, is one of the more self-possessed members of the team. He retains a sentimental regard for Luton, to whom he returned on loan and might have stayed if the money had been right. "Perhaps Fulham was the wrong move for me. Lennie thought so. Then they offloaded me without my having the chance or time to sparkle."

Wilson, not one of the game's extroverts, has by now put his spell of disaffection at Sheffield Wednesday out of his mind. "He has kept faith with me and I hope I've repaid him with the goals," said Thorpe. "We enjoy training under him and the way he keeps things simple."

The 5ft 8in striker is these days more fulfilled and effective than before in a career which was "quite weird for a couple of years". He has bought a house in north Somerset to underline his intention of staying; he likes his rounds of novice golf and dotes on his eight-month-old son.

Push him, however, and he admits that when he was going through a frustrating period with City, destined for a permanent substitute's place, he even thought about turning his back on football altogether. "I talked about it with my best friend John Hartson, with whom I was a young player at Luton and then an usher at his wedding. I don't suppose I'd have gone through with it but it did cross my mind to get out."

Things are very different this season. He is a player who needs to be encouraged and appreciated, recognised for his worth. Like the inventive Brian Tinnion and promising former academy boys such as Aaron Brown and Matt Hill, he will need to be tactically stifled by Leicester's Peter Taylor, so nearly a Bristol City manager himself a year ago.

But first Taylor will need to work out where the ghost-like opportunist is likeliest to materialise.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Roma 0 - 2 Liverpool
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Roma: 1-Francesco Antonioli; 3-Alessandro Mangone, 19-Walter Samuel, 23-Alessandro Rinaldi, 32-Vincent Candela, 2-Cafu; 11-Emerson, 17-Damiano Tomassi, 8-Hidetoshi Nakata; 24-Marco Delvecchio, 9-Vincenzo Montella.

Liverpool: 1-Sander Westerveld; 6-Markus Babbel, 23-Jamie Carragher, 12-Sami Hyppia, 2-Stephan Henchoz; 16-Dietmar Hamann, 21-Gary McAllister, 20-Nicky Barmby; 3-Christian Ziege; 10-Michael Owen, 9-Robbie Fowler.

Referee: Markus Merk (Germany)

1 Barmby kicks off for a Liverpool side hoping to capitalise on the absence of Batistuta and Totti.
2 Emerson tries to get things going with a probing ball down the left flank. He fails.
3 Free-kick to Roma after Babbel up-ends Candela in a dangerous position on the left. Candela takes, comes to nothing.
4 Ziege lucky to avoid a card for a crunching tackle on Cafu. Westerveld forced down to his right by Nakata from distance.
6 Tomassi finds Emerson in the middle of the park with a great ball before Candela is released on the left; Liverpool close him down.
7 Nakata and Delvecchio combine well on the edge of the area but neither can get in a shot. Liverpool respond with a break and Owen gets to the edge of the Roma area before being muscled off the ball. Liverpool's first meaningful move upfield.
10 Delvecchio released into the area with a fine crossfield pass by Nakata. Crosses, but no one meets it.
12 Free-kick to Roma near the left-hand corner flag. Westerveld punches clear for Cafu to shoot wide for distance.
15 Ziege and McAllister play a one-two on the left but Ziege is unable to pick up the return on the edge of the Roma area.
16 Liverpool starting to knock the ball around the bit more after an early onslaught by Roma. Still yet to have a chance on goal.
17 Cafu crunches into Owen and comes off worse. Struggles to shake off the knock.
19 Fowler steals in behind the Roma defence and shoots wide of the right-hand upright.
21 Delvecchio gets away on the left; Henchoz unlucky to be called for a foul when his challenge looked good. Free-kick comes to nothing.
23 Roma corner on the right. Good defending by Liverpool after the corner is played short, but Houllier's men are have trouble getting out of their half.
25 McAllister gets away to the by-line but is run out for a goal-kick with Owen and Fowler waiting in the middle.
28 Liverpool work the ball around to the left of the Roma area, with Owen and McAllister both looking lively, but a poor ball from Barmby back in to Owen finally blows things.
29 Liverpool free-kick, Ziege takes to the far side of the area, Roma clear.
30 Hamann does well to burgle possession in midfield but is hacked down by Emerson after a run across the park.
31 Liverpool free-kick from fully 35 yards out; Delvecchio almost puts into his own net with a glancing header behind. Corner comes to nothing.
37 Babbel finds Fowler on the edge of the area, Roma clear and Ziege shoots from 20 yards.
38 Liverpool free-kick way out on the left; Ziege takes but it comes to nothing.
39 Candela wins a corner on the left after doing a little dance down by the flag. Zilch.
41 Not pretty at the minute - pretty scrappy in fact.
42 Delvecchio comes in beautifully on a great cross from Rinaldi on the right - and puts it fractionally over from less than 10 yards. Best opening of the half, and should have been a goal.
45 One minute extra to play. Cafu gets away on the right, crosses, Liverpool clear and Emerson strikes from the rebound for a corner. Westerveld claims after a bout of head-tennis in the six-yard box. Half-time. Good job by Liverpool to restrict Roma to one clear chance.

46 Roma kick-off the second half with a shot from the centre circle.
47 GOAL: Roma 0 - 1 Liverpool A shocking error by Rinaldi when he tries to lift the ball over Owen on the edge of the area and ends up passing to him; Owen turns on to his right foot, goes wide of Mangone and slides the ball across Antonioli and into the corner off the net.
50 Substitution Assunçao on for Nakata.
52 Another mistake in the Roma defence almost lets in Owen again.
55 Things not going so well for Roma as passes fail to connect and the crowd fall silent. Liverpool's travelling support fill the void.
58 Scrappy again by Roma as Candela gives the ball away in midfield; Owen and Fowler offside so they cannot capitalise.
60 Corner to Roma; Westerveld claims. Batistuta warming up on the touchline.
61 Another corner to Roma; played short. Ziege gives away a free-kick 30 yards out to the right. Assunçao tries to chip over the top but the ball goes for a goal-kick.
63 Good movement by Liverpool; Fowler plays it wide to the left wing and Barmby strikes first time from the return... over the bar.
65 Assunçao forces a great save from Westerveld with a shot from the edge of the area. Roma getting it together again after a shaky period.
66 Substitution Batistuta on for Tomassi.
67 Cafu tries and fails to get Batistuta in at the near post as Roma come looking for a fight with a formidable frontline of Montella, Delvecchio and Batistuta.
71 GOAL: Roma 0 - 2 Liverpool So much for that. After a free-kick to Liverpool 28 yards out on the right, Antonioli punches clear and a Liverpool one-two sends Ziege to the by-line. He crosses and Owen nips in for his second at the near post
74 Substitution Smicer on for Ziege.
78 Roma look to have lost some confidence as Smicer harasses Emerson on the right flank.
79 Booking Mangone. Substitution Litmananen on for Owen.
82 Substitution Guigou on for Delvecchio.
84 Henchoz gets away with a crafty elbow in the side of Batistuta's head. Liverpool still tight at the back, so much so that Roma are yet to have a decent chance this half.
86 Fowler's run carries the ball into the Roma area before he goes down claiming a penalty.
90 Still no sign of Roma pulling a goal back. Instead, Barmby is allowed to reach the Roma area but wastes his chance by shooting straight at the legs of Antonioli. Four minutes extra to play. Roma win a corner after Assunçao, Guingou and Candela work the ball into the Liverpool area. Comes to nothing.
Full-time: Roma 0 - 2 Liverpool

fields.headline: Heat circulation up 138%
fields.trailText: 7pm: Emap's celebrity weekly has reported a staggering increase in sales, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Heat, the Emap-owned celebrity weekly tipped for closure early last year, has reported a staggering 138% increase in sales for the second half of 2000.

The turnaround in Heat's fortunes comes as the whole celebrity magazine sector enjoys a boost in sales.

Titles such as OK!, Hello! and Now are flourishing.

Barry McIlheney, chief executive of Heat publisher Emap Elan, said: "We're thrilled - I can't remember an increase of this scale."

Mr McIlheney added the huge increase vindicated the more female-friendly content introduced last year by Emap.

Stories such as All Saints' bitch-fights and Madonna's wedding have become the staple fare for the magazine.

Heat's circulation is now 172,311 compared with 72,510 at the same period in 1999.

Across the board, celebrity magazines enjoyed a circulation hike.

Northern & Shell's OK! is the market leader with a circulation of 586,176.

This is an increase of 6% on the same period for the previous year but a 20% recovery from its sales dip to 455,162 for the last six months.

OK!'s arch rival Hello! - which has a new editor-in-chief, former News of the World editor Phil Hall - is stable, with a circulation of 502,679.

This amounts to an increase of 1.5% on Hello!'s December 1999 circulation of 495,349.

Also flourishing is IPC Connect's weekly Now.

It has boosted its circulation by 20% to 475,571 over the past year.

The hike has resulted from the combination of price cutting and aggressive above-the-line marketing.

Hello! publishing director Sally Cartwright said the market for celebrity magazines was "extremely healthy" at the moment.

But Ms Cartwright noted an increasing volatility in the market, which she attributed to one-off exclusive issues resulting from deals with celebrities.

"When you look at an average figure for the period, it will have been affected those single big exclusives, like the Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta Jones issue of OK!"

She noted that Hello!'s ABC figures for the second half of 1997 had been boosted to the tune of almost 70,000 by coverage of the death and funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales.

"It has happened to us in the past and it will again," Ms Cartwright added.

webTitle: The best way to see Canada

fields.headline: The best way to see Canada
fields.standfirst:
I'm going to Canada for three weeks in July and August of this year, and am trying to decide between the Inside Passage cruise tour and the Rocky Mountaineer rail tour. Does anyone have any advice on which would be the best experience? Thanks,
Melanie Chapman
fields.trailText: I'm going to Canada and am trying to decide between the Inside Passage cruise tour and the Rocky Mountaineer rail tour. Any advice on which would be the best experience?
fields.body:
· Two years ago my wife and I did a circular trip starting at Vancouver. We took the bus to Nanaimo on Vancouver Island to Campbell River then to Port Hardy. Did the Inside Passage on the regular boat to Prince Rupert - took 18 hours.

From PR we went by ViaRail to Jasper - only 20 passengers and 5 staff to wait on - observation car was superb. Regular stops en route including overnight at Prince George. Stopped at Patricia Lakes, Jasper for five days and toured area in hire car then took bus to Banff along the Icefields Highway.

Stayed in Banff for five days (preferred Jasper), again using hire car to tour the area, before taking the Rocky Mountaineer back to Vancouver. Pricey but food was excellent and scenery spectacular, particularly when standing outside on the vestibule at the end of the rail carriage.

Finished the trip bussing down to Seattle for return flight home - definitely a good move. Seattle is well worth a visit particularly if you're into rock music - the Experience Music Centre is a must.
Dave Ollis

· I would recommend seeing the Canadian Rockies by rail, and Alaska on the ferry leaving from Bellingham, Washington. Bellingham is between Seattle and Vancouver, and there are frequent flights there from both cities. Check out these two websites: Rocky Mountaineer Home and GoldLeaf Service. There was also an excellent article in last Sunday's Seattle Times about ferry travel to Alaska, from Bellingham.
The weather may be a bit better in August, rather than July, but either month should be nice. Best regards,
Ken McRae

· In May 1999, my husband and I flew to Juneau in Alaska and caught the public ferry back down to Prince Rupert on the coast. From there we took the greyhound bus across to Ontario via Jasper and Banff, taking a few days off in the Rockies.

We were advised that the public ferry trip down the Inside Passage was a cheap way of seeing this amazing part of the world. We were pushed for time, otherwise we would have taken longer and spent more time in Alaska and BC. The ferry trip was beautiful but as the weather was very misty and drizzly we didn't see much. As we were going along the captain of the boat would announce when there were whales, dolphins or porpoises in view. We also saw bald eagles. When in Juneau, we encountered a mass invasion by visitors from a cruise boat. Seeing somewhere for just a couple of hours along with hoards of other people is not my idea of a good time. Also, the locals don't get as much out of the deal as you would think. Visitors eat on the boat and often leave their money there too so don't always even buy the assorted souvenirs on offer. People who do benefit financially are often large companies from outside the area.

Our route from Prince Rupert to Jasper was spectacular, in spite of being in a Greyhound bus! The driver was very knowledgeable and willing to share his experience. He pointed out brown bears and mountain goats en route and stopped the bus so we could watch. The Rocky Mountain rail journey does look fantastic from what I've seen on TV. Personally I would be tempted to take the rail journey and then try to pick up a ferry to see some of the Inside Passage. The accommodation won't be quite as plush as a cruise boat but it will be a heck of a lot cheaper, more flexible and you get more of a feel of what life is like in the region as the ferries are used extensively by local people. I'm sure the ferries do have cabins etc and you would be able to pick one up at various places along the coast, including near Vancouver (if that is where your rail journey ends). You could then add a few days return ferry journey to your rail experience, depending on how far you wanted to go. BC Ferries have an internet site which will give you the info you need. Alaska Marine Highways also have a useful site. Hope that helps. Have a great time!
Hannah Rayfield

· A few years ago, my family and I took a trip to Canada for three weeks and had the most fantastic time. We flew to Toronto and stayed in a hotel downtown for two nights to do the Niagara falls trip and see the city. We then flew to Calgary where we picked up a camper van - not one of these old fashioned things, it had a bedroom and bathroom and a fitted kitchen (make sure the cupboard door are locked when you're going around corners!!). We then drove thought the Rockies to Vancouver. It was fantastic: the Canadians are so well equipped for this kind of travel, and depending upon what kind of mood you're in, you can stay in a 'wilderness site' in the middle of the forest where all the pitches have a barbecue and you can see the dusk fall with a nice cold beer and watch all the wildlife happening around you, or you can stay at a site with a swimming pool and amusements.

We drove through Banff and Jasper, walked on the Columbian ice fields and around Lake Louise. The beauty of this kind of holiday (providing you can drive!) is that you can stay as long as you like in the places you enjoy, and there is no rush to stick to a rigid timetable or do what other people want you to do. When we arrived in Vancouver we took the ferry over to Vancouver island, which you have to see. The ferry ride is fantastic in itself, and the island is beautiful. An absolute must on the island is to go whale watching from the harbour.

Liz France

webTitle: Where to stay and what to do in Amsterdam

fields.headline: Where to stay and what to do in Amsterdam
fields.standfirst:
I'm visiting Amsterdam with my two children for four nights: any recommendations of central, reasonably priced hotels or guest houses? Suggestions on what to see and do would also be welcome; the children are 10 and 14 and I'm hoping that they can have some time to themselves (so I can too!)
Mary Rothbury
fields.trailText: I'm visiting Amsterdam with my two children for four nights: any recommendations of central, reasonably priced hotels or guest houses? Suggestions on what to see and do would also be welcome.
fields.body:
 I just had a wonderful, long weekend (child-free!) in Amsterdam, and most highly recommend popping into the Begijnhof, a courtyard containing a former convent which is now an almshouse (I think) and the English Anglican church, all very pretty and peaceful with interesting plaques and statues. We visited the newly refurbished Rembradthuis - as it was in his day, complete with beds in cupboards - and we had the best chips ever, with delicious accompanying sauces to choose from, out of a little kiosk in a tiny street off Heiligeweeg, which is off Kalvierstraat, near Spui (sorry not to be more precise). Also, the Conzertgebouw has superb acoustics if you like classical music and on Saturday mornings there are 2 lovely street markets in Jordaan near Noorder Kerk, Noorder Markt which is full of delicious organic food, and Linden Maarkt which is a large ordinary street market with wonderful flowers!

 The Vondelpark youth hostel is excellent. It's cheap, and you can have a private room with en-suite faciliteis. Very friendly staff, and you can also get discounts on certain museums and canal trips etc. Check out www.iyhf.org for details.

 The youth hostel at Leidesplein has family rooms and is clean and quite economical; there is another one near the red light district though perhaps that wouldn't be suitable. I went with my two children last year, there are loads of places to visit nearby. We went to a couple of museums on the museumplein (Van Gogh museum is very good and you can get close up to paintings that everyone knows; it's also entertaining watching the tortured artist types).

Anne Frank's house is an experience we'll never forget, very quiet and respectful despite the number of American teenagers - I'm very glad we went. The House Boat museum is also great and doesn't take long. There are lots of tourist info places about and the youth hostel has loads of leaflets and advice etc. It's a great place for children. I'd definitely take mine again.
Tara Hughes

 We liked the Botel, which is an easy walk from the station, but do pay the extra to have the outlook over the water. Small cabins but well fitted and comfortable.
John Kersey

 I recently went to Amsterdam and did the city walk through the old Jewish area, the Jordaan. It is well worth it and away from any tourists.
Mourijn Bok

fields.headline: Esquire sheds downmarket readers
fields.trailText: 6.30pm: Esquire is losing readers following its decision to drop the soft-porn approach, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Esquire is still haemorrhaging readers following its decision to drop the soft porn image synonymous with the monthly men's magazine market.

The National Magazine Company title has suffered another double-figure circulation drop.

The latest Audit Bureau of Circulation figures for July to December 2000 show a 13% period-on-period decrease in circulation to 61,271.

Esquire's circulation to the end of June 2000 was 70,435.

The title is now 39% down year-on-year from its December 1999 figure of 100,482.

But Esquire editor Peter Howarth said NatMags had expected the drop as the result of shedding those readers more interested in a high nipple count.

Mr Howarth repositioned the title last year, replacing cover pictures of semi-naked women with close-ups of celebrities such as Johnny Depp.

"This second ABC since our repositioning does not compare like with like," he said.

"The magazine is now palpably different.

"We have changed our readership profile - the age and ABC1 profile has increased and we are left with people who buy the magazine regularly."

He added that comparing the ABC figure period-on-period shows readership is up 37% and that newsstand sales are solid.

"We took a hit and shed a whole load of younger, more downmarket readers when we went from naked Wonderbra models to Johnny Depp and we have not recovered from it," Mr Howarth said.

"The first year after the repositioning was a year of grief and pain, this year we'll see consolidation and next year we'll see growth.

"By the middle of this year, we'll be back up to a 70,000 circulation."

Mr Howarth wants to attract affluent, loyal 30-year-old readers, "and the more upmarket you go, the fewer readers there are".

The editor predicts the men's 30-something market is about to boom and believes Esquire will be held up as the benchmark.

He pointed out that James Brown's I Feel Good, Felix Dennis' Dennis Publishing, Ampersand and Subject are now targeting 30-something men.

Mr Howarth claimed the success story for Esquire was not its circulation figures but its advertising revenue.

It is making more money on a magazine that sells far fewer copies, he said.

Luxury brands that do not want to be associated with bikini-clad weathergirls are flocking back to a classier product, according to Mr Howarth.

Prada has increased its investment in Esquire three-fold and Armani four-fold.

Mediacom TMB's press director Steve Goodman agreed.

"Esquire has been true to its initial word, has stuck with the new concept and the mag still looks great," said Mr Goodman.

"It is not losing the readers our advertisers are interested in."

But another media buyer was more sceptical.

"Esquire is floundering," he said.

"It reassessed its position in the market and lost circulation, but it was then saying it had settled it down," he added.

"But another double-figure drop means even its core readers aren't happy."

webTitle: Charity shops take steps to recover lost ground

fields.headline: Charity shops take steps to recover lost ground
fields.standfirst: Patrick McCurry finds out how charity shops are trying to reverse the recent downturn in their fortunes
fields.trailText: Patrick McCurry finds out how charity shops are trying to reverse the recent downturn in their fortunes
fields.body:
During the mid-to late 1990s, as out-of-town malls sucked shoppers from city centres, charity shops were hailed as the last bastions of the high street.

Thanks to advantages such as donated goods and subsidised property rates, charity shops seemed to be immune from the competitive pressures suffered by other retailers and were able to post regular year-on-year sales and profit growth.

Today, that's all changed. Giants such as Oxfam have seen profits plunge and have been forced to cut shop support staff. Most charity chains have suffered increased competition from clothing retailers and some have had to close loss-making shops.

But there is evidence that charity shops are fighting back, armed with an array of marketing ideas and more professional management.

The highest-profile casualty so far has been Oxfam, which saw profits plunge from £16.5m in 1997-98 to £7.6m in 1999-2000. Without major action, the charity forecast profits would be just £3.7m in 2003-04. It hopes that cutting the jobs of middle managers involved in supporting shops and giving shop managers more autonomy will help reverse the downturn. Like others, Oxfam has been effected by the fierce competition in mid- and down-market clothes retailing, which has clobbered brands like Marks & Spencer.

At Scope, which has also been badly hit in the last two years, trading managers are pinning their hopes on a package of new initiatives designed to raise the shops' profile and attract new kinds of customers. Scope's shops' profits halved to £2.6m in 1999-2000. This was due to factors such as fierce competition among clothing retailers, problems in recruiting staff and higher shop rents. The charity closed 22 shops last year, leaving it with about 300, and has made changes such as ensuring all its shops can accept debit and credit cards. It has also launched promotions, such as Scope for Sound, which focuses on CDs and records and has attracted support from Chris Tarrant and local DJs, many of whom have donated CDs.

"That kind of campaign helps us to attract young people interested in music, who may not have been in our shops before," says spokeswoman Marcella McEvoy. The charity has also experimented with specialist sections in some shops. "For example, we've introduced book sections in some shops, and that's helped raise sales," she says.

Scope is also looking at moving stock around the country to create themed stores in certain areas, depending on the local customer profile. "We're looking at setting up shops dedicated to, say, wedding wear or books," says McEvoy.

At Imperial Cancer Research Fund, which has 430 shops, the record is more positive, according to southern region head of retail Lucy Machin: "We seem to have bucked the trend, with 1999-2000 profits up 18% to £7.1m."

She notes that the charity closed 26 loss-making shops last year. She attributes the strong financial performance in large part to improved management processes. "For example, we've done a lot of work on improving the speed that we get donated goods to shops, which cuts out stock control costs a lot." The charity also ensures its local pricing is competitive, depending on the locality of the shop, says Machin.

Early indicators suggest that Christmas sales in charity shops were relatively strong and many believe a corner has been turned. Thanks to advantages such as donated goods and subsidised property rates, charity shops seemed to be immune from the competitive pressures suffered by other retailers and were able to post regular year-on-year sales and profit growth. Today, that's all changed. Giants such as Oxfam have seen profits plunge and have been forced to cut shop support staff. Most charity chains have suffered increased competition from clothing retailers and some have had to close loss-making shops. But there is evidence that charity shops are fighting back, armed with an array of marketing ideas and more professional management. The highest-profile casualty so far has been Oxfam, which saw profits plunge from £16.5m in 1997-98 to £7.6m in 1999-2000. Without major action, the charity forecast profits would be just £3.7m in 2003-04. It hopes that cutting the jobs of middle managers involved in supporting shops and giving shop managers more autonomy will help reverse the downturn. Like others, Oxfam has been effected by the fierce competition in mid- and down-market clothes retailing, which has clobbered brands like Marks & Spencer. At Scope, which has also been badly hit in the last two years, trading managers are pinning their hopes on a package of new initiatives designed to raise the shops' profile and attract new kinds of customers. Scope's shops' profits halved to £2.6m in 1999-2000. This was due to factors such as fierce competition among clothing retailers, problems in recruiting staff and higher shop rents. fields.headline: Simplify conduct rules, says Major
fields.trailText: John Major yesterday called for parliament "to go back to basics" and redraft its rules and            regulations governing the conduct of MPs to make them simpler and easier to follow.
fields.body:
John Major yesterday called for parliament "to go back to basics" and redraft its rules and regulations governing the conduct of MPs to make them simpler and easier to follow.

The former prime minister attacked the growing complexity of rules governing MPs' behaviour, saying that they had become unnecessarily intrusive since they were introduced in the wake of the cash for questions scandal involving ex-ministers Neil Hamilton and Tim Smith.

"The rules need to be revised every parliament to take account of changes. We need - dare I say it - to go back to basics," Mr Major said referring to a much-derided slogan of the last Tory government.

Mr Major was giving evidence to the Commons standards and privileges committee which is looking at changing the rules for declarations under the MPs' register of interests. He had been shocked at the behaviour of lobbyists and consultants which emerged in the cash for questions scandal and appalled at the behaviour of some of his colleagues. But he told the committee that there was a need for substantial reforms to update the original rules set out by Lord Nolan, first chairman of the committee on standards in public life.

He condemned the use of the Commons standards committee for "tit for tat" disputes between members of opposing parties "who rushed off to inform the press immediately a complaint had been made."

"We have had great public speculation. In the case of some members, grotesquely unfair speculation that has hurt them, their families and their constituencies.

"Some trivial referrals that we have seen, that are simply an error or misunderstanding by the member concerned, have been held up to the public gaze. It exposes them, quite disgracefully, to comment before they have any chance to defend themselves at all."

He said where the complaint was about a MP genuinely forgetting to register a flight or a trip, it should be sorted out with Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards, and never reported.

webTitle: Expenses policy sparks BBC work to rule

fields.headline: Expenses policy sparks BBC work to rule
fields.trailText: 5.15pm: A change to the BBC's policy on expenses has prompted staff to vote for industrial action, writes Wale Azeez.
fields.body:
A change to the BBC's policy on expenses has prompted staff to vote for industrial action.

In a ballot of more than 6,000 BBC staff - all members of broadcasting union Bectu - 85% per cent voted for work-to-rule and 60% supported all-out strike action.

According to the union, the BBC will be given seven days notice of the action, which is likely to start in the last week of February.

Industrial action would hit all areas of the BBC, apart from its commercial arm BBC Worldwide and the corporation's orchestras.

Bectu said the row flared up after the corporation introduced new rules "without agreement" on February 1.

Some allowances for lunches away from the workplace have been scrapped, while claims for evening meals have been restricted to when staff work more than 12 hours away from their workplace.

In addition, a cap of £55 per night has been placed on hotel claims.

"We think the BBC has been unreasonable with its decision on allowances, which are inconsistent with industry standards," said a spokesman for Bectu.

"Workers can get a hot meal after 7.30pm at ITV but BBC workers have to work 12 long hours before they can get a meal."

He added BBC managers authorised and set their own levels of allowance, whereas a cap had been placed on staff expenses.

"It's basically one rule for management and one rule for those that make the programmes."

A BBC spokesman responded by saying the change in policy was about making sure the corporation was "tightening up wherever possible, in a climate of making savings wherever we can, to spend more om priority programming".

He also insisted the rules were not set in stone.

"Some kind of cast-iron rule is not sensible - we try to be flexible where we can."

fields.headline: Blair retreats on patient rights
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday made a dramatic climbdown by changing the contentious government bill set to abolish the community health councils, the bodies that act as patients' champions.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday made a dramatic climbdown by changing the contentious government bill set to abolish the community health councils, the bodies that act as patients' champions.

Bowing to intense pressure from patients' groups and Labour backbenchers, the prime minister accepted two amendments to the health and social care bill, which will improve patients' rights in the NHS.

MPs had bitterly opposed the bill because they feared it would weaken patients' rights. David Hinchliffe, Labour chairman of the select committee on health, described the government's plans as a "dog's breakfast that complicates the complaints procedure".

The bill will set up a patient advocacy and liaison service for complaints against GPs and hospitals requiring immediate attention, and patients' forums to examine longer term complaints. Mr Hinchliffe won the support of 24 Labour MPs, including Blairite loyalists, for his amendments. The first will ensure patients get independent help on making a complaint - answering the fear that complaints might not be treated seriously if handled entirely by health authorities. The second is the introduction of patient councils to oversee and link the forums.

Labour backbenchers, who mounted a vigorous campaign against the bill, last night welcomed the concession. A leading campaigner said: "We still need some fine tuning. But this is a great improvement."

Among others welcoming the government's climbdown was Murray Benham, spokesman for the association of CHCs. He said: "It is fantastic the government is recognising the strength of feeling against the bill, but it's been a long process."

The Tories made clear last night that they would do their best to kill off the bill when it moves to the Lords, despite the amendments.

fields.headline: Milestone gives short measure
fields.standfirst:
Is the unemployment rate at its lowest level for 25 years? The Guardian's economics team investigates

Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Is the unemployment rate at its lowest level for 25 years? The Guardian's economics team investigates.
fields.body:
It is the morning of March 14 and in Downing Street Tony Blair is putting on his best suit in readiness for the short drive to Buckingham Palace. With the cameras watching his every move, the prime minister is off to inform the Queen that he wants to call an election.

The moment when the prime minister is planning to launch his re-election campaign is still a closely guarded secret. But March 14 could be as good a day as any. Why? Because on current trends that will be the day when the office for national statistics announces that in February unemployment fell below the million mark for the first time since December 1975.

After nigh on nine years of steady economic growth, the number of people out of work and claiming benefit fell 25,500 last month to 1,004,800, according to official figures released yesterday. Over the past six months it has been declining by 10,800 a month on average, and if February matches that performance the total will be in six figures.

For a Labour government seeking re-election this looks like an opportunity too good to miss. It has all the ingredients: a sign that economic policies are delivering, the prospect of a return to the full employment era of the 50s and 60s, and the chance to expunge for once and for all memories of the taunts hurled by Mrs Thatcher in 1979. The abiding image of the election that ushered in 18 years of Conservative rule was the Saatchi & Saatchi poster depicting a dole queue with the slogan "Labour isn't working".

Woven into the fabric

David Blunkett said yesterday's data was "a major milestone, shedding the legacy of mass unemployment". While the employment secretary was guilty of a little hyperbole, there is no doubting the significance of the million mark. For more than 20 years, mass unemployment has been woven into the fabric of politics. It was Jim Callaghan who sounded the death-knell for the era of full employment with his speech to the Labour party conference in 1976, and within five years jobless levels were back to totals not seen since the depression of the 1930s. Yosser Hughes in Boys from the Blackstuff summed up the mood of despair in the 1980s. A decade later, the steel workers-turned-strippers in the Full Monty showed the problem had not gone away.

Now it seems mass unemployment may be a thing of the past. Mr Blair will be able to boast that the government is leaving office with the jobless total lower than when it was elected, something that could not be said of either the 1964-70 or 1974-79 administrations. Unsurprisingly, he and his cabinet colleagues will want to make as much political capital as they can out of the encouraging trend, even though they are entitled to only part of the credit.

Labour might like to give the impression that unemployment started to fall on May 1 1997, the day Mr Blair was elected, but the reality is different. Unemployment has been falling since the immediate aftermath of Britain's departure from the exchange rate mechanism in 1992 and had dropped from 2.96m to 1.66m by the time the Conservatives were ousted.

The precise reason for the improvement is hotly debated. Some argue that credit should go to the Conservatives for the supply-side measures of the 1980s, which made the labour market more flexible. However, the big change in the 1990s has been a more benign global economic environment in which the ebbing away of inflationary pressure following the twin oil shocks of the 1970s has made life easier for policymakers. Politicians and central bankers have seized the opportunity and made few blunders in the conduct of macroeconomic policy. The demand for jobs rose under Conservative chancellor Kenneth Clarke and continued to grow under Gordon Brown, at least until recent months when it has flattened out.

Labour's big idea in 1997 was the New Deal, a £5.2bn scheme to take the long-term unemployed out of the dole queue and re-equip them for the world of work. While there is general agreement that the New Deal is on a different plane from all previous make-work schemes, researchers who have tried to disentangle its effects on unemployment have found it of a secondary importance to the general health of the economy. In late 1999, the National Institute for Economic and Social Research said that, of the 145,000 18- to 24-year-olds who had found work through the New Deal, only 30,000 would still have been unemployed without it.

While Labour's commitment to using innovative solutions to long-term unemployment has been commendable, the same cannot be said of its selective use of data for political ends. The government's new-found enthusiasm for the claimant count measure of unemployment represents opportunism of the highest order.

In opposition, Mr Blair and his colleagues fiercely criticised the way the Tories massaged down the claimant count measure of unemployment by repeatedly changing the definition of joblessness to exclude trainees, the long-term sick, early retirees and other segments of the population. After the 30 changes to the count, Labour said it would rely on the more reliable International Labour Organisation definition of unemployment, which includes all those available and looking for work, not just those on benefits. Indeed, in February 1998 the government changed presentation of the monthly unemployment figures to downgrade the claimant and give more emphasis to the ILO method of calculation. But, with an election in the offing, the claimant count makes better headlines. It is not just that the ILO measure is higher, it is a lot higher: 1,560,000 at the latest count. This figure was absent from the statement issued by Mr Blunkett yesterday. According to experts, even the ILO definition does not give a true picture of the labour market.

Paul Bivand, senior research fellow at the Unemployment Unit, which lobbies on behalf of the jobless, said: "I think the ILO definition... excludes large numbers of people for one reason or another. For example, people with family responsibilities who nevertheless want to work, people who have given up hope of finding work, and people who are sick and disabled."

Industrial regions

Professor Stephen Fothergill of Sheffield Hallam University said: "There is no doubt that the true level of unemployment since 1997 has fallen. The last time I did a comprehensive analysis to measure the real level in January 1997 it was 3.9m. Now I suspect the real level is somewhat below 3m. It is a significant improvement but it is perhaps not as big as we would wish to see. There is still a huge problem which is not picked up by the official figures."

There was a tendency of politicians and journalists based in London to ignore the pockets of mass unemployment in the industrial regions ravaged by the deep recessions of the 1980s and early 1990s. Yesterday's figures showed manufacturing has shed 106,000 jobs in the past year, with textiles, leather and transport equipment bearing the brunt.

One indication of the hidden pool of joblessness is the quadrupling of people classified as long-term sick, from 500,000 at the beginning of the 80s to just under 2m now. "You can't explain that by a deterioration in health", Prof Fothergill said. "It is clearly linked to what is going on in the labour market."

For all the caveats, Labour has a good tale to tell the electorate. Whatever the real level of unemployment, it is heading in the right direction and in some of the more prosperous parts of the country the goal of full employment has already been achieved. To his credit, Mr Blunkett admitted yesterday that "a million people claiming benefits and out of work is still too many". With unemployment still blighting many poor regions, such realism is to be welcomed. In those parts of the country where the Full Monty is still a reality, there is a lot of work to do.

The things they say

"My dispute with the statistics is that they are not an accurate measure of the level of unemployment, but that the government continues to represent them as such ... It appears that every effort is being made to discredit my attempts to take politics out of statistics."

John Prescott, March 1994

"Public concern over the validity of unemployment statistics will not go away until the next government takes steps to improve their basis."

Adrian Smith, president of the Royal Statistical Society, April 1997

In February 1998, Labour rejected a switch from the flawed claimant count to a full monthly survey of unemployment as too expensive. It said it would introduce a monthly measure of unemployment based on the existing quarterly Labour Force Survey.

"It is hoped the move will restore public confidence in figures that had become widely discredited."

Andrew Smith, employment minister February 1998

fields.headline: Tories pledge cull of street 'eyesores'
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Ugly and unnecessary road signs would be subjected to a "cull" under a Tory government, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Ugly and unnecessary road signs would be subjected to a "cull" under a Tory government, it was announced yesterday.

The shadow environment secretary, Archie Norman, said that for too long signs had been allowed to sprout unchecked, needlessly creating thousands of "chaotic eyesores".

He promised a review, leading to removal of duplicated and unnecessary signs, posts, bins, and other "street furniture" and rationalisation of those allowed to remain.

A recent survey by English Heritage had found that 70% of all street furniture was unnecessary, and research has suggested that excessive signs lead to accidents by distracting motorists, said Mr Norman.

He added: "Our streets are not just highways for people to drive down. They are where people live. Yet their local character is now being destroyed by a forest of ill-designed signs.

"For too long, little attention has been paid to urban and rural street design. We must now learn from our past mistakes.

"We will organise a systematic review of roadside design and criteria and a cull of unnecessary signs."

Traditional and older signs would be largely exempt, as they added to local character and protect the landscape from "bland standardisation".

fields.headline: Labour ready to curb top pay
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, is to take a tough stance on spiralling board room pay ahead of the election. He is to break his 18-month silence on his plans to curb boardroom excess in an announcement "shortly", following up a consultation document issued to the industry in July 1999.
fields.body:
Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, is to take a tough stance on spiralling board room pay ahead of the election. He is to break his 18-month silence on his plans to curb boardroom excess in an announcement "shortly", following up a consultation document issued to the industry in July 1999.

While this paper outlined ideas to improve shareholder responsibility for setting remuneration of company direc tors, including mandatory voting by shareholders, industry sources now believe that Mr Byers may introduce any changes into an ongoing review of company law.

Sources said the government was in the process of deciding whether it was necessary to make it compulsory for shareholders to vote on remuneration policies.

Mr Byers had been expected to make his decision known six months ago but sources believe he had been impressed by shareholder reaction to the pay award to Chris Gent, the chief executive of Vodafone.

His inaction in the intervening period since the consultation document was issued, however, has prompted Pirc, the pensions investment and research consultants, to demand the right for shareholders to vote on every company's remuneration policy.

Alan MacDougall, managing director of Pirc, who is writing to all the companies in the FTSE All Share index, said he had taken the decision to "up the ante" on pay.

"Overall pay levels continue to spiral, incentive targets are widely perceived to be weak and public controversies persist. In the face of this shareholders have no formal opportunity to exercise oversight over the process," he said.

He is writing to major companies to tell them unless shareholders are given the opportunity to vote on directors' pay, Pirc will advise pension fund and insurance company clients to vote against the re-election of the chairman of the remuneration committee.

webTitle: Running battle between Christie and Coe

fields.headline: Running battle between Christie and Coe
fields.trailText: February 15 2001: The sporting rivalry between two of Britain's most successful athletes erupted into a bout of public character assassination yesterday after Sebastian Coe accused Linford Christie of "boorishness".
fields.body:
The sporting rivalry between two of Britain's most successful athletes erupted into a bout of public character assassination yesterday after Sebastian Coe accused Linford Christie of "boorishness".

Coe claimed Christie was only made captain of the British team to "buy some peace", and his time in charge was marred by "continual conflict".

The squabble was ignited by an interview in which Christie, who yesterday completed a two-year suspension after testing positive for the banned drug nandrolone, labelled athletics officials "corrupt".

Coe, who won two Olympic titles during the 1980s, responded by saying that Christie had been fortunate to escape a drugs ban at the Seoul Olympics in 1988.

"The test result was attributed to ginseng and he was given the benefit of the doubt by the sport he now despises. Some thought him lucky. Me included.

"And in his recent high court battles, tales of abuse and threatening behaviour towards drug testers were shocking."

Coe claimed that Christie made life unbearable for team officials.

In a passage which bordered on racism, Coe, who is now a senior aide to William Hague, wrote: "I sat in one team meeting where he made himself deliberately unintelligible to all but those who had a passing knowledge of jive."

webTitle: New hospitals promised in five-year NHS plan

fields.headline: New hospitals promised in five-year NHS plan
fields.trailText: The government today unveiled a pre-election boost for the NHS promising that twenty nine new hospitals, costing £3.1 billion and providing almost 3,000 extra beds would be built in the next five years.
fields.body:
The government today unveiled a pre-election boost for the NHS promising that twenty nine new hospitals, costing £3.1 billion and providing almost 3,000 extra beds would be built in the next five years.

Health Secretary Alan Milburn told the commons that he was approving 11 more projects than planned, and called it "an unprecedented expansion in new hospital developments in the NHS".

Mr Milburn confirmed a further £250 million would be spent on a new network of "fast track surgery centres" aimed at cutting waiting lists announced by prime minister Tony Blair earlier in the day.

But shadow health secretary Dr Liam Fox called it a "sham announcement" without real substance that was merely aimed at grabbing headlines in the run-up to the widely-expected general election.

He said Labour had produced a "wish list" for voters, "bribing them with taxes they have not paid yet".

Mr Milburn told the Commons: "For too long investment in NHS infrastructure has been a low priority when it should have been a high priority."

He added: "The prevailing culture in the NHS has been one of bed closure and cutback. That is no longer sustainable. What the NHS needs today is more, not fewer, beds."

But there is no guarantee that all the hospitals will be built. Many will be built under the private finance initiative (PFI) and will be subject to tricky commercial negotiations - which may not succeed in all cases.

The NHS Plan published last July indicated that nine new hospital developments would be given the go-ahead this year, with a further nine next year.

But having considered the bids, Mr Milburn said there was a strong case for investment in all 29 proposed schemes.

He told MPs: "I have accepted that advice. Instead of approving 18 schemes, I am today giving the go-ahead to all 29."

webTitle: No end in sight to dome controversy

fields.headline: No end in sight to dome controversy
fields.standfirst:
Tony Blair's hopes of ending political controversy over the Millennium Dome before the general election were dealt a serious blow this lunchtime when John Prescott announced that Legacy is to lose its preferred bidder status, says political correspondent Nicholas Watt
Special report: Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's hopes of ending political controversy over the Millennium Dome before the general election were dealt a serious blow this lunchtime when John Prescott announced that Legacy is to lose its preferred bidder status, says political correspondent Nicholas Watt.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's hopes of ending political controversy over the Millennium Dome before the general election were dealt a serious blow this lunchtime when John Prescott announced that Legacy is to lose its preferred bidder status.

His decision means that embarrassing speculation about the future of the dome will intensify at the very moment when the prime minister hopes to turn people's attention to the government's record on the NHS and education.

Legacy will remain in the field, but it is to be joined by other groups, including the bid by the popular Pierre Yves Gerbeau, the former dome operator, guaranteeing weeks of stories which will remind voters of the government's failure to take a grip of the troubled Greenwich site.

Downing Street has laid out an elaborate grid running up the election date - expected on May 3 - with scores of events hailing the government's achievements. Mr Blair's aides had pencilled in today for a final decision on the dome, with the hope that handing over the site to Legacy would take the political sting out of the issue.

Instead, today's new bulletins will be dominated by scathing reports about the government's handling of the dome, overshadowing a major speech by the prime minister on the future of the health service.

Downing Street is braced for a wave of criticism over its decision, which is likely to be dubbed a "non decision". However, ministers hope that their decision will, in the long term, prove to have been wise. Ministers said yesterday that critics will eventually concede that it is better to take time to reach the right decision, rather than making a hasty decision which proves to be wrong.

On a political level, ministers pointed out that their decision shows that they do not show favours to Labour donors. Robert Bourne, the head of the Legacy bid, has given thousands of pounds to Labour and hosted a birthday party for Peter Mandelson last year.

The dome is unlikely to alter the result of the election which Labour is expected to win. But the issue will jolt the government and remind voters that on a major project - which Tony Blair said would define his government - the government has failed dismally.

webTitle: Dazed & Confused Refuels with motoring title

fields.headline: Dazed & Confused Refuels with motoring title
fields.trailText: 6pm: Dazed & Confused is to launch a global motoring and style magazine called Refuel, reports Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Underground fashion bible Dazed & Confused is to launch a global motoring magazine with a difference called Refuel.

Like its sister title, Refuel will be aimed at ABC1 readers aged 17-35.

The bi-monthly will attempt to combine motoring and style-magazine genres.

The publisher wants to concentrate on the design of cars and their lifestyle effect.

Refuel will not focus on engineering and mechanical features.

The magazine will be printed and published in London from June.

Dazed & Confused founders Jefferson Hack and Rankin Waddell intend to launch Refuel in 70 countries, reaching a readership of over 250,000.

Dazed & Confused editor Mr Hack was not available for comment.

Dazed & Confused, which covers art, music and fashion, has become the definitive youth style magazine since the mid-1990s.

The magazine has recently tried to extend its readership to New York, Los Angeles, Paris and Milan.

fields.headline: Booker judges announced
fields.trailText: The judging panel chosen for the 33rd Booker Prize, announced yesterday, shows a disdain for the 'celebrity' panellist in favour of novelists, poets and academics.
fields.body:
The judging panel chosen for the 33rd Booker Prize, announced yesterday, shows a disdain for the 'celebrity' panellist in favour of novelists, poets and academics.

Chair of the judging panel is Kenneth Baker, formerly Conservative minister of education, now Lord Barker of Dorking and compiler of poetry anthologies.

He will be joined by writer Philip Hensher, a prolific book reviewer whose novel Kitchen Venom won the Somerset Maugham award in 1996; novelist and poet Michèle Roberts, whose 1992 novel Daughters of the House was itself shortlisted for the Booker Prize; Kate Summerscale, literary editor of the Daily Telegraph and writer of the acclaimed biography of eccentric cross-dressing heiress Joe Carstairs; and Rory Watson, Professor of English Studies at the University of Stirling.

Unlike the Whitbread Prize, which has famously included Jerry Hall and Tim Rice on its judging panel, the Booker tends to select more high-brow arbiters in keeping with its claim to be the most prestigious literary accolade. Last year's panel, which chose Margaret Atwood's The Blind Assassin as the winner, raised eyebrows for its inclusion of broadcaster Mariella Frostrup.

 The shortlisted books will be announced in mid-September with the winner announced on 17 October.

fields.headline: Class struggle
fields.standfirst:
Hazel Southam meets the schoolboy who beat the bullies with an award-winning website
More net news
fields.trailText: Hazel Southam meets the schoolboy who beat the bullies with an award-winning website
fields.body:
Oli Watts never expected to be bullied. Then one day he arrived for his lessons and was ostracised by his classmates. After that the name-calling began. It was the start of six months of what he describes as "verbal and psychological abuse".

"It makes you feel very upset and low," he says. "It made me lose all confidence. I was a different person. It can make you feel very friendless and isolated. I liken it to being on a desert island when there's nobody there that you know. It was a horrible experience. I still don't know why it happened. And it doesn't leave you. I still feel the problems from 18 months ago."

But 16-year-old Oli was not about to be beaten by the bullies. And so a year ago, he set up www.pupiline.net, a website to provide a forum for fellow teenagers to talk about bullying.

The site receives between 10,000 and 15,000 hits a month and has just been nominated for the Cable & Wireless Childnet Awards, due to be announced in Washington in April.

"My Dad was driving me to school and we were talking about bullying and what I was doing on the internet, and he said, 'Why don't you put the two together?' So that evening I went upstairs and put my thoughts and feelings onto a web page and from then onwards, it's grown," says Oli, who is now preparing to take 10 GCSEs at a new school, while managing the site.

Pupiline's 250 pages make poignant reading, with subjects ranging from teenage pregnancy to exam stress. But the forum that still receives the most visitors is the one on bullying. "I was bullied because I am thin, so I ate, ate, ate. Then I felt fat, so I stopped eating," says one entry.

"I was punched, kicked and locked in a locker," says another.

"Has anyone else come across the fact that teachers are bullies too?" asks a third.

It is grim reading. There i s clearly a world of bullying out there, and its disparate, isolated, silenced members are given a voice through Pupiline.

"I am eight and I am bullied every day by five boys at my school."

"I am nine-years-old and I am being bullied at my school and it is making me very upset. Every day I come home feeling sad."

There is even one message from a former bully. "Why do people find enjoyment out of seeing others hurt? I used to push people around and laugh at them when they tripped over. Now I know it was wrong.

"Most bullies start with problems at home like I did, then when they can't stand it any more they take it out on people who they see a lot."

Oli's father, David, himself a school teacher, remembers the time when Oli was suffering at school. "He was always into everything, but when I think of the darkest days, he sat and did nothing. It was quite frightening.

"But now he's developed in a very mature and positive fashion. We are incredibly proud of him."

The family celebrated the first anniversary of the site with a birthday cake. Everyone, including Oli's younger brother, Harry (13), who has also been bullied, helps with the site's production. All the contributors are under 21.

The whole family will fly to Washington in April to join teenagers from around the world who have also been shortlisted for the Childnet Awards.

webTitle: Bristol faces big school cuts after tax referendum

fields.headline: Bristol faces big school cuts after tax referendum
fields.standfirst: Education site
fields.trailText: Bristol was last night facing up to the prospect of big cuts in its education budget, with school closures and scores of teaching redundancies, after voters in the city unexpectedly rejected any council tax increase this year - against the advice of the Labour controlled local authority.
fields.body:
Bristol was last night facing up to the prospect of big cuts in its education budget, with school closures and scores of teaching redundancies, after voters in the city unexpectedly rejected any council tax increase this year - against the advice of the Labour controlled local authority.

In a ground-breaking referendum among the city's 278,000 taxpayers, only 18% backed the council's preferred option of a 4% tax increase which would have effectively meant a standstill budget after inflation is taken into account.

Almost 54% backed no increase, despite warnings from the Labour group - which has a majority of only two - of £4.5m cuts in the education budget and the loss of around 180 teaching posts.

David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, accused councillors of being irresponsible and "reckless beyond belief".

He added: "If they accept the decision of the council taxpayers and in the process abdicate their responsibility for education in the city, then there will be severely damaged schools throughout Bristol, and they deserve to be declared a failing local education authority with all the consequences - including privatisation - that will inevitably follow."

The referendum attracted a 40 % turnout, 10% higher than in local elections. Voters were given two other options: a 2% increase on the £351m budget, which would still have meant cuts of £2.2m and a 6% rise, which could have brought extra spending of £2.2m.

Labour councillors appeared cautiously confident of persuading voters to opt for a modest increase, which would have amounted to around £75 on the average band D property which pays £1,000 annually. Council tax in the city has been frozen for two years.

Council leader George Micklewright last night tried to put a brave face on what he called a "worthwhile exercise in local democracy".

But he conceded: "This was not the result we hoped for and we made it clear what the consequences of no increase would be, with some graphic illustrations. No one could say they did not have enough information."

He could not say whether any teachers would be sacked because under local school management individual schools would have to make decisions. "But it looks like some teaching posts will go."

Ministers had been keenly awaiting the Bristol result because they had been hailing the referendum as a ground-breaking exercise in local democracy - the first poll of its kind in a large city.

In a smaller referendum in Milton Keynes two years ago, voters opted for a 10% increase, almost four times the rate of inflation, after being presented with three other options - including the prospect of big cuts in education if they went for a smaller increase.

webTitle: Norfolk county council in school 'no snacks' dispute

fields.headline: Crunch nears in biscuit dispute
fields.standfirst: Education site
fields.trailText: An education authority yesterday intervened in a dispute at a primary school about whether children should be allowed to eat sweets and biscuits during breaks.
fields.body:
An education authority yesterday intervened in a dispute at a primary school about whether children should be allowed to eat sweets and biscuits during breaks.

Norfolk county council said officials would meet Sylvia Trafford, head of Catton Grove first and nursery school, in Norwich, to resolve the issue.

Christopher Purvis, six, was taken out of school by his mother after Mrs Trafford insisted her pupils ate only fruit or vegetables for snacks in their breaks. Bernadette Purvis, 34, believes her son should eat what he wants and has been trying to get the "no biscuit" rule overturned.

Yesterday, a council spokeswoman said that Norfolk had adopted a healthy eating policy which it wanted schools to follow, but that rules on what children could eat and when were a matter for the individual schools.

Mrs Trafford said the "no confectionery at break" policy had run for years.

"We do not have a no crisps or no biscuit rule in school. Children can eat what they like when they arrive . Our rule applies at break times when they are in our care, because we think that's a sensible policy. I have said I'm quite happy for Christopher to eat a biscuit before school starts but the parent insists he must eat it at break time. This is only one parent and she is generally very happy with her son's progress at school."

fields.bodyText: An education authority yesterday intervened in a dispute at a primary school about whether children should be allowed to eat sweets and biscuits during breaks. Norfolk county council said officials would meet Sylvia Trafford, head of Catton Grove first and nursery school, in Norwich, to resolve the issue. Christopher Purvis, six, was taken out of school by his mother after Mrs Trafford insisted her pupils ate only fruit or vegetables for snacks in their breaks. Bernadette Purvis, 34, believes her son should eat what he wants and has been trying to get the "no biscuit" rule overturned. Yesterday, a council spokeswoman said that Norfolk had adopted a healthy eating policy which it wanted schools to follow, but that rules on what children could eat and when were a matter for the individual schools. Mrs Trafford said the "no confectionery at break" policy had run for years. "We do not have a no crisps or no biscuit rule in school. Children can eat what they like when they arrive . Our rule applies at break times when they are in our care, because we think that's a sensible policy. I have said I'm quite happy for Christopher to eat a biscuit before school starts but the parent insists he must eat it at break time. This is only one parent and she is generally very happy with her son's progress at school." Press Association

fields.headline: FootofGod.com forced to close
fields.trailText: 6pm: A football site has been forced to close following threats of legal action from Fifa, writes Sean Ingle.
fields.body:
FootofGod.com, the website that touted itself as the "first ever comprehensive online soccer video clip service" has been forced to shut down after threats of legal action from Fifa and other copyright holders.

The site - a huge online archive of thousands of goals and "moments of soccer history" - claimed it served "as an invaluable resource and source of joy for soccer fans, players, coaches, and administrators alike."

But Fifa and other copyright holders disagreed. They claimed the clips it used, which included several from the BBC and ITV, clearly breached copyright law - and threatened legal action if the site wasn't closed down immediately.

Today a statement on the FootofGod.com site insisted the closure was only temporary. "In response to legal action taken by representatives of Fifa and other copyright owners, Foot of God is temporarily unavailable," it said.

"It is our intent to resolve these issues as soon as possible. If you wish to be informed by email as to when Foot of God is again available, please register. Please check back periodically for additional updates.

"We appreciate your patience and support."

webTitle: Clinton denies taking cash for pardon

fields.headline: Clinton denies taking cash for pardon
fields.standfirst: Special report: Clinton in crisis
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton has denied any wrongdoing over his pardon of fugitive financier Marc Rich.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton has denied any wrongdoing over his pardon of fugitive financier Marc Rich.

His denial follows a federal prosecutor's move to crank up the heat on the former US president by launching a criminal investigation to determine if money played a role in the last-minute pardon.

In a statement issued last night, Mr Clinton said: "As I have said repeatedly, I made the decision to pardon Marc Rich based on what I thought was the right thing to do.

"Any suggestion that improper factors, including fundraising for the [Democratic National Committee] or my library, had anything to do with the decision are absolutely false. I look forward to cooperating with any appropriate inquiry."

US attorney Mary Jo White's probe is expected to examine bank and telephone records and other documents for evidence of illegal conduct.

The move comes after senate and house committees launched similar probes of the Rich pardon, one of 141 granted by Mr Clinton on his final day in office.

Ms White, who was appointed to her post by Clinton in 1993, has said the pardon was granted without consultation with her office, which indicted Mr Rich in 1983.

Critics have noted that Mr Rich's ex-wife Denise contributed an estimated $450,000 [£311,000] to the Clinton presidential library fund, more than $1.1m [£0.76m] to the Democratic Party and at least $109,000 [£75,000] to Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign.

Mr Rich, who fled to Switzerland in the 1980s, was wanted by the justice department on charges of evading more than $48m [£33m] in taxes, fraud and participating in illegal oil deals with Iran.

In testimony before the senate judiciary committee yesterday, justice department pardon attorney Roger Adams said the White House initially failed to tell him during a midnight phone call that Mr Rich was a fugitive.

"I was not told," Adams said. "I learned that from the FBI."

After discovering that Rich and his indicted partner were fugitives, Adams fired off a fax to the White House summarising the facts of their criminal case. The White House then asked Adams to fax over the materials that he had received from the FBI.

The revelations prompted several Democrats to question Clinton's decision to later pardon Mr Rich.

His pardon was one of 177 total clemency actions Clinton handled on January 20. Thirty-two were not reviewed in advance by the justice department's pardon attorney, which is the usual - though neither legally nor constitutionally required - procedure.

Despite the controversy over Mr Rich's pardon, officials at the Democratic senatorial campaign committee and in the Clinton camp said there were no plans to return Denise Rich's contributions.

"There's been no discussion about it," Clinton adviser Harold Ickes said.
