webTitle: Peter Bradshaw gives his Oscar forecasts

fields.headline: All roads lead to Rome
fields.standfirst: Bad news for Billy, good news for Ridley... Peter Bradshaw gives his Oscar forecasts
fields.trailText: Bad news for Billy, good news for Ridley... Peter Bradshaw gives his Oscar forecasts
fields.body:
First, the good news. Lars von Trier's middlebrow dumbfest Dancer in the Dark has been comprehensively snubbed in the Academy award nominations, with the exception - and probably the deserved exception - of a nomination for Bjork's "I've Seen It All" number in the best original song category. The Academy has given the bum's rush to Von Trier's shallow, self-important arthouse/ commercial shocker, unimpressed by its urgent message that capital punishment for innocent blind mothers is unacceptable. Maybe the Oscars are middlebrow. But at least they're honest middlebrow.

Elsewhere, the list contains no great surprises and, in contrast to last year's classy, literate, left-field contenders, such as American Beauty, Blair Witch and Being John Malkovich, it's pretty MOR. The theme of this year's nominations seems to be one big showdown: Ridley Scott's Roman epic Gladiator versus Ang Lee's magic-realist wire-fu fable, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon. Russell Crowe's pecs are, as it were, flexing in sweaty combat with the elfin, elegant forms of Ziyi Zhang and Michelle Yeoh, the most compelling exponents of girl power in the cinema.

Having said that, Yeoh and Zhang are not in contention in the performance categories. Crouching Tiger has nominations in 10 sections - most remarkably best picture (rare for a subtitled movie) - while Gladiator has 12. An equal Gladiator/Tiger split is unlikely; in all probability, only one of the two will carry off the big bag of most of the prizes.

Most importantly, Gladiator has two of the sexy performance nominations - for Russell Crowe and Joaquin Phoenix - with Crowe a virtual shoo-in for best actor. It will be the biggest upset of the night if he doesn't get it, despite the strong competition, though there is always a chance that the wet-blanket turn from Tom Hanks in the dire Cast Away will seduce the Academy. Gladiator is such a powerful, substantial picture, and contains a virile, subliminal element of industry ancestor-worship, in that it is a triumphant revival of the Roman epic, one of the best-loved genres of the Hollywood golden age.

That said, my preference is for Crouching Tiger, a truly remarkable film, managing to combine gentleness, drama, decorum and understated sexiness. It could be that Ang Lee's Taiwanese background will helpfully militate against any residual anti-Chinese prejudice among older Academicians, and the Academy may respond to the film as a revival of the spirit of the western.

But I fear that Crouching Tiger will lose out to Gladiator, with the possible exception of a best director award for Lee (and of course the best foreign film prize). In the final analysis, it is a subtitled film and will be seen as irremediably alien, however well it does at the box office, and the powers that be may feel that nominations mark the limit of their generosity.

Things do not look great on the British front. Billy Elliot, despite the hype and full-page ads, has only two nominations - Stephen Daldry for best director and Julie Walters for best supporting actress - and both are, realistically, long shots in their respective categories. There is a strong possibility that the Billy posse will climb back into their limos sorely disappointed.

Elsewhere, it is now clear that Croupier, the Cinderella of British cinema success, shall not go to the ball. Judi Dench is in with a chance for a supporting award for Chocolat. But British hopes reside chiefly with Ridley Scott - a naturalised Hollywood player who is referred to as "British-born" rather than "British" - and the formidable Albert Finney, who plays the growling, spluttering American lawyer in Erin Brockovich.

In the director's chair, Steven Soderbergh, for years considered a tragic hasbeen, has an embarrassment of riches with nominations for two films: the middling Erin Brockovich, and the powerful Traffic, for which Benicio Del Toro must surely take the best supporting actor prize. Soderbergh might well snatch the award from Lee and Scott.

For best actress, I very much hope that Ellen Burstyn will get it for her outstanding performance in Darren Aronofsky's Requiem for a Dream; but there is every sign that Julia Roberts will get it for her overrated performance as Erin Brockovich. As for best supporting actress, I have a horrible feeling that the young princess of über-hype, Kate Hudson (Almost Famous), will win the Gwyneth Paltrow award for most lachrymose speech, the waterworks kicking off at the first mention of her mum, Goldie Hawn.

Biggest regrets? I am sorry that James Gray will receive nothing for his excellent labour-union drama The Yards, and more disappointed still that Terence Davies's brilliant Edith Wharton adaptation The House of Mirth has been slighted - although Laura Linney, so good in that film, has a nod for being in You Can Count on Me.

On the whole, Oscar night, I predict, will belong to Russell Crowe and Ridley Scott, triumphantly trundling through LA in their stretch chariot, with lowly ranking studio suits hired to murmur in their ear: "You are but mortal."

fields.headline: Presidential pardons
fields.standfirst: Clinton has dragged his own name through the dirt with his profligate use of the presidential pardon, writes Phil Hoad, but he isn't the first to do so
fields.trailText: Clinton has dragged his own name through the dirt with his profligate use of the presidential pardon, writes Phil Hoad, but he isn't the first to do so.
fields.body:
The controversy surrounding Bill Clinton's messy departure from office is congealing on the 140 or so pardons he granted during the final days of his presidency. Several questionable figures were let off the hook in, it's alleged, an equally questionable way, including fugitive businessman Marc Rich.

Nevertheless, the US president's powers of pardon are constitutionally enshrined, far-reaching and relatively unchecked by other bodies. Clinton isn't the first to blithely misuse these powers with in the untouchable twilight days of office, or even the worst. Here are some of the pardons granted by his predecessors:

George Bush Sr
Former defence secretary Caspar Weinburger and five other individuals were pardoned by Dubya's dad in late 1992, just before they were due for trial over their part in the Iran-Contra scandal.

This could just be all-too-predictable Republican chumminess (Bush described his former colleague as a "true American patriot"), but it was speculated that Bush was covering up his own involvement in the affair, as Ronald Reagan's former vice-president.

The incoming Clinton responded by saying he was concerned "by any action which sends a signal that, if you work for the government, you're above the law".

Ronald Reagan
More self-controlled in his final days than Bush, Reagan resisted pardoning John Poindexter and Oliver North, the national security advisor and aide at the centre of Iran-Contra; he (rightly) reasoned that exonerating them would draw attention to his own role and let the matter go to trial.

He did, however, pardon George Steinbrenner for illegal donations to Richard Nixon's 1972 campaign. The decision only provoked a storm of articles about the owner of the New York Yankees and a long-forgotten scandal was clumsily raked over once again

Jimmy Carter
In a magnanimous gesture on the first day of his presidency in 1977, Carter proclaimed amnesty for all Vietnam draft dodgers, extending the more limited overtures offered by previous White House incumbent Gerard Ford. Later in the year he pardoned all military deserters.

He was, however, later criticised by those who were supposed to benefit for failing to carry through these measures - veterans were incensed at the new president's wilfully short memory. One accusation levelled by both parties was that Carter simply made the pledge to ensure his election. All in all, it was far more divisive than Carter intended.

Gerard Ford
Infamously pardoned Richard Nixon after his resignation over the Watergate scandal. Appealing to the same kind of personal clemency invoked in the Bush/Weinburger affair, Ford stated melodramatically that he could not "prolong the bad dreams that continue to reopen a chapter that is closed" - resulting in Nixon escaping trial as a private citizen.

The decision, naturally, was intensely criticised, leading to a terminal decline in Ford's popularity. A rather crucial error, only one month into his presidency.

Richard Nixon
One of "Tricky's" first acts as president was to commute the prison sentence of former Teamster Union leader Jimmy Hoffa, imprisoned for embezzling funds, on the condition that he did not resume union activities. Hoffa was a long-time Republican party supporter and had funded Nixon during his battles with John F Kennedy.

Not entirely unexpectedly, FBI records revealed Nixon received illegal campaign donations in return for the pardon - part of the network of venality that brought his administration crashing down.

webTitle: Blair unveils radical future for NHS

fields.headline: Blair unveils radical future for NHS
fields.standfirst: Profile: Hospital of the future
fields.trailText: Prime minister Tony Blair today underlined his commitment to modernise the NHS, showcasing a radical £250 million blueprint for the "hospital of the future" aimed at radically cutting NHS waiting lists.
fields.body:
Prime minister Tony Blair today underlined his commitment to modernise the NHS, showcasing a radical £250 million blueprint for the "hospital of the future" aimed at radically cutting NHS waiting lists.

The scheme to develop 20 new surgery centres across England - originally announced in the NHS plan last July - is one of Labour's most high profile "modernisation" initiatives.

During an official visit to The Central Middlesex Ambulatory Care and Diagnostic Centre (ACAD) in west London today, Mr Blair said the centres would pioneer new and efficient ways of providing surgery.

ACAD, which has pioneered "production-line" approach to operations, has assumed near-iconic status in LabourÕs NHS reforms programme. Mr Blair officially opened it last year, while health secretary Alan Milburn chose it as the venue to launch his NHS plan.

It serves as the model for the proposed network of surgery centres which will be separate from accident and emergency wards and would specialise in non-urgent surgery, such as hip replacements, appendectomies and cataract operations.

Mr Blair said: "We are creating a brand new concept of what a hospital should be: a hospital that focuses exclusively on diagnostic tests and operations for a wide range of conditions such as cataracts, hernias and cancer.

"And because it will operate separately from the accident and emergency department, it means that extra pressures do not result in cancelled operations and heartache for patients.

"These hospitals are going to work longer hours, including at weekends, and will involve much more day surgery, giving patients the chance to be back in their own homes to recover, which is what many of them want." The Prime Minister said all NHS staff had to be prepared to work in new ways if the new surgery centres were to be a success.

The Central Middlesex's ambulatory care and diagnostic centre has pioneered the type of work that the new centres would be providing.

Mr Blair said: "You have demonstrated that here. One-stop tests and diagnosis, same day results, procedures carried out as day cases that in other hospitals require overnight stays, patient assessments before operations to reduce the risk of cancellations, a comfortable environment designed to fit each stage of the patient's care, support for the patient when they go home.

"I know from talking to you that to achieve this you have had to change the way you work."

He said the Central Middlesex Hospital had significantly reduced its waiting lists by using the new ACAD centre.

webTitle: Charities urged to exploit the net

fields.headline: Charities urged to exploit the net
fields.trailText: Charities have called on the government for financial support to help them exploit the internet revolution. A report released today shows that charities are falling behind the corporate sector in their use of the web.
fields.body:
Charities have called on the government for financial support to help them exploit the internet revolution. A report released today shows that charities are falling behind the corporate sector in their use of the web.

The report Virtual Promise shows that many charities use the internet for news, links to other web sites and for email enquiries but few use it for cost cutting, online-training or job applications.

The report's author, Joe Saxton of the think-tank Future Foundation, says the government is investing £25 million over three years to help small businesses use the internet but doing nothing comparable for the voluntary sector.

Mr Saxton believes there should be a taskforce to lobby decision-makers to secure more funding. "The voluntary sector has a key role in relieving social exclusion. Through not supporting the sector, the government is helping to create digital exclusion just as the Internet revolution is beginning."

Chief executives of charities should also be doing more to take advantage of the internet, according to Mr Saxton. He said: "The internet will be the single most important driver of change in charities over the next decade but at the moment senior managers in the sector lack vision."

To test if a charity is doing enough, Mr Saxton says chief executives should ask themselves four questions:
1. What new audiences have you reached?
2. Have you saved 10% of your support costs or raised 10% extra revenue?
3. Do you have online services that you couldn't offer off line?
4. Who have you made redundant or redeployed because of the internet?

He quoted pioneering examples of NSPCC developing a virtual children's centre where children could access counsellors online and NCVO's partnership with BT to develop a joint purchasing website for charities.

Mr Saxton said charities needed to develop more partnerships with companies and undertake further research in order to maximise internet use.

fields.headline: Government drops asylum computer
fields.standfirst: Special report: Refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: The Home Office has scrapped an £77m computer system that was intended to help clear the backlog of asylum seekers, it was reported today.
fields.body:
The Home Office has scrapped an £77m computer system that was intended to help clear the backlog of asylum seekers, it was reported today.

Home secretary Jack Straw said that the system, which was designed to save more than £100m, would not become fully operational.

The project should have been completed by 1998, it was said.

Mr Straw announced the decision in a written parliamentary answer last week, which was raised in today's issue of Computer Weekly magazine.

German company Siemens Business Services signed a contract in 1996 to set up the system to deal with asylum applications to the Immigration and Nationality Directorate (IND), the magazine said.

The contract would run until 2003 and, while Siemens would continue to work on improving the existing computer network, the full scheme would not be completed, it was said.

In his written answer Mr Straw said: "IND has agreed with Siemens that they should stand down the resources they are using to develop the full casework application.

"At present there is no change to the current contract."

webTitle: Unions snub job plan for Wales

fields.headline: Unions snub job plan for Wales
fields.trailText: The Iron and Steel Trades Confederation yesterday slammed a scheme to retrain 4,000 redundant steel workers as telecom engineers as "cruel fantasy".
fields.body:
The Iron and Steel Trades Confederation yesterday slammed a scheme to retrain 4,000 redundant steel workers as telecom engineers as "cruel fantasy".

EXi Telecoms, with the backing of the AEEU, is offering to retrain and employ workers being shed by Corus, the Anglo-Dutch steel group.

Sir Ken Jackson, AEEU general secretary, said: "This will be a genuinely radical way of dealing with the threat of redundancies at Corus."

But other union leaders said the EXi scheme would undermine their own attempts to preserve the bulk of the 6,000 jobs which Corus intends to cut, mainly in Wales and the north east. They also questioned the timing of EXi's announcement, which came on the day the unions put alternative proposals to the Corus management.

Mick Leahy, general secretary of the ISTC, the largest steel union, said: "It is cruel to suggest 4,000 steel workers will get a job from this. That is fantasy."

Eddie Long, a Transport and General Workers' Union official at Corus's Ebbw Vale plant, which is threatened with closure, said the EXi and AEEU announcement could not have come at a worse time.

"For the AEEU to suddenly announce that they have been looking for alternative employment for steel workers sends out all the wrong signals. It says they have accepted the cuts will take place."

Another union source said: "They [EXi] have only got 1,500 workers, and they're suddenly going to take on 4,000 extra in a short time. It's a PR stunt, it's a con."

An AEEU spokesman admitted that the scheme was aimed at any manufacturing worker facing redundancy. But he insisted that Corus workers would be "first in line".

He said the AEEU would continue to back the unions' rescue plan and put pressure on Corus to accept it. "We thought other unions would support a job creation scheme, not attack it," he said. "We have a social responsibility to our members to make plans for every eventuality."

Shift workers at Corus's Llanwern plant in south Wales said the chance to switch to a high technology industry could offer a lifeline to some. Younger staff with fewer commitments were best placed to take up the offer and change direction.

EXi said that it needed an extra 4,000 telecom workers over the next two years to cope with the installation of third-generation mobile phone and high-speed internet networks. EXi, which was set up in 1995, last year made a pre-tax profit of £269,000 on a turnover of £7.5m.

fields.headline: SMS
fields.standfirst: Text messaging is the new rock'n'roll. Here's our online guide to everything you need to know about the new fad.
fields.trailText: 1. When SMS (Short Messaging Service) between different mobile networks appeared in January 1999, 40m were sent in Britain in the first month. Now the number tops 500m and is steadily rising.
fields.body:
1. When SMS (Short Messaging Service) between different mobile networks appeared in January 1999, 40m were sent in Britain in the first month. Now the number tops 500m and is steadily rising.

2. However, it seems they can cost lives. Lorry driver Paul Browning has just been jailed for five years after driving into and killing a man while typing in a text message to his girlfriend. And a teenager left a suicide text message last year after receiving silent calls and bizarre messages on her mobile phone.

3. It seems they can save lives too, as a tourist, lost at sea off Indonesia, discovered when she text messaged her boyfriend in England, who then set in chain a rescue mission.

4. If you're not yet a texter you'll need to learn the language. In fact, the vocabulary used by expert 'texters' use can be incredibly sophisticated, so >:-( means annoyed, (:<) that you're a blabbermouth and <*:oDX is, bizarrely, a clown with a bow tie.

5. Indeed the "WAN2TLK?" text messaging dictionary was the best seller at Christmas, outstripping even Harry Potter. So if you don't know what ;*) means, here's you're chance to learn.

6. Initially, mobile phone companies had so little faith in its practical use that the service wasn't even included in the instruction manuals. And then it was felt that only teenagers would make use of them to disrupt their lessons at school. Now, however, it seems we're all catching on.

7. It's been possible to send free text messages from the internet for some time, though the major mobile phone companies seem to have got wise to that and are, unsurprisingly, keen for you to pay a 10p charge. However, a quick web search provides a number of free European-based services.

8. Want to keep up to date with the latest Premier League scores? You can personalise your service to hear about your team at Give Us the Score.

9. Not just useful for sending messages in a crowded club, but also for finding out which clubs you should be going to in the first place, SMS messages have become crucial to the nation's weekend revelry.

10. In light of the growth of SMS, we'd love to hear your stories of the most useful messages you've sent or received. Let us know at Guardian Unlimited.

webTitle: Teacher accused of race jibe to face governors

fields.headline: Teacher accused of race jibe to face governors
fields.standfirst:
Special report: race issues in the UK
Education site
fields.trailText: A science teacher who is accused of making racist comments to a black student will face a disciplinary hearing today.
fields.body:
A science teacher who is accused of making racist comments to a black student will face a disciplinary hearing today.

Michael Aldersley was suspended from Calderstones high school in Liverpool after he allegedly called the student "nig nog" during a lesson. Three students made a complaint to the school's headteacher and they are supported by their parents.

A full investigation was launched in November last year and Dr Aldersley, who is in his 50s, has been suspended.

Today he will meet five school governors to determine whether he should be allowed to return to his job.

Dr Aldersley is supported by his union, the National Association of Schoolteachers Union of Women Teachers. NASUWT regional officer John Taylor said the hearing should signal the end of the investigation against Dr Aldersley. "It is not challenged that he used the phrase - but it was in the context of a lesson. I must stress that at no time has any disciplinary action been taken against Dr Aldersley.

"The fact that he has been suspended from his job is not a punishment, it is a neutral act while an investigation is carried out. We feel that the continuation of his suspension has been a very harsh decision."

The episode had made Dr Aldersley very ill and had caused great distress to his family.

Last month, a seven-strong gang kicked the front door of his terraced house a mile from the school and banged their fists on downstairs windows shouting, "racist bastard".

Dr Aldersley, who has overall responsibility for computer development in the national curriculum at Calderstones, joined the school in 1991. He is also a science teacher who specialises in chemistry.

He was suspended by headteacher Brian Davies after the complaints. Mr Davies said yesterday that he was not prepared to confirm or deny whether the allegations were of a racist nature.

He said he decided that there should be a full disciplinary hearing. The meeting, which was originally due to take place in December, had to be cancelled because of Dr Aldersley's ill health.

Mr Davies said the final decision would now be left in the hands of the panel of five school governors. "The governors will now hear the case of both sides at the hearing to be held at the school."

He said it was up to the governors to decide whether any disciplinary action should be taken against Dr Aldersley and he was unable to make any further comment.

fields.headline: Houllier's hopes rise as Italians rest big two
fields.standfirst: Live minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Ian Ross reports as Liverpool's renaissance returns them to Rome, a city redolent of the Merseyside club's past glories.
fields.body:
It is perhaps fitting that the latest phase of Liverpool's renaissance returns them to Rome, a city redolent of the Merseyside club's past glories.

The first and the last of Liverpool's four European Cup triumphs were achieved here, the sheer joy of the 1977 win over Borussia Mönchengladbach being eclipsed in 1984 when tonight's opponents were beaten on their own patch, albeit only in a penalty shoot-out.

Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier is rightly proud of the fact that Liverpool are the only English club still striving for success on four fronts, and if that remains the case in eight days' time the malcontents who regard the Frenchman as more interloper than saviour will be further reduced.

In the Uefa Cup, having already cleared hurdles of varying height in Romania, the Czech Republic and Greece, Liverpool will reach the quarter-finals if Italy's finest can be overcome.

Liverpool's hopes of leaving Rome with a favourable result improved appreciably last night when Roma's coach Fabio Capello announced that he would not risk Gabriel Batistuta, Serie A's top scorer, or the captain Francesco Totti.

The Argentine striker will start tonight on the bench and will appear only in an emergency. Totti, troubled by a slight groin strain, is rested before Roma's league fixture with Lecce at the weekend. "As ever, the league remains the priority of my club and I must act accordingly," said Capello.

Liverpoool have also lost key players to injury, and to red tape. Yet Houllier remains cautiously optimistic.

Despite the absence of the ineligible Igor Biscan and the injured Steven Gerrard and Danny Murphy, Houllier expects to be able to name a side of great experience, one which will flood midfield in the hope of fracturing Roma's rhythm.

Vladimir Smicer and Nick Barmby are likely to be asked to work the flanks of a five-man midfield, with Jari Litmanen roaming just behind Robbie Fowler, playing alone up front if, as expected, Emile Heskey fails to recover from a thigh strain.

Houllier believes Fowler's darker days are behind him. "It would have been a defeat for me if I had had to sell him; I never believed he would go because I know how much he loves the club."

Liverpool's growing strength in depth will be reflected in a substitutes' bench that seems certain to feature Michael Owen and Christian Ziege.

For all that, Roma are six points clear of Juventus at the Serie A summit. Houllier believes that at full strength Capello's team are, with the possible exception of the Champions League holders Real Madrid and Manchester United, the most competent team in Europe.

"They really are a top side, so immediately you are worried that this is going to be a very tough game," he said. "I am so respectful of what my club has achieved in the past but, on occasions like this, it can be a nuisance because people say that our two ties with Roma will show how far we have progressed.

"That is unfair because you cannot really judge a young side, which is only now starting to develop and blossom, against a team like Roma. They are a great side and at the moment there is simply no comparison." Houllier is also aware of the quality of tonight's stand-ins, Vincenzo Montella and Hidetoshi Nakata.

Roma (probable; 3-4-1-2): Antonioli; Samuel, Rinaldi, Mangone; Cafu, Tommasi, Emerson, Candela; Nakata; Delvecchio, Montella.

Liverpool (probable; 4-4-1-1): Westerveld; Babbel, Hyypia, Henchoz, Carragher; Smicer, McAllister, Hamman, Barmby; Litmanen; Fowler.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Telemontecarlo buys MTV's Italian operation
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: Italian broadcaster Telemontecarlo has bought MTV's Italian operation in an all-share deal, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Italian broadcaster Telemontecarlo has bought MTV's Italian operation in an all-share deal.

In exchange, MTV, owned by US media giant Viacom, will take a 49% stake in Telemontecarlo's Beta station.

"This transaction represents the first step towards reaching the target of young people that is part of Telemontecarlo's strategic plan," said Ernesto Mauri, managing director of parent company Cecchi Gori Communications.

Beta's TMC2 channel will now team up with MTV to create a 24-hour service, to be called MTV: Music Television.

MTV's European branch will supply the international programming and non-Italian advertising.

Simon Guild, chief operating officer of MTV Networks Europe, said MTV Italia had been a phenomenal success since its launch in 1990.

"This transaction allows us to combine this success with first-rate distribution," said Mr Guild.

"It will enable us to reach a wider audience and create new opportunities for advertisers and sponsors targeting the Italian youth market."

fields.headline: Bedside stories
fields.standfirst: It's provincial, boring and uncool. But the junior doctor finds life at Boreham General almost surreally friendly
fields.trailText: It's provincial, boring and uncool. But the junior doctor finds life at Boreham General almost surreally friendly
fields.body:
Someone's pulled the grass from underneath my feet: one moment I'm a medical house officer in a glamorous and well-funded central teaching hospital, the next I'm a skivvy for a bunch of surgeons in some district general hospital's concrete box in the middle of nowhere. How did this happen?

It's all part of a grand experiment to disorient and abuse junior doctors. Every six months they move you on to some new alien hospital, and to get full registration with the general medical council you have to do six months of surgery as well as six months of medicine, for one very simple reason: surgeons, who make up about 10% of medical graduates, need a vast army of (barely) qualified medical skivvies to do their dirty work on the wards.

What do we know about doing surgery? Nothing. We are Santa's little helpers. As my new senior house officer pointed out on the first day of the job: "I am the SHO. You are the HO." He likes Eminem. I hold retractors in the theatre. I do bloods and cannulas. I write the results in the notes. I am barely still a doctor, apart from pre-op clinics. "Do you have any allergies? No. Still got that hernia? Jolly good, get your ECG over there. Next."

With time the repetitiveness could become quite therapeutic, in the same way that knitting or raffia work might. And as ever in medicine there is always scope for invigoratingly serious cock-ups.

What is particularly cutting is that this all has to take place in a hospital in an anonymous little market town somewhere between 20 and 60 miles outside of London. Let's call it Boreham General.

Like all other district generals I ever went to as a medical student, you just pitch up at that train station on your first day of work and aim for the big incinerator tower. When we were at medical school, we used to consider our brief sojourns to places like this as cautionary tales.

"I'd better concoct a pretty convincing CV before I qualify," we would all secretly plot in the college library, "because otherwise I'll end up working in Boreham General for the rest of my life, like all those other lost souls."

So here I sit, staring blankly at the walls, in Bedside Manor, the small concrete bunker where they keep the junior doctors at night when they are not using them. I could go out with my new colleagues and drink to excess, once more, in the plastic pub around the corner. Or I could sit in my room and stare blankly at the walls. Some of the other HOs are old hands at district general life.

"Bedside Manor? This is a bloody palace," they say in broad Yorkshire accents. "When I were a lad, in Borebury General, the on-call doctor slept at t'bottom of t'sharps bin, snuggled up against t'used needles and empty glass vials, and we used to wash in t'dirty utility room on t'ward next to t'used colostomy bags."

But don't let me knock the old place. Because for everything I might say, there is one thing about this hospital that left me utterly disorientated for days: everybody, and I mean everybody, is outrageously, absurdly, almost surreally friendly. "Good morning doctor," they chirp. "Hi . . ." I replied for the first few days, trying not to look suspicious.

But it's real. This is the only hospital in the town. Patients do not routinely abuse you. The little old lady in the Friends hospital shop, which still sells Curly Wurlys for 17p please dear: we know each other by name. Her shop is not a prefabricated corporate franchise on a unit of glisteningly valuable retail space in a busy hospital foyer. To be honest, it looks like she built it herself one quiet weekend in 1972.

And last night we all went out with the nurses to the local out-of-town entertainment multiplex centre, with its seven-screen cinema and three restaurant-bar-nightclub venues, for the fortnightly "999" night. ("Where the emergency services let their hoses out.") I never saw ward sisters in their mid-40s get drunk like that in my old hospital.

Who cares about the art galleries and concerts I was always too tired to make it to in my old job? Who cares if everyone over the age of 19 is married around here? Who cares if surgical ward rounds start at quarter to eight in the morning? At least they're over by nine. If I were 20 years older, and my social life had been neatly cauterised by a collection of small children, I might seriously consider bringing them up somewhere not entirely unlike this town.

fields.headline: Thrown off the scent
fields.standfirst: Does the pill destroy a woman's ability to pick the right man?  Alison Motluk  reports
fields.trailText: Does the pill destroy a woman's ability to pick the right man? Alison Motluk reports
fields.body:
It all started with a bit of harmless T-shirt sniffing. A group of women was asked to whiff T-shirts that had been worn by a group of unknown - and unwashed - men. All they had to do was say which shirts smelled best. The experiment, run by Claus Wedekind, a young Swiss scientist then at the University of Bern, was designed to find out if humans, like mice, use body odour to identify genetically appropriate mates. But it revealed something more worrying.

As Wedekind predicted, most female volunteers had equivalent preferences to their rodent counterparts. Numerous studies in mice have shown that, given the choice, they sniff out mates with genes for immunity that differ from their own, and that this seems to increase their chances of producing healthy offspring. But among the volunteers there was a startling exception to this trend. Women on the contraceptive pill showed the reverse preference. Instead of being attracted to the scent of dissimilar men, they chose men whose genes for immunity were closest to their own.

If humans are using smell to find a good partner for reproduction, and the pill is turning things upside down, then there could be serious consequences. By tricking users into falling for the wrong guy, the pill could make it more difficult for them to have children long after they stop taking it - by reducing their fertility, for example.

It's a contentious idea. For a start, not everyone agrees that the human brain can register such smells, let alone that they might influence our behaviour. But if they do, then does the pill interfere with this form of sexual chemistry? "It's a reasonable question," says Wayne Potts, a biologist at the University of Utah in Salt Lake City, who specialises in mate choice. His colleague, Dustin Penn, goes further: "It wouldn't surprise me if sabotaging our reproductive machinery would lead to faulty mate choice."

The genes at the centre of the debate are a large cluster called the major histocompatibility complex, or MHC. Each person has a unique combination of MHC genes that encode various components of their immune system. The idea is that the more varied an individual's MHC, the more robust their immunity. And if your parents have widely varying MHC genes, your own are more likely to be diverse. Parental differences may even increase the chances of your being born in the first place.

If olfactory cues about MHC genes are so important, why do women taking the pill seem to respond so differently from other women? "My guess is that the pill simulates pregnancy and that maybe during pregnancy, odour preferences change," says Wedekind. The theory is that during pregnancy, a female is attracted to the smell of her own relatives, who have similar MHCs to her own. After all, family members have the greatest interest in seeing her offspring survive. Pregnant women - and women whose bodies are tricked into thinking they're pregnant - might have the same tendency, says Wedekind.

To date, almost all the work on MHC differences, mate choice and their effects on offspring viability has been done on rodents. But geneticist Carole Ober from the University of Chicago has come up with a cunning way to explore some of the same questions in humans. For more than a decade, she has been studying a North American religious community known as the Hutterites. Following Wedekind's revelations about the women's preference for certain odours in an artificial laboratory setting, Ober aimed to get information about real partnerships.

In many ways, Hutterites are the perfect study group for "natural" mate choice among humans. They are a socially isolated group who work on communal farms, marry within their own community, and can trace their roots back to a handful of European ancestors in the 16th century. Single men and women visit neighbouring Hutterite colonies, and often end up working or celebrating special occasions alongside potential spouses. They don't use perfumes or deodorants. "They are absolutely maximising the importance of MHC," says Ober. They marry once - divorce is strictly prohibited - and, claims Ober, they marry for love. Once paired off, they place a high value on big families, and seldom use contraception.

So do Hutterites tend to marry people who have dissimilar MHCs? To answer this question, Ober and her colleagues studied 411 couples drawn from 31 Hutterite colonies. Despite the lack of genetic variation within this isolated population, only 44 of the couples matched for certain kinds of MHC. If mate selection were random the probability of that would have been only about 5%. Ober's group concludes that genes in this region of DNA may indeed influence mate choice in humans.

The next question for Ober was whether couples with similar MHCs actually have reduced fertility. She decided to look at this effect more carefully, asking 111 Hutterite women to keep diaries recording all their menstrual periods. She found that miscarriage rates were highest for couples who matched at certain sites.

The fertility gods may well frown on couples with similar MHCs. But where does all this leave pill users? Even if using oral contraceptives alters a woman's sense of smell does smell itself really play such a big part in choosing a man? It's known that humans do use odour cues in at least some matters related to reproduction. For instance, Martha McClintock at the University of Chicago showed in 1998 that when women who live together synchronise their menstrual cycles, they do it through chemical signals known as pheromones.

As far as anyone can tell, whatever chemical signals do pass between people are subconscious. None the less, Rachel Herz from Brown University in Providence, Rhode Island, decided to ask people about it directly. She polled 166 women about what makes a man attractive - specifically, attractive enough to go to bed with. Out of a variety of factors, including appearance, the sound of his voice and how his skin feels, women respondents said that a man's scent was paramount. Body odour was particularly important, the volunteers reported, in decisions not to have sex with a certain individual.

The question is not whether there are human MHC smells - that is more or less resolved. Laboratory rats are able to distinguish between people with different MHC types simply by sniffing their urine.

The real question is, even if these odours are advertising what kind of MHC a person has, do humans still have the capacity to pick up the scent and act on it? Rodents have something called a vomeronasal organ (VNO) - a region high in the nose that can detect chemosensory signals. But there is still a debate raging about whether humans even have a VNO. We do seem to have a structure similar to one during early development, but there is no strong evidence that the vestige that remains into adulthood is functional.

Maybe we don't need one, however. Pigs, rabbits and sheep have a VNO, but detect some pheromones through their main olfactory system. It's possible that humans do too.

Still, Hutterites do tend to marry those with different MHCs. And women did respond differently to a sniff from those T-shirts when they were on the pill. So it's not inconceivable that the pill is meddling with whatever chemosensory perception we have.

For the past 40 years the pill has liberated many women from unwanted pregnancy. Even so, it might be worth taking precautions. Herz suggests that if you are on the pill and meet someone you want to have children with, you should stop taking oral contraceptives. "Go off," she says, "to see if you're still attracted."

fields.headline: Marathon man
fields.trailText: I didn't know pain could feel like this. My physiotherapist Angela has my left ankle in her hands. Her thumbs are kneading my tibialis posterior and I am laughing. I'm laughing like I never have before - sort of yelps and gurgles. If I was 10 years younger I would be in tears. But now I laugh it off, I laugh my head off. I know it's the only relief I'm going to get - either laugh or watch myself break down like a baby. I tell Angela she is hurting me and she says she knows. "Need to be cruel to be kind," she says. She adds helpfully that some of her patients take painkillers before their weekly visits.
fields.body:
I didn't know pain could feel like this. My physiotherapist Angela has my left ankle in her hands. Her thumbs are kneading my tibialis posterior and I am laughing. I'm laughing like I never have before - sort of yelps and gurgles. If I was 10 years younger I would be in tears. But now I laugh it off, I laugh my head off. I know it's the only relief I'm going to get - either laugh or watch myself break down like a baby. I tell Angela she is hurting me and she says she knows. "Need to be cruel to be kind," she says. She adds helpfully that some of her patients take painkillers before their weekly visits.

It is hurting so much now that I'm sweating and I'm sucking in air in gulps. If I grit my teeth any harder I'll bite my nose off. Where are my endorphins? I could almost be delirious. I'm sure that about this time in ER they intubate you, give you air and gas and then take you to the lift to go up to surgery with Dr Benton.

Angela was a complete stranger five weeks ago. Now she is seeing the worst side of me, my schoolboy reaction to pain, my low threshold to agony. Am I her worst customer? I wonder whether I should ever see her again. How can someone inflict so much pain on a fellow human being - and get paid for it?

As my gurgles subside Angela tells me the problem. My tibialis posterior, a muscle which runs behind the shin to a bone near the instep of your foot, has become inflamed by my running schedule and needs to be worked on. Thumbs aside, Angela whips out the ultrasound, spreading a water gel on my ankle and moving it around with purpose. Then comes a bizarre electronic device - an interferential - with two electrodes held in place on either end of the muscle with suckers. She increases a current running between the red and blue connectors and my leg feels as if it's burning - too much current. It is decreased. The machine is sending an electrical pulse through the muscle, vibrating it. Apparently it repairs scar tissue and reduces the inflammation.

All the way through my dreadful half hour at the physio I hear the voice of Fran, my sensible fellow marathon runner and flatmate. "Tortoise and hare, Dave. Don't overdo the training." She's sensible. I'm not. She's been taking it easy, building herself up. I've been obsessive, running too much.

Maybe I'm paying for drinking too much beer, enjoying myself too much in life, eating too many cheese sandwiches. Nothing in moderation. I'm going to calm down - it's a long way to the finish line.

fields.headline: Caught up in chain mail
fields.standfirst: A strange rash of hoax emails are giving charities a major headache, writes Howard Lake
fields.trailText: A strange rash of hoax emails are giving charities a major headache, writes Howard Lake
fields.body:
Email is a powerful tool when it comes to charity. It is direct, personal, low cost, and many donors find it a novelty to receive an email from a charity.

Unfortunately, some charities have found out just how powerful email can be, especially when it is used against them.

The name Craig Shergold might be familiar. He is the young boy with leukaemia who in the 1980s wanted to get into the Guinness Book of Records for receiving the largest number of get-well cards. He succeeded, but then it took some years for the message to get round that Craig and his family, not to mention the Post Office's Guildford sorting office, where Craig lived, really did not want any more cards, thank you.

Unfortunately, by the mid-90s, Craig's name and variations upon it had begun to appear on the Internet as the subject of email "appeals". All of them were hoaxes, and they are still doing the rounds. One message asks you to send a compliment slip to "a young boy, Craig John, who is, sadly, terminally ill with cancer" so that he can get into the Guinness Book of Records. It suggests that you then forward the email message to 50 of your friends and contacts.

Another message from a similarly terminally ill "Craig Sherwood" recommends that recipients send their business cards to the Make-a-Wish Foundation in the USA. Craig Sherwood does not exist, but the Make-a-Wish Foundation does. As a result of this chain email, the charity receives sackfuls of such unwanted mail each week. They have to assume that any letter to them could contain a donation, so they waste hours dealing with the unsolicited cards.

Why would anyone start such a chain email and hurt charities? No one is sure. Was it a misguided attempt to help the charity, a prank, or a malicious attempt to annoy and damage the charity?

The "Craig John" and "Craig Sherwood" email hoaxes are bad enough, but they are just some of the fictitious sick and dying children in chain emails that are causing problems for many charities around the world.

Timothy Flyte, Jessica Mydek, Tamara Martin, Rick Connor and Anthony Parkin are just some of the "children" who are damaging the work and reputations of the American Cancer Society, the National Lung Cancer Association, and the Children's Wish Foundation. Schools in Australia and Portugal and a hospital in the USA are the targets of similar chain emails.

Indeed, there are so many email hoaxes of this kind doing the rounds that they are all referred to generically as the "sick kid hoax". There are dozens of variants too, including the women of Afghanistan campaign and the US Public Broadcasting Service (PBS) funding appeal.

What should you do if you receive an email appeal from a sick and dying kid? Use the delete key, and certainly do not forward it to 50 of your friends.

How can charities protect themselves against such a hoax? The only answer is vigilance. Charities should remain as aware as possible how their name is being used online. They should also avoid launching poorly designed online appeals and campaigns which can be misunderstood or misused.

Finally, like the Make-A-Wish Foundation in the USA, they should adopt and publicise their policy of not endorsing chain letters, whether by email, post or fax.

In the UK, the Institute of Charity Fundraising Managers (ICFM) published a guidance note several years ago on the use of chain letters as a fundraising technique. Although it does not refer explicitly to e-mail the ICFM's guidance is clear: "The ICFM strongly advises charities against using chain letters."

It adds that "charities with a clear policy never to agree to this method of fundraising will know that any who does so will be unauthorised".

Craig Sherwood does not exist, but the Make-a-Wish Foundation does. As a result of this chain email, the charity receives sackfuls of such unwanted mail each week. They have to assume that any letter to them could contain a donation, so they waste hours dealing with the unsolicited cards. Why would anyone start such a chain email and hurt charities? No one is sure. Was it a misguided attempt to help the charity, a prank, or a malicious attempt to annoy and damage the charity? The "Craig John" and "Craig Sherwood" email hoaxes are bad enough, but they are just some of the fictitious sick and dying children in chain emails that are causing problems for many charities around the world. Timothy Flyte, Jessica Mydek, Tamara Martin, Rick Connor and Anthony Parkin are just some of the "children" who are damaging the work and reputations of the American Cancer Society, the National Lung Cancer Association, and the Children's Wish Foundation. Schools in Australia and Portugal and a hospital in the USA are the targets of similar chain emails. Indeed, there are so many email hoaxes of this kind doing the rounds that they are all referred to generically as the "sick kid hoax". There are dozens of variants too, including the women of Afghanistan campaign and the US Public Broadcasting Service (PBS) funding appeal. What should you do if you receive an email appeal from a sick and dying kid? Use the delete key, and certainly do not forward it to 50 of your friends. How can charities protect themselves against such a hoax? The only answer is vigilance. Charities should remain as aware as possible how their name is being used online. They should also avoid launching poorly designed online appeals and campaigns which can be misunderstood or misused. Finally, like the Make-A-Wish Foundation in the USA, they should adopt and publicise their policy of not endorsing chain letters, whether by email, post or fax. In the UK, the Institute of Charity Fundraising Managers (ICFM) published a guidance note several years ago on the use of chain letters as a fundraising technique. Although it does not refer explicitly to e-mail the ICFM's guidance is clear: "The ICFM strongly advises charities against using chain letters." It adds that "charities with a clear policy never to agree to this method of fundraising will know that any who does so will be unauthorised".

webTitle: Smith steps into World Cup rights row

fields.headline: Smith steps into World Cup rights row
fields.trailText:
4.15pm: Chris Smith has stepped into the battle for World Cup broadcasting rights, reports Dan Milmo.
10.45am: World Cup rights battle hots up
fields.body:
Culture secretary Chris Smith has intervened in a court case that could prevent the BBC and ITV from obtaining broadcasting rights to the 2002 and 2006 World Cups.

Mr Smith has petitioned the House of Lords to let his department give evidence in an appeal hearing on a case between the Independent Television Commission and UK-based TVDanmark.

The government is stepping up its campaign to keep the World Cup on terrestrial TV.

Meanwhile, a cross-party group of MPs also joined the fight today.

They filed a House of Commons early day motion registering their concern at the prospect of the BBC and ITV losing World Cup rights.

German media company Kirch owns the broadcasting rights to the next two World Cup tournaments and plans to sell the UK franchise to the highest bidder.

BSkyB or another pay-TV operator would have the financial muscle to outbid the BBC and ITV in an auction.

Kirch believes a victory for the Danish company in the Lords appeal will set a precedent for an EU-based group to bypass UK legislation.

This states World Cup matches must be shown on terrestrial TV.

The ITC is appealing to the Lords against a court of appeal ruling that said TVDanmark could charge Danish viewers to watch its live coverage of the national team's World Cup qualifiers.

Danish national law protects the matches from being shown exclusively on pay-TV but TVDanmark bypassed the rules because it is based in the UK.

It also argues ITC regulations should not apply to its broadcasts, as the programmes are received in Denmark.

A UK source close to the negotiations between the BBC, ITV and Kirch said he expected the ITC to win the appeal.

"Clearly the case has strong implications but we are confident the decision will be overturned, as the ITC's position was upheld in the first place.

"We strongly believe that UK parliamentary legislation should be respected," said the source.

Mr Smith is determined to prevent a rights auction and has stated the World Cup matches must be shown on a free-to-air channel.

This is because they are on a list of sporting events of national importance enshrined in the 1996 UK Broadcasting Act.

The Department of Culture, Media and Sport this week entered a motion in parliament requesting permission for Mr Smith to give evidence at the House of Lords hearing.

The MPs' early day motion, published today, urges Mr Smith and the ITC "to do all in their power" to ensure the World Cup is freely available to UK viewers.

"This house...views with alarm the attempts of the rights holders to the 2002 and 2006 tournaments, the German media company Kirch, to circumvent the 1996 Act and auction the bulk of the broadcasting rights to subscription TV companies," the motion states.

It goes on to argue that: "this great event of huge national and international importance" should continue to be shown on terrestrial TV.

The motion has been signed by six MPs.

They are the former Tory heritage secretary Virginia Bottomley, her husband Peter Bottomley and Labour MPs John Grogan, Anne Begg, Jim Murphy and Joan Whalley.

fields.headline: New Media Markets
fields.standfirst: Publication date: February 9
fields.trailText: February 9: BskyB is delaying the launch of its next-generation personal video recorder box.
fields.body:
BSkyB is delaying the launch of its next-generation personal video recorder box until the second half of this year.

Spanish cable operators are asking the government to make substantial changes to licence conditions set down in franchises awarded in 1997 and 1998.

Vivendi-Universal's new movie channel the Studio may be transmitted direct by satellite - bypassing Sky Digital - if its negotiations with BSkyB hit a dead end.

Diva Europe, the video-on-demand company, to test services on a cable-modem based internet protocol system, as part of trials to be carried out by NTL.

European investors are circling for a stake in the FilmFour channels when they are hived off into Channel 4's commercial arm, 4 Ventures.

Diva Europe, the video-on-demand company, to test services on a cable-modem based internet protocol system, as part of trials to be carried out by NTL. fields.headline: Putin's debt pantomime
fields.standfirst: A budget crisis is threatening the president's credibility, writes Ian Traynor
fields.trailText: A budget crisis is threatening the president's credibility, writes Ian Traynor.
fields.body:
President Vladimir Putin and his government appear determined to turn a middling debt problem into a fullblown budget crisis, highlighting an increasingly prevalent view of the Russian leader which finds that he is not so much the strong, decisive leader sold by his spin doctors, but weak and vacillating.

Since late last year, without any prior agreement or meaningful negotiation, the Kremlin has been performing an on-off pantomime on its foreign debt repayments, one day threatening a technical default on payments to the Paris Club of sovereign creditors, the next day insisting it was all a misunderstanding.

Mr Putin's budget for 2001, hailed as Russia's first balanced budget in years, was thought to be in the can. The only problem is that, without having negotiated any debt restructuring deal with foreign creditors, the finance ministry had omitted to pencil in more than $2bn due in repayments this year.

So the prime minister, Mikhail Kasyanov, blithely announced last month that Moscow would not make its first quarter debt payments in full. The Germans, owed the lion's share of the money, went ballistic. The Kremlin, the finance ministry, and Mr Putin's economic gurus indulged in a cacophony of contradictory declarations suggesting either a staggering level of incompetence or a dangerous degree of brinkmanship.

And the outcome this week is that the prime minister and finance minister are going back to parliament cap-in-hand promising after all that the debt must be repaid and that the budget will need to be rewritten to accommodate the burden.

A backroom deal may well be reached, but Mr Putin could also face his worst parliamentary mutiny since entering the Kremlin just over a year ago.

Relatively speaking, Mr Putin has been blessed by economic good fortune in his first year. The economy grew by 7%, government coffers were filled with revenue from soaring world oil prices, and Russia chalked up a trade surplus of $60bn.

All the more reason, Berlin insists, that Moscow pay its debts.

The bigger part of the problem goes back to the Soviet era. Russia owes $48bn in non-commercial debt to the so-called Paris Club of sovereign creditors, with Germany alone accounting for almost half that sum. More than three quarters of the total is Soviet-era debt which Russia agreed to assume after 1991 when it also appropriated most of the Soviet Union's assets.

Whether it should be paying the old debt is a moot point. It includes billions of dollars owed to old communist east Germany, for example, now demanded with interest by wealthy reunified Germany. Moscow was due to pay $3.4bn dollars on the Soviet-era debt this year, but budgeted only for a third of that sum.

Then Mr Kasyanov dropped his bombshell. With Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder in Moscow last month sounding tough on the debt issue, Mr Putin overruled his prime minister, though not entirely convincingly. Andrei Illarionov, Mr Putin's free market guru, ridiculed his boss's government as ''hooligans''.

On the same day two weeks ago, Alexey Kudrin, the finance minister, said Moscow would after all make its first quarter payments of $1.6bn while his deputy, Sergei Kolotukhin, insisted that it could not pay more than had been budgeted, $1.3bn for the entire year.

Moscow bankers and analysts were amazed and dismayed at the disarray. ''The debt confusion is a disaster,'' said one. ''Putin says one thing one day and another the next.''

With Germany muttering that Russia could find itself suspended from its prestige position in the G8 group of industrialised countries, Mr Putin ordered budget revisions to facilitate the debt repayments. But then his de facto number two and security aide, Sergei Ivanov, chose Munich in Germany as the venue to issue a cryptic warning to the west against profiteering on the debt issue.

''Politics have to be paid for,'' Mr Ivanov declared. ''If you refuse to waive some profits today, you might get results tomorrow which turn out to be more expensive, not only economically.''

Wink, wink. Nudge, nudge.

Eric Kraus, chief strategist at Nikoil Capital Markets in Moscow, observed that ''the Russian government has been misleading and anarchic in its public pronouncements... Virtually every major player, from Putin to Kasyanov, has been giving the 'official' word to the media. Alas, they are all totally contradictory.

"Several colleagues have interpreted this cacophony as a negotiating technique, intended to confuse the opposition. Unfortunately, we are at a loss to see what they could have gained from this confusion, other than to totally discredit themselves.''

There is little doubt that Russia needs at the very least to restructure its Soviet-era debt since a whopping and unaffordable $18bn falls due to the Paris Club in two years' time. Mr Putin and Mr Schroeder appear keen to do a controversial debt-for-equity swap that trades German shares in Russian industry for several billion dollars of the debt.

But the badly planned game of unruly brinkmanship and faits accomplis that are instantly reversed is giving the Kremlin a bad name and sullying Mr Putin's image as stern disciplinarian. It looks like he has just landed himself a budget crisis and a parliamentary revolt he does not need. Government heads could roll.

fields.headline: Fund fails to deliver
fields.standfirst: The social fund has failed those who need it most and must be reformed, writes Bob Holman
fields.trailText: The social fund has failed those who need it most and must be reformed, writes Bob Holman
fields.body:
Prior to Thatcher, the government supplemented income support (as it is now called) by giving long-term claimants entitlements to grants to purchase essential domestic items such as cookers. In 1988, in order to cut public expenditure, the Conservatives installed the social fund under which most grants were replaced by loans, although grants to enable people to return to the community were retained. The awards were discretionary and limited to the budgets of local social security offices.

The effect on poor families was devastating. Few receive the community care grants, but, in 1999-2000, 1,946,000 loans were made with re-payments deducted at source. In Easterhouse, Glasgow, I often meet families wanting furniture, washing machines, prams - even food. Among the last 50 families that our project helped with their financial difficulties, 72% had social fund loans and were paying back £5, £7, £9, £13 or more, a week. Consequently, their cash incomes were, for instance, £90, £85, £79 or less. Their experiences confirm larger studies that families with such repayments then go short of daily living requirements.

Further, in 1998-99, 689,000 applications for loans were rejected. Often, the officials considered the applicants too poor to pay back. Others got nothing because the local budget was exhausted. So even those considered eligible for and needy of social fund loans were turned away.

Social fund recipients may have gained a new item via the loan but their families soon need shoes, a replacement bed, clothes, etc. Their deductions make it impossible to save. Like those rejected for the official loans, many turn to private loan companies. Door-to-door salespersons provide cheques or vouchers to be used in certain shops - at interest rates many times that charged by high street banks.

Provident Financial, the personal finances services group which focuses on credit, cash collections and insurance, now has almost as many debtors as the social fund. Its pre-tax profits on home credit services have soared from £88m in 1994 to £1.5bn in 1999.

The poor find other ways to try and make ends meet. Families walk into shops that do not investigate customers' credit standing, which require no deposit, which deliver washing machines, TVs, etc straightaway - the eventual cost of which is more than double the original price. The poor pay more - and get less.

The social fund is supposed "to help people with needs which are difficult to meet from regular income". It fails. So glaring are its faults that Robin Cook, when shadow social security spokesperson, declared: "I would like to see the social fund go... if a family needs a new cooker... it needs a single payment." On taking office, New Labour did a u-turn and decided against any reform. Only after persistent campaigning from churches, voluntary groups and poor people themselves, is the social fund again receiving political attention. What should be done?

First, at the very least, budgets should be increased so that loans can be made to all eligible claimants.

Second, and better, the grants system should be restored. Professor Gary Craig of the University of Hull estimates this would cost £800m a year - less than the wretched Millennium Dome.

Third, and alternatively, each family surviving long-term on benefits should receive an annual bonus sufficient to buy one major domestic item but would have no access to the social fund. Without the labour intensive processing of applications, the administrative saving would be about £215m a year.

But these reforms address the symptom, not the cause. All families should have incomes adequate for a decent lifestyle. The money should come from direct taxation on those who have too much - some of whom pretend to be socialists - and who take incomes of £70,000 and more. In case New Labour has forgotten, it is called greater equality.

 Bob Holman is professor of social administration at the University of Bath. He is involved in a community project in Easterhouse, Glasgow

fields.headline: Government computer system failures
fields.standfirst:
The Home Office has scrapped a computer system intended to help clear the backlog of asylum seekers. Sarah Left explains why

Special report: Refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: The Home Office has scrapped a computer system intended to help clear the backlog of asylum seekers. Sarah Left explains why.
fields.body:
Why is the computer system of the Home Office immigration and nationality directorate in the news?
Because the Home Office abandoned a nearly £80m system that was meant to streamline asylum and immigration claims. The current backlog of asylum claims stands at 66,000 and immigration claims at 100,000.

Why has the Home Office scrapped such an expensive system?
The home secretary, Jack Straw, has described the computer system - meant to reduce the record backlog of asylum applications - as "over-complex and out of touch with current working practices". The system was meant to handle the whole of an asylum claim from application to acceptance or deportation. Three years after the system's 1998 completion date, it still doesn't do that. Parts of the system are operating on what Mr Straw describes as an "interim basis", presumably meaning until they find and pay for another system that can handle the original requirements.

How did it go wrong?
The last Conservative government commissioned the system in 1996 to speed up the complex paper-based system of processing asylum claims. Computer giant Siemens Business Systems was brought in to install and maintain the system, which was promised to save taxpayers £110m as efficiency improved. But the system never fully worked together, leaving caseworkers dealing with parts of asylum claims manually and moving paper files from building to building.

Why not just forget the computer systems and hire more immigration officers to handle the claims manually?
The Tories knew the number of asylum claims was rising and reckoned a comprehensive computer system would speed up claims processing and allow them to reduce staff numbers by up to 1,200. In fact, the immigration minister, Barbara Roche, said the Home Office has had to recruit "hundreds and hundreds" of immigration officials to handle the extra casework.

Haven't I heard about a lot of these failures?
According to research from the Liberal Democrats, the Home Office is currently implementing 11 IT projects, eight of which are a combined £41m over budget and 11 years late. There have been high-profile failures at the passport agency (Siemens again, by the way) and the probation service, to name but two.

Is government a poor buyer of IT?
The government has to disclose big failures to the public, unlike the private sector, which can keep IT mishaps to itself. But most industry analysts agree that the government does a particularly poor job of buying IT systems.

Why do the failures keep happening?
The government admits that public sector pay is not great, and IT professionals can earn a lot of money elsewhere in the current economy. That means the government can lack the IT and project management skills necessary to handle a longterm and complex projects. Sometimes changes in policy mean the computer system is redundant before it is fully installed. And often the government plans projects over five or 10 years, meaning implementation takes so many years that by the time the system is up and running, it is out of date.

What is the government doing to improve the situation?
As the first step to healing, the cabinet office has recognised it has a problem. Last May, it produced a report designed to improve the government's record on IT projects. Every department also appointed an IT champion to take charge of technological change. The government's new e-envoy, Andrew Pinder, appointed by the prime minister last month, has also pledged to reduce the number of government IT failures. It is still too early to tell if all the sound and fury will produce results.

There have been high-profile failures at the passport agency (Siemens again, by the way) and the probation service, to name but two. Is government a poor buyer of IT? The government has to disclose big failures to the public, unlike the private sector, which can keep IT mishaps to itself. But most industry analysts agree that the government does a particularly poor job of buying IT systems. Why do the failures keep happening? The government admits that public sector pay is not great, and IT professionals can earn a lot of money elsewhere in the current economy. That means the government can lack the IT and project management skills necessary to handle a longterm and complex projects. Sometimes changes in policy mean the computer system is redundant before it is fully installed. And often the government plans projects over five or 10 years, meaning implementation takes so many years that by the time the system is up and running, it is out of date. What is the government doing to improve the situation? As the first step to healing, the cabinet office has recognised it has a problem. Last May, it produced a report designed to improve the government's record on IT projects. Every department also appointed an IT champion to take charge of technological change. The government's new e-envoy, Andrew Pinder, appointed by the prime minister last month, has also pledged to reduce the number of government IT failures. It is still too early to tell if all the sound and fury will produce results. fields.headline: Past government IT mess-ups
fields.standfirst: Sarah Left looks at the government's expensive failed attempts at updating its computer systems
fields.trailText: Sarah Left looks at the government's expensive failed attempts at updating its computer systems.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, Simon Hughes, has released research showing that Home Office IT projects are a combined £41m over budget and 11 years late. The news came on the same day that the Home Office admitted it has scrapped a £77m immigration and asylum system that never delivered the expected cost and efficiency savings it promised.

But a quick look at the government's record on IT projects proves that the Home Office is not alone. Who are some of the worst offenders?

Department: Benefits agency and Post Office (joint project)
System: payment of benefit through post office counters
IT supplier: ICL
Cost of failure: £1bn
The public accounts committee said: "Estimated fraud savings from the automation of benefit payments at post offices, if the project had been completed on schedule, would have been about £190m a year."

Department: Home Office
System: Immigration and Nationality directorate casework programme
IT supplier: Siemens Business Systems
Cost of failure: £77m
Home secretary Jack Straw said the system was: "over-complex and out of touch with current working practices."

Department: Ministry of Defence
System: Project Trawlerman
Cost of failure: £41m
The public accounts committee said: "The planned date for site acceptance testing was October 1991. The project was abandoned in November 1996."

Department: Home Office
System: Passport agency
IT supplier: Siemens Business Systems
Over budget by: £38m
The public accounts committee said: "Processing times reached 50 days in July 1999. The problems received widespread publicity and caused much anxiety for members of the public."

Department: Contributions agency
System: National Insurance recording system (NIRS2)
IT supplier: Anderson Consulting
Cost of failure: £38m in compensation payments to affected pension holders
The public accounts committee said: "Delays in implementing NIRS2 in full have led to the calculation of thousands of short term and long term benefits on an interim or emergency basis, and that payments to personal pension holders continue to be delayed."

Department: Inland Revenue
System: The 10-year contract covers a number of systems
IT supplier: EDS
Original cost agreed: £1bn
Cost as of April 2000: £2.4bn
The public accounts committee said: "Software development productivity achieved under the contract with EDS has been below industry standards, partly because new developments have had to be based on existing, less productive, operating systems to meet the department's timetables."

webTitle: Cosla faces crisis as three councils leave

fields.headline: Cosla faces crisis as three councils leave
fields.trailText: The Convention of Scottish Local Authorities is facing a mounting crisis after three councils decided to pull out and at least two others are considering their position. Simon Parker reports
fields.body:
The Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla) is facing a mounting crisis after three councils decided to pull out and at least two others are considering their position.

Falkirk council decided to withdraw from Cosla yesterday, redirecting its £71,000 membership fee to care for elderly people, while Clackmannanshire council is set to reach its decision at a budget meeting tomorrow night.

The moves follow last week's decision by Scotland's largest council, Glasgow, to pull out and make its own representations directly to the Scottish executive and the parliament. Its £300,000 membership fee will now be spent on special needs education for autistic children.

Meanwhile, South Lanarkshire - Scotland's fifth largest council - is also threatening to withdraw from Cosla and another, Renfrewshire, has said it is examining its position.

Falkirk's decision came after the Scottish National Party successfully challenged the minority Labour administration's budget and forced the council to withdraw from Cosla.

Council leader John Connolly said: "Personally I am disappointed by the council's decision as I believe Cosla has been effective in promoting the interests of local authorities. I believe our best chance for further change would be to remain in Cosla and lobby collectively for the good of local government."

Clackmannanshire's decision seems certain to be ratified at a budget meeting tomorrow, when the ruling SNP group is likely to redirect its £25,000 membership fee to extend opening hours for youth centres.

Council leader Keith Brown said the administration felt that it was not getting best value for money and that it was not properly represented by Cosla in negotiations with the Scottish executive. "I really don't think Cosla has a future. What we need is a radical champion for local government in Scotland, not one that takes its line from a party," he said.

South Lanarkshire's ruling Labour group is concerned about the mounting cost and size of Cosla and is to carry out a best value review of its membership before the end of the month. One suggestion is that the £147,000 membership fee could be spent on providing more aids and adaptations for elderly people.

Council leader Eddie McAvoy stressed that money was not the most important factor. "The most important factor is the way the Cosla organisation has mushroomed beyond the realities of our budget into the realms of wishful thinking," he said.

Renfrewshire said it was examining its position after Glasgow's decision to pull out. "We do believe that some internal reform is necessary, not only in order for Cosla to adjust to the reduction in budget, but so that Cosla can place an increased emphasis on representing areas which suffer social and economic deprivation," said council leader Jim Harkins.

Cosla has been putting a brave face on the latest developments though inwardly it appears worried. Cosla president Norman Murray is understood to be extremely angry that the organisation is being used as a "political football" by the SNP, which he claims has grossly misrepresented Cosla as Labour-dominated.

"We really cannot see the Scottish executive dealing with individual councils, particularly small councils like Clackmannanshire. We are committed to taking our organisation forward, though perhaps we may have to look at how we do that." said a Cosla spokeswoman.

fields.headline: Arredondo quits Yahoo!
fields.trailText: 2.15pm: Yahoo! Europe boss Fabiola Arredondo has quit suddenly 'to pursue private business interests', writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Yahoo! Europe's high-profile managing director Fabiola Arredondo has quit suddenly "to pursue private business interests".

Staff are shocked by her resignation but said they weren't surprised given the battle that lies ahead for Yahoo! in the depressed internet climate.

"During my tenure as managing director of Yahoo! Europe, we have accomplished and exceeded all of our business goals and are well placed for further growth in each of our key strategic areas of focus," said Ms Arredondo.

Internally the feeling is that Ms Arredondo has "just had enough" after four years in the job, and that she wanted to "quit while she was ahead".

Yahoo! has had a tough six months and analysts are expecting the leading internet outfit's fortunes to get worse before they get better.

The downturn in internet advertising revenues has hit Yahoo's revenues and only last month it slashed sales and growth forecasts.

Politically, the company has suffered on the back of the Nazi memorabilia court case in France and pornography allegations concerning its Japananese website.

Sources suggested there has been some internal friction at Yahoo! about the direction in which the product is moving.

Yahoo! Europe's commercial director Jerry Glover left the company four months ago after less than a year in the job, saying he did not have enough pan-European work to keep him busy. He has not been replaced.

It is being suggested that Ms Arredondo also may not be directly replaced, as there is less need for a pan-European boss to report into Heather Killen, Yahoo!'s senior vice-president of international, and each European region now has its own managing director.

According to a Yahoo! Europe spokeswoman, Ms Arredondo will remain with the company for "an interim period", likely to be a couple of months, to ensure a smooth handover.

Before Yahoo!, Ms Arredondo held jobs with BMG Entertainment Latin America, JP Morgan and BBC Worldwide, where she was director of international distribution.
