webTitle: Tough mayor for a tough town

fields.headline: Tough mayor for a tough town
fields.standfirst: The Democrats'  candidate for the New York mayorship is trying to out-Giuliani Giuliani by talking zero tolerance for crime. But, if he think he's got it hard, he should remember past occupants of City Hall, says Michael Ellison
fields.trailText: The Democrats' candidate for the New York mayorship is trying to out-Giuliani Giuliani by talking zero tolerance for crime. But, if he thinks he's got it hard, he should remember past occupants of City Hall, says Michael Ellison.
fields.body:
The man who appears to hold the best hope of winning the job of mayor of New York City for the Democratic party was talking the other day about his approach to crime.

Just in case anyone thought Mark Green was a liberal softie, the image his opponents most often like to project, he had this to say: "In a serious riot situation, helicopters and tanks arguably could be appropriate."

And this from the Public Advocate, or consumer affairs commissioner, derided by the present mayor, Rudy Giuliani, as "the anti-police, anti-law enforcement candidate."

Mr Giuliani, the Republican leader of an overwhelmingly Democratic city, has transformed the criteria for election in New York by cutting crime in half where, once, anything was supposed to go.

So Mr Green, who twice sued City Hall over police misconduct and produced a report on rogue officers, has changed his emphasis. Now he is a victim of crime: his car has been broken into, as has his apartment - twice - and his mother and grandmother were tied up in their home by thugs.

"Those are experiences that no crime victim can ever forget," said this regular attendee of police funerals, at the carefully chosen venue, John Jay College of Criminal Justice. Neither was it a coincidence that among the audience was a former commissioner of the New York police department, Patrick Murphy.

Then, a few days later, another former top policeman endorsed Mr Green. This time it was Bill Bratton, commissioner for two years until 1996, when Mr Giuliani took against him for claiming some of the credit for the falling crime figures.

All in all, not a bad week for Mr Green in the business of repositioning. It was a week, also, when muted eulogies were offered to the memory of a former mayor, Abe Beame, who died at the age of 94. The New York Times said that it was his misfortune to have been elected mayor in 1973 and then overwhelmed by the worst financial crisis in the city's history.

Two months ago, when his predecessor John Lindsay died, an earlier misfortune was identified: that it had been the glamorous, party-switching Mr Lindsay's hard luck to have become mayor at the height of a period of urban unrest.

Further, it was a pity for Mr Beame, the short, grey accountant to have had to follow Mr Lindsay, the dashing superintendent of Fun City from 1966 to 1973, who was blessed with a fixed image of youthfulness.

Perhaps Mr Beame's misfortunate went deepest. Mr Lindsay, in his time, made a mess of the city's finances, and Mr Beame then made such a mess of sorting them out that by 1975 New York was on a precipice of bankruptcy.

On Mr Lindsay's death last December at the age of 79 the portrait was that of the civic leader who went on the streets of the city's black communities on the night of Martin Luther King's assassination to show that someone cared.

That went some way to obscuring memories of strikes and picket lines, mountains of rubbish in the street, rising crime, white flight to the suburbs, financial crises and scandals in the police.

Mr Lindsay got posthumous credit for trying to improve the lot of the poor and minorities, even if his initiatives were fuelled by unsustainable taxation and fiscal jiggery-pokery; Mr Beame for honesty, decency and lack of pretension when more was required. At least neither had the misfortune to be remembered for helicopters and tanks.

fields.headline: Bulger killer 'in violent incidents'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Bulger case
Audio from the court (2mins 23)
fields.trailText: One of the killers of James Bulger has been involved in violent incidents in a secure unit, suggests new evidence presented the high court today.
fields.body:
One of the killers of James Bulger has been involved in violent incidents in a secure unit, suggests new evidence presented the high court today.

Two judges were told of the incidents as James's father attempted to overturn a decision of the lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, which effectively gave the murderers hope of parole.

In October Lord Woolf said of Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, now both 18, "neither has shown any aggression or propensity for violence during his period of detention". While these assertions made the young men eligible for early release, the parole board would have to make the final decision.

But Alan Newman QC, for the murdered child's father Ralph Bulger, 34, argued today that the senior judge was not aware of allegations of violence against Thompson, and therefore made his decision without all the relevant facts.

Applying for permission to seek judicial review, Mr Newman told Lord Justice Rose, sitting with Mr Justice Sullivan and Mr Justice Penry-Davey, that there was evidence "of two separate incidents alleging violence on the part of Thompson whilst in custody".

He added: "I understand that material relating to either one or both of these new incidents I have referred to in recent evidence has been provided by (the home secretary) to the lord chief justice."

James's mother Denise Fergus, 33, said she had been "disgusted and shocked" by Lord Woolf's decision, which meant Thompson and Venables had "got away with murder".

Earlier this week she marked the eighth anniversary of her son's murder by leading a march through her home town of Kirkby on Merseyside. She urged the government to look at the worldwide support she has received from people who believe James's killers should not be freed in the near future.

Thompson and Venables, who were 10 when they abducted and tortured two-year-old James on a railway line in Liverpool in 1993, have so far served their sentences in secure local authority accommodation. If they are released, they are expected to begin new lives under false names in a different part of the country.

fields.headline: Champions League scores for ITV
fields.trailText: 2.15pm TV overnights: Soap and football made ITV champion of the peaktime league last night, reports Wale Azeez.
fields.body:
ITV re-established its peaktime ratings hegemony last night, with a St Valentine's Day diet of soap and European Champions League football.

After BBC1 won a rare peaktime victory on Tuesday, last night's ITV coverage of Valencia v Manchester United led the counter-attack between 7.30 and 9.45pm.

The Champions League clash had 8.5m and a 36% share, according to unofficial overnights, which was ITV's best European football rating this season.

BBC1 held up well against ITV's football for the first hour from 7.30pm. Celebrity Ready Steady Cook had 7.5m and a 34% share, while This is Your Life managed 7.3m and 30%.

But after that BBC1 faltered with two Dale Winton-fronted shows.

Comic Relief quiz show One Thousand to One drew just 5.3m from 8.40pm, followed by the Variety Club Awards 2001, with 5.1m between 9.10 and 10pm.

Before the football on ITV, Emmerdale pulled in 9.9m from 7pm, followed by Coronation Street with 10.6m.

This helped News at Ten hold a 7.5m audience from 10.15pm; while the BBC1 Ten O'Clock News had just 3.9m.

fields.headline: Entranet axes staff
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: E-commerce agency Entranet has slashed its workforce in a move described by staff as a 'Valentine's Day massacre'. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
E-commerce agency Entranet has slashed its workforce in a move described by staff as a "Valentine's Day massacre".

Entranet, which develops e-commerce strategies for clients, this week laid off 30 staff and sources suggest the cull may not stop there.

Employees are concerned that the number of redundancies could reach 75, from a total of 200 in Entranet's London and Goring offices.

"It's like a Valentine's Day massacre around here and a real embarrassment to the company," said one of the Entranet employees laid off.

"We are making 30 staff redundant because of the fast-changing nature of this business," Entranet said.

"As the industry matures, there is less demand for certain types of skills, and more demand for others, such as interactive TV."

We are sorry to be losing some very talented and dedicated people and we'd like to thank them publicly for their tremendous efforts. We will be leaner, fitter, and focused on creating valuable and compelling customer experiences."

Entranet said it would continue to recruit for specific role and was looking for business development managers, strategic account managers and interactive TV specialists.

The agency believes is aiming to become the UK's leading digital developer for the financial services industry, working with clients including Sun Life, Goldfish, Marbles, Eagle Star, the Co-operative Bank and the Woolwich.

Entranet joins the growing number of internet services agencies, such as Razorfish and Agency.com, that have suffered due to the slowdown in the internet economy and clients cutting back online budgets.

fields.headline: Vickers makes British Press Awards shortlist
fields.standfirst: Click here to see the shortlist
fields.trailText:
12pm: MediaGuardian.co.uk's new media editor Amy Vickers has been nominated in this year's British Press Awards.
Click here to see the shortlist
fields.body:
MediaGuardian.co.uk's new media editor Amy Vickers is one of 11 Guardian and Observer journalists nominated for this year's British Press Awards.

Ms Vickers has been shortlisted in the best online journalist category for the awards, which are the industry's most prestigious.

Other nominations from the Guardian include Peter Bradshaw, for critic of the year, with the Observer's Laura Cummings also nominated in this category.

Two Guardian business journalists, executive financial editor Paul Murphy and financial reporter Jill Treanor, are nominated for business journalist and financial journalist of the year respectively.

Maggie O'Kane, who made her name reporting from troublespots such as the Balkans and East Timor, is nominated for feature writer of the year.

Emma Brockes has been shortlisted for young journalist of the year.

The Observer Life magazine has notched up two nominations, Lynn Barber for interviewer of the year and Jane Clarke for specialist writer.

The Observer's football writer Ian Ridley is in the running for sports writer of the year.

The Guardian's Francis Wheen is on the shortlist for columnist of the year.

The British Press Awards, which are organised by trade magazine Press Gazette, will be presented on Wednesday March 21 at the Hilton Park Lane.

The nominations for the BPA newspaper categories will be published early next month.

fields.headline: EM.TV bailed out by Kirch
fields.trailText: 1pm: Muppets owner EM.TV has pulled itself back from the brink of liquidation by signing a rescue deal with the Kirch Group. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
EM.TV & Merchandising, the debt-ridden German owner of the Muppets, has pulled itself back from the brink of liquidation by signing a rescue deal with the Kirch Group.

Under the terms of the deal, Kirch will buy almost half of EM.TV's 50% stake in formula one holding company SLEC for £380m and take a 16% stake in EM.TV.

"The company will strengthen its focus on a structural reorganisation and concentrate on its core competencies," EM.TV said.

EM.TV has been fending off banks that have threatened to shut it down.

The company built up massive debts, after spending £680m buying the Jim Henson Company - which owns the Muppets franchise - and the SLEC stake.

EM.TV has been negotiating the rescue funding deal with Kirch since December.

The protracted negotiations between the parties appeared to be on the brink of collapse after formula one owner Bernie Ecclestone objected to the deal and said he would exercise an agreement forcing EM.TV to pay £680m for a further 25% of SLEC.

But Mr Ecclestone relented after Kirch said it would guarantee a bank loan to finance the acquisition of the increased holding in SLEC.

EM.TV's shares soared in value by more than 35% on the Neuer Markt in Frankfurt on news of the deal, although its current price of 527p is 93% below its high of 7527p in February last year.

Analysts said EM.TV was far from out of the woods, as the company has released little information on its financial prospects for the year ahead.

One key source of EM.TV's woes was its decision late last year to slash its 2000 profit forecast by 90% following serious accounting errors.

However, EM.TV gains complete control of its Junior TV joint venture with Kirch as part of the deal, giving it access to one of the world's biggest film libraries for children's and family entertainment.

"There is plenty of potential in Junior, but they have shown no success in selling it internationally and they need more progress on that front," said Sarah Schmitz, media analyst at Commerzbank.

Ms Schmitz added that EM.TV's extensive programming library, which includes Jim Henson's Muppet Show, is ripe for exploitation and will be boosted by Kirch's support.

But investor confidence in the German media sector has been shaken by EM.TV's rollercoaster ride on the stock market.

"The overall German media market is still quite risky, so you need to pick stocks where management has a good track record and there is a demand for the product," said Ms Schmitz.

fields.headline: Games reviews
fields.trailText: Severance: Blade of Darkness | Kingdom Under Fire | Tokyo Highway Challenge 2
fields.byline: Greg Howson, Mike Anderiesz and Jack Schofield
fields.body:
Severance: Blade of Darkness
PC 29.99 Codemasters ****
Codemasters has released Severance: Blade of Darkness, but convincing occasional PC gamers of its merits is proving difficult.

"Yes," I keep saying, "videogames have changed." Gone are the days when little Billy fought goblins in his bedroom. Now it is all interior furnishings with The Sims and ironic body popping to Dancing Stage. But it is too late. They've seen Severance on the monitor and gaming appears guilty as charged.

"OK, so the game is a fantasy hack'n'slash affair that prides itself on its gory content, but it does have original features." I'm getting desperate now.

"For example, if you fancy a change from swinging your sword then you can simply pick up a freshly severed arm to club the baddie. Great, eh?"

Silence.

"Er, well, what about the lighting, then? Look at that torch flickering, and see how the shadows dance on the dungeon wall."

A murmur of approval.

"Gorgeous, isn't it. Fancy a go now?" I know the stunning visuals will tempt them. "The controls are simple. Double- clicking the mouse makes you run, while pressing the tab key makes you target the enemy and, er, yes, a joypad would be far more enjoyable to use. But don't worry about the clumsy keys: after a little practice you'll be thrusting and parrying like a veteran."

However, one look at the character selection screen, complete with Tukaram the Barbarian and Naglfar the Dwarf, and they seem to lose heart.

"Yes, I know it's fantasy cliche, but give it a chance."

They leave.

It seems that innovative combat and some of the most impressive PC graphics ever are not enough. A shame, as Severance is too good for just the hardcore fraternity. (GH)

Kingdom Under Fire
PC £29.99 Phantagram **
Few genres have been flogged to death so viciously as the RTS (real time strategy) game. For the past five years, publishers have been banging out games about mining resources, building lots of tanks and charging headlong at the enemy, but significant advances over the original Command & Conquer remain few and far between.

Kingdom Under Fire attempts to bring a touch of role-playing to the mix, by including heroes who can be dispatched on individual quests to accumulate some of the 60 or so magical spells. In theory, protecting these units adds another level to the gameplay. Sadly, with KUF, the extra weight is enough to bring the whole structure tumbling down.

For a start the graphics are small and only viewable in a single 2D resolution. Admittedly, they do improve later on, with flying dragons making for some thrilling aerial bombardments, but this is still not a patch on Total Annihilation: Kingdoms, itself badly flawed and now more than two years old.

Worse still is a fiddly interface where mouse clicks are frequently ignored and every skirmish turns into a prolonged struggle against the intelligence of your own men. If units are cornered, they often refuse to retreat or fall over each other. Your heroes thus become all important and, with no mid-level save, later missions almost encourage you to slaughter your own men in order to gain extra hero experience.

In fairness, some of these problems have already been fixed with a patch and the game is keenly priced. But KUF is still a hotch-potch of half-developed ideas from a newish developer too influenced by the Warcraft titles.

More seriously, the RTS is fast going the way of the platform game: a popular genre being used far too often to prop up sub-standard ideas. Yes, you could level similar criticism at mega-hits like Tiberian Sun and Red Alert 2, but at least these were executed with panache. Style over substance can often be forgiven; having neither is a bit harder to swallow. (MA)

Tokyo Highway Challenge 2
Sega Dreamcast £39.99 Genki/Ubi Soft ***
Boy racers start here. Soup up your boxy Japanese car with a custom plate, decals, new bumpers and spoilers, and a range of performance tweaks. Then you can hit the roads, flashing your headlights at other drivers, challenging them to short races. You can spend the winnings on improving your car, eventually buying less brick-like models.

The tweaking is great and takes place on screen in real time: change the wheels on the spec and the wheels change on the car. You can also design your own decals.

The use of shadows and specular reflections means the game sometimes looks great, though all the racing takes place in the dark on boring flyovers or in boring tunnels on boring urban expressways. Japanese road signs and markings add the merest touch of glamour to what is otherwise a dull scene. Basically there's only one track, and it is not very long.

Unfortunately, the racing is not very exciting, and there is not even a two-player mode to rescue what quickly becomes a samey game.

The other problem with Genki's game is that what was original when the first version appeared on the Sony PlayStation looks much less striking now. Games such as Metropolis Street Racer and F355 Challenge mean urban driving is not the novelty it was. Nor are high-resolution car graphics, reflections and motion blur enough to sustain long-term interest, especially if they are the reason the action sometimes slows almost to a halt.

This isn't a bad game, by any means. It is just not good enough. (JS)

webTitle: Milburn to pledge big rise in NHS staff

fields.headline: Milburn to pledge big rise in NHS staff
fields.standfirst: Consultants up by 50%, with more GPs, nurses and midwives
fields.trailText: A near 50% increase in hospital consultants in England over the next decade will be announced by the health secretary, Alan Milburn, today as the government seeks to re-establish its NHS credentials during the pre-election phony war.
fields.body:
A near 50% increase in hospital consultants in England over the next decade will be announced by the health secretary, Alan Milburn, today as the government seeks to re-establish its NHS credentials during the pre-election phony war.

Big rises in nurses, midwives, GPs and physiotherapists will also be promised in a package designed to help restore the credibility of the service amid continuing public disquiet at waiting lists for consultations and treatment, ward hygiene and quality of life in hospitals.

In an attempt to respond to scandals such as the Alder Hey body parts controversy and the bodies in the chapel episode at Bedford, Mr Milburn will announce that all those undergoing medical training will have to pass tests in communication skills with patients and families as well as study ethics and equal opportunities.

The number of consultants is expected to rise from 24,300 last year to 36,000 by 2009, and within that total there will be far higher percentage rises for heart and cancer specialists.

Physiotherapists will rise by 59% to 24,800, midwives by 44% to 32,600, nurses by 17% to 403,000 and GPs by more than 10% to 31,600.

The government has been under sustained criticism from the professions for widespread staff shortages and Mr Milburn will be hoping that the long-term recruitment targets, tied to big increases in training budgets, up to £250m or 11% for next year, will blunt Tory attacks before the election campaign even starts.

The government has already called its "unprecedented" spending increases on the NHS, 6.1% a year on average from 2000 to 2004, the longest sustained period of high growth. The new staffing promises mean yet more funding.

Today's announcement builds on earlier promises. For instance, the 738 consultants working in coronary care in 1999 were already expected to rise to 992 in 2003, an increase of a third.

fields.headline: Warning signs on doctors' roadshow
fields.standfirst: While the NHS is strapped for cash, the pharmaceutical companies have money to woo
fields.trailText: While the NHS is strapped for cash, the pharmaceutical companies have money to woo.
fields.body:
There is a group of eminent British cardiologists who are referred to, by a certain drug company's sales reps in irreverent moments in the pub, as the Roadshow. They spend a considerable amount of time travelling around the UK and abroad, promoting the company's heart drugs. Some of them earn more from this than their annual salary from their hospital or university.

It may well be that these consultants are totally convinced of the value of the medicines and would do it out of conviction even if they were not sometimes paid as much as £3,000-£5,000 a time for an evening lecture which lasts around an hour. But the fact that they receive such large payments undermines the credibility of their opinions.

Peter Wilmshurst, consultant cardiologist at the Royal Shrewsbury hospital who has been a constant critic of the relationship between drug companies and doctors, believes the huge sums of money washing around have the potential to skew people's judgments.

"Some members of the Roadshow have spoken fortnightly for the company .. some also receive fees from other companies. It would be naive to imagine that the size of fees do not affect the statements of opinion leaders," he wrote in a letter to the Lancet last summer.

There is no suggestion that doctors will promote a drug that will do any harm, but they may persuade themselves to promote one drug over another that is just as good.

There are always going to be tensions between the altruism inherent in healing the sick and the baser human imperative that drives the pharmaceutical industry to make money. But there are those who say that in parts of British medicine today, the one is being distorted by the other.

While the NHS is strapped for cash, the pharmaceutical firms have billions to invest in research and marketing. Doctors from early in their career are under subtle pressure to accept the financial support of the industry. Many see nothing wrong, others feel uncomfortable but shrug it off as the prevailing culture, and some consider that there is a real conflict of interest.

Dr Wilmshurst's eyes were opened to the potential for abuse when he was a relatively junior doctor involved in the clinical trials of a new drug for heart failure called amrinone. His team at St Thomas's hospital in London found some patients suffered gastrointestinal disturbances, liver failure and problems with their immune system. "The company asked us not to publish our adverse findings. Then when we said we had to publish, they threatened us with legal action," he says. "When you are threatened by a multinational with infinite amounts of money, some people might find that a good reason not to go ahead."

His team published. Others with similar results did not, he says, after senior cardiologists told them their findings were out of line with everyone else's. The drug was withdrawn on safety grounds in 1984, but was sold over the counter in the Philippines and Africa until 1986.

Dr Wilmshurst believes little has changed and that the largesse of the drug companies is a malign influence on doctors. "I don't think it is the majority of the medical profession, but the big problem is often with the big earners. The big earners are offered the biggest amounts of money."

The Association for the British Pharmaceutical Industry (ABPI) disagrees. Doctors, often those who have run trials on a drug, are certainly asked to speak and are paid for it, said spokesman Richard Lay. "I think that is right and proper. What we do not control is what they actually say."

He claims it is not unusual for a doctor to dissent from the company line. "Companies are not in the position of paying doctors to say what they want them to say. These are top people in their field. I would be astonished to hear that people like that are going to give misleading information to an audience of professionals who are intelligent and well-informed in their area."

Few academic departments could keep going without the revenues from drug company clinical trials. But the money, power and influence games are most noticeable at medical conferences. On the micro level there are corporate logos, ring binders, notepads, pens and bags in which to keep the literature. But that is not all. "The whole system of paying for doctors to go to conferences by drug companies is corrupt, because a company will not only pay for the air fare, the hotel and the registration fee but also for all the entertainment during the conference," says Richard Horton, editor of the Lancet.

"The payback is that they will make sure that doctor goes to all the symposia that promote their drugs. At the major cardiology conferences, almost no doctor will ever pay for any of those things him or herself. It is all paid for by the industry. The whole thing is one massive promotion."

The ABPI points to its code of practice which says hospitality must be a subsidiary part of a bona fide meeting. "If there is any suggestion that it is just a good jolly, that is not allowed," says Mr Lay.

Even so, Dr Horton is concerned by the growing number of these symposia at medical conferences. A study of the published articles that came out of symposia, carried out by Lisa Bero and colleagues in 1992, found that they had "strong promotional attributes" and warned that readers should "approach symposium issues that are sponsored by a single pharmaceutical company with scepticism".

It is hard to step out of line and those who do, such as Dr Wilmshurst, find their careers take a slide. "You wouldn't get money to do clinical trials if you didn't go along with it," says Dr Horton, "but you are making a Faustian pact by doing so.

"The days of pharmaceutical companies taking doctors out on holiday are over. You can't do that any more - it's been banned. But the way it is done now is very, very heavy."

Those at the very top of the profession, whose work is readily funded by the Medical Research Council or the Wellcome Trust, do not have to depend on the generosity of drug companies, he says. "But for people in the middle rank it is very difficult. It starts very young. They are junior doctors and along comes a friendly drug company rep who takes them out to dinner every week. Immediately you become very sympathetic to industry."

He does not think the UK is any different from America. "I think it is in some ways worse. The reason is that when you are working in a bit of a downtrodden NHS and along comes the rich company that will take you to wonderful cities at the weekend, you become very susceptible. It is just too easy. It is sad."

In his recent book, "Don't Tell the Patient", Professor Bill Inman, who started the NHS "yellow card" scheme for doctors to report to the Department of Health the side effects of the medicines they prescribe and later founded the Drug Safety Unit at Southampton, alleges that drug company "post marketing surveillance" schemes, where GPs are paid for filling in forms on the side effects experienced by patients on a new drug, are nothing more than covert marketing.

As a result of his campaigning, industry guidelines called Samm (safety assessment of marketed medicines) were agreed, stipulating that no inducement must be offered to a GP. But, says Prof Inman, he has seen a letter from one company doing a so-called Samm study for angina, offering a doctor £275 to treat four patients with the new drug to be compared with two given the old one. The letter says GPs may enrol up to 18 on the new drug "but the ratio[new drug to old] will be maintained".

Prof Inman believes it is wrong that the Committee on the Safety of Medicines, the government advisory body responsible for drug safety in the UK, should have so many members with links to industry. So does Charles Medawar of the watchdog body Social Audit. "I to some extent buy the argument that it is difficult to recruit top people who don't at least have indirect interests," he said, "but the scale is distinctly unhealthy." In the latest declaration of interests from the CSM, 15 out of 36 had either shareholdings, fees or paid consultancies from drug companies.

"The very fact that they insist the chairman should have no ties indicates that they think it is significant," he said. The present chairman, Alastair Breckenridge, resigned from the advisory board of SmithKline Beecham to take the job.

Members leave the room when a drug from a company they have interests in is being discussed. But Joe Collier, professor of medicines policy at St George's hospital school of medicine, says there is "institutional bias" - so many on the committee are close to drug companies they cannot help but take an industry point of view.

webTitle: Analysis: pharmaceutical industry and the developing world

fields.headline: Conflict between profits and philanthropy trips up industry
fields.trailText: For the past three years I have been tracking the progress of a global alliance, created by the World Health Organisation and SmithKline Beecham, the multinational pharmaceutical company, to eliminate the second most disabling disease in the world: lymphatic filariasis.
fields.body:
For the past three years I have been tracking the progress of a global alliance, created by the World Health Organisation and SmithKline Beecham, the multinational pharmaceutical company, to eliminate the second most disabling disease in the world: lymphatic filariasis (LF), best known for one of its worst outcomes, elephantiasis, the gross swelling of limbs. It infects 120m people in 80 poor countries and threatens 1.2bn, one fifth of the world's population.

Dating back to Pharaonic times, it was identified in 1993 by the international taskforce for disease eradication, which examined 94 infections, as one of only six that could be eradicated. The world health assembly voted its eradication a "public health priority", but little progress was being made until December 1997, when WHO and SB announced a global campaign to eradicate the disease.

SB had agreed to provide free donations of its crucial drug, albendazole, over a 20-year period for all 1.2bn people at risk. Each will require five annual doses. With support costs, it could come to $1bn. It was described by the Financial Times as "the single biggest act of corporate philanthropy in any industry".

How does this square with this week's civil suit in Pretoria, brought by 42 pharmaceutical companies including the newly created Glaxo SmithKline, to stop South Africa from importing cheap medicines? It does not.

I have talked to a succession of key people in earlier eradication campaigns. In the history of man, we have only eliminated one disease: smallpox. But we are on the point of eradicating two others: polio, now down to 7,000 cases; and guinea worm, a threadlike worm, up to three feet long, which emerges through painful blisters on the skin, which is down to a similar number. LF could be the fourth to be eradicated.

Bill Foege, former head of the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, has played a key role in all four eradication campaigns. He is convinced that the only way diseases can be eradicated is through global alliances, such as the LF campaign has created. It combines three international bodies (WHO, the World Bank, Unicef), two pharmaceutical giants (Glaxo SmithKline and Merck), seven national aid agencies, 12 non-government organisations; and nine academic and research institutes.

Dr Foege points to the huge support effort needed in eradicating a disease - transport, training, distribution, epidemiological surveillance, community education - on top of free drugs. Part of the success of the polio campaign was getting the support of Rotary, which raised $400m for the campaign and used its influential members in developing countries to help persuade national governments to endorse the eradication drive.

Dr Foege notes that the smallpox campaign, jointly promoted by the US and USSR in 1966, was at the height of the cold war: "If we could form this alliance during the cold war, how many alliances can we form now?"

In fact, a growing number of alliances is emerging. There are two separate alliances fighting onchocerciasis (river blindness) in Africa, both involving free drug donations from Merck and bilateral aid from 30 donor nations, organised by the World Bank. The older of the two covers 11 states, has prevented 600,000 cases of blindness and added 5m years of productive labour. The second, covering 19 states, has given out more than 100m treatments.

Pfizer has a drug donation campaign against trachoma, the disease in which eyelashes turn inwards blinding its victims; Norvadis, a Swiss company, a drug donation programme for leprosy; and Glaxo Wellcome, now merged with SB, an anti-malarial drug project.

How does all this square with the criticisms set out this week in our series on the pharmaceutical industry? It doesn't. The industry is pursuing contradictory courses: pursuing profits far beyond reasonable boundaries, yet seeking to maintain philan thropic programmes, too.

The media indictment - both here and in the US - is uncontradictable: the industry has indulged in indecent overcharging for drugs in developing nations; wrongly and ruthlessly resisted third world production of generic drugs in developing states; exaggerated its research costs; and underplayed the role that public institutions, such as the National Institutes for Health in the US, have made in drug breakthroughs. Two of the key drugs in the triple therapy for Aids were invented by the NIH and several others relied on NIH clinical trials.

Yet sales in Africa account for a mere 1% of the industry's turnover. Belatedly, the industry has recognised the damage which its pursuit of profit has done to its public image, with promises of reduced drug prices to developing nations.

So where now for Aids treatment? Brazil offers one route by producing its own generic drugs for Aids, but Brazil is much richer than Africa. There are three other models which could be emulated for an Aids drug programme: Unicef's worldwide child immunisation programme; the World Bank's river blindness campaign; WHO's LF eradication programme. What is needed is an international organisation, such as UNaids, which would receive aids drugs at cost price (or lower) from the industry, or the generic equivalent. Backed by donations from bilateral donor nations wider drug distribution could be achieved.

No one should underestimate the challenge. The annual medicinal cost of triple therapy for Aids might be cut from $10,000 a head to $600 or so. But many African countries spend less than $10 per head. Even if drugs were given free, support costs would be huge. LF is facing a $500m bill for its first five years.

The main hope remains a new Aids vaccine. Just when that breakthrough will come is unclear.

fields.headline: £1,000 of assets for all babies
fields.trailText: Every child is to be given assets worth up to £1,000 in an attempt to rebuild Britain's savings culture and attack the root cause of long-term inequality.
fields.body:
Every child is to be given assets worth up to £1,000 in an attempt to rebuild Britain's savings culture and attack the root cause of long-term inequality.

The assets, to be set aside for all 680,000 children currently born every year, could be realised at 18 either to buy a property, fund further training or help set up a business.

For poorer children any extra savings injected by their parents would be matched by the state or local voluntary groups.

Downing Street believes the proposal will give the poor a new stake in society, as well as reduce dependence on the week-by-week dripfeed of benefit payments.

The measure - which would cost around £700m in the first year - might also reverse the recent rapid fall in the savings ratio. From 1979 to 1997 the proportion of people without any financial assets doubled from 5% to 10%.

Providing the poor with an asset base comparable to the funds typically passed down middle class generations might also help poorer workers through periods of unemployment in an increasingly insecure labour market.

The idea was briefly referred to in a speech by the prime minister last week.

Already the subject of bipartisan support in the US, the plan is seen within Whitehall as one of Labour's big second term ideas. It has the backing of the education secretary, David Blunkett, who has made a series of speeches on the need for welfare to generate autonomy and individual responsibility.

"It is how we can make a reality of the claim that the welfare state must be a ladder rather than a safety net," said one Downing Street source.

Government sources were reluctant to spell out the precise sums likely to be realisable at 18, but suggested it could be between £2,000 and £20,000, depending on the precise mix of savings schemes adopted.

"It would be crazy if all the cash was invested in the stock market: there would be a mix," said a Downing Street source.

They added it was politically more sensible to give the cash to all children at birth, rather than just the poor.

Fidelity Investments, one of the biggest unit trust companies in the UK, said yesterday that if someone had invested £1,000 in its UK Growth & Income fund 18 years ago, it would have grown to £12,835 by January 2001.

But current projections suggest £1,000 invested in an Individual Savings Account would be worth £3,380 over the next 18 years, mainly due to lower inflation.

However, these figures ignore the big impact of matching top-up state funds over the intervening years.

The scheme has been brought across the Atlantic by the influential thinktank Institute of Public Policy Research. It is likely to be marketed in Britain as an individual savings account for all children, or a children's trust fund.

The government claims that current Isas have had some, but only limited, impact in spreading a savings culture among the poor, but argue the time is ripe to go much further.

The assets, to be set aside for all 680,000 children currently born every year, could be realised at 18 either to buy a property, fund further training or help set up a business. For poorer children any extra savings injected by their parents would be matched by the state or local voluntary groups. The measure - which would cost around £700m in the first year - might also reverse the recent rapid fall in the savings ratio. From 1979 to 1997 the proportion of people without any financial assets doubled from 5% to 10%. Providing the poor with an asset base comparable to the funds typically passed down middle class generations might also help poorer workers through periods of unemployment in an increasingly insecure labour market. The idea was briefly referred to in a speech by the prime minister last week. Already the subject of bipartisan support in the US, the plan is seen within Whitehall as one of Labour's big second term ideas. It has the backing of the education secretary, David Blunkett, who has made a series of speeches on the need for welfare to generate autonomy and individual responsibility. fields.headline: 'I liked feeling full. I thought about it all day'
fields.trailText: At school Suzanne Pearce wore a size 10 and was the slimmest girl in her class. At 20, she put on five stone in one year. Clinically, she was obese, although she never used the word and had no bathroom scales to measure it.
fields.body:
At school Suzanne Pearce wore a size 10 and was the slimmest girl in her class. At 20, she put on five stone in one year. Clinically, she was obese, although she never used the word and had no bathroom scales to measure it.

"I was pregnant and suffered bouts of sickness. The only thing that would ease it was crisps. I started eating two bags at a time. I kept thinking I would lose the weight when I had the baby," she said.

But after the birth, Ms Pearce, now 21, a former bartender from Manchester, gained more weight. She ate a carrier bag of chocolate bars while watching TV.

Ms Pearce ate Chinese takeaway once a week and chips no more often than that, if at all. The problem was not food, it was exercise. A full-time mother of a baby, she did around two minutes' of physical activity a day. "I went out of my front door, got in the car and drove to my mum's. Then I spent the rest of the day sitting in a chair.

"I didn't know how big I was because I had no scales. I didn't realise I could cut the size of my portions. I liked feeling full. I thought about it all day. Then I realised it was the car. I sold it and started walking. I lost two stone."

John Pendlebury, 41, is a community psychiatric nurse. He learnt about nutritional value as part of his training. But three years ago, he was classed as obese. "I am a nurse, I know how to eat properly. But I wasn't putting it into practice because of stress. I was always driving. I would pull in at a chip shop or takeaway, unfasten my seatbelt, eat a beef satay and fried rice in under five minutes, then drive off. I was four stone overweight. You never think you are obese. You think, 'I'll do something about it tomorrow'.

"It's not manly to eat a salad. But there are no healthy places to eat if you're on the road. I used to park in the tiniest space outside a house because I didn't want to walk round the corner. Now I park as far away as possible."

Linda Nicholson, Weightwatchers area manager for Manchester, was once two stone overweight. "People carrying extra weight are not hulks throwing food down them just for the sake of it. There are usually good reasons: people don't have time to cook; they are stressed, ill or bereaved; they can't fit exercise into their lives; they are affluent so can afford ready meals. Or they are living with a formulaic idea, encouraged by the media, that very low calorie diets will turn them into Kate Moss, when actually yoyo-dieting wreaks havoc with their systems."

She said the numbers of people gaining weight reflected a boom in so-called "low fat" convenience food which, despite fat content, was high in calories.

Related story

fields.headline: Police recruitment drive 'a success'
fields.trailText: 12.15am: The government today hailed its £7m police recruitment campaign a huge success, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
The government today hailed its £7m police recruitment campaign a huge success.

Home office minister Charles Clark said the TV campaign - which featured Falklands War veteran Simon Weston and ex-EastEnders actress Patsy Palmer - has so far attracted 22,563 "quality responses".

Mr Clark said the Metropolitan Police alone has received almost 2,000 formal expressions of interest.

A Home Office spokesman admitted the ultimate success of the campaign would be judged on an increase of "bobbies on the beat".

However, he claimed the advertising initiative had also raised general appreciation of police work.

Home secretary Jack Straw has set out his aim to fill 9,000 police vacancies across the country over the next three years.

The campaign was created by M&C Saatchi last August.

It features a series of celebrities musing on whether they could handle the day-to-day challenges faced by police officers.

It used the endline: "Could you?".

Following appearances by footballer John Barnes and TV presenter Joan Bakewell, the advertising drive has now moved into its second stage.

Nina Wadia, star of BBC2's sketch show Goodness Gracious Me, is now featuring in TV and radio ads in a drive to attract more ethnic recruits into the police force.

webTitle: Hacker launched Anna bug 'as a warning'

fields.headline: Hacker launched Anna bug 'as a warning'
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: A young Dutchman confessed yesterday to having engineered the Anna Kournikova computer virus that brought chaos to millions of machines around the world this week, saying he believed that the Russian tennis star deserved the extra attention.
fields.body:
A young Dutchman confessed yesterday to having engineered the Anna Kournikova computer virus that brought chaos to millions of machines around the world this week, saying he believed that the Russian tennis star deserved the extra attention.

The computer bug, which has been compared to the "I Love You" virus that paralysed 45m computers last year, asked anyone who received it to click on a file attachment which appeared to be a picture of the 19-year-old athlete.

When they did so, the virus entered the recipient's email address book and sent itself to everyone on the list, jamming computer servers worldwide.

The unidentified 20-year old Dutchman is thought to go by the hacker nickname "On The Fly".

He has argued on a Dutch website that he carried out the cyber attack "just because I am a big fan of hers [Kournikova]. She deserves some attention, doesn't she?"

Bizarrely, he also claimed to have wanted to warn internet users about the risks of computer viruses. "I never wanted to harm the people who opened the attachment," he wrote. "But after all, it's their own fault they got infected."

Concerned about the impact his stunt was causing as it spread he told his parents in the northern Dutch town of Sneek what he had done and then turned himself over to the local police.

He could face a four-year jail sentence if the Dutch authorities decide to charge him with damaging computer software and property.

The police moved swiftly to confiscate all of his computer equipment for further investigation, but decided to release him on bail pending a decision on whether to charge him.

webTitle: Pleat: Graham turned down Dyer and Keane

fields.headline: Pleat: Graham turned down Dyer and Keane
fields.trailText: Tottenham manager George Graham turned down the chance to sign Kieron Dyer and Robbie Keane because he didn't think they were good enough to be first-team regulars, the High Court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Tottenham manager George Graham turned down the chance to sign Kieron Dyer and Robbie Keane because he didn't think they were good enough to be first-team regulars, the High Court heard yesterday.

Director of Football David Pleat told the Alan Sugar libel case that Dyer and Keane were recommended to Graham while they were still at Ipswich and Wolves respectively. But Graham decided against making any move.

"Our chief scout at the time came from Dyer's club Ipswich and liked him," Pleat told the court. "The name was put before the manager but he didn't move to make a bid. He felt if he was to proceed with Dyer he would not find a regular place in the team.

"I believed Robbie Keane was a top, top, top striker but the manager didn't want to make an offer. He didn't consider he wanted to purchase Keane," Pleat added.

"I thought he was one of few outstanding young players in Britain but the manager decided not to buy him because he wasn't certain he would be a regular first-team striker."

Dyer later joined Newcastle for £6.5m while Keane went to Coventry for the same fee before moving on to Internazionale for £12.

Pleat went on to reveal that Davor Suker was another big-name player who Graham decided against signing.

"Suker was offered to us," said Pleat. "The manager is not too keen on players from Eastern Europe, he feels they are probably more mercenary and less reliable than players from Western Europe and that British players are more reliable still than those from Western Europe.

"The next thing we knew Arsenal had taken the gamble on Suker."

Pleat's comments were greeted with astonishment by Mark Jacob, the spokesman for the Tottenham Action Group.

He said: "We find it frightening that the manager was offered the chance to sign three players of international repute yet rejected all of them.

"We have all seen Keane's value soar as he has moved from Coventry, to Inter Milan and then on to Leeds.

"Dyer is one of the hottest young properties in the English game and would certainly have been a major asset to the team, let alone the squad, and would now command a fee of more than £10m in today's transfer market.

"As for Suker, he is a proven international goalscorer and given Tottenham's current strike problems he would have been a useful acquisition, rather than having to loan players from a struggling Division One side, as has been the case."

Jacob is more optimistic that once new owners ENIC take the helm, Spurs will not miss out if such talent becomes available in the future.

He added: "We are well aware of the ambitions ENIC has for the club and therefore believe that they will be more sympathetic to the expectations of Spurs fans, which means actively pursuing the best players in the world."

webTitle: Caribbean severs link to privy council

fields.headline: Caribbean severs link to privy council
fields.trailText: Eleven island states in the West Indies yesterday formally ratified an agreement scrapping the privy council's role as a final court of appeal, severing a judicial link with Britain that had survived for 170 years.
fields.body:
Eleven island states in the West Indies yesterday formally ratified an agreement scrapping the privy council's role as a final court of appeal, severing a judicial link with Britain that had survived for 170 years.

The decision to establish a shared Caribbean court of justice - advocated as a means of establishing full legal independence for the region and throwing off one of the last vestiges of colonialism - is likely to speed up the rate of hangings. There are scores of prisoners on death row in the region.

There has been growing tension between Commonwealth states in the West Indies and the judicial committee of the privy council, which sits in London to hear appeals from West Indians facing execution.

Civil rights lawyers in Britain have succeeded in frustrating many death sentences passed in the Caribbean on the grounds that they were unsafe or that not all the legal challenges had been exhausted. Caribbean governments, faced with a rising tide of violence and drug trafficking, have been eager to prove they are enforcing the law by proceeding with executions.

The judicial committee of the privy council "has served the region well over the years", the prime minister of St Lucia, Kenny Anthony, said. But, he added: "The cycle of independence which began in 1962 _ cannot be considered to be complete until the determination of rights, duties, and interests of Caribbean litigants are pronounced on by a regional court."

The Caribbean summit, due to last three days, is being held in Bridgetown, the capital of Barbados.

Signatories to the agreement were Guyana, Barbados, Antigua and Barbuda, Belize, Dominica, Grenada, Jamaica, Trinidad and Tobago, St Lucia and St Kitts and Nevis. Suriname also signed on to use the new court of justice because it is a member of the Caribbean community trade bloc, though as a former Dutch colony it never sent cases to the privy council.

"We will spare no resource to ensure that the Caribbean court of justice is celebrated as an icon of Caribbean achievement and an inspiration of what we can do together and achieve," said the Barbados prime minister, Owen Arthur.

Before the court is established, at least three member countries have to ratify the agreement at their annual summit in July, and governments will have to deposit five years of dues in a special trust fund. It is unlikely to sit before early 2003. It is expected to be based in Trinidad.

Several governments need to amend their constitutions, and some will have to hold referendums to get the change approved.

Once convened, the court will hear everything from trade disputes to regular criminal and civil cases.

Human rights groups fear the new court will be a "hanging court", although the leaders say it is an issue of sovereignty. Amnesty International has expressed concern about "statements made by a number of political leaders in the region, which have appeared to link the supreme court with the expedited use of the death penalty".

Guyana, Barbados, Jamaica, and Trinidad and Tobago already have said they will ratify the court.

webTitle: In brief: Soderbergh torn between Erin and Traffic

fields.headline: Soderbergh torn between Erin and Traffic
fields.standfirst: Plus: Patrice Chereau defends Intimacy; Spike Lee attacks racism in the US; Richard Attenborough tribute at Bradford Film Festival; Edward Scissorhands to become stage musical
fields.trailText: Plus: Patrice Chereau defends Intimacy; Spike Lee attacks racism in the US; Richard Attenborough tribute at Bradford Film Festival; Edward Scissorhands to become stage musical
fields.body:
 Like the father of two gifted children, Steven Soderbergh is refusing to say which one of his two Oscar-nominated films - Erin Brockovich or Traffic - he prefers. Friends of the feted film director are saying that he will be keeping mum over his own individual favourite for fear of hurting his chances. Insiders worry, however, that he may already be a victim of his own success and that he may wind up splitting the vote and delivering the Oscar to one of the other nominees. The omens are ominous: Soderbergh is the first person to be nominated for two Best Director awards since Michael Curtiz in 1938 (nominated for both Four Daughters and Angels With Dirty Faces). In the event, Curtiz lost out to Frank Capra, who won for You Can't Take it With You. Filming Ocean's Eleven in Vegas yesterday, Soderbergh said he was stunned by his nominations: "I think if I didn't have the distraction of shooting a film I would have to be sedated."

 French director Patrice Chereau had his work cut out defending his controversial new film Intimacy at the Berlin Film Festival yesterday. A tale of everyday adultery, Intimacy features copious sex scenes and one extended 35 minute spell in which the stars Mark Rylance and Kerry Fox grapple naked on the floor of a seedy London flat. Speaking at a press conference, however, a tetchy Chereau was determined to play down the sex angle. "Just because 35 minutes is about intimacy it should not be reduced to a film about sex," he scolded reporters. "This film is not about sex. It is about love, about emotions. It is not like a porno film."

 More news from Berlin. In town to promote his new picture Bamboozled, Spike Lee was in typical firebrand form, pouring scorn on the notion that black actors were making big strides in the Hollywood film industry. On the contrary, said Lee, actors of colour were still marginalised and demeaned: "I can give you examples of films where there has been no progress made. Look at black characters in The Green Mile, The Legend of Bagger Vance, Family Man." Expanding his targets, Lee went on to attack last year's supposed election shenanigans in Florida. "Black people were stopped by the police in Tampa from voting," he said. "If someone wants to be delusional and say 'here we are in America in 2001, we've made so many great strides, everything is OK', go ahead and live in that dream world."

 The Bradford Film Festival, running from March 1-17, is to hold a major retrospective of the work of Sir Richard Attenborough. The festival will screen past Dickie works such as Oh! What a Lovely War, A Bridge Too Far, Gandhi and Cry Freedom and the man himself will take to the stage for an interview on March 7, following a screening of his acclaimed film Shadowlands.

 Tim Burton's 1990 fairytale Edward Scissorhands looks set for a new lease of life in the form of a London stage musical. Choreographer Matthew Bourne is hoping to produce the musical - based on the movie starring Johnny Depp, Winona Ryder and Vincent Price - at the Old Vic in March next year. The cast has yet to be put in place, though the way her career has been going of late original star Ryder may well have some windows in her schedule.

webTitle: Obituary: Kristina Söderbaum, Swedish actress who became a cinema star in Nazi Germany

fields.headline: Kristina Söderbaum
fields.standfirst: Swedish actress who became a cinema star in Nazi Germany
fields.trailText: The extravagantly blonde Kristina Söderbaum, who has died aged 88, starred in 10 box-office hits in Nazi Germany directed by her husband Veit Harlan. She was the pin-up of the Wehrmacht, admired by Franco and parodied as the Lorelei.
fields.body:
The extravagantly blonde Kristina Söderbaum, who has died aged 88, starred in 10 box-office hits in Nazi Germany directed by her husband Veit Harlan. She was the pin-up of the Wehrmacht, admired by Franco and parodied as the Lorelei. She also achieved a certain distinction as one of the few film actresses of the Third Reich who did not at some time enjoy a liaison with Josef Goebbels - a circumstance dictated as much by Veit Harlan's extreme possessiveness as by the propaganda minister's private predilection for dark-eyed brunettes. She was later tried by the Allies for war crimes.

Born in Sweden, the daughter of a chemistry professor who sat on the Nobel Prize committee, she initially studied art, but after the death of her parents, who opposed her theatrical ambitions, she went to Berlin to train for the stage under Rudolph Klein-Rogge. A minor part in the film comedy Onkel Brasig (1937) led to her discovery by Veit Harlan, an innovative and vigorous director already much favoured by Goebbels. Harlan gave her the lead in the dark and moody Jugend (1937), a sentimental drama of doomed love, and made her his third wife. Thereafter, until 1945, Söderbaum appeared exclusively in her husband's productions.

Diminutive, but amply blessed with rococo curves, cascading golden hair, violet eyes and a china-doll complexion, Kristina Söderbaum had the slightly comical look (at least in stills) of a porcine Alice Faye. On screen, glowing in Agfa colour (in use from 1941), she was the embodiment of florid Aryan girlhood, bursting with energy, spirit and gefühl .

A highly popular star, Söderbaum appealed to German audiences who could enjoy the drama of her regular defloration and death, comforted by the knowledge that this was, after all, a neutral Swedish actress - Goebbels' policy was to cast women from outside the Fatherland (and on at least one occasion from the inmates of the concentration camps) in the parts of wronged, erring or otherwise tainted women. Söderbaum drowned so frequently on film that she earned the soubriquet of Reichswasserleiche (the National Drowned Corpse).

Though most of her later films were expositions of Nazi dogma, a few played as straight romantic melodramas: Verwehte Spüren (1938) was later reworked as the Dirk Bogarde vehicle So Long At The Fair; Die Reise Nach Tilsit (also 1938) was an inferior remake of FW Murnau's Sunrise. Its premiere was notable for the abrupt exit of Magda Goebbels, who fancied she saw in the script allusions to her husband's then current affair with the Czech actress Lida Baarova. Titillated audiences were further aroused by glimpses (albeit brief and decorous) of a nude Kristina beneath a slipping mink coat in her next vehicle, Die Unsterbliche Herz (1939).

After the invasion of Poland, Goebbels commissioned Jud Süss (1940), a repulsive travesty of the sentimental Feuchtwanger novel already filmed in England in 1934. Harlan, with hideous deftness, neatly inverted the plot showing an 18th century court infiltrated and perverted by a villainous coterie of Jews who exhibit every vice and loathsome habit.

One of the few openly and insistently anti-semitic films of the period, presenting inconceivably gross racist concepts, Jud Süss was not only a huge box-office success throughout occupied Europe (especially in France), but was also used as an active instrument of the Holocaust, customarily shown in cities before Jewish deportations. After the war, Harlan and Söderbaum (once again raped and drowned in the film) pleaded, successfully, that they had worked on the film under duress.

From 1943 the Harlans were engaged in making the film Kolberg, Goebbels' obsessive riposte to Gone With The Wind (the latter having made him literally ill with envy). This massive historical epic ground to its conclusion during the final months of the war, consuming apparently unlimited resources. Two hundred thousand troops were drafted from the eastern front to appear as extras in battle scenes later cut as detrimental to civilian morale. The Third Reich had collapsed before the film could be generally released, though as a final propaganda stunt prints were parachuted into besieged cities.

After the war, Söderbaum, her husband and their two sons were apprehended by the Allies at Hamburg as they attempted to reach Sweden. Söderbaum received a five-year ban on working, while Veit Harlan was tried for complicity in war crimes. After a sensational year-long trial he was acquitted. Making the somewhat unlikely claim that she had declined offers of film work from around the world, Söderbaum then chose to tour provincial Germany in a play written pseudonymously by her husband. The deception was unsuccessful: her appearance provoked hate mail, demonstrations and death threats from former fans.

Like many of her contemporaries, Söderbaum continued to appear - an anachronistic if still youthful curiosity - in a few inferior German films during the 1950s. Veit Harlan refused to hear of his wife abandoning the screen, but following his death in 1964 she began a second and modestly successful career as a photographer. Latterly, she lived and worked in Munich.

In interviews, Söderbaum appeared maternal, tranquil and benign, if none too bright. She displayed little awareness of the past and the rather grotesque nature of her career; neither did she react with the agitated defensiveness of some of her contemporaries (one thinks, for example, of Zarah Leander - another Swede - and the film-maker Leni Riefenstahl).

Söderbaum converted to Roman Catholicism in the early 1960s. She is survived by two sons.

webTitle: Driver on phone who killed gets 5 years

fields.headline: Driver on phone who killed gets 5 years
fields.trailText: A lorry driver who hit and killed a pedestrian in a layby while sending a text message on his mobile phone to his girlfriend was jailed for five years yesterday.
fields.body:
A lorry driver who hit and killed a pedestrian in a layby while sending a text message on his mobile phone to his girlfriend was jailed for five years yesterday.

Sentencing Paul Browning, Judge Daniel Worsley at Southend crown court told him it was hard to imagine a more blatant act of cold-blooded disregard for safety on the road.

Paul Hammond, 24, from Hockley, Essex, died when the heavy goods vehicle hit him while he was talking to his mother who was in her car in a layby.

Browning, of Kenley, Surrey, had admitted causing death by dangerous driving. He had claimed the accident happened because he was distracted by paperwork fluttering around in the cab of his lorry.

Browning, 36, had told the court that he composed the message to his girlfriend, now his wife, while he was in stationary traffic and had sent it by mistake after the accident when he returned to the lorry to collect his mobile phone.

But Judge Worsley said this was "wholly unbelievable."

He said: "I am convinced that he was composing the material part of it as he was approaching the layby."

The judge also rejected Browning's claim that he had been distracted by the paperwork.

The text message read: "Oh yes! A real scorcher! Well, just leaving Benfleet 4 West Thurrock job no 7 of 11. Shit! call you back."

The judge agreed with the prosecution that the final sentence of the message was composed by Browning after the crash. Judge Worsley said he then "deliberately" sent the message.

Paul Hammond had parked his BMW car behind his mother's in the layby on the A13, near Pitsea, Essex, last June. They had arranged to meet up because he had forgotten his glasses.

Judge Worsley said: "In the seconds before the collision, I find that he was keying in a text message with his eyes on that and his concentration on that and off the road."

The judge said composing a text message to his girlfriend was "wicked."

Browning, whose wife is expecting the couple's baby in April was a "decent family man", who was a good and reliable driver, said the judge.

The court heard that Browning did not know he had hit a person until he saw Mr Hammond's body on the road.

His lorry had veered toward the layby scraping the side of Mr Hammond's BMW and his mother's car.

Judge Worsley said: "Text messages are now very cheap and in use by huge numbers and ... a stern deterrent sentence is necessary."

Speaking outside the court after the sentencing, Mr Hammond's father, Alan, said: "A lesson has been learnt that mobile phones can be lethal weapons. People who use mobile phones should not in anyway use them while driving."

Roger Vincent, spokesman for the Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents (Rospa), said this was the 16th road death linked with mobile phones in recent years and he called for a blanket ban on using them while driving.

"We fear this case could just be the tip of the iceberg and that many more accidents could be being caused by people sending or trying to read text messages on the move.

"This tragic case underlines the need for the introduction of a specific offence to ban the use of mobile phones while driving."

Mr Hammond's death is believed to the first involving a driver sending a mobile phone text message while behind the wheel, said Mr Vincent.

Policeman Darren Riley, 25, from Somerset, died in May last year when he lost control of his car - the inquest into his death was told that he might have been trying to read a text message while driving.

Mr Vincent said: "We believe that there have been at least 15 road deaths in recent years where mobile phones have been implicated.

"This reinforces Rospa's argument for a specific offence to ban the use of mobile phones while driving."
Press Association

fields.headline: Mugabe's law
fields.standfirst: The situation in Zimbabwe isn't improving, reports Simon Tisdall, and the president's domineering rule shows no signs of waning yet
fields.trailText: The situation in Zimbabwe isn't improving, reports Simon Tisdall, and the president's domineering rule shows no signs of waning yet.
fields.body:
The continuing, escalating depredations and abuses for which Zimbabwe's president Robert Mugabe is held primarily responsible pose a challenge to the "international community" that it has so far failed miserably to meet.

Some people think Mr Mugabe is mad and therefore beyond the reach of reasoned argument. Others say he is merely old and angry - he will be 77 next week. Whatever the cause of his behaviour, Zimbabwe's business and farming community and many former supporters are convinced he is ruining the country.

The United Nations and the Commonwealth have been sharply critical of his conduct of elections. Independent observers fret about human rights abuses. Britain, the former colonial power, got into a futile shouting match with the president last year.

His neighbours, led by South Africa's Thabo Mbeki, have tried a gentler, comradely approach, concerned above all at Zimbabwe's economic implosion and spiralling debts. Even Nelson Mandela has lent his weight to efforts to halt the central African war, centred on Congo, in which Zimbabwean troops are deeply embroiled.

But all apparently has been to no avail. Mr Mugabe's objectionable activities continue unchecked, his latest targets being the country's independent judiciary and free press which he seeks to neuter and muzzle. Members and supporters of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change that made significant gains in last summer's general election are also singled out for intimidation and worse by thuggish elements linked to the ruling Zanu-PF.

Mr Mugabe pays no heed, takes no notice as the storm rages around his head. His critics and accusers are dismissed as traitors, stooges and, of course, racists. In power for nearly 21 years, he seems to see himself straddling a founding father's podium, looking down with disdain on the political pygmies at his feet.

Perhaps he thinks he is indispensable. Perhaps he has come to think of power as a right, not a responsibility. There is no doubt that his achievements in the early post-Rhodesian years were substantial. Equally, there can be little doubt now that he is Zimbabwe's biggest single problem.

But will he go? He will not. He clearly intends to run again in the presidential poll due about one year from now. And in the meantime he will do all he can, by fair means and foul, to ensure the election goes his way. Zanu-PF fiddled the last poll. There is no reason to believe the next one will not be fiddled, too.

Mr Mugabe's rule is not exactly a tyranny, not yet at least. But it is an autocracy with very unpleasant tendencies. So what, if anything, is to be done? If, by common consent, a man is driving his country down the drain, he and his self-serving clique of henchmen must surely be stopped?

But how? The options are as familiar as they are uninspiring. The first is persuasion and dialogue. This has been tried and it has signally failed. The second is some form of international ostracism or sanctions. Some such curbs are already in place. The IMF and World Bank, for example, have frozen aid over the illegal land seizures of the past year. Britain has withheld bilateral assistance. But this has not modified Mr Mugabe's behaviour one whit.

Tougher measures could be applied, such as pressure on assets and bank accounts held abroad, restrictions on foreign visas for government members, reduction or suspension of diplomatic contacts, and trade and arms embargoes.

But history suggests such sanctions would hurt ordinary Zimbabweans most, would not be universally enforced or observed, and would serve to entrench the regime. Such treatment would also help Mr Mugabe portray himself in his favourite role as a champion of the developing world's struggle against the wealthy North, a liberation leader defying the capitalist-colonialists.

Direct outside intervention in Zimbabwe is not an option for western countries or its regional neighbours. There is no political will and the military means are lacking. However egregious Mr Mugabe's treatment of his own people, and however damaging the regional economic and social impact, other African leaders would not support his forcible overthrow. Apart from anything else, they would object to the precedent such action would set.

Within Zimbabwe itself, the opposition is strong - but not strong enough to oust him. The MDC has so far eschewed a mass campaign of civil disobedience. They fear, with justification, that intensified, violent repression would be the result - and the possible imposition of a state of emergency and suspension of parliament. They would prefer, rightly, to defeat him at the polls. But the likelihood of a free and fair election next year is remote.

People's power, as seen recently in Serbia and the Philippines, only works if the armed forces and police are supportive - or at least, are not prepared to oppose unarmed protesters. But the security forces, backed by vigilantes, are firmly in Mr Mugabe's pocket at present. That might change. But nobody should welcome the prospect of yet another African military coup. The continent has suffered too many in recent years and they rarely make things better.

A sudden, unstoppable and widespread deterioration in living conditions could bring matters to a head. But in the absence of that sort of dramatic collapse, there seems to be little the Zimbabweans and others can do now to stop the rot.

The sad fact is that Mr Mugabe knows all this very well as he calculates and plots his way towards another presidential term. Even sadder is the consequential, certain prospect of greater suffering before Zimbabwe finally gets a chance to start afresh.

So next time a politician is heard urging action by the "international community", think of the people of Zimbabwe. Despite all the fashionable talk about the "internationalist century" and the interconnected "global village', the ability of outsiders effectively to influence or topple a determined and ruthless national leader remains very limited indeed. Just look at Bob.

fields.headline: Clampdown on e-marketing loopholes in tobacco bill
fields.trailText:
11.30am: The government has moved to close potential internet marketing loopholes in its anti-tobacco bill, writes Daniel Rogers.
Jan 24: Government urged to stop 'invisible' marketing of cigarettes
fields.body:
The government has moved to close potential loopholes in its anti-tobacco legislation created by internet marketing techniques.

Under pressure from MPs and the anti-tobacco lobby, public health minister Yvette Cooper has added new clauses to the tobacco advertising and promotion bill to prevent tobacco firms and advertising agencies exploiting "developments in technology relating to publishing or distributing by electronic means".

There is concern that tobacco advertisers will use email marketing techniques - often called viral marketing - to promote cigarette brands.

Emails containing adverts for tobacco that are sent in the course of business will be outlawed, but it is believed that advertising on a website where tobacco products are offered for sale would not be an offence.

The government is trying to keep its powers open-ended to allow for future technological developments in marketing.

Anti-smoking pressure group ASH backs the government's efforts but recognises the inherent problems in regulating the internet.

"The government is making a good stab at clamping down in this area," said Amanda Sandford, research manager at ASH.

fields.headline: What the Israeli papers say
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Israeli papers are understandably obsessed with yesterday's horrific bus massacre at Holon, and its aftermath.
fields.body:
The Israeli papers are understandably obsessed with yesterday's horrific bus massacre at Holon, and its aftermath.

The Jerusalem Post, very predictably, dismisses the US view that Israel shares some responsibility for the latest surge in violence.

Its leader is, by the paper's normal standards, quite restrained. It only uses the word 'terror' and its derivatives eight times.

But the message is clear: "It is not clear why the Bush administration would continue the failed Clinton policy of moral equivalence between terrorism and the fight against it.

"The policy of willful moral obtuseness was considered necessary by the Clinton team when the US was hip-deep in brokering an Israeli-Palestinian final-status agreement.

"Now that the Palestinians have chosen to blow up the negotiating table, there is no possible rationale for rewarding terrorism by placing it on par with self-defence.

"President George Bush, while condemning the bus attack, missed an opportunity to do himself and the region a tremendous favour by some plain speaking: Terrorism must be fought, and the US stands behind Israel in fighting terrorism.

"Such a simple statement would send a powerful signal: The US will no longer blame Israel for defending itself, it will blame the Palestinians for scuttling peace."

Ze'ev Schiff, a veteran analyst of politico-military affairs, writes in the Tel Aviv daily Ha'aretz that Israeli army strategists believe the Palestinians want to provoke a wider regional confrontation.

"The defence establishment does not, however, believe that the rest of the Arab world wants to be drawn into a wide-scale confrontation.

"Still the IDF (Israeli Defence Forces) is not discounting this possibility. Many logistical preparations are thus being carried out by the army. The various fronts have been given permission to withdraw the funds necessary to revamp their artillery, even though the finance ministry has yet to make good on its pledge to the IDF."

In its breaking news section, Ha'aretz reports a chilling warning by Danny Yatom, a top adviser to outgoing prime minister Ehud Barak.

"We cannot continue to allow a situation where, as a result of the Palestinian authority's lack of desire to fight terror and cooperate with us in the war against terror, we continue to suffer terrorist attacks "

"If the Palestinian authority doesn't straighten itself out and begin to do these things," added Yatom, "we will need to take steps that could very badly hurt the Palestinian authority itself, to the point of bringing about its collapse.

"Would this improve the Palestinians' lot? Under no circumstances. Would this bring about quiet? Also probably not. But if we are backed into a corner and must act, we will."
