webTitle: World Cup rights battle hots up

fields.headline: World Cup rights battle hots up
fields.trailText:
10.45am: Kirch is taking the battle to auction off World Cup broadcasting rights to the European court. By Dan Milmo.
Feb 12: World Cup rights could go to pay-TV
fields.body:
German media company Kirch is taking the battle to auction off World Cup broadcasting rights to the European court of justice.

Kirch is furious EU commissioners have upheld the UK government's argument that all the matches in the 2002 and 2006 tournaments must be made available to free-to-air broadcasters.

"Kirch has filed a complaint to the European court of justice claiming that the European commission has acted illegally. It is important the company makes a legal complaint about this," said a source close to Kirch.

The pay-TV group is trying to bypass the 1996 UK Broadcasting Act, which states that the BBC or ITV must be allowed to show the entire tournament since it is on a list of sporting events of national importance.

In a document submitted to the European court earlier this week, Kirch claimed the commission only brought the UK list of protected events into EU legislation in May last year.

Because Kirch bought the rights to the World Cup in September 1996, it claims the blocking of an auction is "retroactive" and therefore illegal.

"The commission approved the UK list, knowing that our deal was made in 1996. We think it is a violation of our property rights and a restriction of free trade," added the source.

If Kirch gets its way, the BBC and ITV will almost certainly lose out in an auction to BSkyB or another pay-TV bidder, as they are only willing to pay £20m for the rights and not the £180m sought by Kirch.

A united front comprising the Independent Television Commission and the Department for Culture, Media and Sport as well as ITV and the BBC, has asserted that the protection of World Cup rights was first enshrined in UK legislation in 1985.

One UK broadcasting source close to the stalled negotiations between the BBC, ITV and Kirch criticised the German company's behaviour.

"The essence of the legislation is that there should be fair and reasonable negotiations," said the source.

"That does not seem to be the case with Kirch. They are trying to hold the country to ransom.

"There is no way round the listed events legislation - Kirch have absolutely no chance," the source added.

"They have paid an enormous amount for the rights and they are trying to claw it back somehow."

In a further twist to the dispute, a DCMS spokesman admitted that a House of Lords decision in March could overrule the 1996 Broadcasting Act.

The ITC is appealing against a court of appeal ruling that said UK-based broadcaster TVDanmark could charge viewers to watch its live coverage of the Danish national team's World Cup qualifiers.

The decision was made despite the fact that Danish national law protects the matches from being shown exclusively on pay-TV.

"There is a possibility that it could cause problems, but we will have to wait for the ruling," said the DCMS spokesman.

Kirch is hoping that the TVDanmark case can be used as a precedent for allowing the World Cup rights auction, as it attempts to recoup the £670m it paid for the rights.

fields.headline: Broadcast
fields.standfirst: Publication date: February 16
fields.trailText: February 16: Channel 5 is making no effort to expand its coverage, forcing millions of viewers to wait up to 10 years to receive the station via multichannel platforms.
fields.body:
Channel 5 has admitted it is making no effort to expand its coverage, forcing millions of viewers to wait up to 10 years to receive the station via multichannel platforms.

Darren Bender, Channel 4 commissioning editor, night-time, has resigned but is discussing a new role within the channel's 4Later slot.

Factual independent Cafe Productions has been saved from closure, having been acquired by Canadian company Alliance Atlantis.

BBC Choice controller Stuart Murphy has earmarked a £15m war chest - more than a quarter of the channel's proposed £57m budget - to turn forthcoming BBC3 into the home of "funky" new drama.

The government has plans to release a digital spectrum - equivalent to more than half the capacity of ONdigital - according to the Independent Television Commission.

The Independent Television Commission has issued guidelines on interactive services to ensure commercial opportunities arising from digital technology do not confuse viewers.

webTitle: Ralph Lauren and Donna Karan's equestrian collections

fields.headline: Thoroughbreds hit town
fields.standfirst:
Ralph Lauren and Donna Karan gallop along

Special report: London Fashion Week 2001
fields.trailText: Ralph Lauren, king of sleek uptown dressing, dubbed his look for next winter "thoroughbred dressing", as Donna Karan embraced "equestrian gallantry" in her DKNY diffusion line. Whatever you wish to call it, horsey dressing is back.
fields.body:
Two of New York fashion's biggest rivals are singing from the same song sheet, for one season at least. Ralph Lauren, king of sleek uptown dressing, dubbed his look for next winter "thoroughbred dressing", as Donna Karan embraced "equestrian gallantry" in her DKNY diffusion line. Whatever you wish to call it, horsey dressing is back.

At Ralph Lauren, pony club chic meant white jodhpurs worn with polonecks, high-buttoned jackets and leather boots buckled at the knee. Luxury fabrics - the softest chocolate leather and suede, finest ivory cashmere and richest herringbone tweed - suggested this was not a look for hacking through muddy fields. No matter, the closest the Lauren customer gets to a muddy field is likely to be the view of Central Park from her penthouse apartment.

But the riding theme was an astute choice from Lauren - tight jodhpurs and shiny boots ooze the upmarket sex appeal to which his devotees aspire - and this was an elegant and assured collection. As well as the equestrian pieces, there were beautiful coats and suits in a cream and chocolate reworking of the windowpane check that Lauren showed for summer 2001. For evening, the tuxedo-inspired plunge-neck dresses and evening suits in black, satin-edged crepe were impeccably chic.

At DKNY, equestrian dressing was developed into a Jekyll and Hyde collection. The English rider theme relied on cosy cable knits, sleek blazers, lace blouses and buckled suede coats in caramel, cream and jade, while the bareback Lady Godiva concept was for a wilder ride - Gladiator-influenced shearling collars, bronze sequin vests and distressed, layered chiffon skirts.

Across town, a different kind of show was staged by the hip label Imitation of Christ. While Lauren and Karan are household names and big-league players, Imitation of Christ are designers of edgy, one-off pieces. They sell to the select few who have serious money to spend on seriously offbeat fashion. The label, whose creative director is the actress Chloe Sevigny, came to prominence last season with a presentation in a funeral parlour, which, combined with their name, attracted accusations of blasphemy.

True to their quirky image, this was a catwalk show with no catwalk. Instead, the audience, having been pressed for a charity donation of $150 at the door, watched a video of the models, posing for cameras, on a red carpet. The technique got the point across - that the premiere red carpet is the new catwalk, and that celebrities are the new models - but the hand-held filming made it difficult to see the clothes properly.

The few outfits clearly visible were vintage-inspired dresses in bright satins bearing angelic lace sleeves.

After the fashion show, the models filed into the cinema and took their front-row seats for a short film, made by the Imitation of Christ collective. It featured a star-studded cast that included Wes Craven, Reese Witherspoon, Patricia Arquette and Paul Sorvino.

fields.headline: Oftel leans on BT over unmetered access
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Oftel has stepped up the pressure on BT to loosen its grip on the unmetered internet access market, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Oftel has stepped up the pressure on BT to loosen its vice-like grip on the unmetered internet access market.

BT, which supplies 80% of British homes with the phone lines that deliver internet access, has already launched an unmetered wholesale product, Friaco - flat rate internet access call origination.

But now regulators says BT must go one step further and open up the whole of its network to rival operators.

The upgrade to Friaco is being billed as St Friaco, the patron saint of unmetered access.

Friaco allowed operators to pay flat-rate fees for the line between the home and BT local exchange, but not regional exchanges.

St Friaco extends this flat-rate charge from local to regional exchanges in the BT network.

"Oftel has taken a series of actions to enable other operators to compete effectively with BT to supply unmetered internet access to consumers," said David Edmonds, director general of Oftel.

"Today's decision should ensure that UK consumers continue to have some of the widest choice and lowest prices for internet access in Europe."

With St Friaco, internet calls can be transferred over BT lines to another operator's telephone network at regional exchanges, thus paving the way for the likes of Energis, Kingston and Colt to offer consumers their own cut-price unmetered services.

The new rates will be offered from February 26.

Increasing the range of wholesale products available to operators will boost competition in the unmetered access space and lead to cheaper, more versatile packages.

Any problems encountered by BT in providing the network capacity to rivals must be ironed out by February 2003.

Last May, Oftel forced BT to open up its local exchanges to rival unmetered operators for a flat-rate tariff.

fields.headline: El Salvador's unlucky thirteenth
fields.standfirst: A report on the country's second earthquake in a month
fields.trailText: Salvadoreans will no doubt look at the number 13 as some kind of curse as they pick themselves up from a second earthquake, just one month after the first. Both happened on the 13th of the month.
fields.body:
Salvadoreans will no doubt look at the number 13 as some kind of curse as they pick themselves up from a second earthquake, just one month after the first. Both happened on the 13th of the month.

Frequent aftershocks had become routine since the first quake struck last month, so when the ground began to shake at 8.30 on Tuesday morning, people believed it was yet another brief sideshow to their difficult life of recovery and rehabilitation.

But after Tuesday's 6.1 tremor, it was immediately clear to everyone that felt it that this was not so much an aftershock as another earthquake.

Meetings at Oxfam's offices in San Salvador came to an abrupt halt as the roof, floors and cables started to shake. Staff ran out into the street along with residents of neighbouring buildings - this now being the spontaneous reaction to the first indication of any tremor.

All too soon, the tell-tale signs of a serious earthquake were evident. Traffic lights were out, electricity down and phones were knocked out. Some cellphones still worked and these were soon buzzing with news and updates on what was happening.

Within a short time, some of the key facts emerged. Three provinces, southeast of the capital, San Salvador, had been badly affected - Cuscatlan, La Paz and San Vicente, the latter two for the second time.

Again, it's the hilly region which has borne the brunt of the damage but in a smaller, more concentrated area than before. The destruction is greater because the epicentre was on land.

This time seven towns were damaged, four of them - Candalaria, San Pedro Nonualco, Santa Maria Ostuma and Santa Cruz Analquito - all over again. The casualty figures are still climbing, but more than 230 people have died, nearly 1,700 people have been injured and 2,400 homes destroyed.

While Oxfam's existing emergency work - the installation of water tanks and support for local NGOs distributing shelter, food and blankets - is intact, the quake has ruined plans that were being drawn up for relief work in the coming weeks.

The mayor of San Emidio was in Oxfam's offices on Monday working out the next consignment of emergency food for 250 people. Less than 24 hours later, his priorities had totally changed. Instead, rescue teams were needed. New places are now on the emergency map and those that were partially damaged are now flattened.

The silver lining, if there is such a thing in the aftermath of an earthquake, was the speed and effectiveness with which the government deployed helicopters to send in rescue teams and ferry the injured to hospital.

Everyone - including government officials, military personnel and aid workers - was sadly well rehearsed in the procedures needed to deal with this type of emergency.

So, too, was Oxfam, whose water and health workers were on site soon after the earthquake. By the afternoon they'd identified key places to start providing emergency water supplies. Water is a vital ingredient to saving and maintaining lives in the disruption that follows an earthquake.

Following up on water, Oxfam and its partner organisations are now handing out thousands of family hygiene kits, buckets and plastic sheeting to people who've lost their homes and belongings.

Some families believed themselves lucky to have escaped the effects of the first earthquake, only to find their lives wrecked after all.

Across El Salvador teams have been hard at work for the past month digging at rubble, restoring public services and clearing main roads. Ordinary people have been clearing piles of timbers that were once their homes, repairing roofs and removing mounds of concrete and bricks. Schools had reopened.

It's cruel to see their efforts and progress now dealt such a severe blow. The fear felt in many parts after January's earthquake has returned in greater measure, and for good reason.

webTitle: GMC looks to make changes as public complaints grow

fields.headline: GMC looks to make changes as public complaints grow
fields.trailText: Complaints against doctors rose by an unprecedented 50% last year, according to the General Medical Council.
fields.body:
The GMC will meet today to debate radical changes aimed at restoring public confidence in the profession following the conviction of serial killer Harold Shipman, inquiries into Alder Hey and Bristol hospitals and the striking off of gynaecologist Richard Neale. The measures include allowing more lay people to be involved in disciplinary hearings and the separation of its prosecution and judgment functions.

A total of 4,470 complaints were made last year, compared with about 3,000 in 1999. A GMC spokesman said the rise in complaints could be due to the body's higher profile: "Because we dealt with several big cases last year, more members of the public know about us and take grievances to us." Growing numbers of GPs are also now ready to blow the whistle on incompetent colleagues. Medical defence organisations report calls at a rate of one a week or more from doctors worried about the behaviour of partners in their practices, ranging from drink and drug problems to ill-health and failure to act in the interests of their patients. Young GPs in particular appear ready to risk the wrath of their older colleagues and their immediate future by reporting their concerns. The increase in informing on colleagues coincides with a huge rise in complaints about all doctors' behaviour to the GMC.

The trends were reported coincidentally as the council's president, Sir Donald Irvine, stepped up his campaign for a change in NHS culture, saying the public believed many doctors put their interests before those of their patients. The rise in whistleblowing was revealed by the Medical Protection Society, one of two main organisations indemnifying doctors which also offer advice to members.

Sherry Williams, its head of medical services, said: "Pre-Shipman we were getting perhaps a few calls each year, now we are receiving a few each month. Typically, the concerned caller is a young GP, new to a practice, who is complaining about older partners." She added: "The focus of the medical profession is so heavily on criticism of a small number of doctors who have stepped over the mark that all doctors have become more aware that to turn a blind eye is not on." Dr Williams said GPs could find complaining about colleagues more difficult than hospital doctors because there may be only one or two others in the practice, whereas a hospital offered distance, anonymity and a management structure to deal with problems.

The Medical Defence Union said: "The question of whistleblowing is no longer an optional extra in the way it once was." The trends were reported as the government announced an extra £30m a year for three years from April to help fund its promise that all patients would be able to see a GP within 48 hours by 2004. At present, about half of all patients have to wait longer. The health secretary, Alan Milburn, said the money could also help fund a wider range of treatments by GPs and other primary care staff. He hoped six in 10 patients would see GPs within 48 hours by March next year. Doctors' organisations said big increases, of up to 10,300 new GPs, were needed as well as extra training so they could carry out more minor operations.

fields.headline: Sweet success
fields.standfirst: She made her name playing tragic women. Now she stands to win an Oscar for her role as a free-spirited confectioner.  Danny Leigh meets Juliette Binoche
fields.trailText: She made her name playing tragic women. Now she stands to win an Oscar for her role as a free-spirited confectioner. Danny Leigh meets Juliette Binoche
fields.body:
I've had firmer handshakes. But not many. And then you remember that the fearsome grip whitening your knuckles belongs to the leading European actress of her generation: Juliette Binoche, famous for her porcelain beauty and elegant melancholy, evidently blessed with the fists of a trucker.

Big, hearty smile. Exchange of how-are-yous. I say fine. She smirks. "Not too bad," comes the reply, before she looks away, puzzled, like it's the first time she's thought about it. Big, hearty laugh. "Hmm. I guess I'm fine too."

If the handshake is jarring, the laugh is more so: loud, open-mouthed and utterly at odds with her own iconography. It's the kind of raucous guffaw she delivers repeatedly in Lasse Hallstrom's Chocolat, in which she plays a free-spirited confectioner bringing candies and single-parenthood to an uptight post-war French village.

Two days ago Binoche received an Oscar nomination for her troubles (her second; she won best supporting actress for The English Patient in 1997). When asked what she thought of her chances, she allowed herself a "We'll see"; hours later, the news wires were brimming with hastily posed pictures of her in celebration, pretending to devour a vast bar of chocolate.

Which is not quite what you expect from Juliette Binoche. Neither is the feelgood warmth of Chocolat. "You think I'm cold?" she asks. I gabble that that wasn't what I meant. Just that there has been a constant undercurrent of tragedy to the widows, mistresses and blinded artists that have filled her career since her early-80s breakthrough in Godard's Hail Mary.

"Oh, tragedy," she says airily. "Well, yes. But cold doesn't go with tragedy. And anyway, I think the characters I've played have been survivors of tragedy. So, really, they were kind of positive in their way."

I ask if the move was deliberate, whether the frothiness of her latest project was a conscious attempt to sidestep her image. While I am talking, she nods, as if indulging a harmless but slow-witted child. "On this movie?" she says eventually. "No. That's not what I wanted at all. But to express something like this story, in which there is a light - yes, I wanted that. In life, you have to demand. It clarifies your will. So, for me, more than trying to be different this way, or that way, it's about telling a story I feel connected to, as a human being and an actor."

Another smile, more fixed this time, then a pregnant pause, and a long, impassive gaze into the middle distance. That's more like it - Juliette Binoche, gazing impassively into the middle distance.

The soulful looks and enigmatic silences come as no surprise. After all, despite her protestations, that's what she does best, a half-stunned gravity in keeping with her status as an arthouse heroine with a vocal distaste for Hollywood. So you watch her gazing round the room and assume, as so many have assumed, that she must be thinking of pain, and loss, and the darker corners of philosophy. Until she laughs her silly-me laugh, and you know she was just thinking about lunch, or picking up her laundry.

Then she starts talking and you realise you were right the first time. She explains her pain and loss with the straight-faced passion of someone for whom everything else is chit-chat.

I mention that she laughs more in Chocolat than in her previous body of work combined. "Yes, but, I mean... life is tragic. And sometimes you need the distance of laughter, because you don't know why we live, or why we die, or why we're called human beings when we act like animals. So yes, I like to put those questions inside people." She reels through a litany of her characters, pointing out how and why they may be troubled, but never tragic. Or cold.

"When I was younger," she says, "I was always the optimist. But the more I go through life, the more I think pessimism is truly realistic. It's more fun, too, because if you are a pessimist you are shocked about the good things." Cue laugh.

I ask what stemmed her optimism. "Well, being an optimist was like a disguise. I was using it to get through life, you know? And there is a heaviness with me. It's like when you asked me if I was well. To be truthful, I'm exhausted. But at the same time there is a lightness to my exhaustion, because I chose to be here, and I'm happy if this film makes people happy."

She segues into an anecdote about a woman with one lung who taught her Gregorian chants, and a lengthy metaphor describing how "when you break your knee, you enjoy walking differently". Triumph in adversity, I say hopefully. She nods again, as if the slow-witted child has finally caught up. "Yes. When we learn that tragedy is a treasure in disguise, then we begin to understand life. It's like when I see a lot of comic films, I feel depressed. Like this is so shallow, and such... nonsense. To me, saying, 'This is tragedy and this is comedy,' putting everything in its box, it doesn't make sense."

But if she doesn't see the world like that, the directors she has worked with usually have, habitually dispatching her into doomed affairs and bereavements. She may be laughing now, but in the past, the self-conscious auteurs she gravitates towards have forbidden her from doing so, in case it ruins their angst-ridden tableaux.

How does it feel, being ordered not to smile? "Well, sometimes I felt like a horse." She pulls at the corners of her mouth, as if wearing a bit. "Like, I promise I won't gallop. But the relationship between directors and actors is full of competition. And sometimes directors fall under the power of an actress."

With Binoche they certainly have. Other than tragedy, the recurring motif in her films is their devotion to her face; huge chunks of screen time are given over to her static, masklike features. And the ardour isn't restricted to male film-makers: last week, Gwyneth Paltrow was reported to have signed up for an adaptation of Jeanette Winterson's The Passion on the condition that Binoche play her lover.

"Are you only interested in my face?" she asks. I can't tell if she's joking. No, I say, but I've read three articles about her in the last two days, all of which have remarked that the best medium for her undoubted beauty may not be movies, but photographs. "Someone said that? Hmm... maybe it's true then. But I think what's important is behind the face. Anyway, I don't think I have a particularly beautiful face."

Her features, it would seem, fall into the category of what Binoche regards as trivia. So we move on to ageing instead and - at 36 and playing mothers as routine - she becomes more animated. "I know it's a big issue," she says, "but truly, for me it's not. I think 20 is a beautiful age, but it's also very difficult. Thirty was better. Forty, who knows? It will be strange for me as an actress, but there are different ways to be seductive.

"It's like, sometimes there is something between you and yourself - the ego, right? And the person with the ego inside you says, 'Oh, I'm angry with this' or 'Oh, I'm jealous of that'. And you have to be tolerant of that little person, and say to them, 'Ssh. It's OK to think that, but you must know that you're wrong.' " I'm already anticipating our farewell handshake when she lets out another of her laughs. "Like a teacher. You know?"

fields.headline: Government drops asylum computer
fields.trailText: The Home Office has scrapped an £77m computer system that was intended to help clear the backlog of asylum seekers, it was reported today.
fields.body:
The Home Office has scrapped an £77m computer system that was intended to help clear the backlog of asylum seekers, it was reported today.

Home secretary Jack Straw said that the system, which was designed to save more than £100m, would not become fully operational.

The project should have been completed by 1998, it was said.

Mr Straw announced the decision in a written Parliamentary answer last week, which was raised in today's issue of Computer Weekly magazine.

German company Siemens Business Services signed a contract in 1996 to set up the system to deal with asylum applications to the Immigration and Nationality Directorate (IND), the magazine said.

The contract would run until 2003 and, while Siemens would continue to work on improving the existing computer network, the full scheme would not be completed, it was said.

In his written answer Mr Straw said: "IND has agreed with Siemens that they should stand down the resources they are using to develop the full casework application.

"At present there is no change to the current contract."

webTitle: Auction reveals big interest in Bond nostalgia

fields.headline: Auction reveals big interest in Bond nostalgia
fields.trailText: Memorabilia connected with the James Bond films has been sold for high prices at an auction at Christie's in London
fields.body:
Derided in some quarters as a relic of the Cold War era, the James Bond films continue to hold a grip on British popular culture. Yesterday's auction of 291 lots of 007 memorabilia provoked a veritable feeding frenzy among buyers at Christie's in London.

Among the items on offer were the original golden bullets (actually brass) used in the 1975 film The Man With the Golden Gun (sold for £2,114), Roger Moore's magnetic Rolex from Live and Let Die (£25,850) and the Walther P99 pistol used by Pierce Brosnan in Tomorrow Never Dies (£9,987).

Perhaps the most bizarre item on the list was the ivory bikini worn by Ursula Andress in the first Bond outing Dr No (see earlier story). It sold to Robert Earl, the co-founder of Planet Hollywood, for an impressive £41,125. Diners will be able to view it (behind glass, of course) over burgers at the restaurant in Times Square, New York.

All told the Bond auction amassed a cool £600,000. But the most expensive purchase was made by computer businessman Max Reid from Sheffield, who forked out £157,750 for the silver Aston Martin driven by Brosnan in 1995's GoldenEye. "It is a gift for my wife on Valentine's Day," Reid told reporters. "I had two reasons - it's a great present for her and it will be wonderful publicity for my business as well."

fields.headline: Tory posters blast bureaucracy
fields.trailText:
10.45pm: The Conservatives' new campaign slams the government's record on public services, reports Daniel Rogers.
Jan 9: Tories launch advertising blitz
fields.body:
The Tories will this morning fire the latest salvo in the escalating pre-election advertising war with a poster campaign attacking government bureaucracy.

The advertising drive will be unveiled by leader William Hague at a press conference at Conservative HQ.

It will criticise the government for forcing teachers, nurses and other public sector workers to fill in forms rather than concentrate on their real jobs.

One advert shows a harassed-looking teacher with the strapline, "Form fillers? Teachers will be teachers under the Conservatives".

The poster campaign has been created by Tory ad agency Yellow M and will be rolled out over the coming month.

The theme continues Mr Hague's onslaught on the Labour government's record on public services.

The last campaign accused the government of wasting tax-payers' money.

The adverts used straplines such as, "You've paid the tax - where are the police?".

fields.headline: Blair retreats on patient rights
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday made a dramatic climbdown by changing the contentious government bill set to abolish the community health councils, the bodies that act as patients' champions.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday made a dramatic climbdown by changing the contentious government bill set to abolish the community health councils, the bodies that act as patients' champions.

Bowing to intense pressure from patients' groups and Labour backbenchers, the prime minister accepted two amendments to the health and social care bill, which will improve patients' rights in the NHS.

MPs had bitterly opposed the bill because they feared it would weaken patients' rights. David Hinchliffe, Labour chairman of the select committee on health, described the government's plans as a "dog's breakfast that complicates the complaints procedure".

The bill will set up a patient advocacy and liaison service for complaints against GPs and hospitals requiring immediate attention, and patients' forums to examine longer term complaints. Mr Hinchliffe won the support of 24 Labour MPs, including Blairite loyalists, for his amendments. The first will ensure patients get independent help on making a complaint - answering the fear that complaints might not be treated seriously if handled entirely by health authorities. The second is the introduction of patient councils to oversee and link the forums.

Labour backbenchers, who mounted a vigorous campaign against the bill, last night welcomed the concession. A leading campaigner said: "We still need some fine tuning. But this is a great improvement."

Among others welcoming the government's climbdown was Murray Benham, spokesman for the association of CHCs. He said: "It is fantastic the government is recognising the strength of feeling against the bill, but it's been a long process."

The Tories made clear last night that they would do their best to kill off the bill when it moves to the Lords, despite the amendments.

fields.standfirst: Consultants up by 50%, with more GPs, nurses and midwives
fields.trailText: A near 50% increase in hospital consultants in England over the next decade will today be announced by health secretary Alan Milburn as the government seeks to re-establish its NHS credentials during the pre-election phony war.

A near 50% increase in hospital consultants in England over the next decade will be announced by the health secretary, Alan Milburn, today as the government seeks to re-establish its NHS credentials during the pre-election phony war.

Big rises in nurses, midwives, GPs and physiotherapists will also be promised in a package designed to help restore the credibility of the service amid continuing public disquiet at waiting lists for consultations and treatment, ward hygiene and quality of life in hospitals.

In an attempt to respond to scandals such as the Alder Hey body parts controversy and the bodies in the chapel episode at Bedford, Mr Milburn will announce that all those undergoing medical training will have to pass tests in communication skills with patients and families as well as study ethics and equal opportunities.

The number of consultants is expected to rise from 24,300 last year to 36,000 by 2009, and within that total there will be far higher percentage rises for heart and cancer specialists.

Physiotherapists will rise by 59% to 24,800, midwives by 44% to 32,600, nurses by 17% to 403,000 and GPs by more than 10% to 31,600.

The government has been under sustained criticism from the professions for widespread staff shortages and Mr Milburn will be hoping that the long-term recruitment targets, tied to big increases in training budgets, up to £250m or 11% for next year, will blunt Tory attacks before the election campaign even starts.

The government has already called its "unprecedented" spending increases on the NHS, 6.1% a year on average from 2000 to 2004, the longest sustained period of high growth. The new staffing promises mean yet more funding.

Today's announcement builds on earlier promises. For instance, the 738 consultants working in coronary care in 1999 were already expected to rise to 992 in 2003, an increase of a third.

Now the total is set to rise by 83% on the 1999 figure by 2009. Similarly the 17% rise in cancer consultants by 2003 has now been extended to a 55% rise over 10 years.

A Department of Health source said last night: "Increasing the number of staff in training is vital if we are to increase the capacity of the NHS and its ability to deliver faster, better care for patients when and where they need it."

A common core curriculum for all health professionals in communication skills, including bedside manner, with patients and their families will be drawn up over the next two years.

The source said: "All individuals will have to demonstrate competence in order to qualify."

The Alder Hey scandal in Liverpool, where parents were not informed about how their children's organs were to be stored for medical use, and other incidents had shown the need for improvements.

Mr Milburn has been keenly aware of the row within the medical profession about how far doctors should go in seeking to repair considerable damage to public confidence.

He also believes the government needs to go further in breaking down barriers between them and other NHS staff.

fields.headline: Banners signal a revolution
fields.standfirst:
A new technology that allows web adverts to be hidden by messages from other advertisers is set to create a storm, reports Justin Hunt
More net news
fields.trailText: A new technology that allows web adverts to be hidden by messages from other advertisers is set to create a storm, reports Justin Hunt.
fields.body:
Banner advertisements are an almost universal feature of web pages these days, appearing at the top of everything from personal sites to the Yahoo! portal. But a new web advertising product created by a British company could turn the banner ad market on its head.

It has the potential to hit some of the web's best known names hard, let consumers choose what kind of ads they see, and could in the process create a valuable new revenue stream for internet service providers (ISPs).

Fotino, a package from Leeds company Meltingpoint Technologies, is a small browser plug-in which lets ISPs place their own banner ads directly over the top of other adverts on the web. The replacement ads will be selected on the basis of personal information supplied by their customers.

In a demonstration for Online, Fotino quickly sent a replacement advert across the computer screen and neatly covered up the main banner ad on a dummy site. In practice, it is likely that consumers would only get a quick glimpse of the adverts on sites like Yahoo! or MSN before they are covered up by the new ones. It would be possible for the user to remove the overlaid ads if they wanted, and Meltingpoint claims there is little overhead for the consumer in terms of longer download times.

Julian Graham-Rack, Meltingpoint's chief executive, believes Fotino has the potential to cause a massive shake-up in the online advertising market. Graham-Rack, who was previously internet development manager for Asda, hopes Fotino will help hand power back to ISPs, who he believes are in a much better position to target ads effectively at their customers. "The performance of banner ads is bloody awful," he says. "The click-through rate is about 1%."

But the launch of Fotino raises lots of big questions. The likes of Yahoo! and other major search engines are not going to be happy with the idea that different banner ads could be served up over their sites, covering up existing ones.

"We have taken advice about it," Graham-Rack says. "We do not interfere with the page underneath. We're using overlays and there is no infringement of copyright. The ad has a small border around it. We are not trying to pass it off as an ad on the resident page."

He suggests that ISPs might have to agree revenue-sharing deals with web sites.

But Peter Brownlow, a partner at Bird & Bird, a new media legal firm which acts on behalf of dot.coms such as Lastminute.com, is quick to spot potential problems. He argues that Fotino's new ad service could damage the reputation of online companies if the replacement adverts are not managed sensitively.

For example, problems would be bound to arise if Fotino ran replacement Pepsi ads on a Coca Cola site, or if banner ads for a men's magazine appeared on a family-orientated site such as Disney.

"I can see a number of legal problems with it," explains Brownlow. "It might be that they can be remedied. It has to be quite clear to the user at the time that the advert was completely unconnected with the site."

Not surprisingly, Yahoo! is hostile to the idea of Fotino covering up ads on its pages, given that they have already been sold on the basis that they will reach a certain number of visitors.

"ISPs would need to buy advertising. They cannot serve ads onto Yahoo! without us allowing them to do so," says Lee Thompson, sales director for Yahoo UK and Ireland. He adds that he does not believe that ISPs will necessarily be any better at targeting banner ads than anyone else.

But banner adverts do generally have extremely low click-through rates, with many consumers reluctant to click on banner ads to visit advertisers' sites. And frequently the pages of new media marketing magazines are filled with new media execs agonising over whether or not the banner ad is dead.

But there are still plenty of new media advertising directors who are prepared to defend them against new technology upstarts such as Fotino.

"Banner ads are better targeted than any other previous form of advertising," argues Jeremy Wright, managing director of Engage Media, the online marketing agency. "It's not all about click-throughs. Other media have never had click-throughs before. Click- throughs are an additional benefit."

Wright believes banner ads can still effectively build brand awareness. He argues that Fotino is a deliberate move to help ISPs "grab land" and extend out from the boundaries of their existing services. But he feels the new advertising product will never gain a large share of the market because it runs counter to entrenched principles of media ownership.

If a web site has invested money in attracting people then he believes it is fully entitled to control all the advertising that is run on its site. However, he does accept that net-based technology has a nasty habit of successfully - and quickly - ripping up traditional ways of working.

"It's quite natural that the boundaries of media ownership will be tested," he says. "We hope the existing principles remain. It's important that common sense prevails."

Meltingpoint Technologies is not expecting an easy ride. Fotino, which has just been launched, has not yet been signed up by any ISPs. But Graham-Rack believes they will be eager to seize the opportunity to control more of the advertising their customers are exposed to.

ISPs, he thinks, will want to become more of an integral part of their customers' browsing experiences and he feels constructive commercial dialogues with major sites should be possible.

Last December, Meltingpoint released another controversial e-business product called Mirazo. Online customers choose to sign up to the service which informs them when cheaper comparable products can be brought from another site. Surfers can simply link through to the site with the cheaper deal.

Mirazo is already being used by WH Smith to remind their customers - visiting Amazon, for example - that they can get specific books or CDs at cheaper rates from WH Smith's site.

"It offers us another means of communicating with our customers," explains Rick Latham, managing director of WHSmith.co.uk. "When they are looking at competitive products, we can use it to give them information. There is an element of brand-build ing as well." Despite that, Amazon does not appear to be too worried by these guerrilla tactics at the moment. Tom Allchurch, Amazon's European marketing director, says such devices are becoming an everyday part of e-business life. "We co-exist in a world with lots of opportunities to compare prices. Our customers can decide whether to shop with us or anyone else."

Allchurch has not seen Fotino yet. But like Yahoo!, Amazon is likely to be concerned about a product that interferes with the relationships it has with its advertisers. Fotino has already successfully re-ignited the debate about the future of banner advertising on the net.

Despite the tough obstacles facing its widespread adoption, Graham-Rack remains quietly confident that this radical new ad service will generate valuable additional revenues for ISPs. "The free call charge ISP model has failed to be sustainable because of lack of revenue. Fotino could change that."

Only time will tell.

fields.headline: Liverpool fan stabbed in Rome
fields.trailText: A Liverpool fan has been stabbed in Rome after fighting broke out between rival fans in the early hours of this morning.
fields.body:
A Liverpool fan has been stabbed in Rome after fighting broke out between rival fans in the early hours of this morning.

The man, whose injuries are not believed to be life-threatening, is recovering in hospital. Two other Liverpool fans suffered head injuries after clashing with AS Roma supporters in Rome city centre.

A Foreign Office spokeswoman said: "I can confirm that a man was involved in an incident last night. He is receiving treatment."

Police in Rome identified the stabbed man as Gerard Collins and said he was injured in the left arm and in the thigh. Glen McAlbin and Terry Blake suffered head injuries and were treated briefly in hospital.

During the fighting a British fan also broke the windows of a pub, police said.

Despite the incidents, there are no reports of any arrests.

About 4,000 Liverpool fans are expected in for the Uefa Cup fourth-round match tonight at the Olympic Stadium. It is the first time the two teams have met since the 1984 European Cup final, which Liverpool won on penalties.

webTitle: Oscar odds say Roberts, but Crowe and Hanks neck and neck

fields.headline: Oscar odds say Roberts, but Crowe and Hanks neck and neck
fields.trailText: Bookmakers are united in backing Julia Roberts as winner of the Best Actress Oscar but are divided over whether Russell Crowe of Tom Hanks will take the Best Actor Academy Award
fields.body:
After all the hoopla of Tuesday's Oscar nominations, it seems that for one section of American observers the contest is already over. According to the Las Vegas oddsmakers Julia Roberts is a shoo-in for the Best Actress award for her role in Erin Brockovich. But the bookies are more circumspect over the Best Actor Oscar which appears to be coming down to a too-close-to-call contest between Russell Crowe in Gladiator and Tom Hanks in Cast Away.

According to entertainment website Mr. Showbiz, David Scott of Vegas-based America's Line thinks that Hanks will take the award. But Joe Arello, the director of odds for Bally's and Paris hotel casinos, and Joe Lupo, of Stardust hotel and casino, both lean towards Crowe by a slender margin. The Vegas uncertainty is mirrored by the odds given by British bookmakers. Ladbrokes currently makes Hanks the favourite, while William Hill plumps for Crowe. Both companies tip Gladiator to take best film, a prediction widely backed up in Vegas. David Scott, however, reckons that Steven Soderbergh's Traffic may just spring an upset.

The Vegas oddsmakers are regarded as crucial indicators of Oscar form as they have predicted the results with a large degree of accuracy in the past. Last year they correctly annointed American Beauty as the frontrunner and uniformly predicted that Kevin Spacey would win for Best Actor.

The trouble is that the Vegas odds have no cash value in America. "Wagering on the Academy Awards is illegal in the US, even in Nevada," Scott points out. "However, the practise of betting on the Oscars is both lawful and popular in Britain." What further incentive do you need?

fields.headline: Morrissey swaps lager for milkshake
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Men Behaving Badly star Neil Morrissey is swapping lager for milkshake in new ads for Yazoo, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Men Behaving Badly star Neil Morrissey is turning his attention from lager to milkshake in a new ad for Yazoo.

Mr Morrissey, the voice of BBC children's show Bob the Builder, is doing the voiceovers for three animated TV ads featuring the Yazoo dinosaur who teaches kids to "Do what you've gotta do to get your Yazoo".

The £1m, six-week TV, press and promotions campaign breaks next week to coincide with the school half-term holiday.

The commercials, targeting five to 12-year-olds, also promote collectable glow-in-the-dark "stickeroos" free on millions of special edition packs of Campina-owned Yazoo milkshakes and desserts.

Advertising agency WFCA Integrated created the campaign with media planning and buying by AMS.

"The beauty of the creative theme is that it challenges kids to be adventurous, outgoing and active - all key Yazoo brand values," said Johan Stas, Yazoo UK marketing manager.

"The glow-in-the-dark on-pack sticker promotion provides the 'I want' factor required to get it onto mum's shopping list as well as ensuring brand saliency beyond the life of the commercials."

webTitle: Legacy loses exclusive dome bidding rights

fields.headline: Legacy loses exclusive dome bidding rights
fields.standfirst: Special report: The Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, said today that the government will consider new bids for the troubled Millennium Dome, possibly ending the hopes of the £125m Legacy bid.
fields.body:
The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, said today that the government will consider new bids for the troubled Millennium Dome, possibly ending the hopes of the £125m Legacy bid.

Up to this point, Robert Bourne's Legacy consortium - which would turn the former tourist attraction into a hi-tech business park - has been the only one under government consideration.

But the consortium only had until yesterday to maintain its preferred bidder status by reaching an agreement with the government.

Speaking today, Lord Falconer said that Legacy had until yesterday to meet government parameters for the sale and, as Mr Bourne's group had not met those parameters, other groups would now be welcome to bid for the dome. He expected to start accepting bids within the next few weeks.

Legacy had hoped that yesterday's deadline would be extended.

The government has been concerned that Legacy lacks sufficient backing, but yesterday the bid received a boost when the Teesland Group, a property company chaired by a business associate of Mr Bourne, said they will back Legacy by taking a 10% stake.

According to the minister responsible for the dome, Lord Falconer, the government pays out well in excess of £1m a month to maintain the building after it stopped accepting visitors on January 1.

One bid that the government will now consider is that of the Millennium Dome chief executive, Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, who wants to turn the dome into an international entertainment venue and visitor attraction. Yesterday he gave the government a 48-hour deadline to make a decision about Legacy's preferred bidder status.

Property group Stanhope and engineering company Pell Frischmann may also put in competing bids to develop the dome as a business complex.

The dome cost £958m - half of that from lottery funds and much of which was never recovered - during its one year of operation, but it was the most popular admission-charged visitor attraction in Britain last year. However, at 6.5m visitors, it fell disastrously short of expectations for 12m visitors.

The prime minister, Tony Blair, is said to be eager for a quick sale ahead of the expected spring election, but Mr Prescott, is said to support a plan for English Heritage to take control of the dome site, allowing it to remain in public hands.

The Legacy consortium, which is largely backed by Irish financiers Treasury Holdings, has argued with Whitehall's demands for a share of any profits made in the first 10 years and a slice of the money made if it is later resold.

The treasury is believed to feel the government is attempting to tighten the clauses to avoid later charges that it sold the dome too cheaply.

Legacy was made the "preferred bidder" last November when Japanese bank Nomura dropped out.

webTitle: Tourists saved after phone text message sparks rescue

fields.headline: Tourists saved after phone text message sparks rescue
fields.standfirst: What's the most useful message you've ever sent?
fields.trailText: A remarkable search and rescue operation succeeded today, after British tourists, stranded in a boat drifting in stormy seas off Indonesia, sent a mobile phone text message to England to raise the alarm.
fields.byline: Rebecca Allison and John Aglionby in Jakarta
fields.body:
A remarkable search and rescue operation succeeded today, after British tourists, stranded in a boat drifting in stormy seas off Indonesia, sent a mobile phone text message to England to raise the alarm.

The drama began five hours after the boat Ombak Indah set sail yesterday to follow an island hoppers' route between Bali and Lombok with 10 Britons, an Australian and a New Zealander and six local crew on board.

Disaster struck at around 3am GMT when the boat's engine suddenly failed when they were a kilometre away from Lombok's west coast. They started drifting back out to sea as the weather began to deteriorate.

With no proper radio on the boat, the crew were unable to signal for help, and a mobile phone carried by one of the British travellers represented the only hope of making contact and raising the alarm.

Thousands of miles away in England Nick Hodgson received the phone text message from his 19-year-old girlfriend in Indonesia. It said: "Call Falmouth Coastguard, we need help - SOS."

Mr Hodgson, 23, works as an assistant manager at a holiday park. He telephoned his girlfriend, and, as her phone's battery was running out, heard just enough to understand the situation.

He contacted the Thames coastguard which relayed the mayday to Falmouth coastguard in Cornwall who then tried unsuccessfully to contact the Indonesian authorities. Instead Falmouth reached their Australian counterparts who managed to get through to Bali where authorities then contacted the search and rescue team in Lombok. Seven and a half hours after the first mayday message was sent a rescue ship put to sea from Lombok.

But eight hours later the drifting vessel had still not been found.

Via mobile phone yesterday at 5.30pm GMT (1.30am local time) one of the seven British men on board said: "The sea is pretty bloody rough. The wind is picking up and the waves are getting bigger."

At that point the passenger thought they were about 10km (six miles) south of Gili Trawangan, a small island to the north west of Lombok. "We've got the anchor fixed now," he said. "Or we that think we have. We could be dragging it along. The crew seemed unable to do anything to help us so we just started drifting. At one point a ship came near us and then just pissed off again. Since then we've seen nothing."

None of the passengers was reported to be seriously ill, although some were feeling seasick after 23 hours on the water. One of those on board said they desperately wanted a plane to help with the search because an aircraft would be able to find them more easily than a boat in the choppy sea.

"We have one generator powering three lightbulbs so they [a plane] should see us while the ship is having problems spotting us in the heavy sea." He did not know how long the generator would continue working.

Their problems were exacerbated by their not being able ring for help on the phone.

Ketut Dede, the captain of the boat, a 23m-long wooden outrigger, said their food was starting to run out. "We don't have that much left," he said.

A spokesman for the Falmouth coastguard, which is the designated point of contact for communications between the UK and Indonesia in emergencies, said that there had been minimal contact with the boat.

Speaking of the passenger who sent the message, he said: "Her mobile has lost power now, but during the night when it all started, the coastguard on duty spoke to her to find out what was going on. They were not sure where they were. The lady was backpacking in Indonesia. We believe she hired the boat with friends and the engine lost power so they were unable to get back. They were obviously concerned and knew they must do something. But unless she can speak the local language she wouldn't get very far trying to ring the authorities in Indonesia herself.".

He added: "They are very lucky that the phone worked. You only have to go a few miles offshore and there is no signal. It is not the thing to rely on when at sea."

Meanwhile, the search team was struggling to pinpoint the stricken vessel's location. The boat has no global positioning system for determining its exact coordinates and, allegedly, even its compass is thought to be faulty.

Mr Junaidi, a member of the search and rescue team on Lombok, said last night: "Our boat is looking for them where they said they think they are, but it cannot find them. In clear weather Lombok can be clearly seen from Bali because the islands are less than 50 kilometres apart."

Coastguard officials in Jakarta said that they would not launch a plane to help with the search unless they had a more accurate indication of the boat's position.

Mr Junaidi thought it highly likely that if the boat were still missing at daybreak a plane would be used to help find it.

The British embassy in Jakarta was only made fully aware of the situation by the Guardian more than 17 hours after the Ombak Indah started drifting. A duty officer at the embassy said they were doing everything they could to help with the rescue.

webTitle: Bristol faces big school cuts after tax referendum

fields.headline: Bristol faces big school cuts after tax referendum
fields.trailText: Bristol was last night facing up to the prospect of big cuts in its education budget, with school closures and scores of teaching redundancies, after voters in the city unexpectedly rejected any council tax increase this year - against the advice of the Labour controlled local authority.
fields.body:
Bristol was last night facing up to the prospect of big cuts in its education budget, with school closures and scores of teaching redundancies, after voters in the city unexpectedly rejected any council tax increase this year - against the advice of the Labour controlled local authority.

In a ground-breaking referendum among the city's 278,000 taxpayers, only 18% backed the council's preferred option of a 4% tax increase which would have effectively meant a standstill budget after inflation is taken into account.

Almost 54% backed no increase, despite warnings from the Labour group - which has a majority of only two - of £4.5m cuts in the education budget and the loss of around 180 teaching posts.

David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, accused councillors of being irresponsible and "reckless beyond belief".

He added: "If they accept the decision of the council taxpayers and in the process abdicate their responsibility for education in the city, then there will be severely damaged schools throughout Bristol, and they deserve to be declared a failing local education authority with all the consequences - including privatisation - that will inevitably follow."

The referendum attracted a 40 % turnout, 10% higher than in local elections. Voters were given two other options: a 2% increase on the £351m budget, which would still have meant cuts of £2.2m and a 6% rise, which could have brought extra spending of £2.2m.

Labour councillors appeared cautiously confident of persuading voters to opt for a modest increase, which would have amounted to around £75 on the average band D property which pays £1,000 annually. Council tax in the city has been frozen for two years.

Council leader George Micklewright last night tried to put a brave face on what he called a "worthwhile exercise in local democracy".

But he conceded: "This was not the result we hoped for and we made it clear what the consequences of no increase would be, with some graphic illustrations. No one could say they did not have enough information."

He could not say whether any teachers would be sacked because under local school management individual schools would have to make decisions. "But it looks like some teaching posts will go."

Ministers had been keenly awaiting the Bristol result because they had been hailing the referendum as a ground-breaking exercise in local democracy - the first poll of its kind in a large city.

In a smaller referendum in Milton Keynes two years ago, voters opted for a 10% increase, almost four times the rate of inflation, after being presented with three other options - including the prospect of big cuts in education if they went for a smaller increase.

fields.headline: Kingfisher sails in with new wave of MacArthur sponsorship
fields.trailText:
9.15am: Kingfisher is to continue its partnership with round-the-world yachtswoman Ellen MacArthur. By Julia Day.
Feb 13: BBC brings forward MacArthur film
fields.body:
Kingfisher has pulled off a sponsorship coup with confirmation it is to continue its partnership with round-the-world yacht heroine Ellen MacArthur.

The owner of the Superdrug, B&Q, Comet and Woolworths retail chains will put together a substantial promotional package for Ms MacArthur's next race, the Atlantic Challenge in July.

Kingfisher has reaped huge rewards for its initial £4m investment in the Vendee Globe race, which Ms MacArthur completed in second place on Sunday.

It spent £2m on the boat, its maintenance and back-up team and a further £2m on promotional and media events.

But Kingfisher got more than its money's-worth as its brand was emblazoned worldwide across TV stations, newspapers and internet sites after Ms MacArthur's epic struggle catapulted her from relative obscurity to sporting superstardom.

Now the 24-year-old yachtswoman wants to use the Kingfisher boat for the Atlantic Challenge.

"We will be Ellen's sponsor. She thinks she can do the Atlantic Challenge. We have said we would like to support her and she said she is happy to stick with us," said a Kingfisher spokesman.

"There is a hell of a lot of work to do, but we can safely say we are pulling together a promotional package for the next race," he added.

The relationship between Ms MacArthur and Kingfisher began two years ago when the group sponsored her in a French transatlantic solo race.

fields.headline: Nicholson follows Cainer to Mirror
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Daily Express assistant editor David Nicholson is leaving to join star astrologer Jonathan Cainer at the Mirror, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The man responsible for the Daily Express pages featuring star astrologer Jonathan Cainer has followed him to the Mirror.

David Nicholson, Daily Express assistant editor for special projects, will join the Mirror on a part-time, freelance basis, to develop and edit Mr Cainer's pages.

"I've worked with Jonathan Cainer since he was at Today and I'm really looking forward to it," Mr Nicholson said.

He will also be working on developing Mr Cainer's website, Cainer.com.

Mr Nicholson is expected to join the Mirror in mid to late March, shortly before Mr Cainer starts on the paper.

Mr Nicholson said his departure was not connected to the change of ownership at the Express and that the move was motivated solely by his desire to work with Mr Cainer.

Mr Cainer, Britain's highest paid astrologer, has been the subject of a number of high-profile catfights among Fleet Street's movers and shakers.

He was wooed from the Daily Mail to the Express last year by then editor Rosie Boycott for a reported £1m salary and £1m in bonuses and extras.

But it is understood Mr Cainer was lured to the Mirror by the promise of a cut of the revenues from his lucrative astrology phone lines.

fields.headline: Members bail out First Tuesday
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Members of networking group First Tuesday yesterday became owners of the organisation, paying just £1m to Yazam, writes Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
Members of networking group First Tuesday yesterday became owners of the organisation, paying just £1m to Yazam, the Israeli investment firm which bought it for an estimated £33m five months ago.

The group, which was set up to introduce entrepreneurs to venture capitalists and has 100,000 members worldwide, has been sold to 11 of the network's representatives.

Steven Carlson, First Tuesday's Budapest city leader, said the city's representatives had bought the group in the "name of the network" and planned to offer broader ownership to the other members.

Yazam also announced yesterday it is to be sold to US Technologies, which funds and manages emerging technology companies.

Yazam withdrew from First Tuesday at the beginning of the year after falling into financial difficulties.

Mr Carlson, however, emphasised there was still demand for First Tuesday's networking events, despite the lack of venture capital funding and the negative sentiment surrounding dot.com companies.

"People are still coming to meet each other and there is a real value there," Mr Carlson said.

The group, which holds events in 85 countries and generates revenue from sponsorship and matchmaking fees, said the future looked bright and profitable.

Reade Fahs, chief executive officer of the firm, said: "First Tuesday will continue to be a key source in the driving of the worldwide internet economy."

First Tuesday has helped to launch online businesses such as Confetti, the interactive party and wedding planning company, and the ill-fated Clickmango, which went into voluntary liquidation.

First Tuesday started as a drinks party in a Soho bar two years ago.

The organisation quickly grew into a network of meetings held in British cities and others around the world on the first Tuesday of each month.

webTitle: Obesity in England is nearing epidemic proportions

fields.headline: Action urged to cut the fat of the land
fields.standfirst:
Poor diet and lack of exercise blamed for rise in obesity

Talk about it
fields.trailText: Poor diet and lack of exercise blamed for rise in obesity.
fields.body:
Obesity in England is nearing epidemic proportions with one in five adults now dangerously overweight, costing the economy and NHS £2.6bn a year, the national audit office warns today.

More than 31,000 people a year are dying prematurely - 6% of all deaths - because of a lifestyle of fatty diets, over-reliance on the car and energy-saving devices such as lifts and escalators.

In a stark report sure to revive the spectre of the nanny state, the national audit office (NAO) warns that in 10 years obesity levels could reach those of the US, where a quarter of the population is obese, unless more action is taken by government, employers, the food industry and individuals.

In addition to the 21% of women and 17% of men in England regarded as obese, another 32% of women and 46% of men are overweight. This means nearly six in 10 adults - more than 20m people - should change their lifestyles, say the report's authors.

England, where obesity levels have tripled in 20 years, already has one of the worst records in Europe. Studies have also shown alarming rises in children's weight. As many as one in 10 children aged four or under is obese, while one in four is overweight, research in the British Medical Journal revealed last week.

Philip James, the professor who first persuaded Tony Blair to establish the food standards agency, and who now chairs the International Obesity Taskforce, suggested there should be a new public health lifestyle council, as exists in some Scandinavian countries, together with a cabinet-rank minister to tackle public health reforms "forgotten since the advent of the NHS."

He added: "We need to focus on transforming the diet of children and adults, even if the initiatives threaten some components of the food and soft drinks industries."

Obesity is measured using body mass index (BMI), which is the person's weight in kilograms divided by their height in metres squared. A BMI of 20 to 25 is normal, 25 to 30 is overweight and more than 30 is obese. A man of about 5ft 10in weighing more than 15 stone or a woman of 5ft 6in and 13.5 stone would be regarded as obese.

The report says treating obesity and related illnesses cost the NHS about £500m in 1998. The loss to the economy, through 18m days of sickness and 40m days of working life through early death of workers, was £2.1m. But this took no account of conditions where proportions due to obesity could not be calculated, including back pain, one of the most common causes of absences.

The report illustrates changing lifestyles by using earlier studies which suggested the number of 17-year-olds walking to school fell from 59% to 49% between 1986 and 1996 while car journeys to schools doubled. Average television watching in England doubled from 13 hours a week to 26 over 30 years to the mid-1990s and a recent government-funded study of the diet of 4 to 18-year-olds revealed average consumption of fruit, vegetables and fruit juice was 188 grams a day, less than half the 400g recommended for adults.

Life expectancy

The report says problems of obesity and excess weight increase with age, so that while less than 30% of 16 to 24-year-olds are above normal levels, seven in 10 over-65s have a problem. The prevalence of obesity grows among lower socio-economic groups. Obesity is reducing life expectancy by nine years on average, according to the report. But only one in seven health authorities has a plan to prevent or treat obesity and only 40% of GPs attempt to identify patients at highest risk of excessive weight gain.

The report calls on the government to build on existing cross-cutting Whitehall initiatives, including the NHS plan on nutrition, on increased participation in sport and on supporting healthier methods of transport. The NAO is particularly worried by inconsistency between certain food industry sponsorship of schools and initiatives designed to promote balanced diets. "Schools have participated with businesses in schemes to provide free books and maths equipment in return for tokens from crisps and biscuit packets. This type of commercial involvement, which has the effect of directly promoting sales of particular products, may encourage children and their families to buy more snack foods with a high fat, salt and sugar content."

James Robertson, director of health value for money at the NAO, said yesterday "It is a mistake to say there is a problem which cannot be tackled . There need not be a counsel of desperation. We are not seeking a nanny state." Suzi Leather, deputy chairman of the food standards agency, said: "We won't fight flab with only willpower. Consumers also need to be armed with information about the nutritional content of food. Improved labelling could do a great deal to help."

But the food industry, while cooperating with government and health bodies in attempting to reduce levels of ingredients such as salt in the public's diet and providing lifestyle advice, remains suspicious of state dictation. Martin Paterson, director of public affairs for the Food and Drink Federation, said: "Since the days of Edwina Currie, nannying is a busted flush. It may be well-meaning but never works. Education is the only key."

Fat facts

Main findings

 Obesity in England has tripled since 1980

 1 in 5 adults is now obese, by 2010 it could be 1 in 4

 Two-thirds of men and over half of women are either obese or overweight

 Obesity costs the NHS at least £500m a year and the economy another £2bn a year

Trimming tips

 Take at least 30 mins of light to moderate exercise, such as a brisk walk, five times a week

 Eat a piece of fruit or drink fruit juice with every meal

 Eat two portions of salads or vegetables for main meals

 Rice, pasta or potatoes should take up about a third of your plate for main meals

 Eat fish 2-3 times a week

 Use semi-skimmed or skimmed milk

 Avoid salt

 Keep sweets, etc, for special occasions

Related story
'I liked feeling full. I thought about it all day'
Fat is fab

webTitle: EU follows British lead on music piracy

fields.headline: EU follows British lead on music piracy
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Music lovers and film buffs will continue to be allowed to make private copies of their favourite songs or movies after the European parliament yesterday agreed Europe-wide internet piracy legislation. By Andrew Osborn.
fields.body:
Music lovers and film buffs will continue to be allowed to make private copies of their favourite songs or movies after the European parliament yesterday agreed Europe-wide internet piracy legislation.

In a vote that attracted ferocious lobbying from all sides, MEPs approved a copyright directive that will ensure European clones of song-swapping website Napster can be swiftly shut down through legal action.

But they rejected calls from the music industry to outlaw reasonable private copying for personal use and opted to strike a balance between the interests of the entertainment industry and consumers.

"This is a victory for common sense," said Labour MEP Arlene McCarthy. "We've voted to neither legalise electronic theft nor to criminalise consumers, and no major amendments to UK copyright law will now be needed."

"It's about defending rights we take for granted in the UK. It's about making a copy of Big Brother on Friday to watch on Saturday. And making a copy of your favourite CD for your own use."

British MEPs successfully defended their domestic status quo on private copying in the face of lobbying from countries keen to impose a levy on blank video and audio tapes. Libraries, schools, universities and other educational and charitable institutions will be allowed to copy intellectual property for their purposes.

The actors' union Equity and four other trade organisations had been concerned that MEPs would vote through amendments that might cheat them of income and amounted to "legalised theft".

One clause which was defeated yesterday would have allowed broadcasters to use archive material on websites or digital TV and pay only minimal royalties to writers and actors involved.

The music industry, which lined up stars to lobby on its behalf including Irish pop group the Corrs, Beatles producer Sir George Martin, Sting and Dave Stewart, yesterday said it could live with the new legislation.

"There are enough elements here for the industry to speed up the offering of music to consumers in a wider range of ways," said Jay Berman of the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry.

webTitle: Cadbury aims to bridge gap with cocoa cafes

fields.headline: Cadbury aims to bridge gap with cocoa cafes
fields.trailText: Cadbury is to open a chain of cafes catering for chocolate lovers, writes Andrew Clark.
fields.body:
Cadbury Schweppes is to open a chain of cafes catering for chocolate lovers, in an attempt to breathe life into the increasingly dull market for confectionery in Britain.

The sweets and drinks firm is also considering installing vending machines in pubs and hospitals, after two years of flat UK sales of its snacks - which include Dairy Milk, Creme Eggs and Trebor Mints.

The initiative emerged as Cadbury announced a 15% rise in annual profits to £792m, helped by a strong US performance from soft drinks such as Dr Pepper and Seven Up.

Chief executive John Sunderland said: "The UK market was subdued. The key to stimulating more consumption is availability. Chocolates are impulse purchases - people have to have the products in front of them to be tempted to buy."

The company recently opened a three-storey Cafe Cadbury in Bath, specialising in drinking chocolate but also serving tea, coffee and meals. The cafe contains a restaurant, a sweet shop and a "relaxation area" where customers can rest with a steaming mug of cocoa.

The firm could face the loss of its contract to run vending machines on London Underground stations and, to fill the gap, Cadbury is seeking new sites for machines. The public's appetite for snacks has waned due to the decline of independent grocers, and mergers among supermarkets - which demand stiff terms for sweets in prime positions at tills.

Cadbury's profits from confectionery throughout Europe edged up by £1m to £200m. The main driver of the company's performance was its US beverages business, which increased its profits by 22% to £406m. This included a first contribution from the US fruit drinks brand Snapple, which Cadbury bought for £1bn in September. Cadbury shares rose 15.8p to 471.8p.

fields.headline: Ireland gets cross-border tourist board
fields.trailText: 8.30am: A new tourist body is being set up to market both Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
A new tourism body is being set up to market both Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic.

Tourism Ireland will be the first cross-border tourist board and is a joint venture between the governments of Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic.

The new body will control the marketing of Ireland abroad and will be responsible for establishing an Ireland brand to increase the number of visitors to the island.

Tourism Ireland has come about as a result of moves to develop closer cross-border ties between north and south following the 1998 Good Friday Agreement.

The establishment of Tourism Ireland will affect the current roles of the Northern Ireland Tourist Board and Bord Failte, the Irish Tourist Board in Dublin, according to a Bord Failte spokesman.

It is thought that the existing tourist boards will retain responsibility for domestic tourism and organising the tourist industry within Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic.

A 10-strong Tourism Ireland board has been created, chaired by the group chief executive of Queens Moat Houses, Andrew Coppel.

The board also includes Mircosoft Ireland marketing manager Ann Riordan, Irish Ferries marketing director Tony Kelly and executives from both the existing Irish tourist boards.

A chief executive is being recruited for Tourism Ireland, who will then formulate a marketing strategy and appoint a staff of more than 100 people.

The appointment of branding, advertising and PR agencies will not proceed until the chief executive has been appointed and a strategy drawn up.

It is proposed that the new body, which will be based in Dublin, will be in operation for the 2002 tourist season.

webTitle: 5 Live to run election game show

fields.headline: 5 Live seeks mavericks for election game show
fields.trailText: 8.30am: BBC Radio 5 Live is to broadcast a Big Brother-style political reality game show in the run-up to the election, writes Wale Azeez.
fields.body:
BBC Radio 5 Live is to broadcast a Big Brother-style political reality game show in the run-up to the general election.

The Magnificent Seven, which is being made by Sunday Service producer Ten Alps, will pit seven people with diverging political views against each other.

Ten Alps is currently looking for seven "political mavericks" to spend a week in a bed and breakfast debating and testing each other's political convictions.

Each day the "Select Committee", a panel of 5 Live listeners chaired by the landlady of the B&B, will decide which one of the contestants to throw off the show, until a winner emerges.

"The Magnificant Seven will converge on a dreary bed and breakfast in a mystery town,for a week of political infighting," said a Ten Alps spokesman.

"We like to think of it as Temptation Island meets On the Record meets Hotel. There are also elements of The Mole."

"The idea is to recapture what we briefly had in the petrol crisis - politics as direct action by interest groups, engaging real people without the intermediary of parties, spinmeisters and manifestos."

The contestants will be expected to perform two daily tasks.

They will take part in a serious Teatime Debate, discussing issues such as National Health Service privatisation over tea and biscuits.

There is also to be a more lighthearted Test of Political Skills.

In addition, Magnificent Seven contestants will be subjected to a Primary School Question Time, interrogation by an ex-CIA agent and choosing between a five-star gourmet lunch and working in a soup kitchen for the Naked Bribery feature.

Listeners will get the chance to quiz the contestants in phone-ins.

The Magnificant Seven is expected to air sometime in March, with the exact scheduling dependent on the date of the general election.

It will be broadcast on 5 Live for eight consecutive days, with three or four daily instalments varying in length from a few minutes to half-an-hour.

The show is being produced by Sam Cash, son of Tory MP Bill Cash and co-creator of Sunday Service.
