webTitle: US TV giants admit poll shambles

fields.headline: TV giants admit poll shambles
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Senior executives at the main US TV networks promised to change the way they cover elections yesterday,after the election night fiasco, writes Julian Borger.
fields.body:
Senior executives of the main American television networks and the Associated Press news agency promised to change the way they cover elections yesterday, after the fiasco on US election night in November, when the results were wrongly declared twice.

The network heads told a congressional committee that the misjudgments had not been politically motivated, but were the result of undue haste and over-reliance on a single exit-poll organisation. They insisted that in-house reform rather than government intervention was the right way to correct the problem.

The networks first announced that Al Gore had won the presidential vote in Florida shortly before 8pm on November 7, even while people in the west of the state were still voting. The statement was withdrawn two hours later. Then all the networks said that George Bush was the overall winner, before being forced to admit that the result was too close to call.

In fact, Mr Bush was only declared the winner a month later, when the US supreme court intervened to resolve the dispute over manual recounts in Florida, the deciding state in a historically tight race.

Andrew Heyward, head of CBS News, said CBS and other network news operations "made serious mistakes that long, confusing night, mistakes I deeply regret".

The five networks - ABC, CBS, NBC, CNN and Fox - have all admitted that they were in too much of a hurry to declare a winner and relied too much on a single exit polling organisation, Voter New Service, a consortium established by the networks in 1993.

Billy Tauzin, the Republican chairman of the House of Representatives' energy and commerce committee, said that VNS had provided "clearly flawed data models and clearly biased statistical results". VNS has since admitted that it did not take the absentee vote sufficiently into account.

An independent report commissioned by CNN described the television election coverage as "a collective drag race on the crowded highway of democracy, recklessly endangering the electoral process, the political life of the country, and their own credibility, all for reasons that may be conceptually flawed and commercially questionable."

Joan Konner, one of the CNN report's three authors and a professor at Columbia University graduate school of journalism, said: "We had several recommendations. At the core of it was: Slow up, slow up. Don't use exit polls for projections. Don't use key precincts for projections. Count the votes. The public appears willing to wait. They want real results."

The network heads said they would stick to the recommendations by their internal inquiries to avoid making projections until all the polls in the state being called were closed, to insulate the exit-polling organisations from the competitive pressures of the television networks, and to use AP statistics and other sources to check the accuracy of VNS projections.

Tom Johnson, chairman of the CNN News Group, said CNN would not declare a winner in polls if there was a margin of less than 1% between the candidates. Mr Heyward said that CBS would create a new category in tight races, to indicate whom the results were "leaning" toward.

Louis Boccardi, president of AP, said that while there were "serious shortcomings" in the Florida coverage, "fixing them is a job for the nation's editors and news directors, not its legislators".

webTitle: Contestant claims Survivor show was rigged

fields.headline: Survivor sued
fields.standfirst:
Contestant claims show was rigged

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: One of the original contestants in CBS's top-rating TV reality show Survivor is to sue its producers for allegedly rigging her early removal, writes Duncan Campbell.
fields.body:
It is a test of willpower, stamina and raw courage. It throws ordinary members of the public into a savage jungle where ruthless creatures lurk. There can be only one survivor. Yes, it's the US legal system.

It has emerged that one of the original contestants in CBS's top-rating television reality show Survivor is to sue its producers for allegedly rigging her early removal from the show.

A San Francisco lawyer, Stacey Stillman, is suing both CBS and the programme's creator, Mark Burnett, for fraud and breach of contract.

In a 14-page lawsuit, Ms Stillman claims that Mr Burnett convinced two fellow-contestants to vote her off the island early, to protect 72-year-old Rudy Boesch, who became one of the programme's main characters.

Ms Stillman is seeking punitive damages of $75,000 (£50,000), in addition to potential lost prize money.

She claims that she was voted off third out of 16 contestants because Mr Boesch was the only remaining survivor aged over 40 and the programme did not want to lose older viewers. He made it through to the final four. The victor, Richard Hatch, won $1m.

CBS denies the claims and Mr Burnett is not commenting. "We heard about Stillman's allegations several months ago," CBS said. "They had no merit then. They have no merit now that she has packaged them into a frivolous and groundless lawsuit."

webTitle: Soap's melody lingers but sets won't wobble

fields.headline: Soap's melody lingers but sets won't wobble
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Diehard Crossroads fans will be delighted to learn that the new version has kept the next most recognisable aspect of the original series: the theme tune. By Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The sets may no longer shake, but diehard Crossroads fans will be delighted to learn that the producers of the new version have kept the next most recognisable aspect of the original series: the theme tune.

Carlton TV has enlisted Rod Stratfold, art director of Stanley Kubrick's Full Metal Jacket, to ensure that the new reception does not wobble and the bedrooms don't sway. But the programme-makers have stopped short of abandoning the music that introduced Crossroads for 23 years until it was axed in 1988.

The theme - composed by soap music veteran Tony Hatch - has been updated to match the soap's revamped setting. "Crossroads is now a four-star hotel, not a no-star motel," Carlton said yesterday.

There can be no better indication of how times have changed than the hotel's new handyman, who is far removed from Benny, the social misfit of the original. Bradley Clarke, played by Luke Walker, is swarthy, handsome - and gay. His partner is the cafe manager Tom Curtis, played by former Hollyoaks star Toby Sawyer. But there are strong links to the past: three original cast members return.

Jane Rossington's Jill Chance is back, claiming 30% of the hotel she once owned. So too is Tony Adams as her ex-husband Adam, and Kathy Staff's laundry maid Doris Luke.

David Liddiment, ITV's director of programmes, predicts Crossroads will quickly regain a strong following when it starts, probably towards the end of March. "You will see all of the warmth, drama and humour which earned the [original] show such loyalty and affection amongst viewers. But you will also see contemporary storylines delivered with real pace and energy and new faces to engage a whole new generation," he said.

It will run twice daily: at lunchtime with a repeat, probably at teatime.

Mr Stratfold said he applied film studio standards to his latest project. Carlton initially "panicked" when he insisted the floors be covered in chipboard instead of the usual vinyl - but, he explained, it was the only way that sets could be screwed down.

Producers pay homage to loyal fans - the show had 11m viewers when it was dropped - with knowing references in early episodes. Sherrie Hewson, the former Coronation Street actress who is the hotel's new receptionist, speaks into the telephone: "Hello, Crossroads Hotel, can I help you?" It is a copy of the original series' opening line, with one change: Crossroads was then a motel.

webTitle: Smith plays down aid for digital TV

fields.headline: Smith plays down aid for digital TV
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Culture secretary Chris Smith yesterday played down the chances of direct government intervention to speed up the adoption of digital television.
fields.body:
Culture secretary Chris Smith yesterday played down the chances of direct government intervention to speed up the adoption of digital television.

Mr Smith, giving evidence to the Commons select committee on the communications white paper, was reluctant to give any commitment to funding the take up of digital TV ahead of the switch off of the analogue signal between 2006-2010.

"I wouldn't want to speculate on subsidies," he said. "That is a proposal which has been made by quite a number of people. But there are serious problems. At the moment set top boxes cost between £200 and £300, and it is almost certain that that cost will come tumbling down. But we don't know how fast or at what figure it will end up."

If the government put forward a proposal to subsidise digital set-top boxes it would make people wait before switching, he argued. "In this rapidly changing world it would be rather foolhardy to make decisions now."

The issue of analogue switch off has potentially explosive implications for the government in power. Analysts estimate that at least 20% of the population will not take pay-TV before switch off, leaving a question of who funds the set- top boxes, which will have to be given away.

Mr Smith said the BBC's role in encouraging people to take up digital TV would be a key consideration in his review of the corporation's proposed new services including BBC3 and BBC4.

Patricia Hewitt, the government's e-minister who was also at the committee, said she was exploring the possibility of Europe-wide regulation forcing manufacturers of television sets to make them compatible for digital signals.

"It is my understanding that we wouldn't be able to impose such a condition unilaterally but I have asked my officials to see if we should be pursuing this issue in Europe," she said.

webTitle: Germans reluctant to trade mark for euro

fields.headline: Most Germans fear euro is not up to beloved mark
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: The closer the date comes for the biggest currency changeover most Europeans have ever seen - the advent of euro notes and coins on January 1 next year - the more reluctant Germans seem to be to relinquish the mark.
fields.body:
The closer the date comes for the biggest currency changeover most Europeans have ever seen - the advent of euro notes and coins on January 1 next year - the more reluctant Germans seem to be to relinquish the mark.

In the latest survey by the Forsa polling institute 71% of those questioned said they would hold on to the mark if they had the choice. The figure rose to 80% among people over 60.

Only 27% were for the adoption of the euro, placing Germany 11th in the euro-enthusiasm ratings among the 12 countries that have agreed to adopt the single currency.

The fear of losing the mark is greatest in the formerly communist east, where the survey showed that 83% want to keep it.

In recognition of people's deep affection for the mark, which came into being more than 52 years ago, the Bundesbank is using a small part of its gold reserves to issue a commemorative 12-gram pure gold mark piece.

A million of these "farewell deutschmarks" are to be produced in the five state mints to go on sale this summer for between DM230 and 250 (£75-£83 at current rates), depending on the gold price at the time.

But while the authorities turn out this expensive keepsake, it is the ordinary mark in people's pockets that is the object of an outpouring of tributes.

Newspapers are counting down to the mark's disappearance, and columnists are lamenting its demise.

"In our memory it will remain an immense, rich, and wonderfully beautiful treasure," one wrote recently in Die Welt.

Dieter Lindenlaub, historian and archivist at the Bundesbank in Frankfurt, said: "The degree of identity attached to the D-mark is very high, because it's connected to a piece of positive German history" - namely the economy's strong recovery after the war.

"It is seen as an integral piece of Germany, and there is a strong sense that no other currency can offer us the [same] level of stability."

The deutschmark was born on June 21 1948, when a currency reform law was passed to replace the reichsmark. One hundred reichsmarks were worth 10 deutschmarks.

"It was a huge attempt to kick-start the economy after the war," Professor Lindenlaub said. "People initially saw themselves as victims of financial reform, but there was a general acceptance that we had to pay for the war."

By the beginning of 1950 the so-called economic miracle, the wirtschaftswunder, was well under way.

Prof Lindenlaub believes it will be far harder to persuade the Germans that conversion to the euro is a positive step.

"It was easier to build acceptance in 1948 because it was an attempt to make good money out of bad," he said. "Now the Germans widely believe to accept the euro is to turn good money into bad."

But anticipating the mark's death, the Bundesbank has awarded a contract to a Bremen firm to turn more than 3,000 tonnes of banknotes into the most richly denominated compost in the world.

webTitle: Britain must embrace euro, says EC president

fields.headline: Britain must embrace euro, says EC president
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown cannot hope to control the British economy as long as the United Kingdom remains outside the euro, European commission president Romano Prodi said today.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown cannot hope to control the British economy as long as the United Kingdom remains outside the euro, European commission president Romano Prodi said today.

"How can you control your economy being surrounded by the euro and not having your man inside the European Central bank?" Mr Prodi told a parliamentary press gallery lunch at Westminster. He went on: "The decisions are taken and will influence you. In practical terms this is the biggest loss of sovereignty."

Mr Prodi made clear that outside the euro, Britain had little influence when other nations were discussing European economic policy.

"When we are in the room in which we are 15 and then the British delegates and the Swedish and the Danes [also not in the euro] then get out and we have to decide on other issues, I'm sorry."

Mr Prodi added: "When you are a club you shape a debate in which you really create some sort of construction of policy. This is what's happening.

"This is what happens when they take a decision - there's no British [delegate] inside."

Mr Prodi stressed he was not attacking the right of states to maintain their sovereignty, nor criticising the present government, but simply stating facts.

He said all his life he had fought for political decisions to be taken at the lowest possible level and did not want to create a European superstate.

But the EC president threatened to ignite controversy over Europe still further by insisting countries had to address the issue of common taxation - a policy Tony Blair and Gordon Brown are fiercely opposed to.

"Tax is like sex, you cannot talk about it," said Mr Prodi.

"From now on in the future let us talk about tax."

Before his speech this afternoon, Mr Prodi had talks for 90 minutes with Mr Blair over breakfast in Downing Street.

A Number 10 spokesman said the two discussed a broad range of European issues, including "tangentially" the euro.

fields.headline: Ask Jack
fields.standfirst: Send your questions and comments to Jack.Schofield@guardian.co.uk. Published letters will be edited for brevity but please include full details with your original query
fields.trailText: Streaming madness | Unreadable
fields.body:
Streaming madness
I went to the BBC Education website to study one of the languages there. However, I am unable to access the audio and/or video sections. The prompt to "save to disk" is successful and files appear as icons on the desktop. Clicking on Open File, however, brings up a warning message: "Access to the device, path, or file is denied". I am running Windows 98. How can I access programs of this type? June Rayner
June.Rayner@tesco.net

Jack Schofield replies: The files are in RealMedia format, so you must install the free RealMedia player, RealPlayer 8 Basic, from www.real.com/player/index.html?src=010207realhome_2 (they make it hard to find: look in the grey band just above the Gold Pass box).

Unfortunately, RealPlayer will only allow you to view these audiovisual files as they are "streamed" to your computer. You cannot save them and watch offline, which would be more convenient. If you "save" a file, it is only a pointer, not the file itself.

Streambox www.streambox.com solved this problem by launching a test version of a VCR program that let users capture RealMedia streams. However, RealNetworks responded with a lawsuit that led to it being withdrawn.

Streambox VCR was a bit tricky to use. You had to start the RealMedia file, then look on your hard drive for the "stub" for that stream, usually in the Temporary Internet Files folder. Opening the stub in (say) Notepad showed the origin of the stream. For example, the great Coca Cola Hilltop advert might have an address such as rtsp://rmserv1.loc.gov/ammem/ccmp/komt1600.rm

Copy that address to Streambox VCR and you could capture the streaming file and save it to disk, where it could be played at any time.

The legal and financial settlement between RealNetworks and Streambox, announced late last year, should enable Streambox to produce a version of VCR that respects copy protection in streamed RealMedia. As far as I know, it has yet to appear.

The internet being what it is, copies of Streambox VCR version 1.2 are being circulated underground in a "cracked" version. Obviously no one would want to use that. Equally, no one would want to use the non-cracked version either, as it registers your name and email address with Streambox's server.

In the meantime, you could always ask the BBC to provide files that can be downloaded (eg avi or mpg files), or use a different streaming format, such as Microsoft's ASF. A program called ASF Recorder allows streaming format (asf/asx) files to be captured using a similar approach to Streambox VCR.

Unreadable
I have collected on disk several pages of a book in PDF files, but the screen image is nearly unreadable. Using Acrobat Reader 2.1, I find that I can only print a few lines from a page. I cannot select the text by highlighting it in the usual way, so I cannot copy the text to Word. I cannot even print the screen using the Print Screen key and transferring the text to WordPad. I should value any comments you may have. Leslie Hall
LEdwinHall@care4free.net

JS: Adobe's PDF (Portable Document Format) works well for converting things like brochures into digital files. Sadly, it is awkward for word processed text - unless the document's owner wants to prevent you from changing it. This may also stop you doing things such as searching the text, filing it in a database, using a screen reader to voice it, or converting it to Braille.

You may make better progress if you upgrade to the latest Acrobat Reader 4, which is available online or on computer magazine cover discs. However, in this case, it sounds as though the files do not contain any text at all, just low-quality scanned images (bitmaps) of pages.

Adobe is well aware that PDF files may be inaccessible to people with less than perfect eyesight, so it provides ways to convert them to plain text or web format (HTML). You can do this by entering the web address of a PDF file, by mailing the file to Adobe's server, or by downloading Acrobat Access for Windows and converting it yourself (there is no Mac version). Either way, multicolumn texts may not convert properly, and texts in non-Roman alphabets will not convert at all. See http://access.adobe.com/tools.html for details.

Of course, if the PDF file is password protected, you cannot convert it without the password. A quicker and easier solution is simply to delete PDF files when they arrive.

Time slips
Is it possible to set a limit on the number of minutes/ hours that I can play Patience or Minesweeper, other than by using non-existent self-control? Julian Dunn
eisendora@compuserve.com

JS: After I answered this question (January 18), I heard about a new program that does what you want. It is called PC Time Cop, and it is distributed by Access Technology Group. You can download a beta test (trial) copy from www.parental-control-software.com or www.pctimecop.co.uk

Reader tips
Many thanks to all the readers who wrote in with additional information about various points. On the topic of keyboard shortcuts, Peter Rowland recommends the guide to Microsoft Word 97 shortcuts at http://support.microsoft.com/support/kb/articles/Q157/9/35.asp, while Mike Hurden recommends downloading a free copy of WinKey. This lets you create your own "Windows + another" key combinations. Finally, several readers suggest eFax as a way of receiving faxes by email, instead of Yac. It also allows you to send faxes.

webTitle: Comment: Nato mocked those who claimed there was a plan for Caspian oil.

fields.headline: A discreet deal in the pipeline
fields.standfirst:
Nato mocked those who claimed there was a plan for Caspian oil

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Nato mocked those who claimed there was a plan for Caspian oil.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown knows precisely what he should do about BP. The company's £10bn profits are crying out for a windfall tax. Royalties and petroleum revenue tax, both lifted when the oil price was low, are in urgent need of reinstatement. These measures would be popular and fair. But, as all political leaders are aware, you don't mess with Big Oil.

During the 1999 Balkans war, some of the critics of Nato's intervention alleged that the western powers were seeking to secure a passage for oil from the Caspian sea. This claim was widely mocked. The foreign secretary Robin Cook observed that "there is no oil in Kosovo". This was, of course, true but irrelevant. An eminent commentator for this paper clinched his argument by recording that the Caspian sea is "half a continent away, lodged between Iran and Turkmenistan".

For the past few weeks, a freelance researcher called Keith Fisher has been doggedly documenting a project which has, as far as I can discover, has been little-reported in any British, European or American newspaper. It is called the Trans-Balkan pipeline, and it's due for approval at the end of next month. Its purpose is to secure a passage for oil from the Caspian sea.

The line will run from the Black sea port of Burgas to the Adriatic at Vlore, passing through Bulgaria, Macedonia and Albania. It is likely to become the main route to the west for the oil and gas now being extracted in central Asia. It will carry 750,000 barrels a day: a throughput, at current prices, of some $600m a month.

The project is necessary, according to a paper published by the US Trade and Development Agency last May, because the oil coming from the Caspian sea "will quickly surpass the safe capacity of the Bosphorus as a shipping lane". The scheme, the agency notes, will "provide a consistent source of crude oil to American refineries", "provide American companies with a key role in developing the vital east-west corridor", "advance the privatisation aspirations of the US government in the region" and "facilitate rapid integration" of the Balkans "with western Europe".

In November 1998, Bill Richardson, then US energy secretary, spelt out his policy on the extraction and transport of Caspian oil. "This is about America's energy security," he explained. "It's also about preventing strategic inroads by those who don't share our values. We're trying to move these newly independent countries toward the west.

"We would like to see them reliant on western commercial and political interests rather than going another way. We've made a substantial political investment in the Caspian, and it's very important to us that both the pipeline map and the politics come out right."

The project has been discussed for years. The US trade agency notes that the Trans-Balkan pipeline "will become a part of the region's critical east-west Corridor 8 infrastructure ... This transportation corridor was approved by the transport ministers of the European Union in April 1994". The pipeline itself, the agency says, has also been formally supported "since 1994". The first feasibility study, backed by the US, was conducted in 1996.

The pipeline does not pass through the former Yugoslavia, but there's no question that it featured prominently in Balkan war politics. On December 9 1998, the Albanian president attended a meeting about the scheme in Sofia, and linked it inextricably to Kosovo. "It is my personal opinion," he noted, "that no solution confined within Serbian borders will bring lasting peace." The message could scarcely have been blunter: if you want Albanian consent for the Trans-Balkan pipeline, you had better wrest Kosovo out of the hands of the Serbs.

In July 1993, a few months before the corridor project was first formally approved, the US sent peacekeeping troops to the Balkans. They were stationed not in the conflict zones in which civilians were being rounded up and killed, but on the northern borders of Macedonia. There were several good reasons for seeking to contain Serb expansionism, but we would be foolish to imagine that a putative $600m-a-month commercial operation did not number among them. The pipeline would have been impossible to finance while the Balkans were in turmoil.

I can't tell you that the war in the former Yugoslavia was fought solely in order to secure access to oil from new and biddable states in central Asia. But in the light of these findings, can anyone now claim that it was not?

webTitle: Michael Stone to face new trial

fields.headline: Stone to face new trial in September
fields.trailText: Michael Stone, the man jailed in 1998 for the murders of Lin Russell and her daughter Megan and for the attempted murder of her other daughter Josie Russell, will be tried in Birmingham next September after three appeal court judges ruled yesterday that he could expect a fair hearing.
fields.body:
Michael Stone, the man jailed in 1998 for the murders of Lin Russell and her daughter Megan and for the attempted murder of her other daughter Josie Russell, will be tried in Birmingham next September after three appeal court judges ruled yesterday that he could expect a fair hearing.

Following the quashing of Stone's conviction last week, Lord Justice Kennedy, Mr Justice Maurice Kay and Mrs Justice Hallett gave their reasons for not freeing Stone but making him face another trial.

Lord Justice Kennedy, reading from a 15-page written judgment, said the central question in a new trial would not be Stone's character, but whether the evidence of the key prosecution witness could be believed.

He said that "in justice to the Russell family and the wider community" there should be a retrial to answer that question.

Stone was given three life sentences at Maidstone crown court in 1998 after being convicted of the two murders, and the attempted murder of Josie near the Russell family home at Chillenden, Kent, in 1996.

The judges ruled last week that Stone's appeal "must succeed" on the basis of the unreliability of the key prosecution witness Barry Thompson, who gave evidence at the trial alleging Stone had confessed to the killings in prison.

Yesterday, Lord Justice Kennedy said that "the evidence of Thompson has been shown to be hopelessly unreliable".

Stone's counsel, William Clegg QC, had argued that he could not have a fair trial because of "prejudicial" material in the media following the original trial. But Nigel Sweeney QC, for the crown, submitted that a fair trial was possible.

Stone was given three life sentences for the two murders and attempted murder. Lin, Megan and Josie Russell were tied up and beaten with a hammer in a 15-minute attack.

Lord Justice Kennedy said the question for the court was whether it could be satisfied "on a balance of probabilities" that if a jury later this year returned a verdict of guilty, "the effect of the pre-trial publicity between October 1998 and February 2001 will be such as to render that verdict or those verdicts unsafe".

He went on: "We accept that the early publicity was sensational, possibly in parts inaccurate, and extended far beyond what a jury in 2001 might normally be told, but, at least in so far as it was accurate, it was legitimate."

The judge said: "The retrial will not start until nearly three years after the October 1998 publicity, which is the principal target of complaint, and people do forget. Even if they do not forget entirely the passage of time makes it easier for them to set aside that which they are told to disregard."

Outside the court, Stone's sister Barbara said she was "a bit disappointed" that certain evidence had not come out, "but we are still all really pleased the conviction has been quashed".

webTitle: Paris unveil tribute to princess Diana

fields.headline: Paris tribute to princess
fields.trailText: The official memorial dedicated to Diana, Princess of Wales, by the city in which she died was unveiled yesterday as the mayor of Paris, Jean Tiberi, and the British ambassador, Sir Michael Jay, inaugurated a 1,200 square yard flower and vegetable garden for schoolchildren.
fields.body:
The official memorial dedicated to Diana, Princess of Wales, by the city in which she died was unveiled yesterday as the mayor of Paris, Jean Tiberi, and the British ambassador, Sir Michael Jay, inaugurated a 1,200 square yard flower and vegetable garden for schoolchildren.

Plans for Le jardin du Clos des Blanc-Manteaux, a £930,000 "nature initiation centre" in the courtyard of a disused school in the ancient Marais district, had been derided by French and British opponents as a mean and inappropriate tribute.

A cabbage patch complete with compost heap was, they said, no way to honour a princess who had no obvious connection to the Marais and no known interest in vegetables. She once said "I never cook", and left the gardening to her husband.

But Mr Tiberi said the classic walled garden was a fitting memorial to Diana "who showed great interest in the welfare of children as well as in the environment."

Reading a brief message from the royal family and Diana's family, the Spencers, Sir Michael said there could be "no better tribute to her memory than a garden in which young children can play and learn about nature." Paris normally allows five years before establishing an official memorial, but made an exception for the princess because of her immense popularity. The centre, approved by the royal family, the Spencers and the British government, will be open to the public only at weekends.

Several miles from the underpass where Diana died on August 31 1997, it is unlikely to distract the thousands of pilgrims who leave bouquets and messages on the gilded flame by the Pont de l'Alma that has become her unofficial shrine.

webTitle: Engineering and technology board to be created

fields.headline: Engineers refurbished
fields.trailText: The government yesterday sought to improve the image of industry's scientists by announcing creation of an engineering and technology board.
fields.body:
The government yesterday sought to improve the image of industry's scientists by announcing creation of an engineering and technology board.

The organisation would bring together new and old economies while assisting professionals in marketing their skills, said science minister Lord Sainsbury.

This is the first response to the findings of the group chaired by Robert Hawley, chairman of the Engineering Council and Taylor Woodrow. The group was established 16 months ago to revamp the Engineering Council.

fields.headline: Any more fares?
fields.standfirst:
The Cinderella of the transport services comes under scrutiny with Labour's 10-year plan, but it remains a poor relation to the trains

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The Cinderella of the transport services comes under scrutiny with Labour's 10-year plan, but it remains a poor relation to the trains.
fields.body:
Two out of three journeys by public transport are made by bus. Yet buses are the Cinderella of travel, a poor relation to trains. Labour's 10-year transport plan promised £60bn in public and private investment in railways, delivering a 50% increase in passenger miles. The equivalent target for buses is a 10% increase in passenger journeys, less than the 17% forecast for overall growth in road traffic. The only new money specifically for buses in the 10-year plan is £40m for an urban bus "challenge fund", together with a previously announced increase for rural services.

While the trains target was based on an analytical model, the target for buses was plucked out of the air, except for London. Here the 10-year plan projects 50% growth in bus journeys both into central London and across the conurbation. Given that the capital accounts for 30% of bus journeys in Britain, government planners seem to be assuming bus use in the rest of the country will continue to fall.

All local transport authorities will be required to develop bus strategies as part of their statutory local transport plans, but their powers are weak. Under the latest transport act, "quality partnerships" may see councils requiring higher vehicle standards and better customer care from bus operators in return for bus lanes and other infrastructure improvements. Councils will seek better information for passengers and transferability of tickets between operators but the fundamentals of fares and frequencies will remain in the hands of the private operators.

Councils may pay for concessionary fares. A national minimum half fare concession for pensioners and disabled people will apply from April. Concessions may be extended to children and job seekers. A half fare concession for 16 to 18-year-olds in education could be the basis for bringing in the Social Exclusion Unit's idea of a "youth card" combining entitlement to college courses with cut price travel and other discounts.

Since the deregulation of bus services outside London under Tory legislation in 1985, bus use has fallen by a third. The chart shows the steep fall in the urban areas of England. But in London it has increased by 13%. The capital is good bus territory with its high population density, traffic congestion and low car ownership. The big thing is that bus services in London were not deregulated. They were contracted out, so that the operators compete for the licences to run each route for a fixed term, usually five years.

London has maintained the benefits of a planned network with fares and ticketing integrated with rail and tube and savings have been made thanks to competition between firms to operate services. Wages and conditions have also been driven down, as they have outside London. Bus drivers in Britain now earn on average about half the hourly rate of train drivers. This is an unsustainable position in a buoyant labour market as well as undesirable for the quality of services.

The secret of London's success is a comprehensive approach to the improvement of bus services and the mayor has acquired extensive transport powers. They include enforcing a network of bus lanes to make services faster and more reliable: the power that London boroughs have to use cameras and impose penalty charges should be extended to all local authorities. London is also leading the way with the introduction of smartcard ticketing and congestion charging.

Alone among countries in the European Union the UK has seen significant decline in bus use since the 70s. In Italy and Denmark passenger miles have more than doubled. A variety of factors underpin our poor performance. One is that no other EU nation has opted for deregulation, though a number have followed London's example by introducing competition to operate services. The UK could also learn from performance-incentive regimes, such as Copenhagen's where every three months the best operator gets a bonus, based on customer satisfaction surveys.

Another major factor is that fare subsidies are seen as a normal part of life on mainland Europe, as are the local taxes to pay for them. The low fares policies pursued in London, South Yorkshire and other metropolitan areas were brought to an end by the nationalisation of London Transport and deregulation outside London in the mid 80s. Since then, average bus fares have increased by more than 30% in real terms.

New research suggests that the long-term effect of fare increases is worse than previously thought, typically a 9% decrease in passengers for a 10% increase in fares. There is no mechanism for general fare subsidies under bus quality partnerships. By contrast, key rail fares are pegged to increase by 1% less than inflation each year as part of a passenger franchise.

The government should have the same ambition for buses as for trains. The social case is strong given that people on low incomes make three times as many journeys by bus as those on high incomes, who make more than four times as many journeys by train. The transport act includes provisions for contracts between councils and firms which could see them introducing regulated networks - but ministers are holding this power in reserve. Without such powers and better funding, even the government's small ambitions for buses are not likely to be fulfilled.

 Tony Grayling is at the Institute of Public Policy Research. Any More Fares? Delivering Better Bus Services is available from Central Books 0208 986 5488.

fields.headline: Somerfield's £26m fight back
fields.trailText: Ailing supermarket group Somerfield, the fifth biggest grocery chain, has launched a discount campaign to pull in customers and restore the group's fortunes.
fields.body:
Ailing supermarket group Somerfield, the fifth biggest grocery chain, has launched a discount campaign to pull in customers and restore the group's fortunes.

It said its Megadeals scheme, which replaces its PriceCheck promotion, would save shoppers £26m in the first two weeks. The Premier loyalty card would be dropped to help pay for the scheme.

Somerfield has been battered by the tough price competition between its bigger rivals in recent years - and by an ill thought-out merger with Kwik-Save which hit sales at both chains. It recently installed new management but slumped to a £22m loss in the first half of last year and had a bad Christmas - with like-for-like sales down 1.1%.

It said it was "turning up the heat" on its rivals, which recently announced price discounts. Associate marketing director Richard Smith said the cuts would absorb £500m of the group's margin, but sales should increase.

Somerfield's strategy is one of high-low pricing - with big discounts on selected lines to pull in shoppers, but higher "background prices". Safeway is pursuing the same strategy but Asda and Tesco use EDLP - everyday low prices - which aims to provide cheaper shopping across the board. Asda last month announced it was reducing prices by £52m over the first three months of 2001, while Tesco said it would cut £70m off a range of products.

Somerfield shares closed up 1p at 97p. Ten months ago they were at 50p, though two years ago they stood at 450p.

webTitle: McLaughlin talks to Bloody Sunday inquiry

fields.headline: Sinn Fein chairman says he ran into 'turkey shoot' by soldiers
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: Mitchel McLaughlin, the chairman of Sinn Fein, yesterday denied he had belonged to the IRA or knew anything about its members or their activities on Bloody Sunday.
fields.body:
Mitchel McLaughlin, the chairman of Sinn Fein, yesterday denied he had belonged to the IRA or knew anything about its members or their activities on Bloody Sunday.

He told the new inquiry into the deaths of 14 unarmed Catholic men that it had been like "running into a turkey shoot" when British troops opened fire in Derry's Bogside on January 30 1972. At one point he mistakenly believed his father had been shot right in front of him.

Mr McLaughlin, who was 26 at the time, claimed in a written statement that a soldier had made a "serious effort" to blow his head off. But in the witness box this week, in Derry's Guildhall, he admitted the soldier might have been firing a warning shot to scare people away.

However, he insisted there was an understanding that the Provisional IRA would stay away from the civil rights demonstration, and that there would have been fewer people on the march if they had thought paramilitaries would be present.

Raymond McCartney, a former hunger striker and an IRA "prison commander", was among the packed public gallery as Mr McLaughlin, a Northern Ireland Assemblyman for the Foyle constituency, took the stand at the tribunal, chaired by Lord Saville. Asked if, at the time, he had any knowledge at all about active IRA members, the original Officials or the Provisionals who split from them, Mr McLaughlin replied: "No, none whatsoever."

Mr McLaughlin was also questioned about a book by Niall O'Dochartaigh, entitled From Civil Rights to Armalites: Derry and the Birth of the Irish Troubles, which quoted him as saying he had joined the republican movement in 1966, and stayed with the Officials after the 1970 spilt but then later joined the Provisionals.

But he was adamant that he belonged only to Provisional Sinn Fein, and while others might have been influenced by Bloody Sunday to join the IRA, he was not, and had deliberately not become involved in discussions about what others had done.

He was shown a transcript of an early 1970s television interview of his Stormont colleague, Martin McGuinness, now education minister, being asked as "officer commanding the Derry part of the IRA Provisional operation, whether the bombing is likely to stop, in response to any public demand?" Mr McGuinness was quoted as replying: "Well, we will always take on the considerations, the feelings of the people of Derry, and these feelings will be passed on to our GHQ in Dublin, you know."

But when questioned by Edmund Lawson QC, representing most of the soldiers, Mr McLaughlin insisted that it was the first time he had ever seen the clip.

Pressed again, he said: "There were many people and some of them would have been regarded as very foolish indeed to have claimed that they were members of the IRA. My impression of the IRA is that people who would talk like that would not in fact be likely to be members of the IRA. So, I did not know, to my certain knowledge, of any individual who was a member of the IRA."

Counsel for five Official IRA men, who were present on Bloody Sunday, asked the inquiry on Monday that they be given anonymity in return for highly significant evidence.

Earlier, lawyers criticised the wall of silence surrounding IRA activity on the day.
fields.bodyText: Mitchel McLaughlin, the chairman of Sinn Fein, yesterday denied he had belonged to the IRA or knew anything about its members or their activities on Bloody Sunday. He told the new inquiry into the deaths of 14 unarmed Catholic men that it had been like "running into a turkey shoot" when British troops opened fire in Derry's Bogside on January 30 1972. At one point he mistakenly believed his father had been shot right in front of him. Mr McLaughlin, who was 26 at the time, claimed in a written statement that a soldier had made a "serious effort" to blow his head off. But in the witness box this week, in Derry's Guildhall, he admitted the soldier might have been firing a warning shot to scare people away. However, he insisted there was an understanding that the Provisional IRA would stay away from the civil rights demonstration, and that there would have been fewer people on the march if they had thought paramilitaries would be present. Raymond McCartney, a former hunger striker and an IRA "prison commander", was among the packed public gallery as Mr McLaughlin, a Northern Ireland Assemblyman for the Foyle constituency, took the stand at the tribunal, chaired by Lord Saville. Asked if, at the time, he had any knowledge at all about active IRA members, the original Officials or the Provisionals who split from them, Mr McLaughlin replied: "No, none whatsoever." Mr McLaughlin was also questioned about a book by Niall O'Dochartaigh, entitled From Civil Rights to Armalites: Derry and the Birth of the Irish Troubles, which quoted him as saying he had joined the republican movement in 1966, and stayed with the Officials after the 1970 spilt but then later joined the Provisionals. He was shown a transcript of an early 1970s television interview of his Stormont colleague, Martin McGuinness, now education minister, being asked as "officer commanding the Derry part of the IRA Provisional operation, whether the bombing is likely to stop, in response to any public demand?" Mr McGuinness was quoted as replying: "Well, we will always take on the considerations, the feelings of the people of Derry, and these feelings will be passed on to our GHQ in Dublin, you know." But when questioned by Edmund Lawson QC, representing most of the soldiers, Mr McLaughlin insisted that it was the first time he had ever seen the clip. Pressed again, he said: "There were many people and some of them would have been regarded as very foolish indeed to have claimed that they were members of the IRA. My impression of the IRA is that people who would talk like that would not in fact be likely to be members of the IRA. So, I did not know, to my certain knowledge, of any individual who was a member of the IRA." Counsel for five Official IRA men, who were present on Bloody Sunday, asked the inquiry on Monday that they be given anonymity in return for highly significant evidence. Earlier, lawyers criticised the wall of silence surrounding IRA activity on the day.

fields.headline: Plastic that heals like skin
fields.trailText: A smart type of plastic which automatically "heals" itself like human skin when cracked or broken has been developed by scientists, it was disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
A smart type of plastic which automatically "heals" itself like human skin when cracked or broken has been developed by scientists, it was disclosed yesterday.

The material, successfully tested by researchers in the United States, begins to mend as soon as it is cut, eventually looking as good as new.

The substance, containing embedded microcapsules filled with a special healing agent, could mark a revolution in materials for systems that cannot easily be repaired once in use.

Examples include the components of spacecraft and space stations, satellites, rocket motors, artificial organs and bridge supports.

Plastics are made from linked chains of polymer building blocks which are susceptible to cracking caused by vibration, bending and heat.

Often the damage is deep in a structure, where it is difficult to detect and almost impossible to repair. The tiny capsules peppering the new material contain a repair fluid that renews the building blocks, making the plastic appear to "heal up".

Scott White, professor of aeronautical and astronautical engineering, who led the research, said the technology would reduce wear and tear and could increase the lifetime of structural components by as much as two or three times.

In fracture tests, self-healed composites recovered as much as 75% of their original strength, the scientists reported in the journal Nature. A major challenge for the researchers was developing the right sized microcapsules. Too big, and they would have weakened the material.

Richard Wool, from Cara Plastics Inc. and the University of Delaware, Newark, said the worldwide market for plastic composites was huge. Some 20m tonnes of composites were used each year in civil engineering, aerospace and defence, offshore oil exploration, electronics and biomedicine.

Writing in Nature, he said: "The concept of self-healing composites cuts against the grain of current material design principles, but has far reaching consequences for improving product safety and reliability."
Press Association

webTitle: Russian warplanes alarm Oslo and Tokyo

fields.headline: Russian warplanes alarm Oslo and Tokyo
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Russia sent a number of nuclear-capable and supersonic bomber aircraft on exercises along the Japanese and Norwegian coasts yesterday for the first time in years, triggering protests from Tokyo about violations of airspace, and the scrambling by Norway of F-16 fighters to ward off the Russians.
fields.body:
Russia sent a number of nuclear-capable and supersonic bomber aircraft on exercises along the Japanese and Norwegian coasts yesterday for the first time in years, triggering protests from Tokyo about violations of airspace, and the scrambling by Norway of F-16 fighters to ward off the Russians.

The Japanese defence ministry reported two brief incursions into Japanese airspace in incidents that recalled the cat-and-mouse games of the cold war, first of four Tu22 Backfire bombers and then of another two Russian aircraft about two and a half hours later.

Tokyo said it was the first such incident in six years involving Russian aircraft. The timing of the incidents was odd since President Vladimir Putin of Russia and Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori of Japan had just concluded weeks of tortuous negotiations and agreed on a summit in the Russian far east set for next month.

The Japanese foreign ministry summoned the Russian ambassador in Tokyo to lodge a protest about the airspace violations.

The incursions are said to have taken place off the northern tip of Japan on the other side of Hokkaido from the disputed Kurile islands which Moscow seized in the second world war and whose return Tokyo is demanding. Each incursion was said to have lasted three minutes.

The Russian defence minister, Igor Sergeyev, categorically denied any airspace violations, declaring that six Russian bombers were engaged in exercises hugging the Japanese coastline, but not intruding.

"We analysed all our flights," Marshal Sergeyev told the Interfax news agency. "There were no violations."

A few months ago in the far east, Russian Sukhoi-27 fighters buzzed an American aircraft carrier several times, suggesting that under President Putin, the Russian air force was behaving more boldly and assertively than it did throughout the 1990s.

At the other end of Russia, meanwhile, Norwegian military officials said they had scrambled two F-16 fighters to keep a watch on two Russian nuclear-capable Tu-160 Blackjack bombers in international airspace close to Norway's northern border.

Norwegian officers said Moscow had told Norway and Britain that its aircraft could approach both countries' coasts this week as it was stepping up air exercises from its Kola peninsula bases in the Arctic where the nuclear submarine Kursk sank last August.

webTitle: Comment: Dr Oliver James is free to make outrageous comments on Peter Mandelson. But he should be gagged.

fields.headline: What's up, doc?
fields.standfirst: Dr Oliver James is free to make outrageous comments on Peter Mandelson. But he should be gagged
fields.trailText: Dr Oliver James is free to make outrageous comments on Peter Mandelson. But he should be gagged.
fields.body:
Dr Oliver James, the television psychologist, is used to remote diagnosis. A lack of personal experience of his subject presents no obstacle to Dr James, who has delivered himself of the view that Peter Mandelson was at a "high risk of suicide attempt" because of his sacking from the cabinet. Without the slightest professional qualm, he further stated that Mandelson is likely to suffer "a terrible depression" and that there is some kind of "design fault" in him.

The only risk to Mandelson's health is this egregiously self-confident doctor who has no business diagnosing anyone - whether a private individual or public figure - on the basis of one encounter and then giving his opinion to journalists on the Sunday Telegraph. But because Dr James interviewed Mr Mandelson for a 1997 TV show, he claims he is able to fathom that his "whole identity has been built around his relationship with his mother and grandfather [Herbert Morrison]", and that he is trying to evade the truth about the deep fault in his personality.

Dr James, apparently an expert on everything from paedophilia to the meaning of Princess Diana's death, is not a member of the British Psychological Society, which forbids such behaviour for two very good reasons. If Mr Mandelson was indeed a suicide risk or vulnerable to depression, nothing could be more dangerous than for a doctor to announce it in the press. But since Mandelson is suffering from strain - a natural reaction to his summary dismissal - it is extremely presumptuous of James to suggest severe, long-term instability. In other words James was either downright irresponsible, or he was wrong. Whichever way you look at it, he infringed Mr Mandelson's rights and dignity.

Worse, perhaps, is that this garrulous professional allowed himself to be used in support of a Downing Street whispering campaign which, from the start, had been hinting that Mr Mandelson was detached and not quite himself.

It seems extraordinary that he can get away with this behaviour which in most areas of medicine would be regarded as unethical. But there is of course no professional body to which psychologists have to belong to practice and which has statutory power to limit the profession's taste for public speculation about an individual's mental health. Curiously, it is precisely James's ignorance of Mandelson's state of mind - he is not a client - which allows him to blather on without breaking the sacred confidentiality between patient and doctor.

These reasons might suggest to Dr James that he shuts up. But this is an unlikely course for him. If for a moment we turn the tables and analyse the good doctor's behaviour, some may see signs of acute egotism, propelled by an unrealistic view of his own importance. Also suggested by his outpourings is a difficult relationship with authority - a sense that he wishes to control prominent people with his professional definitions and thereby exercise power.

Perhaps this is unfair, but it's no less just than his effusions to the Sunday Telegraph. What one can say about James, and the other clinical psychologists and psychiatrists who make a living in the media, Is that they are often profoundly silly. James is, after all, the man who on one occasion attacked the media's obsession with child murderers, yet the next day contributed to the unhealthy interest with an article on this precise subject in the Daily Express.

On that day he wrote that Sarah Payne's naked body "may indicate that he wanted power over her, or that he wanted to remove any material which could contain DNA". Following this, the ridiculous James gave an interview to the Today programme in which he demanded: "Why do we care whether she was wearing clothes?" When confronted with this kind of feverish inconsistency in a patient, James would conclude some kind of personality disorder. My own view is that this restless attitudinising is the mark of a split personality - one half is trying to supply professional views, albeit simplistic ones, while the other has a keen respect for a newspaper's cheque book.

On this occasion Dr James generously gave his material to the Sunday Telegraph, which deemed this intrusive rubbish to be so good that it was placed as a news story on the front page.

Despite James's eminence in the community of media shrinks, his presence alone in the story was not quite enough for the newspaper and so it consulted Peter Mandelson's former assistant, Derek Draper, who said: "Subconsciously, he is trying to attract Tony Blair's attention. He is like a neglected child, who misbehaves just to get noticed, because getting a smack is better than being ignored." Draper, once a lobbyist then an art historian for a brief moment, is now - yes, you've guessed it - a psychology student.

One day he may be hanging a brass plate on the door and making regular contributions to the papers like the great Dr Oliver James. Let's hope by then that psychologists are constrained by law from offering such devastating unethical opinions.

fields.headline: West rebukes Israel's assassins
fields.standfirst:
Major powers declare that murdering Palestinian fighters is illegal, but Israelis support the state's policy

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: International opprobrium was directed at Israel yesterday for its state-approved assassinations of suspected terrorists - a practice widely regarded as illegal.
fields.body:
International opprobrium was directed at Israel yesterday for its state-approved assassinations of suspected terrorists - a practice widely regarded as illegal.

A Foreign Office spokesman said the British government was shocked by what it described as the "murder" of one of Yasser Arafat's bodyguards by Israeli forces on Tuesday and of nine Israeli soldiers by a Palestinian yesterday.

"We condemn all acts of violence and urge both sides to refrain from reprisals. Neither side will gain from an escalation of the violence," the spokesman said.

Earlier, the outgoing Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, had publicly congratulated Israeli forces on the killing of the bodyguard, Massoud Ayad, whose car was rocketed by two helicopters.

Yesterday's attack, in which a Palestinian driver ploughed into Israeli soldiers at a bus stop, is thought to be a reprisal for Ayad's killing.

"This is exactly the kind of escalation we had feared," said a European diplomat close to recent peace negotiations.

Mr Barak's security adviser, Danny Yatom, defended the assassination of Ayad, telling Israel Radio: "We don't take pride in liquidating terrorists. We are in the midst of a battle, in the midst of a war against terrorism, and in this war we must strike at those who [threaten Israel]."

He described Mr Ayad, 53, an "arch terrorist" linked to the Lebanon-based organisation Hizbollah.

Britain has also backed one of the strongest statements yet from the European Union. In a declaration issued by current president Sweden, the EU said it "deplores the practice of so-called "eliminations" or extra-judicial killings of Palestinians carried out by Israeli security forces".

The EU, which is Israel's biggest trading partner, reiterated "its strongly held opinion that Israel's policy in this regard is unacceptable and contrary to the rule of law".

It continued: "The European Union urges Israel to cease this practice and thus respect international law."

The United States, while also condemning Palestinian violence, made clear its disapproval of the assassinations.

State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said: "The use of Israeli helicopter gunships, Palestinian attacks against settlements and motorists, the use of mortars by Palestinians and the targeted killings by the Israeli Defence Force ... are producing a new cycle of action or reaction which can become impossible to control."

Mr Boucher added that the new Secretary of State, Colin Powell, who is due to visit the Middle East next week, had spoken several times "about the need to avoid these kind of actions".

Apart from the risk of provoking reprisals which escalate the violence, liquidations have also caused unintended casualties.

Israel began selective assassinations of suspected senior Intifada militants in November, sending helicopter gunships to kill Hussein Abayat in Bethlehem on the same day that Mr Arafat was visiting the White House in Washington.

On that occasion, the rocket which hit the vehicle in which Mr Abayat was travelling also killed two elderly Palestinian women nearby and injured 10 other people.

More than 20 Palestinians have been liquidated by Israeli forces in targeted attacks.

Under international law, the assassinations are illegal unless the Israelis and Palestinians are considered to be at war.

Colonel Daniel Reisner, the Israeli military's head of international law, wrote recently in a briefing document: "International law actually only recognises two situations: peace and war. But life isn't as simple as that."

He continued: "We have reached the decision that the current situation has more of a semblance of war than of peace. As a result, we are also applying the principles applicable to warfare to the current situation."

This led him to conclude that the assassination of various Palestinian activists and militia leaders could be justified under the rules of war.

"You are allowed to target combatants," he wrote. "In the current situation, people who attack us have been identified by us as combatants. As a result we view them as legitimate targets. That specific individual falls under that category, therefore he was attacked and killed."

For the Israelis, one problem with this interpretation is that it would also have to apply equally to the Palestinians.

Palestinians would then be legally entitled to kill Israeli soldiers (as happened yesterday) and anyone else they regard as a combatant, such as armed settlers.

The death toll so far

 February 13 2001: Massoud Ayad killed by rocket attack.

 December 31 2000: Thabet Thabet shot dead.

 December 17: Samih Maliabi killed by bomb - possibly a booby-trapped mobile phone.

 December 14: Hani Abu Bakra shot dead by anti-terror police unit.

 December 13: Abbas al-Ewiwi shot dead by snipers.

 December 12: Yusuf Abu Swayeh ambushed by elite Kingfisher undercover unit.

 December 11:Anwar Hamran shot by Israeli forces. Mahmoud al-Mughrabi shot by Israeli undercover unit.

 November 23: Ibrahim Bani Odeh killed by bomb, most likely detonated by Israelis.

 November 22: Jamal Abdel-Razak ambushed by Israeli soldiers.

 November 9: Hussein Abayat died in rocket attack.

Source: The Palestinian Human Rights Monitoring Group.

webTitle: Comment: Mr Blair must speak out on Europe - it will be a winner

fields.headline: Mr Blair must speak out on Europe - it will be a winner
fields.standfirst:
The euro is dividing the Tories on both the left and the right

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: The euro is dividing the Tories on both the left and the right.
fields.body:
When Tony Blair said a week ago that he would assess the economic case for entry into the euro within two years of the election, the only resonance came from the reactions of his enemies. His words weren't a serious departure. Perhaps he didn't know when he would say them, but it was always his plan to say something soon. To wait until the brink of the campaign to declare what was meant by the sheltering mantra "early in the next parliament" would have been politically crazy. Knowing he would be dogged for an answer, he needed to supply it before the question became a focus of obsessive and sceptical attention.

The response, though, mixed outrage with incredulity. The sceptic press couldn't believe Mr Blair had dared escape the box they'd put him in. By promising an assessment, he promises also a decision, yes or no, on a referendum, which they've long reported he was going to dodge. They thought their polls and their power had trapped him into endless prevarication. His lucid statement of the fairly obvious prompted sulphuric rumblings from these victims of his presumption.

For sceptics who've kept their heads, it should also provoke alarm. For the electoral equation is changing. Specifying the assessment periodis a way of reclaiming the initiative. As regards Europe, the election looks as though it is going to do a lot more harm than good to the Conservatives. Awareness is dawning among anti-Europeans in and out of the party that, far from validating their belief in the irresistible potency of their cause, the coming contest will probably do the opposite.

First, William Hague is going to lose it. The margin could be large, and it might be massive. Though Hague is said to be the only man alive who doesn't believe this, he doesn't always talk that way. His very response to Blair's statement spoke triumphantly about the pound now being on the verge of death, as if to prove the point he'd always made about the covert iniquity of Labour's secret agenda. This doomy epitaph didn't come from a winner. The premise of what Hague said seemed to be that Labour would win not only the election but the referendum too. No doubt that's not what he means. But electoral defeat will have major consequences.

For, secondly, the Conservative election campaign will have focused heavily on Europe. Hague is determined to make it one of the front-line questions. The further Labour invades Tory territory on domestic issues, with such things as the semi-abolition of comprehensive schooling, the more likely he is to be driven in the direction of what is in any case an idée fixe . He's barely capable of extempore utterance these days without banging on about the pound. The tactical error of concentrating on an issue that is remote from most people's real concerns is compounded by the strategic disaster that looms, of a big defeat associated with a cause that has to be fought all over again at the referendum. This is why some shadow cabinet people would prefer to find something else to talk about. They're seeing clearly the damage the first contest could do to the second. Surrounding the leadership are parliamentary candidates who want to go further than the official line, and insist the euro poses a constitutional threat which must "never" be accepted. The Tory split on the left, with the Clarke-Heseltine faction, is about to be mirrored, as personal election manifestos are published, by a split on the right, which Hague will find harder to handle. If Sunday's performance with Jonathan Dimbleby is anything to go by, he has trouble himself, when under audience pressure, explaining why he regards the euro as a monstrous threat to sovereignty -yet might change his mind in five years' time.

I t's therefore wrong to see Europe as an electoral issue that will give the Conservatives a fillip in the country. On the contrary, it seems destined to cause them nothing but trouble in the short term and the long: the handmaiden of division and the mother of defeat. But there's a message to the other side as well, as Blair circles his own strategic conundrums.

If he's to capitalise on this projection of Tory catastrophe, it seems more than ever necessary to be proactive in helping it along. Blair should not meet Hague's obsessional challenge with an equally fetishistic silence. To be seen to run away from an inconvenient question is bad enough when defeat might beckon, but absurd when victory is certain and the question need not be inconvenient at all. Indeed, there could not be a better moment than the election campaign for the setting out of a measured explanation of the visionary case for strengthening not weakening Britain's European connection. It would be the proper prelude for what is to follow. For Labour, as for the Tories, the link between the first and second contests is in truth indissoluble.

Another factor should add momentum. Blair's setting of the limit to "within" two years is a necessary piece of caution that may have to be revised. The case for an earlier rather than later economic assessment, and gauging of the final judgment, could become pressing.

As several economists, including sceptic camp-followers, have now pronounced, convergence between the island and mainland economies is approaching fast. Insofar as the five economic tests can be objectively measured, they may soon be as close to satisfaction as anyone but an unremitting europhobe could hope they might reach. The politics also are likely to be not merely favourable but compelling quite soon after the election: more so, again, than could reliably be expected at any other time.

Positive and negative politics point in the same direction. An election the Tories have lost heavily in the circumstances outlined here will leave the main political force for a "no" vote seriously destabilised. The moment will be ripe. But there's another consideration. An assessment delayed for a full two years could not produce a referendum in time to see the single currency in place before the next election. I know senior Tories who are determined to reject a positive referendum result, if it is narrow or if an English no is wiped out by a Celtic yes, until the last pound has been liquidated. If the euro notes and coins are not in place before the election after next, don't count on the referendum finally laying this most bitter of questions to rest.

This is the case for an early rather than a late referendum. If Labour wins big, I believe it will be the only choice the government can make - unless it opts for an entry into the euro indefinitely delayed. If the moment is missed, that delay could be for a decade or more. Self-exclusion, once survived for a few months and then years of the euro becoming the only coinage in Europe, may come to seem the cosy option. The slow sundering from Europe would begin. This is not what Mr Blair, or anyone who matters in the government, wants. All the electoral signals are now pointing towards a result that absolves them from making such a retreat. If they're willing to see it plain.

webTitle: Exorcists in demand to purge Mexico's demons

fields.headline: Exorcists in demand to purge Mexico's demons
fields.trailText: The exorcist and his helpers began to relax, convinced they had beaten back the demons attacking Arturo Sanchez who looked on vacantly, too weak to move. Then suddenly Arturo leapt into the air, his body contorted and eyeballs rolled back, and the struggle for his soul resumed.
fields.body:
The exorcist and his helpers began to relax, convinced they had beaten back the demons attacking Arturo Sanchez who looked on vacantly, too weak to move. Then suddenly Arturo leapt into the air, his body contorted and eyeballs rolled back, and the struggle for his soul resumed.

"In the name of Jesus Christ get out, you have no business here!" ordered Pastor Hugo Alvarez. Amid broken phrases of Hebrew he sat astride the writhing 25-year-old salesman who responded with a low-pitched inhuman howl.

Two helpers held down Arturo's legs, while others moved around the church hall shooing away the evil spirits they saw massing in the corners, in the lights that flickered and went out, and behind Arturo's distressed wife who looked on in horror.

Gradually the exorcist regained control, the lights came back on, Arturo vomited and was declared "liberated" - for the time being at least.

"That was a tough one," Pastor Alvarez said after their three-hour sweat-drenched spiritual battle. "I'm going to lose a lot of weight with you," he said smiling at Arturo.

Pastor Alvarez is one of Mexico's foremost exorcists, claiming to have chased the devil from over 5,000 people since taking charge of the Divine Saviour Ministry of Liberation in a working class area of Mexico City 18 years ago.

He says demonic presence is on the increase and his services are in ever more demand.

But this jeans-wearing pastor with his roll-up-your-sleeves, get-down-to-business approach to Satan is only one option for the tormented in Mexico, who may prefer a more traditional exorcism from a Roman Catholic priest.

"I don't do exorcisms just like that," said Father Alberto Alvarez, one of eight priests named by the bishop of Mexico City to serve as the capital's official exorcists. "I need to check out each case, and I need to prepare myself."

Father Alberto said he saw about a dozen disturbed people every week, but most were not genuine cases of possession.

"Each case is a matter for investigation and diagnosis, and if the person is not possessed I tell them straight out that they have a different problem," he said. But once he has dispelled any doubts, Father Alberto said he takes the whole affair "very very seriously".

"It is a beautiful rite, a very solemn and serious celebration," he said.

A new translation of the Latin exorcism liturgy issued by the Vatican last year changes little of the 16th century original, although it does authorise exorcism of places and objects as well as people, and extends the scope of the ritual to include demonic influence as well as possession. It also expressly bans the curious public from the ceremony.

Things do go wrong, however. Last year in central Mexico a priest was accused of torturing a young girl during a non-authorised exorcism in which she received candle wax burns.

And a completely non-institutional exorcism carried out by a shaman left seven people dead, apparently suffocated by incense that filled the sealed room where the ritual was performed.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: •The Observer's Life magazine has carried a long, intriguing interview with Amazon boss Jeff Bezos. Although the online retailer still loses fortunes, Bezos is convinced it will survive to become the world's biggest company, a primary cause of his optimism being its "intelligent search agents" which automatically steer customers who have bought one thing towards others that might appeal. This allows him to offer punters a more personalised experience, says Mr Bezos, than on the high street, and will be the saviour of his firm. How very true. A friend whose mother-in-law has high blood pressure ordered the BMA family doctor series book on the subject, and was impressed when Amazon.co.uk suggested three related products. One was a US book on high blood pressure, and the second, cleverly, was the BMA book on stress. The third was the DVD of Gladiator. Is there anything better than the most gruesomely realistic scenes of slaughter in cinematic history to bring down the systolic rate?
fields.body:
The Observer's Life magazine has carried a long, intriguing interview with Amazon boss Jeff Bezos. Although the online retailer still loses fortunes, Bezos is convinced it will survive to become the world's biggest company, a primary cause of his optimism being its "intelligent search agents" which automatically steer customers who have bought one thing towards others that might appeal. This allows him to offer punters a more personalised experience, says Mr Bezos, than on the high street, and will be the saviour of his firm. How very true. A friend whose mother-in-law has high blood pressure ordered the BMA family doctor series book on the subject, and was impressed when Amazon.co.uk suggested three related products. One was a US book on high blood pressure, and the second, cleverly, was the BMA book on stress. The third was the DVD of Gladiator. Is there anything better than the most gruesomely realistic scenes of slaughter in cinematic history to bring down the systolic rate?

 Good luck to everyone nominated for Royal Television Society awards when the ceremony is held on February 28 - particularly Ulster TV, which is nominated in the best regional current affairs programme category for Michael Stone: Portrait of a Killer. I'd want a decent price on that myself, but fingers crossed.

 Years of chaotic Diary admin force my colleague Marina Hyde to call Downing Street with an inquiry. We're just updating our database, explains Marina, and wanted to check our listing for Fiona Millar (my friend Alastair Campbell's common law wife). We have her down here as lady-in-waiting to Cherie Blair. Is that correct? "I'm not sure if that's the title she would use," replies a relaxed and friendly James Fletcher (and I swear this is absolutely verbatim), "but the role is correct, yes." Thank you James. You're very kind.

 So kind that, later, Marina rings back. "I can't talk, I'm afraid. I'm very busy," says a tetchy James. Too busy for an enquiry? "Well, what is it?" Recalling how Number 10 tends to smear perceived enemies as mad, Marina asks for confirmation that Hartlepool One Liberation Army (Hola!) leader Robert Harris is doolally. "Could you hold, please?" says James. A new voice comes on, and is asked for his name. "A DowningStreetPressOfficer" is the reply. That's unusual, says Marina, are you one of the Lincolnshire DowningStreetPressOfficers? "I speak for the prime minister," he says, and Marina puts the Harris sanity question, asking for off-the-record steer. "You can have an on-the-record quote," declares Mr X. "We have no intention of taking part in junk journalism like this." Click, brrrrr.

 In the Independent, Andrew Neil rails at the inaccuracy of broadsheet media diaries, mentioning a Guardian story about a Scotsman editor having a lunch he says never happened - a typical contribution to "a damning epitaph for the way we cover our industry". Gosh. Some weeks ago, Sunday Business's diary related how, when the Guardian and Mirror editors had lunched, the former badgered the latter into appointing a readers' editor ... an idea Piers Morgan was later forced to drop, wrote Damien McCrystal, by his colleagues' mirth. In fact there was no lunch and no ethical lecture and Piers did make the appointment. Sunday Business is one of Andrew's papers. Now shut up for a while, Andrew, there's a good boy, and no more babyish whining.

 Mixed news from Moscow zoo, where Anton Brieszov became trapped in the lion's enclosure when the ladder he climbed down to retrieve a toy dropped by his child toppled over. Mr Brieszov managed to outrun the lions and climb to safety. He then jumped into a moat surrounding the enclosure and, being a non-swimmer, drowned.
