fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In our report, Blair pledges to cut class sizes in problem schools, page 6, yesterday, we were wrong to say that proposals to limit class sizes in some secondary schools do not appear in the new green paper on schools. They do. The pilot is mentioned in paragraphs 4.59 and 4.60 on pages 57-58.
fields.body:
In our report, Blair pledges to cut class sizes in problem schools, page 6, yesterday, we were wrong to say that proposals to limit class sizes in some secondary schools do not appear in the new green paper on schools. They do. The pilot is mentioned in paragraphs 4.59 and 4.60 on pages 57-58.

In an article in Media, page 50, February 12, we stated that Talkcast's texer.com was "seemingly spamming users" of its SMS chat room service. Talkcast has asked us to say that neither it nor its Texer service sends unsolicited messages to its users and that the company condemns the practice of spamming.

Oliver James is a clinical psychologist and not, as we suggested in a piece headed The decline and fall of the august cabinet secretary, Comment, page 20, February 13, a psychiatrist.

Our leader, EU shows yellow cards, page 21, February 13, referred to Ireland's monetary policy. We should have said fiscal policy.

In a column headed Only fools and horses, page 7, Society, yesterday, we made a number of references to the Seebohn reforms. We should have said Seebohm. The references were to the reforms following publication in 1968 of the Report of the Committee on Local Authority and Allied Personal Social Services, known as the Seebohm Report.

In a panel headed Great railway feats, page 3, February 10, Kapiri Mposhi in Zambia was spelt wrongly and we were woefully out on its distance from Dar es Salaam in Tanzania. The Tazara rail line between the two places is 1,139 miles long and not 2,900 miles as stated.

In the same panel (above) referring to feats of railway engineering, page 3, February 10, we misspelt the Nullarbor Plain in south Australia (calling it Nullabour).

webTitle: Leader: Are the British a threat to the bullfight?

fields.headline: The blame in Spain
fields.standfirst: Are the British a threat to the bullfight?
fields.trailText: Spain's foreign minister, Josep Pique, has a beef with Britain. Several, in fact. The first fit of Pique was provoked by Gibraltar, which he described as a "large duty-free shop", an unproductive parasite "living off" Spain.
fields.body:
Spain's foreign minister, Josep Pique, has a beef with Britain. Several, in fact. The first fit of Pique was provoked by Gibraltar, which he described as a "large duty-free shop", an unproductive parasite "living off" Spain. This seems an odd way to convince the colony's residents that they would be better off governed from Madrid. Anyway, as millions of British Costa tourists will testify, Spain has no objection in principle to duty-free shops. It just wants control of the racket.

More piquettishness is in evidence over HMS Tireless (and engine-less), the nuclear sub under interminable repair in Gibraltar. Far from being feted as gallant Nato allies, Nelson's radiant heirs have been castigated as health hazards.

Now comes piquant news that Britain is also being blamed for the looming ruination of Spain's favourite bloodsport: bullfighting. The spread of BSE to Spain means the gory carcasses of the corrida may no longer be sold for human consumption. The Fighting Bulls Breeders Union is gloomy. Mass matador unemployment beckons. All of which might tempt many here to cry: Olé !

Far from being feted as gallant Nato allies, Nelson's radiant heirs have been castigated as health hazards. Now comes piquant news that Britain is also being blamed for the looming ruination of Spain's favourite bloodsport: bullfighting. The spread of BSE to Spain means the gory carcasses of the corrida may no longer be sold for human consumption. The Fighting Bulls Breeders Union is gloomy. Mass matador unemployment beckons. All of which might tempt many here to cry: Olé !

fields.headline: Council cash
fields.trailText: The district auditor states that the financial standing of Hull council is sound and has given an unqualified opinion upon the accounts (Dreams dashed for city with 'pot of gold', February 10).
fields.body:
The district auditor states that the financial standing of Hull council is sound and has given an unqualified opinion upon the accounts (Dreams dashed for city with 'pot of gold', February 10). A key issue recognised by the district auditor is that the proceeds of the Kingston Communications flotation cannot be applied directly to the council's revenue accounts and, in effect, can only be reinvested in capital assets. Many people are not aware of the complexities of the legal and financial regimes which govern local authorities, yet are only too happy to advise on how these authorities should utilise their resources. For the local councils concerned, however, life is not that simple. Michael Price
Chief financial officer, Kingston upon Hull council

webTitle: Leader: It must be made easier to stay on at work

fields.headline: Able but wasted
fields.standfirst: It must be made easier to stay on at work
fields.trailText: What do Bobby Robson (67), Alfred Brendel (70) and John Mortimer (77) have in common? If they had been in most other forms of employment, rather than football management, music and writing, they would have been unemployed long ago.
fields.body:
What do Bobby Robson (67), Alfred Brendel (70) and John Mortimer (77) have in common? If they had been in most other forms of employment, rather than football management, music and writing, they would have been unemployed long ago. Indeed, current figures show most people have ceased to work long before the official retirement ages of 60 for women and 65 for men. A mere 37% of men are in full time work at the age of 64. The age for involuntary retirement has been creeping remorselessly downwards as life expectancy has continued to lengthen. Over one-third of those over 50 are no longer in work. In the US, where this trend began, the retention of older workers is at last increasing. The same could happen here now that ministers have belatedly agreed to legislate against age discrimination and abolish fixed retirement ages.

The background to this policy switch is familiar: the 25 years added to life expectancy in the last century. Rarely has there been such a huge demographic shift. We already live in the oldest society that has existed and it is going to get older. Fewer births and longer life mean the number of people aged 65 and over will increase at 10 times the overall rate of population growth in the next 40 years. Projections suggest that by 2010 40% of the population will be over 45. How does a society which has been so successful in reducing the injuries of biological ageing, move forward? Both individual - and collective - interests point to the need to reduce the social injuries imposed by ageing. Some individuals, although by no means all, do want to work beyond the fixed time. They should be allowed to. Women, in fact, are already having their fixed retirement age, given as a sweetener in 1942 when more women workers were needed in war factories, gradually extended to 65.

But the first battle in which ministers should engage is with involuntary retirement. This is costing an estimated £26bn in lost production, lost taxes and extra benefits. (Whitehall is a serious offender, compulsorily retiring people at 60.) Pushing out the over 50s has not created more jobs for the young. What it has done is to create a skills shortage. Ministers were reluctant to legislate, but their hand has been forced by an EU directive requiring age discrimination to be outlawed. Seven nations have already demonstrated the effectiveness of a legal ban. It is time the UK joined them.

webTitle: Leader: Drug companies must temper their power.

fields.headline: Millions of lives at risk
fields.standfirst: Drug companies must temper their power
fields.trailText: By 2010, life expectancy in South Africa will have fallen by 20 years because of the spread of HIV/Aids. The dreadful dimensions of this plague brutally expose the growing inequality of health provision across the globe.
fields.body:
By 2010, life expectancy in South Africa will have fallen by 20 years because of the spread of HIV/Aids. The dreadful dimensions of this plague brutally expose the growing inequality of health provision across the globe. Aids is a death sentence in Africa, whilst in Britain a cocktail of drugs can manage the disease. What is true of Aids is also true of many other less high-profile diseases, such as pneumonia and tuberculosis. As the human genome discoveries launch us into a new era of customised medicine in the developed world, this gulf in provision will only yawn wider. Right at the heart of it lies the issue of how access to essential medicines is now regulated and patented under the trade related intellectual property agreement (Trips) enforced by the World Trade Organisation.

Here, there is grave cause for concern. On Monday we reported the lawsuit brought by 42 pharmaceutical companies against the South African government for its interpretation of Trips on the importing of cheap copies (known as generics) of Aids medicines. This is an outrageous scandal. Other instances in Ghana and Uganda of Glaxo Smith- Kline's bullying over importing generic drugs for Aids are equally shocking. The US is taking Brazil to the WTO disputes procedure, alleging that it is flouting Trips in producing a generic copy of AZT drugs, which cost a mere $3,000 a year, instead of the $15,000 charged in the US. But the cheaper drug enables 60,000 Aids sufferers in Brazil to receive free treatment.

Patents are necessary and important to reward innovation. In few other industries is this so crucial, given the high risks of developing medicines for the market - as the pharmaceutical industry justifiably points out. But there is a trade-off between the benefits of a patent system and human well-being. This was clearly understood in the negotiations for Trips. Two provisions were included to safeguard the latter - compulsory licensing and parallel importing of generic drugs in the case of a national emergency. But the wording of these vital provisions was left dangerously vague and countries such as South Africa are struggling to find the international intellectual property lawyers to prove their case that they have a national emergency. Equally disturbing is the way the US government blatantly disregards Trips when it chooses. There are now 16 countries being threatened by the notorious "301" legislative clause under which the US can impose trade sanctions without going through the WTO. All the disputes involve drug patenting. The reason for this aggression on the part of the US government is not difficult to discern. The pharmaceutical industry, as we reported earlier this week, is a powerful operator within the Washington establishment. In just two years, members of the US pharmaceutical association spent a staggering $236m on lobbyists and and a further $14m went to political parties. This is likely to get still worse under a Bush administration, which includes several members with close links to the drug companies.

In their defence, the companies point to examples of corporate philanthropy and there are some good examples, such as Merck's pledge to fight river blindness. But while philanthropy has an important role, the bigger picture must be reform - a shortening of patents in developing countries, a strengthening of the Trips provisions and a greater sense of responsibility from the drug companies. Without such measures, there is a real danger of a public backlash. We expect the highest ethical standards from drug companies because their business is the lives and deaths of human beings; we expect consideration for the well-being of all human beings to temper their drive for profit. Over the last few days, there has been disturbing evidence from Argentina to Britain that this is far from the case. A handful of drug companies now dominate the global health industry, which is among the most profitable industrial sectors, and yet they insist that patent laws cannot be tailored for the needs of desperately poor countries where millions will die. What the drug companies potentially face is a public relations disaster. Jean -Pierre Garnier, the president of Glaxo SmithKline, pointed out on our pages yesterday that drug companies cannot solve the problem of global poverty. True. But what he can certainly do is to pull out of the lawsuit against South Africa.

webTitle: Letters: Patients should come before patents

fields.headline: Patients should come before patents
fields.trailText: According to Jean-Pierre Garnier (Drug giants aren't the problem, February 14), patents do not have the effect of increasing prices.
fields.body:
According to Jean-Pierre Garnier (Drug giants aren't the problem, February 14), patents do not have the effect of increasing prices. In which case, why, until recently, was his company selling the anti-Aids drug Combivir in developing countries at twice the price of a generic equivalent? Why are generic drugs producers in Brazil providing triple therapy to Aids patients at less than one-quarter of the price for patented drugs? And why are generic companies in India able to produce one of the most effective treatments for childhood diarrhoea at one eighth of the price of brand name versions?

Does Mr Garnier believe the central laws of economics (ie higher price produces less demand) are suspended in markets for drugs? For poor households, the difference in price between patented and generic drugs is often - quite literally - the difference between life and death. That is why the onslaught being conducted against developing countries by the global pharmaceuticals industry is so disturbing. In South Africa, which has 4.2m Aids victims, 42 drugs companies, including Glaxo SmithKline, are seeking to revoke a law allowing for the importation of affordable medicine. Brazil is in the dock at the WTO for wanting to allow local companies to produce life-saving drugs at less than one-third of their patented price.

As a global leader, Mr Garnier recognises that GSK has global responsibilities. He has made welcome pledges to make GSK's medicines more available to poor people. We appeal to him to discharge those responsibilities in a positive way by withdrawing from the case against the South African government, and waiving patent claims on life-saving drugs in poor countries.
Phil Bloomer
Head of advocacy, Oxfam

 For too long now, the argument has been put forward that the high cost of drugs to treat Aids means that such treatment would be a misuse of a poor country's health resources. Instead of reducing the cost, western standards and prices have been used to conclude that the "developing world" isn't developed enough for Aids drugs.

But not everyone in Africa lives in grass huts miles from the nearest health centre. In South Africa, for example, 52% of the population live in urban and peri-urban areas where they do have access to primary health care. It has been demonstrated, not only by MSF, that it is perfectly possible to offer anti-retroviral treatment at the primary health care level, with more complicated medical tests being done in referral hospitals/labs in the city centre.

Now that international public pressure has finally started to drive drug prices down, the international community must start to look seriously at how we can practically support the efforts of third world governments to provide treatment.

We who work in the field don't see Aids simply in terms of statistics, but as people: patients, colleagues and friends who have to be told to go home and prepare to die because the medicines that could keep for them alive are not available for them. It is no longer morally acceptable to debate whether or not anti-retrovirals should be provided. We must concentrate now on finding, quickly, ways to make sure they are.
Dr Eric Goemaere
Médecins Sans Frontières Aids program, South Africa

 Let's get a few things straight. The pharmaceutical companies did not fund the initial trials into anti-HIV drugs. It was left to cash-starved public health laboratories and radical campaigners to wring research grants out of the US Food and Drug Administration, which was afraid to release funds to study a "gay disease". It is largely thanks to a courageous and determined campaign by early Aids activists that anti-HIV drugs are available in the US and Europe at all. The drugs companies were prepared to write off the lives of thousands of people infected with HIV in the 1980s because they were either gay or injecting drug users. We must not allow them to do the same in 2001 because this time those who are ill are too poor to be profitable.
Anne Alexander
Liverpool
r_annealex@hotmail.com

 Dick Bentley writes (Letters, February 13) of Big Pharma: "In a democratic society we are the ones who make the laws that define their conduct." This presumed division of labour is the big lie of democratic society. Big Pharma, together with Big Oil, Big Corporate Media and the rest, have more than enough clout to ensure that "politics is the shadow cast on society by big business", as John Dewey put it.
David Edwards
Bournemouth
david@awed.fsnet.co.uk

 Congratulations on an excellent series. Colleagues at the Queen Mary intellectual property research institute in this university warned of the implications of the WTO Trips agreement on the developing world well in advance of current disasters. At present they are much concerned with the consequences that may flow from the use of intellectual property rights over agricultural biotechnology. It seems a pity that important issues are not given an airing until the die is irretrievably cast.
Fiona Macmillan
Reader in law, Birkbeck College, University of London
f.macmillan@law.bbk.ac.uk

fields.headline: Fingering the killer
fields.trailText: In your report (Son urges inquiry into murder of solicitor, February 13) on the murder of Patrick Finucane, you referred to advice I gave last weekend on whether the surname of an alleged British army agent handler, which had been posted on a US website, was now in the public domain.
fields.body:
In your report (Son urges inquiry into murder of solicitor, February 13) on the murder of Patrick Finucane, you referred to advice I gave last weekend on whether the surname of an alleged British army agent handler, which had been posted on a US website, was now in the public domain. My full advice was that it was clearly in the public domain (even more so now than then) but that if the Ministry of Defence and a newspaper disagreed over how widely her surname was in the public domain, this became something for a court to decide. In fact, neither side took the matter to court last weekend.

I also added that, irrespective of the legal aspects, my advice was that the British media should continue not to publish details of the operator not already in the public domain, since these details could further endanger her life.

The story itself is certainly of valid public interest, but unless an inquiry and/or court decides otherwise, the names of junior operators are not at present. The names of senior people may not always achieve quite the same protection, but one of the responsibilities of the senior is to take responsibility.
Rear Adm Nick Wilkinson
Secretary, Defence, Press and Broadcasting Advisory Committee

webTitle: Letters: Politicians fight over dwindling habitats

fields.headline: Politicians fight over dwindling habitats
fields.trailText: Labour promised before the last election they would put the environment at the heart of government (Fragile habitats 'sacrificed' for development", February 13). Considering the Conservatives' record, you wouldn't think this would be hard to do.
fields.body:
Labour promised before the last election they would put the environment at the heart of government (Fragile habitats 'sacrificed' for development", February 13). Considering the Conservatives' record, you wouldn't think this would be hard to do. The news that the government is to be sued by the European Commission for failing to protect the environments of endangered species is a cause for great sadness.

The EU's habitats directive protects the environments of endangered species from development, but allows exemptions in special circumstances. The government has apparently treated this as a formality and been handing exemptions out like sweeties to anyone who asks. This makes a farce of Labour's commitment to the environment. It also shows that the government is still failing to understand that environmental policy is something that must permeate every part of policymaking, from the Treasury to planning. Lip service is not good enough and now the government is facing a court case because of their lack of comprehension.
Tom Brake MP
Liberal Democrat environment spokesperson braket@parliament.uk

 Licences in relation to European protected species on development sites are only issued after ensuring that their issue complies with the habitats directive. Habitats of endangered species, such as the great crested newt, are already receiving much greater protection through tough new measures in the Countryside and Rights of Way Act, which introduced prison sentences and fines for wildlife crimes.

We have also boosted the protection to sites of special scientific interest and additional safeguards are on the way, as we have identified almost 200 UK sites as possible or candidate special areas of conservation under the habitats directive.
Michael Meacher MP
Michael Meacher MP
Minister for the environment

 Ros Coward (Green battle-line, February14) mentions various artists and writers inspired in Hastings with the glaring omission of Robert Tressell, author of The Ragged Trousered Philanthropists. Tressell's words that it is the system that requires change are still relevant.
Trevor Hopper
Brighton

fields.headline: Teachers set standards
fields.trailText: At the unanimous request of the general teaching council, I write to condemn the prime minister's press secretary's reference to "bog-standard comprehensives" (Blair pledges to cut class-sizes, February 14).
fields.body:
At the unanimous request of the general teaching council, I write to condemn the prime minister's press secretary's reference to "bog-standard comprehensives" (Blair pledges to cut class-sizes, February 14).

Teachers take great pride in responding to the specific needs of their charges and the different communities they serve. They take great offence at having their efforts dismissed in such a cavalier way, having raised standards year on year against the odds. The GTC is working with teachers and government to make real changes for the better and to project the profession fairly. The remark will have done nothing to encourage high-calibre young people to join the profession or cement the loyalty of those already in it.
Hans Ruyssenaars
Chair, recruitment committee, General teaching council

 My daughter passed 11 O'levels at our local comprehensive and four A-levels at the local sixth-form college. She read PPE at Oxford and is now a fast-streamer in the Foreign Office. I was so bored at my grammar school, I was put off university completely.
Celia Berridge
Lewes, E Sussex

 The demonstrations in Croatia must be looked at in context (Report, February 12). Croats are angry nothing is being done to prosecute the Serbs responsible for the slaughter of 15,000 Croats. The International War Crimes Tribunal has brazenly ignored most of these massacres, preferring to focus on incomparably lesser crimes against Serbs to appease the new Yugoslav government.
Brian Gallagher
Croatian Information Office

 I am delighted to see your Valentine's Day edition is not awash with the usual bilge in the message section. Is this because of mobile phone messaging? At last a reason to celebrate this technology.
Robert Hill
Edinburgh

fields.headline: Oil leak
fields.trailText: Sir John Browne, BP's chief executive, insists that it would be wrong for BP to use profits from one side of its business to subsidise another side (Calls for windfall tax after BP's record profits, February 14).
fields.body:
Sir John Browne, BP's chief executive, insists that it would be wrong for BP to use profits from one side of its business to subsidise another side (Calls for windfall tax after BP's record profits, February 14).

We hope this approach will be applied to BP's own investments in PetroChina, which - it is feared - helps to subsidise civil war in Sudan through its state-owned parent company China National Petroleum Corp (CNPC). Investment in PetroChina indirectly frees up resources for CNPC's expansion in Sudan, where it has been implicated in deaths and human rights violations.
Ian Wallace
Director, Tearfund

fields.headline: Second sight
fields.standfirst:
More net news
A free-for-all philosophy is not a good business model
fields.trailText: A free-for-all philosophy is not a good business model
fields.body:
Picture the scene. You have just had a brilliant idea for a new business utilising the still hugely unexplored potential of mobile phones. It doesn't matter what the idea is. It could be anything from a multi-player quiz game to a treasure hunt making use of the fact that soon your phone will not only know who you are but also where you are.

With a bit of luck your idea could earn you some money and in the process create new jobs. And if enough people devise other wireless-based projects it could give birth to a new industry that could put Britain at the leading edge of an exploding technology.

The trouble is, as things stand at the moment, there is no way you can make any money out of it. Why? Because there is someone in the middle - your friendly telephone company (telco) - which is creaming off all the income. If your project involves the participants making a phone call then the telco collects the whole cost of the call. If it also involves sending out text messages to the caller then you could be caned for up to 10p a message (with discounts for bulk purchases).

In other words, from the start your project is doomed because you have to do all the work, put up all the money - and invest your intellectual property rights - while telcos such as BT and Vodafone collect all the income. Yet the phone calls wouldn't have been made in the first place if you hadn't invested you time and money in your idea. Something wrong, surely.

The telcos will argue that they had to invest in the capacity so why shouldn't they collect the money - especially at the moment when they are sagging under the costs, running into tens of billions of pounds, of bidding for radio spectrum for the third round of mobile phones. They have a point.

But the fact is that when they laid down all that capacity they hadn't a clue that text messaging would explode into one of the fastest growing industries of all time - with approaching a billion messages already being sent monthly in Britain. The same could be said of emailing years ago when that unexpectedly took off. And even if they had foreseen it they shouldn't be allowed to smother a nascent new industry at birth which could have given a vital boost to economic growth.

Things are starting to change but not nearly fast enough. If you are big and successful enough (and have the negotiating power to take your business elsewhere) then the telcos will reluctantly agree a revenue sharing agreement allowing you to keep a percentage (usually a very small one) of the cost of the telephone call. If you can combine that with buying cheap text messages in bulk then you might be able to defray the costs of the text messages but little else.

All this is extremely myopic on the part of the telcos. It is not the successful companies with bargaining power that are at risk but the small start-ups who haven't got any clout but whose businesses will wither on the vine unless the telcos move into the 21st century.

All they have to do is stop thinking like traditional telcos (ie squeezing as much money as they can out of the transmission capacity they dominate) and start thinking about encouraging new sources of growth in future.

If only they would think long-term they would realise that they stand to gain far more revenue in future from encouraging new industries that would not otherwise exist than they would from milking existing customers.

But asking a company like BT to change its spots is easier said than done. BT should look to Japan for inspiration. Over there, the giant telephone company NTT DoCoMo's i-mode revenue-sharing model for mobile applications is one of the reasons for its runaway success - and why so much "content" is being sold.

It is vital to do this otherwise the next stage of the information revolution (wireless, wireless, wireless) won't deliver the wealth-creating potential it is capable of. Telcos in the UK are desperately trying to turn their portals into fortresses behind which they can shelter their own content providers. But instead of amassing their own tied content providers they should be throwing their doors open to the new generation of developers. And if they don't then the regulators should separate their "common carrying" function from the provision of content.

This is a conflict of interest at the heart of the information revolution that must be resolved. It is the reason AOL has merged with Time-Warner - in order to build an electronic fortress in which the company owns the medium and the content (whether cable, satellite or wireless) that passes through it.

The trouble with the mainstream internet at the moment - as the continuing collapse of the consumer-based dot.coms daily re-affirms - is that no one has worked out a way of making an honest penny out of it without resorting to monopolisation. Mostly, this is good. The mutuality of the internet - whereby individuals and organisations freely exchange information - is this century's equivalent of one of the Wonders of the World.

But the "free-for-all" philosophy doesn't make a good business model. If entrepreneurs are to build successful businesses and employ more people then they must be able to see a revenue stream enabling them to make profits.

It is one of the central weaknesses of the business-to-consumer side of the internet that no one has yet worked out a universal formula for doing that. It would be tragic if we repeat the same mistake during the wireless revolution. But unless attitudes change quickly, we will, we will.

webTitle: Spread it by word of  mouse

fields.headline: Spread it by word of  mouse
fields.standfirst:
Why pay for banner ads when you can get customers to sell your product for you on the net? Matt Haig reports on the growth of viral marketing
More net news
fields.trailText: Why pay for banner ads when you can get customers to sell your product for you on the net? Matt Haig reports on the growth of viral marketing
fields.body:
The phenomenal success of Hotmail, Napster and the instant messaging service, ICQ has proved how companies can attract new users much faster through the internet than they can using traditional off-line advertising. What is less clear is exactly how such rapid, word-of-mouth growth is achieved.

In an attempt to explain this unique ability of the internet to accelerate interest in a product, venture capitalist Steve Jurveston coined the term 'viral marketing' in a 1997 Netscape newsletter.

Jurvetson, who helped to finance the free email service Hotmail, had clearly witnessed the power of viral marketing at close range. By Christmas 1996, within a year of its launch, Hotmail had 10m registered users. At that time, such phenomenal growth had not occurred anywhere else in media history.

Furthermore, this unprecedented performance had been achieved with a marketing budget of just $50,000 (needless to say, this was before Microsoft bought the company). Hotmail's fast-track success was not the result of an extensive advertising campaign, either online or offline. Instead, it has been attributed to a decision made by another Hotmail seed investor, Tim Draper.

Draper was adamant that every email sent by a Hotmail user should incorporate the following message: "Get your free Web based email at Hotmail". By clicking on this line of text, the recipient would be transported to the Hotmail home page. While this message would not have had much effect at the foot of an email sent by the company itself, when sent by a friend or relative it made an impact, confirming Marshall McLuhan's belief that the medium validates the message. The very act of sending a Hotmail message constituted an endorsement of the product and so the current customer was selling to future customers just by communicating with them. The recipients of a Hotmail message learnt not only that the product works, but also that their friend is a user.

Jurveston now believes that a viral marketing component must be built into the DNA of every internet company in order for it to succeed. "I can't think of any dot.com that I'd consider that doesn't come with a viral marketing element," he says. Jurveston also cites Metcalfe's Law to illustrate the viral effect of word of mouth on the net.

According to Metcalfe's Law, the value of a network increases as the square of the number of users connected to it. This law of increasing returns evidently applies to viral marketing in a way that it does not apply to offline word of mouth publicity. This is because, for better or worse, people are more connected in cyberspace than they are in the real world. As Seth Godin writes in his e-book, Unleashing the Ideavirus: "With word of mouse you can tell 100 friends, or 1,000 friends. Because the numbers are larger and faster than they are offline, the virus grows instead of slows." (See www.ideavirus.com)

While the most vocal proponents of viral marketing are to be found in the US, over the past year many companies in the UK have been successfully adopting viral techniques. Last summer, for instance, Thomas Cook, generated 250,000 new customers through its Weekend Breaks email marketing campaign, while rival travel operator Lastminute.com achieved similar results with its PDA-based Euro 2000 campaign.

Islay Malt, which makes Laphroaig malt whisky, used a viral marketing campaign to boost awareness of the brand in the run up to Christmas. Four different e-Christmas cards were distributed to 7,000 UK members of Friends of Laphroaig. According to the company, more than 40% of those who received the email (which incorporated a link to the selection of e-cards) went on to send a personalised copy to a friend. Michelle Pitts, brand director of Laphroaig, claims that the recipients "loved this distinctive approach, with almost 1,000 sending a card to a friend within three hours of the email being sent out".

While these examples involve using deliberate direct marketing tactics in order to encourage recipients to pass on a marketing message to others, other companies take a more organic approach. For UK-based gambling site Flutter.com, which has built an online community on the concept of person-to-person betting, viral marketing occurs naturally and therefore needs little encouragement.

Websites enabling consumers to engage with each other clearly have a head start when it comes to generating recommendations. (This explains why the only dot.com to have received more consumer-to-consumer referrals than Hotmail is file-swapping music site Napster.)

It is important to remember, however, that word-of-mouth can travel in two directions. Although many people find the term 'viral marketing' offensive, it not only suits the infectious nature of network enhanced word of mouth, but also conjures up its negative potential.

By losing control of the marketing message, companies are at the mercy of online opinion. If customers have a bad experience of a certain product, word can spread at alarming speed. As The Cluetrain Manifesto states: "The networked market knows more than companies do about their own products. And whether the news is good or bad, they tell everyone."

This is not to say that viral marketing should be discouraged. Indeed, viral marketing occurs whether a company wants it to or not - via email, Usenet discussion groups, consumer opinion sites such as E-pinions.com, and other interactive forums.

The only way companies can limit viral marketing's negative capacity is, paradoxically, by openly embracing it. By making it easy for conversations between customers to occur, companies will be satisfying the internet user's primary objective: to interact with other people.

"It's imperative to stop marketing at people," says Godin. "The idea is to create an environment where consumers will market to each other."

This view is supported by John Owrid, a management partner at UK direct marketing agency Ogilvy One, which opened a virtual marketing unit last August."As the net's infrastructure gets stronger, viral marketing gets easier and the rewards for those who can do it properly, get bigger," he says.

Viral marketing therefore completely reverses standard promotional methods such as TV advertising and web banners. Instead of excluding the customer from the creation of a marketing message, once initiated, viral marketing cuts the role of the company to that of a passive bystander. Ultimately, this has a democratising effect on the whole marketing process.

"One of the beautiful things about viral marketing is that all these mechanisms only work when you're talking about a good product," says Emanuel Rosen, author of The Anatomy of Buzz.

However, for companies with confidence in their product, viral marketing can prove more effective than web banners and interruptive forms of advertising. By drawing the customer into the selling process, companies are not only stretching their marketing budgets further, but are also acknowledging the way in which the net has radically redefined the notion of marketing itself.

fields.headline: Games watch
fields.trailText: Gameplay rejig in store | French kiss
fields.body:
Gameplay rejig in store
Gameplay is shedding 275 staff and has closed the eight high street stores it picked up late last year. (The shops were owned and staffed by Dixons.) In the restructuring, Gameplay is being divided into two divisions: technology and boxed software. Although the company is best known for its online service, which includes what was BT's Wireplay, the latter generates most of the company's income.

French kiss
Bruno Bonnell's Infogrames, Europe's biggest games company, says its quarterly revenues have grown by 26% to $325.5m. The company made a profit of $16.5m, compared to a loss of $118.0m for the same period last year. Driver 2 was a particular success, selling more than two million copies.

Ubi Soft, another French games giant, reported that its sales jumped by 49% to € 114.4m. Growth was fuelled by the acquisition of Italy's 3D Planet and America's Red Storm. Successes included Disney Dinosaur and Donald Duck: Quack Attack.

Game over
CNet is closing its GameCentre website, which has been online more than four years. It has lost out to its rival, ZD Net's GameSpot, which CNet acquired along with the Ziff Davis publishing empire. The zine's last issue includes the games of the year for 2000 with comments from GamerX ("but don't worry - he wrote them before he found out he'd been fired"). Staff who had been anonymous are finally given credits with each brief bio being followed by a shopper-friendly "Add to your cart" symbol.

Group therapy
British video game developers have formed TIGA, The Independent Games Developers Association (the D is silent). The aim is to share opinions on things like mobile gaming, and to co-ordinate actions, such as lobbying for government support.

Smashing
Virtua Tennis is already one of the best games on the Sega Dreamcast, and the sequel will pack a much bigger promotional punch: Venus and Serena Williams have signed up to endorse it. The game is expected to appear in November. The inferior competition includes Anna Kournikova Smash Court Tennis on the Sony PlayStation. Martina Hingis, who recently beat both Williams sisters, remains without a videogame to her name.

fields.headline: Now we're getting the message
fields.standfirst:
Text messaging is not solely for teenagers: teachers and lovers are communicating via text, too. Sara Gaines reports
More net news
fields.trailText: Text messaging is not solely for teenagers: teachers and lovers are communicating via text, too. Sara Gaines reports
fields.body:
It wasn't meant to be like this. By now computers were supposed to have turned us into a bunch of geeks, so used to huddling over our screens we could barely communicate with only our anoraks for comfort. Instead, people have subverted new technology and used it to find more and more ways to share saucy jokes and expand their network of friends.

There has been a huge boom in the use of email and text messaging. Last month a Guardian/ICM poll found text messaging had taken off astonishingly quickly since it was introduced in 1992, with 43% of adults using it, and 76% of all 18 to 24 year olds. Email use is proving just as popular a tool. Like most such phenomena, the attraction might not be initially clear but you soon get sucked in.

Alice Thompson, 23, is a fan of both. She is known as the Text Queen to her friends and says she sends between five and 10 messages a day. There's a certain tribalism in the way she uses it to rally friends for a night out, sending out a clarion call to meet.

"My friends and I take our phones out with us and send messages to other friends saying, 'We're in this club and it's really good. Come and meet us'," she said. "It means we don't have to spend ages planning a night out. You can send the same message to everyone."

It is also a great tool for relieving office boredom, in the human resources department of the company where she works, by sharing secret messages and passing jokes along the cyber grapevine. Alice has found text messaging has given a fillip to her flirting skills too.

"If there is a guy I like I find it easier to send text messages rather than phone him up," she said. "I just banter with them and forward funny jokes. Because we're not face to face I can be cheeky and a bit abusive!

"There is one guy, and I did not know him that well, but we've started to text message each other and that's how we communicate. He is a friend of a friend and I would never have phoned him up but this way it's not intimidating.

"It's just a bit of flirting. I have met him for a drink a few times but we have probably kept the friendship going through text messaging."

There are other benefits. Messaging help Alice keep in touch with old school friends she would probably have lost contact with if it wasn't so easy to send a message saying "Hi, thinking of you" rather than having to compose a long letter. All her friends have text message-friendly phones and at work Alice uses email and internet site www.boltblue.com through which you can send text messages too.

It seems these new forms of communication have filled a gap, offering something that face to face conversation does not. After research into how people use new technology, psychologist Professor Pam Briggs, of the University of Northumbria, believes people have embraced them because they offer a chance to present yourself the way that you want to and be a bit more playful.

And its ring tone and icon down loads have proved popular as mobile phones evolve from practical tools into personalised accessories.

Chief executive Michael Brown said the mobile market has developed way beyond "mere" voice communications. "Boltblue was one of the first to recognise and meet this need," he said. "The mix of content we provide has enabled us to overtake household names."

Another company that was quick to recognise the potential of SMS and offer services to help develop it is Austrian company UCP (universal communication platform), which offers free text messaging via the portal www.uboot.com.

It announced €36.8m in financing from Deutsche Telekom in September and last month signed a co-operation agreement with One 2 One.

fields.headline: How to text for free
fields.standfirst:
To save paying out on inter-network SMS text messages, Steve Gold has some solutions
More net news
fields.trailText: To save paying out on inter-network SMS text messages, Steve Gold has some solutions
fields.body:
Since the start of February, all of the UK's cellular networks have started charging each other three pence for inter-network SMS text messages.

While these charges will roughly cancel each other out in respect of text messages sent by the mobile networks' own subscribers, it spells doom for the wealth of web portals that offer free internet-to-SMS text messaging services.

Already, SMS Boy and Totalise have closed their web-to-SMS services, and other web portals are weighing their options.

You can't blame the networks, as the success of SMS text messaging has caught them unawares, with around 70 million messages being handled in the UK every month. Originally, SMS text messages were a useful extra source of revenue for the suppliers, using spare capacity on the network.

The sheer volume of messages, however, has placed a heavy load on the networks, which are already strained at peak times because of significant volumes of voice calls.

Coupled with the need to spend extra money on SMS computer centres to handle all this text messaging traffic, the inter-network charge is a logical way of slowing down the growth of SMS messages.

Consumers do not have to knuckle down and pay the 10p per message that the networks charge for mobile-originated SMS, rather than use the freebie web portal services.

For one thing, non-UK web portals continue to exist and will allow UK- bound text messages, since most of them do not pay the 3p text messaging charge to the UK networks.

This is because only a few European cellular carriers have agreed with BT Cellnet, One 2 One, Orange and Vodafone to pay the inter-network SMS charges on UK-bound text messages.

Secondly, if your organisation sends a lot of text messages, you can talk to Xtempus, the first of a new breed of text messaging intermediaries to send high volume two-way messages across Europe easily and cost-effectively.

Xtempus's service for high volume text messaging is already operational in the UK, and will be rolled out in France, Germany, Spain and Italy within the next few months.

For humbler SMS text messengers, web portals that can still be used include the Lycos service, as well as foreign portals in Belgium and Switzerland. The Swiss service operates on a pay-to-use basis with modest fees.

Free web-to-SMS services come and go with surprising regularity. A quick search through your favourite search engine, such as www.google.com or www.excite.co.uk will reveal the latest additions.

There are other routes for text messages, too. Web sites to explore for further information include:

www.dogphone.com
www.excell.to
www.iwap.com
www.n-systems.com
www.smsyes.net
www.winsms.com

fields.headline: Hasta la vista, blowfly!
fields.standfirst: Farmers are replacing sheep dip with databases to protect their flocks, says  David Hambling
fields.trailText: Farmers are replacing sheep dip with databases to protect their flocks, says David Hambling
fields.body:
The great thing about a time machine would be the ability to change the course of history. You could nudge Lee Harvey Oswald's elbow at the critical moment, or delay Hitler for a few minutes so he dies in the blast in a Munich bierkeller in 1939. The same idea is used in the film Terminator of going back in time to kill your enemy's parents before they are even conceived. Now this principle is being used to tackle a different kind of menace.

Blowfly maggots are genuine flesh-eating monsters. They have mouth hooks and digestive enzymes to tear through damp skin. This produces lesions which become open wounds as the maggots feed and grow, an effect known as strike. The wounds attract flies which lay more eggs. Then there are more larvae, fever, infections and sometimes death. It is fortunate for us that blowflies attack sheep rather than people; some 15,000 die in Britain every year as a result.

The traditional way of preventing blowfly strike is by dipping, a method invented by William Cooper in 1843. The problem is that the chemicals used for sheep dipping can be highly toxic. The most controversial are organophosphates (OPs), originally developed as chemical warfare agents. The ministry of agriculture maintains that sheep dips are safe as long as the correct precautions are used, but it is estimated that more than 2,000 farmworkers have been affected by OP poisoning. Ironically enough, OPs were introduced to replace the previous generation of environmentally damaging organochlorine compounds.

Scientists have long been seeking a better solution. At the Centre for Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIRO) in Australia, a vaccine is being developed against blowfly strike with the help of genetic engineering. The basis of the vaccine is a modified protein from the blowfly itself, which stimulates the sheep's immune system to produce antibodies. If the sheep suffers from strike, the blowfly larvae ingest the antibody which interferes with their digestive system. The larvae are effectively starved; their growth is slowed and they may die.

The vaccine has been under development for almost 10 years and is not in its final form yet. Even if it is technically successful, consumer resistance is likely to be a serious obstacle. In the last few years we have seen increasing concern over the issue of GM crops. The idea of introducing a new GM factor which will find its way into the insect population at least will not be popular.

At Bristol University, Dr Richard Wall is using a very different approach to combat blowflies, one which minimises environmental damage. There are always some blowflies around, but it is only when the conditions are right for them that they can become a menace to sheep. In particular, the temperature needs to be within a certain range, and there needs to be enough moisture - typically the larvae can only infest sheep when their skin is already damp.

By analysing a database of weather conditions and blowfly numbers, Dr Wall has developed software called Strikewise that can predict in advance when the blowfly population is about to explode.

The entire blowfly lifecycle from egg to adult takes only a few weeks, and each female lays hundreds of eggs. According to research, in early spring there is on average only about one female blowfly per hectare. This single blowfly can mean hundreds in the next generation and tens of thousands in the generation after that. Killing this one blowfly at the crucial time is much more effective than killing thousands later when sheep are already suffering.

The software takes in weather information for each area, and by comparing this with a model of the population dynamics it gives warning of areas where blowflies are about to multiply dramatically. One way of using this information would be to dip the flock only when the warning comes, reducing the use of harmful chemicals to the times when they are necessary. There is also a more subtle approach.

Dr Wall has developed a device in the form of a hollow plastic pyramid. It has slits in the sides, and contains a scent lure which is irresistible - to blowflies, at least. There is also a strip of sticky flypaper to trap any fly which enters. The lure is only appealing to blowflies, so beneficial insects such as bees and dragonflies are not caught. And because there is no insecticide involved, the trap is environmentally friendly. One trap can cover a hectare; the only maintenance needed is replacing the sticky strip every couple of weeks.

Initial trials have been very successful and further trials will take place this spring as the blowfly strike season gets under way. Given that the system requires only one computer in Bristol and the usual national weather reports, it could be made available to farmers nationwide next year if funding is forthcoming.

This could be the start of a new era in pest control. There are many different animal and crop pests, from parasitic worms to cabbage flies, which are always present in small numbers but which cause massive damage when their population suddenly increases. This sudden population explosion is not random, but rather the result of factors such as weather, crop variety and the number of livestock per hectare.

Given sufficient study, it should be possible to accurately predict the patterns for every type of pest. This is no small task - Dr Wall's system took 10 man-years to develop - but it could mean the end of the indiscriminate use of pesticides in favour of a more targeted approach.

According to research, in early spring there is on average only about one female blowfly per hectare. This single blowfly can mean hundreds in the next generation and tens of thousands in the generation after that. Killing this one blowfly at the crucial time is much more effective than killing thousands later when sheep are already suffering. The software takes in weather information for each area, and by comparing this with a model of the population dynamics it gives warning of areas where blowflies are about to multiply dramatically. One way of using this information would be to dip the flock only when the warning comes, reducing the use of harmful chemicals to the times when they are necessary. There is also a more subtle approach. Dr Wall has developed a device in the form of a hollow plastic pyramid. It has slits in the sides, and contains a scent lure which is irresistible - to blowflies, at least. There is also a strip of sticky flypaper to trap any fly which enters. The lure is only appealing to blowflies, so beneficial insects such as bees and dragonflies are not caught. And because there is no insecticide involved, the trap is environmentally friendly. One trap can cover a hectare; the only maintenance needed is replacing the sticky strip every couple of weeks. Initial trials have been very successful and further trials will take place this spring as the blowfly strike season gets under way. Given that the system requires only one computer in Bristol and the usual national weather reports, it could be made available to farmers nationwide next year if funding is forthcoming. This could be the start of a new era in pest control. There are many different animal and crop pests, from parasitic worms to cabbage flies, which are always present in small numbers but which cause massive damage when their population suddenly increases. This sudden population explosion is not random, but rather the result of factors such as weather, crop variety and the number of livestock per hectare. Given sufficient study, it should be possible to accurately predict the patterns for every type of pest. This is no small task - Dr Wall's system took 10 man-years to develop - but it could mean the end of the indiscriminate use of pesticides in favour of a more targeted approach.

webTitle: Israeli journalist explains Israel's assassination policy

fields.headline: Controversial policy with a hidden agenda
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Most Israelis accept the killing of Massoud Ayad. Even more so after yesterday's bush shelter atrocity in Tel Aviv.
fields.body:
Most Israelis accept the killing of Massoud Ayad. Even more so after yesterday's bush shelter atrocity in Tel Aviv.

Israeli intelligence (the domestic security agency known by its Hebrew acronym Shabak) held Ayad responsible for a failed mortar attack on a Jewish settlement in Gaza earlier this week and for a plot to kidnap senior Israeli military officials.

The public acceptance of the killing of the Palestinian officer is based on the fact that he was involved in attacks against Jews and served as an officer in Yasser Arafat's security apparatus. He was also a ringleader in an underground cell of Hizbullah, the virulent anti-Israeli, Lebanese Shi'ite movement sponsored by Iran.

Hizbullah has recently made inroads into Palestinian areas to incite Arabs to step up the battle against Israel.

Ayad and the eight Israelis who died in yesterday's attack are the latest casualties of the intifada, which has already claimed the lives of more then 60 Israelis and 350 Palestinians.

At least 12 of the Palestinians were killed in what is called the "liquidation" policy of Israel. This is government approval of action against a "wanted" list of Palestinians accused by Israeli intelligence of guerrilla warfare or planning terrorist attacks.

In other words this is a policy of "shoot on sight".

The intelligence and the army special forces that carry out the operations prefer to kill during a battle, thus giving the impression of military action and not a mafia-style execution.

Yet, the aims justify the means and sometimes they will sacrifice niceties for efficiency and the achievement of the designated goal.

Many international critics bash Israel for this policy, claiming that it is not in accordance with international law and democratic values.

But there is nothing new in Israel's readiness to adopt controversial methods. In the course of more than 30 years Israel has from time to time resorted to assassination of Palestinians and other Arabs suspected of terrorism.

The liquidation policy is intended to disrupt operational plans, prevent the implementation of terrorist attacks and deter others from attempting to carry out such attacks.

In rare cases - such as the 1995 assassination in Malta of Fathi Shkaki, the leader of Islamic Jihad - does the killing of the senior commander bring about the paralysis of the organisation.

However, in most cases the true motivation is to do with domestic policy rather than operational considerations. The hits are meant to appease an angry and frustrated public, drum up public opinion in support of the government, fulfil the desire for revenge and raise waning national morale. In practice, the liquidations only accelerate the vicious cycle of violence.

The operations were always accompanied by doubts as to their usefulness. These were raised not only by Israeli leftwingers and liberals but also by some of those at the heart of the intelligence and military establishment.

Supporters of this policy claim that "surgical" operations are better then an all-out assault on civilians and urban centres that would result in thousands of casualties.

And above all, Israelis feel that they are in a war imposed on them by Yasser Arafat's Palestinian Authority at the moment when Israel was offering the most generous concessions to end its occupation.

 Yossi Melman is a commentator on intelligence and security matters for the Israeli daily Ha'aretz.

webTitle: Scientists put Bible's Samson on couch

fields.headline: Scientists put Bible's Samson on couch
fields.trailText: The biblical strongman Samson displayed symptoms of a serious personality disorder, according to a team of American psychologists.
fields.body:
The biblical strongman Samson displayed symptoms of a serious personality disorder, according to a team of American psychologists.

Researchers claim Samson demonstrated six of the seven recognised traits associated with Antisocial Personality Disorder (ASPD), including impulsiveness, recklessness and getting into fights.

The Californian psychologists point out that Samson routinely fought: he once killed 1,000 Philistines single-handedly with a donkey's jawbone.

He also showed a reckless disregard for his safety when he told Delilah - who had tried to kill him three times - the secret of his strength.

The Bible tells how Samson lost his powers when Delilah cut off his hair. He was enslaved by the Philistines before his hair regrew and returned his strength, allowing him to pull down their temple.

Samson also burned Philistine fields, demonstrating both impulsiveness and an inability to conform to social norms. He was deceitful and, like many people with ASPD, he behaved badly as a child, causing fires and bullying other children.

Eric Altschuler, of the University of California at San Diego, told New Scientist: "It's almost as if the writer of the story has the [ASPD] criteria tacked to the wall and he is writing a sketch. But this was 3,000 years ago."

fields.headline: Kaufman the clown brings the house down
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: A measure of Tony Blair's success is that with an election just a few weeks away he has managed to turn question time into what Americans call a celebrity roast.
fields.body:
A measure of Tony Blair's success is that with an election just a few weeks away he has managed to turn question time into what Americans call a celebrity roast.

At these events a popular or famous figure is dined by his friends and colleagues and jokily told how awful he is. I suspect that sometimes the victim must work hard to keep his delighted smile in place. William Hague didn't seem to find it all that easy yesterday.

Take Gerald Kaufman's question. I feel sorry for Gerald. A man of great ability, he'd have been foreign secretary if Neil Kinnock had won an election. Spitting Image took him seriously enough to make a Kaufman puppet with a scary mouth cage, like Hannibal Lecter.

But by 1997 his time had somehow passed, and he is now chairman of the culture committee, where he passes his time blamelessly making life hell for TV executives.

But he remains loyal to the leader who has so heartlessly ignored his talents. Could the prime minister, asked Kaufman silkily, say whether he thought that winter fuel payments and free TV licences for pensioners were complicated and patronising and so should be abolished, "in which case he agrees with what the leader of the Conservative party was saying at the beginning of last week", or the opposite, in which case he would be agreeing with Mr Hague's view at the end of the week.

Labour MPs erupted with joy at this sally. Mr Kaufman celebrated by eating some lightly grilled brain. Sorry, my mistake, I mean that Mr Kaufman, who used to be a comedy scriptwriter, is quite capable of coming up with a gag as good as, or better, than the one he had just enjoyed - but it sounded like a line scripted by the whips and dished out to greasy young hopefuls who wish to be known for their sycophancy.

At the end of question time, the new Speaker mumbled out a statement (he still has some trouble reading aloud). He told MPs that questions should be meant to hold the executive to account, and should not be attacks on the policies of opposition parties.

Mr Martin is, I fear, much keener to restrain mere backbenchers and shrinks from confronting the truly powerful. "I think it right to allow the prime minister and leader of the opposition a greater degree of latitude," he muttered.

Well, that's lucky, because the prime minister does little else but attack Tory policies. Asked why he intended to abolish community health councils for no apparent reason and without asking anyone who might have a contrary opinion, he assailed Tory health spending.

Asked about the small number of asylum seekers who were being ejected from the country, he attacked Tory plans for detention centres.

(There's an idea about that there was once a golden age of question time, when it consisted of a Socratic dialogue between MPs and the premier. This is nonsense. I went back to a 1964 Hansard and found it was full of Harold Wilson assailing the policies of his predecessor but one, Harold Macmillan.)

The roast was almost over. Time for one last turn of the spit. Mr Blair said that two days ago Lord Strathclyde, leader of the Tory peers, had said: "I think there is always a danger of political parties peaking too soon. William Hague and the shadow cabinet have very cleverly avoided that." So leaving us with the question of whether this was a stumbling attempt at a genuine compliment or the most dazzling use of irony.

Either way, it left the prime minister slicing beautiful tender pink slices off Mr Hague, served up with roast potatoes, Yorkshire pudding and lashings of meaty gravy.

fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: Physician trick (heal thyself) | Diagnosis by Dr Feelgood
fields.body:
Physician trick (heal thyself)
University of Illinois researchers have a new answer to the problem of the cracked plate or the burst drainpipe. Just fit it with an autonomic healing response, they report in Nature today. Skin mends, bones knit, and they think other materials can patch themselves up too, with a micro-encapsulated healing agent embedded in a composite structural matrix. When the second ruptures, so does the first, and binds the wounds. In fracture tests, the composites recovered 75% of their strength. There is a British wildflower called self-heal, once recommended by herballists for healing wounds.

Diagnosis by Dr Feelgood
Forget about popularity, influence, money and luxury. They are at the bottom of everybody's list of must-haves, according to a team from the University of Missouri-Columbia, reporting in the Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Groups of US and South Korean college students were asked what they really wanted. And what did they want? Autonomy, competence, relatedness and self-esteem, they said - a sense of effectiveness, self-endorsement, sense of belonging, and the feel good factor. Self-esteem topped all US lists. The researchers say that now "psychological needs can be targeted to enhance personal thriving".

First, stoppeth one of three
An arresting letter in the latest Chemistry In Britain sorts out a 200-year-old problem of poetic licence. Coleridge's Ancient Mariner saw that "ice mast high came floating by/ as green as emerald". Actually, in all the prizewinning camera studies, icebergs are blue. This is to do with light refracted by bubbles in the compressed snow. But, says David Taylor, of Scarborough, green icebergs are very rare indeed, and derive from the bottom of the ice shelf. It's colder down there, and sea water rich in algae plates out as ice. After that, all it needs is for the shelf to break, the berg to overturn, and any passing mariner gets the green light.

fields.headline: A polymer you cannot refuse
fields.standfirst: David Bradley  on why potato peelings and coffee grounds are a recipe for perfect plastic
fields.trailText: David Bradley on why potato peelings and coffee grounds are a recipe for perfect plastic
fields.body:
Imagine you are sitting on a nice comfortable sofa. It is padded with biodegradable polymer foam reinforced with waste coffee grounds. You might be eyeing up the latest cars in a magazine that sports a model with the super-shiny finish. That is made from trees and the dashboard from recycled potato peelings. Or, you might be watching an environmentally friendly TV, whose case is made from recycled waste from the food industry that was originally destined for a landfill somewhere near your home.

A recycling nightmare? Nothing so ugly, this is the ultimate world of natural products that might be coming soon. Thanks to chemists round the world, we are finding ways that might help us use the megatons of organic waste we generate every year. Biomass becomes the raw materials for chemical reactions for making tough new biodegradable plastics and polymer composites. This last word in recycling might help reduce the burden on landfills everywhere as well as providing industry with a cheap and renewable resource to replace oil and petroleum, the usual suspects in plastics manufacture. Moreover, these natural plastic products will be biodegradable, so when their useful life is over, they too can be readily recycled - either by manufacturer or microbe.

Hyoe Hatakeyama of Fukui University of Technology is reported in January's Chemical & Engineering News as being something of a recycling pioneer. He and his team are using two of the most commonly wasted biomass sources as their starting materials for making polymer foams and composite materi als, that might be used in countless consumer products. The first unlikely material they are using is coffee grounds. Several million tons a year are produced as the by-product of making instant coffee, which are simply dumped. The second natural material is molasses, another waste product this time of the sugar industry. Some molasses is used in agriculture, the rest is disposed of at sea.

The Japanese team first converted their molasses into a plastic form by reacting it with polyethylene glycol, which strings the sugary molasses molecules - sucrose, glucose and fructose - along thousands of sub-microscopic polymer chains. Then, they simply add coffee grounds, some activating agent and a catalyst, and the materials bind together to form a tough and durable composite material. If they carry out a similar reaction scheme but missing out the coffee grounds ingredient, they end up with a new version of flexible polyurethane foam. One of the advantages of these strange hybrid products is that they are more environmentally benign than conventional oil-based plastics, since they are readily biodegradable.

Kitchen sponges made from such waste materials are already on sale in Japan, C&EN reports. In the US, the efforts of Brian Seiler and his colleagues at Eastman Chemical in Kingsport, Tennessee, have taken inspiration from some of the earliest plastics and brought them right up to date. Before synthetic polymers, such as nylon and PVC, were invented there was cellulose. Cellulose is a natural polymer composed of thousands of sugar molecules strung together forming the fibrous parts of plants and trees. A century ago, it was used as the raw material for making semi-natural plastics, such as celluloid, famous as the transparent "film" of movie fame. Today, cellulose is still commonly used to make the materials for cigarette filters, suit linings and specialist photographic films. While the family of esters of cellulose with carboxylic acids ('cellulose esters') has been known for more than 100 years, the family continues to grow, as does its influence, says Seiler.

But Seiler and his colleagues did not want to make simple celluloid, they wanted a high- tech polymer that could be made from waste cellulose. The manufacture of synthetic polymers generally relies on building up the long polymer chain from chemical units called monomers. Seiler and his team reasoned that they could start with the natural cellulose polymer and simply modify it using chemistry to endow it with new physical properties.

He and his colleagues have now developed a variation on the cellulose polymer for use in car body finishes. The material, called carboxy methylcellulose acetate butyrate, can be dispersed in water, so it does away with the need for a toxic organic solvent. Moreover, it not only dries faster but also helps the paint form a much smoother, shinier finish.

Food and wood waste too are finding application in making new polymers. Nobuo Shiraishi of Kyoto University is working on methods of converting one of the biggest sources of biomass waste - wood shavings and food industry waste, such as potato and other vegetable scraps - into plastics. He and his team have developed techniques to produce both thermoset and mouldable plastics from biomass. They can make thermoset plastics, for instance, by gently heating their biomass starting material with alcoholic organic compounds with sulphuric or phosphoric acid for just an hour or two.

The team has already made materials with what Shiraishi describes as "fine plasticities, physical properties and biodegradability". The resulting plastics could be used as glues, foams, and mouldings for less environmentally damaging packaging and consumer products from TV cases to mobile phone covers.

In a similar vein, Shiraishi and his colleagues are also looking at how recycled newspaper, magazine, and box paper might be used as a cheap source of cellulose. They believe this is perfect for conversion into mouldable cellulose acetate and the fabrication of composites. Such an application would not only reduce the strain on the oil industry of using reserves for manufacturing but also provide a more environment friendly route for the disposal of waste paper destined for landfill.

We currently utilise only about 7% of the biomass we produce, mostly as wood fuel in the developing world, rather than as consumer products. But, in the West, we simply dispose of millions upon millions of tons of organic molecules in the form of waste wood materials, literally junk food and other garbage.

These materials are based on renewable and sustainable resources and have biodegradability that can be tuned and triggered by the producer and end-users.

With a little chemical ingenuity, we could avoid squandering this valuable resource and bring a little nature back into our lives. These are the perfect 21st century materials.

 David Bradley is a freelance science writer at www.sciencebase.com
