fields.headline: Web watch
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText:
Bar humbug
You might say artist Scott Blake is scanning the possibilities of online images on his clever bar-code site at www.geocities.com/barcodesite. The lowly barcode aspires to high art as Blake takes cultural icons from Jesus to Ronald Reagan to Bill Gates, and renders them in bar codes. Appropriately, Andy Warhol gets the zebra-stripe treatment as well. There's a zoom feature that enables an extra close-up look at the structure of the images, and even the visitor counter is in the form of a bar-code.
fields.body:
Bar humbug
You might say artist Scott Blake is scanning the possibilities of online images on his clever bar-code site at www.geocities.com/barcodesite. The lowly barcode aspires to high art as Blake takes cultural icons from Jesus to Ronald Reagan to Bill Gates, and renders them in bar codes. Appropriately, Andy Warhol gets the zebra-stripe treatment as well. There's a zoom feature that enables an extra close-up look at the structure of the images, and even the visitor counter is in the form of a bar-code.

Body politic
The New Statesman's Fantasy Politics site lets you create your own fantasy cabinet and submit it to their judging panel to win a bottle of booze. The judges' fantasy cabinet includes Harriet Harman as PM, Tony Benn as deputy PM and England rugby captain Martin Johnson as foreign secretary, with Prince William heading up culture and Eminem as treasury chief secretary. Competitors have also suggested Alan Greenspan, Bob the Builder and the Guardian's Polly Toynbee as ministers without portfolio. Wouldn't it be great to see them all in the same room at the same time?

Skip off
Are you a Palm fanatic? Blue Squirrel software in Utah has come up with a free program and a Palm portal called Skipwire that lets you download and manage Palm applications wirelessly - if your Palm is Internet-enabled. One advantage is that applications can be stored in a personal Skipwire account and reinstalled as needed, which keeps device memory clear. There are plenty of applications available directly from the site.

Score draw
Allegroassai is an Italian software company that markets music notation programs in five languages for composers and music students. Now, the company has created a portal www.allegroassai.com where you can download a free application that lets you listen to digital scores archived on the site. The site also has other music resources, including a wide range of directories on topics such as genres, instruments, music organisations and performers.

Smash hit
If the "blue screen of death" or the little Macintosh bomb has appeared once too often on your screen, you may need the computer hammer from www.computerhammer.com. A frustrated computer user is selling the 20-inch inflatable hammer on this website for $6.99 (Canadian). He says: "The Computer Hammer version 1.0 was designed specifically for striking computer screens when aggravation sets in." He is also holding a competition for the best - or perhaps that is worst - computer let-down story. Winners will receive an autographed computer hammer.

Pay UK
Web users have not flocked to the idea of alternative online payment systems, but new company UK Smart is betting its "Smart creds" will do the job. The system is based on smart cards worth £20, which can be bought from participating post offices around the country in the same way as pay-as-you-go cards for mobiles. Users sign up for a Smart Wallet account at the UK Smart website and load in the value by entering a 16-digit number from the card. Members can then spend their Smart creds at participating online vendors. These include Countrybookshop, Obsessions, Wicked Colours, e2save, Lush, Skates Direct, Top-up Shop, Fastbeat.com, Fashion Nightmare, Laden Online, Cap factory and Watch Heaven. The company hopes to attract under-18s without credit cards and those who prefer not to use credit cards online.

 Virgin mobile customers can shop by Wap. Register at www.virgin.com/mobile

 Maporama is offering maps and itineraries through www.WAPPUP.com

 The BBC's Good Homes site has had a spring cleaning: www.beeb.com/goodhomes

* Make it personal with an email address of yourname@yoursurname from www.YOURemail.tv

http://emuseum.mankato.msus.edu

fields.bodyText: Bar humbug You might say artist Scott Blake is scanning the possibilities of online images on his clever bar-code site at www.geocities.com/barcodesite. The lowly barcode aspires to high art as Blake takes cultural icons from Jesus to Ronald Reagan to Bill Gates, and renders them in bar codes. Appropriately, Andy Warhol gets the zebra-stripe treatment as well. There's a zoom feature that enables an extra close-up look at the structure of the images, and even the visitor counter is in the form of a bar-code. Body politic The New Statesman's Fantasy Politics site lets you create your own fantasy cabinet and submit it to their judging panel to win a bottle of booze. The judges' fantasy cabinet includes Harriet Harman as PM, Tony Benn as deputy PM and England rugby captain Martin Johnson as foreign secretary, with Prince William heading up culture and Eminem as treasury chief secretary. Competitors have also suggested Alan Greenspan, Bob the Builder and the Guardian's Polly Toynbee as ministers without portfolio. Wouldn't it be great to see them all in the same room at the same time? Skip off Are you a Palm fanatic? Blue Squirrel software in Utah has come up with a free program and a Palm portal called Skipwire that lets you download and manage Palm applications wirelessly - if your Palm is Internet-enabled. One advantage is that applications can be stored in a personal Skipwire account and reinstalled as needed, which keeps device memory clear. There are plenty of applications available directly from the site. Score draw Allegroassai is an Italian software company that markets music notation programs in five languages for composers and music students. Now, the company has created a portal www.allegroassai.com where you can download a free application that lets you listen to digital scores archived on the site. The site also has other music resources, including a wide range of directories on topics such as genres, instruments, music organisations and performers. A frustrated computer user is selling the 20-inch inflatable hammer on this website for $6.99 (Canadian). He says: "The Computer Hammer version 1.0 was designed specifically for striking computer screens when aggravation sets in." He is also holding a competition for the best - or perhaps that is worst - computer let-down story. Winners will receive an autographed computer hammer. Members can then spend their Smart creds at participating online vendors. fields.headline: The search for web profits
fields.standfirst:
Is it possible for a dot.com to make a profit? We sent Sean Dodson out on mission impossible: to find six consumer sites making money
More net news
fields.trailText: Is it possible for a dot.com to make a profit? We sent Sean Dodson out on mission impossible: to find six consumer sites making money
fields.body:
Is it possible to make a profit on the internet? It has been if you are a lawyer or a telecommunications giant or even a trendy design house. But is it possible to make a profit if you are a dot.com selling goods or services direct to the consumer?

The received wisdom is no. So far, most dot.coms have yet to break even. But despite a daily barrage of stories detailing news of yet another dot.com collapse, there are a few UK companies that are turning a tidy profit selling goods and services direct to the consumer. And most of them have never asked for a penny of venture capital.

According to sources like NetValue and the Post Office, British shoppers are taking to the internet like never before. Record sales were recorded this Christmas - with as many as between five and six million of us buying goods over the net by November, over a third more than the year before.

But January has also seen a record number of dot.coms falter. Some have already filed for bankruptcy, while others are rapidly being bought up by "old economy" companies. For the UK's online community, these are proving to be hard times.

One reason might be that there are simply too many of them. The high street has room for only a couple of major pharmacists: the online community is served by seven. Which all leads to too little money spread among too many hands and confidence in dot.coms at rock bottom. But just because so many management consultants, venture capitalists and private investors got it so fabulously wrong doesn't mean the business-to-consumer (B2C) model is irrevocably flawed.

If you start small, grow organically and resist the temptation to blitz the market with expensive ad campaigns, then making a profit from selling goods and services to the consumer is still possible.

And turning a buck on the net doesn't mean you have to be very small. CNN Interactive has been in the black since launch, while Conde Naste recently announced that its raft of internet properties is already breaking even. And let us not forget that pornographers and online casino owners have been making bucketloads of cash selling their wares direct to the consumer.

Just as the new economy received far, far too much hype, perhaps now it is buckling from an equally distorting amount of pessimism. Somewhere in the middle is a healthy dose of reality.

The following six stories come from companies that claim to make a profit online. Each tale has a moral, and all of them suggest there might be gold in them there hills after all.

Mail order works
Hard to find records
"It used to be that we were quiet in the summer and winter was just mental. Now it's just mental all the time," says Lora Nash, head of online sales at HTFR.com (Hard To Find Records) - a rare vinyl specialist in Birmingham.

Run out of a 2,000 sq ft warehouse, HTFR's online catalogue of rare and deleted vinyl contains over 47,000 titles. The company buys up old record collections, catalogues them and sells them either through the superstore or on the net. Online sales now amount to nearly 90% of the company's total sales.

The company says it is making a profit on the internet because it was already making a profit before it went online. Hard to Find Records was formed as a mail-order business by Jason Kirby, a former computer programmer, in his bedroom in 1991. The firm went online in 1995.

What started as little more than a hobby is today a multi-million pound business employing 35 people. It is entirely self-funded and has grown out of its profits. "We've got such a specialised business," says Nash. "A lot of people have tried to follow us, bit we did it first and that gives us one hell of a reputation."

Do everything in-house
The Alternative Gift Company
www.alt-gifts.com
Its turnover may be no greater than a couple of country craft shops, but one small company in Banbury, Oxfordshire, is proving that selling goods on the net can be profitable. The Alternative Gift Company sells unusual gifts, like plots of the moon, direct to the consumer. The company has a core staff of five and hires more to cover the busiest periods, around Christmas and Valentine's day. "I think our business model makes us profitable at the end of the day," says Jonathan Aylmer of Alternative Gifts. "We are very careful with what we spend and do everything in house.

"We design and build our own website and we undertake our own fulfilment. We can operate a next day delivery service because they stock everything on the premises."

Doing things in-house means that a company like Alternative Gifts can keep its costs down. "A lot of dot.coms have had massive advertising budgets, which I feel is a kamikaze attitude," says Aylmer, who sold his furniture business to fund the company.

But Aylmer also claims that the company's pragmatic approach to business extends even further. "We have no fantasy titles here," he insists. "No project managers or online developers. Nothing that can demand huge salaries which no online business, in my opinion, can support at this time."

Go for the slow buck
Jobserve.com
www.jobserve.com
Tucked away in the sleepy Essex village of Tiptree lies one dot.com with one of the fastest growing profit margins in the UK. Ten miles out of Colchester lies Jobserve, a kind of virtual labour exchange for IT workers.

Jobserve is a bustling medium-sized company employing 70 people. It was formed in 1993 by Robbie Cowling, a former IT contractor, and a business partner. The pair invested £2,000 of their own money and have never received any outside investment.

The company went in to profit within the first couple of months and has funded its growth through its takings. Last year Cowling bought his partner out.

"I saw no reason for us to go for funding," says Cowling. "The plans we have got in the way of growth we can afford to do ourselves. So we didn't want to give up any of our share. And we've never fancied floating."

Last year the company found itself at the top of the ProfitTrack list of fastest growing companies not listed on the stock market.

"A lot of people were getting in to it just because they thought that they could do that, float it and get out," claims Cowling.

"But they are not living and breathing what they are doing. If we'd have taken that sort of attitude we wouldn't be here today."

Find a niche market
Med4u.co.uk
www.med4u.co.uk
Despite so many of their contemporaries falling by the wayside, there are still start-ups out there looking for venture capital. Some like www.med4U.co.uk are even making a modest profit.

Med4U.co.uk is an online medical consulting service. The company has recruited a panel of 20 doctors and it offers medical consultation via email. For this it charges a £25 consultancy fee and most customers get a response within 48 hours.

A company like Med4U makes a small operating profit, partly because its two founders are paying themselves a reduced salary and the overheads are low because they are working from home. The company receives between 30 and 40 customers a week and nearly 80% of them are men.

"We think that men are far more reticent to take time off work or bother to consult their GPs," says Graham Boyd, who formed the company along with business partner Dr Liz Miller.

The company also found most of those men also happen to be gay, so last month, it launched www.GayMed4U.co.uk.

"In London it is perhaps easier for a gay man to find friendly GPs. It's less easy if you are out in the sticks," says Boyd.

Run a traditional business
www.findaproperty.com
"In a sense we are just a traditional business. We've always felt that the fact that we are on the internet is really irrelevant," says Michael O'Flynn of FindaProperty.co.uk.

The company advertises properties on the internet, for which it charges £29. One reason why the company has been successful is that it chose to specialise in the south-east of England, rather than go national. Just like a traditional estate agent.

O'Flynn insists that the company attracted most of its customers through word-of-mouth. It hasn't spent money on massive ad campaigns although it does advertise in local newspapers.

FindaProperty, which is based in Brighton, decided not to go for any venture capital. "We felt that there was a degree of unreality about the kind of money that was being thrown around last year says O'Flynn."

Use outside investment
Vavo.com
While new media wannabies pile-up by the wayside, one site catering for silver surfers is already making money on the net. Vavo.com is a lifestyle portal for the over 45s. The company makes money principally through the sale of insurance, but profitability has also been helped by sales of banner advertising.

The company tipped over into the black after a healthy Christmas. Vavo insists it has been experiencing steady growth since launch. "We haven't gone out aggressively with a high profile marketing plan and he haven't got a big ad spend," says Oliver Needham, the site's head of public relations.

Unlike the other dot.com success stories, Vavo has received outside investment. The company received £2m from an undisclosed private investor in 1999 and received a second round £10 million private placement led by GE Insurance Holdings and the Prudential.

It claims to be making an "operating profit" with "the vast majority" of its investment capital safely tucked away in the bank.

So why has Vavo done so well when so many have faltered? "A lot of the recent dot.com start-ups thought that it was better to being first instead of be simply better," says Needham. "We didn't go that route."

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: The Material World | Leading Edge | The Mancunian Way
fields.body:
A research report observed sardonically that there is no "normal" temperature for the earth. The planet's history has run from unbroken ice cover to intolerable hothouse. In The Material World (4.30pm, Radio 4) Dr Jeremy Marlow reports on recent discoveries off the west African coast by his multinational team. Marine samples gathered there suggest that three million years ago our climate was 10 degrees cooler than now. Since this coincided with hominids' initial migration from Africa, the question is whether it significantly affected our subsequent evolution.

Next week the Russians begin the final preparations to destroy their Mir space station. If they get their sums right, the wreckage of the 15-year-old vehicle should splash into the Pacific south of New Zealand. As Geoff Watts points out in Leading Edge (9.0pm, Radio 4), their calculations can be a bit patchy. In an unwelcome version of Russian roulette, an earlier unwanted vehicle barely missed Rio de Janeiro.

Was June 4 1976 or September 11 1996 the key date in Manchester's modern musical history? For Mark Radcliffe, on The Mancunian Way (10.0pm, Radio 2), the September opening of the Halle's new Bridgewater Hall might have happened on Mars. He regards the Sex Pistols' gig at the Lesser Free Trade Hall as the world shaker, introducing punk rock, persuading delirious fans that two guitar chords could earn them a fortune. Can this stretch to five more episodes?

fields.headline: TV pick of the day
fields.trailText: Basic Instinct | Helmut By June | Non-League Football Show
fields.byline: Paul Howlett, Will Hodgkinson and  Simon Burnton
fields.body:
Films

Basic Instinct Paul Verhoeven, 1992) 9pm, 1am, Studio Michael Douglas's bitter, sleazy-looking cop and Sharon Stone's cool, calculatedly sexy maybe-murderess - famously flashing at the boys in the interrogation room - definitely deserve each other in this hard-edged thriller. It's very naughty 90s, but it's the same old message: bad women get their come-uppance.

She's All That (Robert Iscove, 1999) 10pm, Sky Premier Diverting romantic comedy that just about overcomes its formulaic plot with some bright, zesty performances. Freddie Prinze Jr stars as high-school hero Zack, who bets friends he can turn even the most unlikely girl into a prom queen. Enter Rachael Leigh Cook's scary Laney Boggs to test his skills to the limit - well, sort of, she's obviously a Hollywood beauty underneath.

The Year Of Living Dangerously (Peter Weir, 1982) 10.50pm, TCM Torrid 1965 Indonesia, with Sukarno tottering, is a dangerous place to be. Enter Mel Gibson's rookie foreign correspondent, crashing into delicate arrangements and getting involved with worldly-wise British diplomat Sigourney Weaver. Both fine performances, but they're upstaged by Oscar-winning Linda Hunt as (male) photographer and local fixer Billy Kwan. It's incoherent at times, but Weir conjures a chaotic world of frantic dangers and sweaty passion.

The Club (Bruce Beresford, 1980) 2.55am, FilmFour Bruce Beresford goes behind the scenes in the muscular world of Aussie football, where rule number one is, there are no rules. Both on and off the pitch, the hard and sometimes dirty play is contrasted to the hard and always dirty backroom dealings that are going on.
Paul Howlett

Documentary

Helmut By June 8.30pm, Artsworld In this home-movie-style documentary made by his wife, one of fashion's most respected photographers comes across as an overexcited scout master, a mixture of enthusiastic child and grumpy old man who looks like he should be birdspotting on the Broads rather than in Monte Carlo photographing the world's most beautiful women. Helmut Newton, who made the ringflash technique his trademark and feminists his enemy with a career based on making women look sexy and uncompromising, is a charming if irascible old man, inspired by the kind of women who look as if they could bend him over backwards. June, a classic German hausfrau, is utterly unfazed by anything Helmie comes up with.
Will Hodgkinson

Sports

Non-League Football Show 7pm, Sky Sports 1 OnDigital may have the rights to the Champions' League, the BBC might be showing Liverpool's UEFA Cup exploits, but Sky's got highlights of Chester v Yeovil in the Conference. Seriously, this, the third of a new series made by the people behind the weekly Non-League Newspaper, reflects a growing interest in the more humane face of the national game and is not to be sniffed at.
Simon Burnton

Enter Mel Gibson's rookie foreign correspondent, crashing into delicate arrangements and getting involved with worldly-wise British diplomat Sigourney Weaver. Both fine performances, but they're upstaged by Oscar-winning Linda Hunt as (male) photographer and local fixer Billy Kwan. It's incoherent at times, but Weir conjures a chaotic world of frantic dangers and sweaty passion. The Club (Bruce Beresford, 1980) 2.55am, FilmFour Bruce Beresford goes behind the scenes in the muscular world of Aussie football, where rule number one is, there are no rules. Both on and off the pitch, the hard and sometimes dirty play is contrasted to the hard and always dirty backroom dealings that are going on. Paul Howlett Documentary Helmut By June 8.30pm, Artsworld In this home-movie-style documentary made by his wife, one of fashion's most respected photographers comes across as an overexcited scout master, a mixture of enthusiastic child and grumpy old man who looks like he should be birdspotting on the Broads rather than in Monte Carlo photographing the world's most beautiful women. Helmut Newton, who made the ringflash technique his trademark and feminists his enemy with a career based on making women look sexy and uncompromising, is a charming if irascible old man, inspired by the kind of women who look as if they could bend him over backwards. June, a classic German hausfrau, is utterly unfazed by anything Helmie comes up with. Will Hodgkinson Sports Non-League Football Show 7pm, Sky Sports 1 OnDigital may have the rights to the Champions' League, the BBC might be showing Liverpool's UEFA Cup exploits, but Sky's got highlights of Chester v Yeovil in the Conference. Seriously, this, the third of a new series made by the people behind the weekly Non-League Newspaper, reflects a growing interest in the more humane face of the national game and is not to be sniffed at. Simon Burnton

webTitle: Lie back and think of India

fields.headline: Lie back and think of India
fields.trailText: Position Impossible | Embarrassing Illnesses | Coronation Street
fields.body:
Sir Richard Burton was quite a guy. Not only did he go on daring undercover missions as a policeman for the East India Company, he found the source of the Nile, translated 1001 Arabian Nights, got a knighthood for his troubles and he could speak at least five languages. A cunning linguist, he was the first to translate the Kama Sutra into English. Also well versed in its practical application, he must have been pretty darn good at everything else too.

Burton's story was told - and with only one Elizabeth Taylor joke - in the second part of Position Impossible (Channel 4), Sanjeev Bhaskar's disappointingly uneven examination of the Kama Sutra. Tracing back from the book's exposure to Victorian sensibilities, which deemed it erotic smut, to its fourth-century origins as a guide to courtly life, Position Impossible is quite interesting, but overdoes things, rather like an Englishman in India trying to disprove his reputation as a duff lover by overly gymnastic displays of prowess. By throwing in a stampede of footnotes without assessing whether they are interesting or not - and including some pointless stand-up material which, one assumes, is supposed to advance the narrative but simply slows it down - Position Impossible is effectively a bloated three-part documentary with a sleeker two-hour effort trapped inside it.

We're told that only one fifth of the Kama Sutra is actually about sex, while the other four-fifths are about gymnastics, dressing, interior design, eating and playing tunes on glasses filled with different amounts of water. So after these diversions, you can understand why people mainly concentrate on the one fifth that's about sex. It's a lot more interesting.

A fine example of this is Burton's story about a friend (probably himself) who was shocked when, while making love to his Indian mistress, she caught a mosquito between her toes. It could have been a lot worse, but even with the emphasis on toes, it's a whole lot more captivating than How To Be An Effective Courtier. And this being the case, one suspects the Kama Sutra won't be turning up on the next series of Living By The Book.

Tiptoeing along the fine line between sensitive concern and smirksome voyeurism - and rarely tipping into the latter - Embarrassing Illnesses (Channel 4) concluded with a programme on stammering. With no apparent cause or cure, stammering affects some 450,000 adults in the UK and, of those, Rob and Sean were seen doing their best to come to terms with their affliction.

Rob had been trapped inside a world of words since he went to school and realised he talked differently from other children. He had problems when buying things, going to the bank and making phone calls. Shop assistants, he continued, sometimes walked away from him, mid-sentence. This latter example notwithstanding (shop assistants are trained to behave in such surly ways to everyone and not just stammerers), Rob had had enough and learnt how to "costal breathe" at a workshop. Initially, this meant wearing a belt round his chest - not a good look - but by the time he was ordering nine Chicken McNuggets, he was just fine and beltless. Bless.

Sean, meanwhile, had been sent out to ask people in Covent Garden if they knew anyone with a stammer. Again, this seemed unfair since one assumes, rightly or wrongly, that anyone approaching you in Covent Garden is to be ignored. But Sean did surprisingly well. Not only did he actually speak to some people, he managed not to punch one of those people who pretend to be statues.

When the time comes to meet one's maker, one would hope it wouldn't be on the motorway just outside Preston. Yet poor Susan Barlow's rendezvous with fate occurred just so in Coronation Street (ITV) after she and Mike Baldwin had a barney about Adam. With his mammy with the angels (and her own electrocuted mother), Adam is destined to become the subject of a tug-of-love between Ken and Mike.

Adam thus finds himself in a lose-lose situation since, if Ken wins, he will have to live with Deirdre, who might try to marry him. On the other hand, if Mike wins, Linda will definitely try to deflower him. No doubt he'd be better off with Hayley and Roy.

fields.headline: Merrill buys CeNes stake
fields.trailText: Oversold positions and resistance levels are normally the preserve of chartists - that peculiar breed of City analysts who study the movements of share prices.
fields.body:
Oversold positions and resistance levels are normally the preserve of chartists - that peculiar breed of City analysts who study the movements of share prices.

But market professionals reckon CeNes Pharmaceuticals, the company that develops drugs for the central nervous system, is a "charting buy".

CeNes shares fell 10p to 49p yesterday after Biotechnology Value Fund revealed its had sold its stake in the company - some 5.8m shares. According to traders, the fund did not sell the shares on the open market but offered them to stockbroker Merrill Lynch, which grabbed them at 40p each.

Merrill then proceeded to try to unwind its long position by offering them for 47p - a 12p discount to Tuesday's closing price.

When Merrill finally clears the stock overhang, dealers expect the shares to bounce back to 60p - the level they have held for the past few weeks.

webTitle: Brown's budget date points to May election poll

fields.headline: Brown's budget date points to May election poll
fields.standfirst:
Special report: election countdown
Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: The government put a red circle round another crucial date in the 2001 general election calendar yesterday when it announced that Gordon Brown's budget will be on March 7 - almost exactly a month before the likely dissolution of parliament and eight weeks before polling day, May 3.
fields.body:
The government put a red circle round another crucial date in the 2001 general election calendar yesterday when it announced that Gordon Brown's budget will be on March 7 - almost exactly a month before the likely dissolution of parliament and eight weeks before polling day, May 3.

The chancellor has already lined up a clutch of new benefits to impress voters when they come into force on April 1 and his £10bn projected budget surplus will give him scope to add a few more goodies at the last minute without frightening City sentiment.

Downing Street last night backed away from an apparent hint from Tony Blair at prime minister's question time that the current pensioners' winter fuel allowance of £200 will be maintained or increased, instead of being put back to £150 as basic pension rates rise by £5 a week for a single person, and £8 for a couple on April 1.

"Future spending decisions are a matter for future budgets," No 10 said. This week's education plan will be followed by a 10-year crime plan in late February as Mr Brown completes his consultations on the budget. Yesterday's publication of a 1.8% inflation rate for January, combined with the prospect of unemployment falling below 1m for the first time since 1975 underlines how well the chancellor has succeeded in realigning the political and economic cycles.

Even average earnings, rising at 4.4%, will boost the feel-good factor and not cause immediate alarm, and this week's more optimistic predictions for the troubled US economy ease another potential worry for Mr Brown and Mr Blair.

With the tempo of quasi-campaigning increasing by the day Mr Blair will combine an upbeat emphasis on Labour's plans to reform key public services in a second term with a negative drumbeat against the Tories' "boom and bust" reputation in general and William Hague's opportunistic policy-making style in particular.

The social security secretary, Alistair Darling, yesterday gave another foretaste of Labour tactics when he taunted Mr Hague with figures from the opposition's own experts that suggest the cost of his plans to privatise state pensions for the under-30s would be £5bn in the first year, rising to £15bn a year or more.

Mr Hague remains adamant that, like Edward Heath in 1970, he can surprise the pollsters and snatch victory as a strong Tory turnout - galvanised by such issues as asylum, crime and "save the pound" - combines with Labour apathy to confound Mr Blair. "I do believe we will win. It's not yet showing up in the polls, but there is a lot of unhappiness around," a senior member of the shadow cabinet said yesterday. "Fear or disgust wins elections. The economy is too strong for disgust to work, so it must be fear, fear that that we may be inside the eurozone in two years."

In their determination to keep the Conservatives guessing ministers are still refusing to confirm the first Thursday in May - which is also local election day - though rival party strategists have been busily gearing their campaigns towards it for months. In theory a March 7 budget will still leave the option open to wrongfoot Mr Hague and the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy.

Reports that shadow ministers are already plotting Mr Hague's fall were widely discounted yesterday. If he gets his party from 164 seats to the 200-220 range that will suffice, MPs tell each other.

fields.headline: Valentine's Day heartache
fields.trailText: The FTSE 100 index closed 52.3 points adrift at 6,176.2 yesterday but to dealers it felt a much, much, worse Valentine's Day.
fields.body:
The FTSE 100 index closed 52.3 points adrift at 6,176.2 yesterday but to dealers it felt a much, much, worse Valentine's Day.

"Complete capitulation" was how one described trading in telecom and technology shares as the fallout from the Orange flotation and more earnings gloom from the other side Atlantic descended on the London market.

Trading on a "when issued" basis, Orange shares opened at 603.5p, fell to 554.5p before recovering to end the day at 559p, down 44.5p. All sorts of wild theories were put forward to explain pressure on the stock.

The most popular was that hedge funds long on Orange convertible bonds were shorting the ordinary shares in a complex and highly profitable arbitrage play. Another unlikely tale suggested that Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, one of the global co-ordinators on the float, had used up the entire "green shoe" - the block of funds set aside to stabilise the share price during the first month of dealings.

Whatever the truth - it seems likely institutions that got more shares than they bargained for in the float were behind the selling - the implications of the Orange flop was not lost on investors.

BT, which is committed to slicing £10bn from its £30bn debt mountain this year, was hardest hit, falling 43.5p to 567.5p. But it was not alone. Vodafone fell 6p to 210.5p, while telecoms equipment companies Marconi and Spirent lost 36p to 579p and 25p to 485p respectively.

The negative sentiment even affected fixed-line telecoms stocks such as Energis, down 33p to 463p, and Colt Telecom, off 134p to £13.86, which was also hit by "sell" advice from broker Investec Henderson Crosthwaite.

Cable & Wireless managed to emerge from the carnage only 13p down at 809p, supported by institutional buying after a well-received product and strategy presentation.

In the tech sector things were little better. Earnings disappointments from Nasdaq heavyweights Applied Materials and JDS Uniphase, combined with another profits warning from Bookham Technology (down 98p to 691p), undermined the FTSE Techmark 100, which ended the day 66.64 points weaker at 2,560.03.

Double-digit share price falls were common across the tech world with Imagination Technologies dropping 14p to 145.5p, Orchestream slipping 20p to 186p and Fibernet falling 70p to 760p.

At least software group Autonomy, down 65p at £15.68, provided some amusement. Early in the session a mystery trader mistakenly placed an order for 500m Autonomy shares on the stock exchange's electronic trading system, Sets. The order, said to be the largest in the history of the stock exchange, was quickly cancelled.

One had to look hard but there were some bright spots. Insurance outfit Royal & Sun Alliance advanced 17p to 531p on the back of "buy" advice from Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, while rival Prudential gained 40p to £10.50 on Tuesday's cost-cutting plan.

Logistics group Exel was also in demand, rising 18p to 958p after an upgrade from HSBC Securities.

The FTSE Mid 250 slipped 27.5 points to 6,747.5, with electronics firm Volex Group taking the title of worst performer, down 332.5p at £12.82 after a shock profits warning.

Even further down the corporate ladder, Mayflower, the bus builder and truck body group, was marked 12.5p lower at 85.5p after full-year figures fell short of expectations. But water company Mid-Kent Holdings climbed 17.5p to 480p. Dealers reckon a 550p cash offer is on the way.

webTitle: Simplify rules on Commons conduct, urges Major

fields.headline: Simplify rules on conduct, urges Major
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: John Major yesterday called for parliament "to go back to basics" and redraft its rules and regulations governing the conduct of MPs to make them simpler and easier to follow.
fields.body:
John Major yesterday called for parliament "to go back to basics" and redraft its rules and regulations governing the conduct of MPs to make them simpler and easier to follow.

The former prime minister attacked the growing complexity of rules governing MPs' behaviour, saying that they were becoming unnecessarily intrusive since they were introduced in the wake of the cash for questions' scandal involving ex-ministers Neil Hamilton and Tim Smith.

"The rules need to be revised every parliament to take account of changes. We need - dare I say it - to go back to basics, even though that phrase got associated with sex, which was never my intention," Mr Major said yesterday, in reference to a much-derided slogan of the last Tory government.

Mr Major was giving evidence to the Commons standards and privileges committee which is looking at changing the rules and declarations under the MPs' register of interests. "You need clarity and certainty to have equity and justice," he said.

Mr Major said he had been shocked at the behaviour of lobbyists and consultants which emrged in the cash for questions scandal and appalled at the behaviour of some of his colleagues. But he told the committee that there was a need for substantial reforms to update the original rules set out by Lord Nolan, first chairman of the committee on standards in public life.

He said the committee should be smaller, contain more lawyers and should concentrate solely on whether MPs had been in breach of the rules, and not become a body that made moral judgments on the conduct of MPs.

"If it started looking at cases involving members' morality it would be covering some very extraordinary cases," he said.

He condemned the use of the committee for " tit for tat" disputes between members of opposing parties "who rushed off to inform the press immediately a complaint had been made."

"It might a good idea that if the committee does have to deal with trivial complaints that it makes this clear in its findings. If that damages the reputation of the MP who brought the complaint, so be it. After one or two cases it would probably lead to this being stopped," Mr Major said.

He said where the complaint was about a MP genuinely forgetting to register a flight or a trip, it should be sorted out with Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards, and never reported.

Mr Major reserved his greatest criticism for a finding by the committee that affected him, when he was asked to declare his employment contract with an agency he had engaged to promote his speeches abroad.

This came in the wake of the upholding of a complaint against Ken Livingstone, Labour MP for Brent East, and now mayor of London. Mr Livingstone had failed to declare some £168,000 on speaking fees negotiated by agency agreements. Mr Major was then told he had to deposit his agreement, giving financial details of his fees after a complaint was made claiming he had not declared all his income.

"The requirement for the deposit of an employment agreement is onerous and artificial - and implies distrust of the member concerned. The registration of the remuneration that followed an employment agreement is unnecessary and intrusive and simply provides the media with ammunition against the member - and ultimately the institution of the Commons," he told MPs yeserday

Mr Major said that there was no need for such information to be deposited in parliament. Instead he said all MPs collecting big speech fees should have to sign a declaration saying they did not offer consulting services or were not offering any parliamentary advocacy of any kind.

Earlier this week the Conservative leader, William Hague, was forced to admit making misleading claims in the Commons register of MPs' interests over the distribution of profits from public speaking engagements to a charitable trust that had never actually been established in law.

webTitle: HIV man in court over 'unsafe sex'

fields.headline: HIV man in court over 'unsafe sex'
fields.trailText: A man accused of recklessness in giving his girlfriend HIV had twice been warned of the necessity of safe sex, the high court in Glasgow heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A man accused of recklessness in giving his girlfriend HIV had twice been warned of the necessity of safe sex, the high court in Glasgow heard yesterday.

Stephen Kelly, 33, of Provanmill in Glasgow, denies endangering the life of Anne Craig by having sexual intercourse between December 1993 and March 1994, knowing he was infected with HIV. He is accused of culpable and reckless conduct in repeatedly having unsafe sex even though she had no idea of his condition and he was fully aware of the risks.

The court heard from Anne Thompson, a nurse treating HIV and drugs misuse, that she had told Kelly, before and after he was tested for the virus, of the dangers associated with unsafe sex. In 1993, she was in a team sent to Glenochil prison, Stirlingshire. She told the court she twice met Kelly for pre-test counselling before breaking the news he was HIV-positive.

"Stephen's results had come back with a positive for HIV so I was expecting to have to give him that news," she told James Drummond Young QC, prosecuting. "I spoke to him about the result of his test, what it would mean and what could happen afterwards."

Ms Thompson said that during counselling she gave him information about medical help, how he should tell his family, and on his sexual behaviour. "It would particularly be about safe sex and sexual behaviour," she said. "It is quite specific, and many times quite intimate as well."

The court heard that Kelly said he was heterosexual and sexually active, and that Ms Thompson had given him specific advice about safe sex and the necessity of barrier contraception. Ms Thompson said she also discussed how best to tell prospective partners he was HIV positive.

Under cross-examination from defence counsel Donald Findlay QC, Ms Thompson was asked whether she thought Kelly would have been secretive about his condition: "I found him to be intelligent around the issue of people needing to know."

Later the court heard from Andrew Leigh-Brown, a professor at Edinburgh university and a specialist in HIV, that he had investigated an apparent outbreak at Glenochil in 1993, when Kelly was a prisoner there. His team found 14 men with the virus, of whom 13 had the same strain. Six definitely contracted the virus while in prison, he told the court.

Asked by Mr Findlay if it was possible to say who had infected whom, the professor said it was not possible. But he agreed that, given other information, it was possible to identify the likely source.

The trial continues.

webTitle: Decision due today on Legacy dome bid

fields.headline: Decision due today on Legacy dome bid
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Ministers will decide today whether to reject Legacy's bid for the Millennium Dome or extend yesterday's deadline.
fields.body:
Ministers will decide today whether to reject Legacy's bid for the Millennium Dome or extend yesterday's deadline.

A cabinet committee chaired by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, is poised to end months of speculation over the ownership of the Greenwich site ahead of the expected May election.

A senior Whitehall source made clear yesterday that the government would give the consortium longer to finalise a deal only if it believed an agreement was close.

The alternative was to invite fresh offers, which would inevitably mean the complex was still in public hands at the election.

"Everyone knows it is make your mind up time," the source said.

Legacy, bolstered by the inclusion of the property developer Teesland in the consortium, was confident that it would be given between eight and 28 days to complete the £125m deal.

"The champagne is on ice," an executive involved in the discussions said. "We will be very surprised if it does not happen."

But critics of the deal, led by the former dome chief executive Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, who is seeking to put his own bid together, urged the government to reopen the competition.

Legacy is pinning its hopes on the involvement of the developer Teesland overcoming fears expressed by English Partnerships, a government agency, that the bid was flawed and few companies would sign up for space in the dome.

Scarborough-based Teesland is already involved in projects with English Partnerships.

Mr Prescott's committee includes the dome minister, Lord Falconer, Treasury chief secretary, Andrew Smith, local government minister, Hilary Armstrong, and tourism minister, Janet Anderson.

webTitle: MPs may get extra pay for asylum workload

fields.headline: MPs may get extra pay for asylum workload
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: MPs overburdened with high numbers of asylum seekers in their constituencies may be given more money to pay for an extra member of staff to help cope with their ever-increasing caseloads.
fields.body:
MPs overburdened with high numbers of asylum seekers in their constituencies may be given more money to pay for an extra member of staff to help cope with their ever-increasing caseloads.

In the first overhaul of parliamentary allowances for five years, the independent Senior Salaries Review Body (SSRB) is considering recommending increasing MPs' office allowances of £51,572 a-year.

A decision is not due until the start of next month, but the board's chairman, Sir Michael Perry, is believed to be sympathetic after hearing evidence from inner-city MPs who spend more time on asylum seekers than on their voting constituents.

Some politicians fear MPs may be forced from parliament by a combination of working 100-hour weeks and dipping into their own pockets to fund extra staff.

Pressure for an increase has come from the likes of Simon Hughes, Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman and MP for Southwark North and Bermondsey, who last year spent £25,000 of his £48,371 salary to pay for an extra employee and who estimates a third of his constituency time is spent on asylum work.

Labour's Karen Buck, MP for Regents Park and Kensington North, said: "I have 500 letters, emails and phone calls a week - up to a half of which will deal with asylum seekers.

"My asylum caseload and that of other colleagues would easily outweigh the total case load of hundreds of other MPs."

But Tory David Wilshire, whose Spelthorne constituency covers Heathrow, denied he needed extra funding. "I have a huge problem ... but that doesn't mean I'm going to demand an extra member of staff. This is a very dangerous precedent to set."

His comments came as his leader, William Hague, accused the prime minister during question time of sinking "to a new low" by agreeing with a minister's statement that the cost of supporting asylum seekers was £664m when an internal Home Office memo placed the cost at £835m.

Mr Blair argued that the lower figure, which he stood by, was the budget for asylum, while the larger was the actual cost, which varied depending on numbers.

webTitle: Just one duetto, Lucy urges Madge

fields.headline: Just one duetto, Lucy urges Madge
fields.trailText: "Big Lucy to Material Girl: Call, just call". This was Luciano Pavarotti's Valentine plea yesterday to Madonna asking her to sing with him, as he announced plans for his first giant, open-air London concert in 10 years.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
"Big Lucy to Material Girl: Call, just call". This was Luciano Pavarotti's Valentine plea yesterday to Madonna asking her to sing with him, as he announced plans for his first giant, open-air London concert in 10 years.

The opera star hopes also to lure Sir Paul McCartney to the stage in July. But Madonna has not yet replied. He appealed to journalists: "You should ask her, you should implore her to come to my concert."

He revealed that he had already discussed singing the romantic aria, Caro Mio Bene, with her at one of his concerts in his home town of Modena. "She is busy, I think ... If you can make a contact I thank you very much."

The charity concert in Hyde Park, on July 14, is being put on to raise £1m for the Prince's Trust. The sponsor, Safeway, will be selling 17,000 tickets, priced £17.50, from today, in more than 500 supermarkets.

Pavarotti, solo and with Placido Domingo and Jose Carreras as the Three Tenors, is credited with pioneering "stadium opera", which smashed the barriers between classical and popular culture.

Since the Hyde Park concert in July 1991 he has performed live to millions, including one of the largest classical concerts ever held, when he sang to more than 500,000 in Central Park, New York.

Yesterday Pavarotti said the 1991 Hyde Park concert remained one of the highlights of his 40-year career. It took place on one of the wettest evenings of the summer, in relentless rain. Prince Charles and Diana were among those who obeyed pleas not to block the view of others with umbrellas and sat through the entire performance with raincoats pulled over their heads.

"Rainalotti," he said fondly, remembering the tabloid headlines. "I will never forget to see the prince and princess, and all the politicians of every party, sat in the front row without umbrellas, as had been asked. From this point of view I will say I hope it is raining again this time."

The state of the tenor's health and his voice have been endlessly debated in the past five years. While critics have detected signs of wear in his voice, he remains one of the world's greatest box office attractions. Yesterday, he looked well, and was in jokey mood. Asked if he saw himself still performing into his 80s, he said fervently: "No, no, I will definitely stop before that."

webTitle: Parklife Leeds' new urban space dazzles experts

fields.headline: Parklife Leeds' new urban space dazzles experts
fields.trailText: Yorkshire's answer to Barcelona unveiled the most technically advanced public space in Europe yesterday, to a conference of international urban experts who were - quite literally - dazzled.
fields.body:
Yorkshire's answer to Barcelona unveiled the most technically advanced public space in Europe yesterday, to a conference of international urban experts who were - quite literally - dazzled.

As temperatures in Leeds climb into the 70s, commuters had picnics under the new plaza's mobile trees and ice-skaters rolled up shirt sleeves on the central ice rink.

"This place is uniquely successful in Britain in drawing back people into the city," said Lord Rogers, the dome architect and head of the government's urban task force, squinting at the £12m Millennium Square's laser tower and 36-channel sound mixer console.

"This is how you make a city a place for people once again, somewhere friends and strangers can meet."

The ghosts of long-dead Leeds aldermen may puzzle over some of their city's new ornaments, which include a 15-metre high rugby ball sculpture - still to be finished - and underground quarters for singers and bands who will stage regular concerts for up to 7,000 people right outside the council chamber.

"The idea from the start is that this should be a democratic space," said John Thorp, Leeds civic architect and designer of the the 4,500 square metre showpiece. "We drew on the model of Athens, with a bit of help from World of Interiors magazine, which is where I spotted a piece about the mobile trees at Versailles."

The 18 full-size trees have their own designated forklift truck to rearrange their position allowing small gatherings or major concerts. Other technical innovations, demonstrated last night to the Urban Vitality conference delegates, include eight diode lasers and two haze machines which recreate minor versions of the great smogs of yesteryear.

The initiative was also praised at the conference by Ed Balls, chief economic adviser to the Treasury and tipped for a parliamentary candidacy in West Yorkshire at the coming election. He said that although the critical mass of London inevitably dominated, urban enterprise was spreading, encouraged by increasing devolution of power to cities and regions.

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.trailText: Bad day | Optimist of day | Today
fields.body:
Bad day

Portcullis House. Tory MP Nicholas Winterton claimed that despite £233m being spent on the plush MPs' offices, every toilet in the building was broken. This follows problems with escalators, lifts and the the 12 fig trees imported at a cost of £150,000 which have started shedding leaves. The Speaker, Michael Martin, blamed a burst water main for the latest problem.

Optimist of day

Bookmakers William Hill disclosed that an unnamed woman from Durham has staked £3,500 on the Tories to win the next election. She stands to win £14,000, after getting odds of 4-1. It is the biggest single bet on the Tories since the last election.

Today

Commons: Trade and industry questions. Debate on BSE inquiry report.

Lords: Political Parties, Elections and Referendums Act (disapplication of part IV for Northern Ireland parties) order 2001. Vehicles (crime) bill, second reading.

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Tide and time
fields.trailText: Tide and time
fields.body:
The Burren, Ireland

A King Canute coin of 1035 was found last year in Limerick City South during excavations near the rivers Shannon and Abbey. I find archaeological discoveries deeply satisfying, a marriage between the factual and the imaginative. In these same excavations, still in progress, were also found a well-preserved fulacht fiadh (cooking place), a Viking zoomorphic mound, a spur and silver groat minted in Calais (Henry VI), a port seal of the 16th century, mortar bombs, and a beautifully decorated sword hilt of the Williamite Wars, as well as revolvers and a hand grenade from our own Civil War. What a historical sequence, all in the same tight-knit location, portraying human occupa tions, cooking, trading, making war, and its corollary, killing. What busy creatures lived and died there? What hopes and fears filled their hearts? And now, whether full of importance or lowly in their living, their "little lives are rounded with a sleep" (Shakespeare) .

Such were my musings as I stood beside our nearest fulacht fiadh, a green mound with a round cut in one side, near the O'Loghien Castle of Gleninagh, each separated in time, both so close to the ocean's edge. As I walked by the sea I saw its excavatory efforts: stones and shells flung by raging tides; a bright yellow bucket; one canvas shoe. I turn for home and after the last round of the road I see spread before me, as if for the first time, a few of Ballyvaughan's rooftops and the small green fields ascending in their infinity of shapes, bordered by the simple drystone walls, limited by the stark beauty of the limestone hills whose line I follow to the Flaggy Shore and its Martello Tower.

fields.headline: Letter
fields.trailText: Julia North and George Costigan write: Cyril Taylor (Obituary, January 8) was our family doctor when we had our first two children in Liverpool in 1979-84, and the debt is large. Cautious of giving antibiotics to babies, he would rather monitor the infant's ability to cope.
fields.body: Julia North and George Costigan write: Cyril Taylor (Obituary, January 8) was our family doctor when we had our first two children in Liverpool in 1979-84, and the debt is large. Cautious of giving antibiotics to babies, he would rather monitor the infant's ability to cope. "Let the immune system develop," he would say. We believe it is no accident that our children enjoy robust health. He taught us how to recognise our babies' signals, trust our instincts and never be afraid to demand more of our doctors. Help people help each other seemed to be his mantra, and the marvellous Princess Park Health Centre was a testament to this tenet. On leaving Liverpool and being cast out into the real world of prescription-writing GPs, we wrote to Cyril, thanking him and his colleagues. In typical fashion he wrote back, courteously thanking us, but with the firm reminder that it was up to educated, articulate people like ourselves to campaign for good quality health care for all; to make things better. More than 10 years later I happened across him walking down Bold Street. I stopped him with: "You won't remember me..." to be interrupted with "Julia North, three boys. How's George?" Flattered? You bet. He must have touched thousands in similar ways.

webTitle: Obituary: Moses Molelekwa, young jazz musician from the townships.

fields.headline: Moses Molelekwa
fields.standfirst: Young jazz musician from the townships whose blend of the African and western offered a new vision
fields.trailText: The pianist, composer and producer Moses Taiwa Molelekwa, who has been found hanged at the age of 27 next to the body of his wife, Florence, was the brightest hope for a renaissance of South Africa's jazz culture. During the 1990s, his synthesis of African and western idioms, both traditional and contemporary, offered a brave new vision of the Rainbow Nation.
fields.body:
The pianist, composer and producer Moses Taiwa Molelekwa, who has been found hanged at the age of 27 next to the body of his wife, Florence, was the brightest hope for a renaissance of South Africa's jazz culture. During the 1990s, his synthesis of African and western idioms, both traditional and contemporary, offered a brave new vision of the Rainbow Nation.

The two albums he released were heralded in the west as cutting edge and also earned him South African Music Awards. Despite his limited recording career, he was acknowledged in South Africa as a "modern great". He had recently widened his range by producing some of the hottest stars of kwaito music - the new, urban groove which melds garage, ragga and hip-hop with the ambience of township jive.

Molelekwa was born in Tembia township outside Johannesburg, growing up among what he described as "the lost generation". Both his father and grandfather were musicians, and Moses was introduced to jazz through his father's collection of John Coltrane, Thelonious Monk and Miles Davis records. He started playing guitar and Casio keyboard before studying piano on Saturdays at the Federated Union of Black Arts Academy. "There is no question that music saved my life," he said later.

When he graduated in 1987, with a diploma and best student award, he was already working at Kippie's nightclub, where he accompanied internationally-renowned artists including Miriam Makeba and Jonas Gwangwa.

In 1988, he joined Hugh Masekela's band and later toured the US with Dorothy Masuka and Julian Bahula. He founded two bands, Brotherhood and Umbongo, in which he played simultaneously and which alternately won awards in 1991 and 1992. He also worked on theatre productions and film soundtracks.

In 1994, Robert Trunz, owner of the Melt2000 label, invited him to join other progressive South African musicians for the Outernational Meltdown compilation, to celebrate the diversity and hope of the new South Africa. His first album, Finding Oneself (1995), announced the arrival of a serious innovator in South Africa's ongoing relationship with jazz, continuing the path opened up by Abdulla Ibrahim. The album won two South African Music Awards, for best traditional and best contemporary jazz, and was highly praised in Europe.

Molelekwa then spent more than a year recording his second album, Genes And Spirits, of which he said: "I wanted both to reach a wider audience and experiment more." He succeeded on both counts; his musical versatility, eclectic repertoire and suave presentation helped define the new cool. With guests such as the Brazilian singer Flora Purim, Cuban pianist Chuco Valdes and Cameroonian funk drummer Wassy Brice, this CD was less obviously South African, incorporating reggae and drum 'n' bass along with world music input.

Genes And Spirits won Molelekwa another South African Music Award, while the high production values of Trunz's label and the slick marketing made the music internationally accessible. He played at the Queen Elizabeth Hall, London, and at the North Sea Jazz Festival in two consecutive years. In 2000, he toured Britain with Joanna MacGregor. Sales of the Genes And Spirits CD have just started to take off in the US, where the video is being shown on cable TV stations.

Robert Trunz described Molelekwa as "an extremely talented musician, a very delicate and sensitive person". He had virtually completed a third album of solo piano numbers for MELT2000 and was gigging with a line-up of younger musicians.

He had also spread his attentions from jazz to the more commercial and frenetic kwaito scene. He had started producing other artists, including Sibongie Khumalo and TKZee, the biggest selling kwaito group, and had produced the leader Tokolo's new record for BMG. In recent months colleagues say he had been working and playing too hard.

It was known that his marriage was in difficulty. His 35-year-old wife and manager, Florence Mtoba, was also a prominent figure. fields.bodyText: The pianist, composer and producer Moses Taiwa Molelekwa, who has been found hanged at the age of 27 next to the body of his wife, Florence, was the brightest hope for a renaissance of South Africa's jazz culture. During the 1990s, his synthesis of African and western idioms, both traditional and contemporary, offered a brave new vision of the Rainbow Nation. The two albums he released were heralded in the west as cutting edge and also earned him South African Music Awards. Despite his limited recording career, he was acknowledged in South Africa as a "modern great". He had recently widened his range by producing some of the hottest stars of kwaito music - the new, urban groove which melds garage, ragga and hip-hop with the ambience of township jive. Molelekwa was born in Tembia township outside Johannesburg, growing up among what he described as "the lost generation". Both his father and grandfather were musicians, and Moses was introduced to jazz through his father's collection of John Coltrane, Thelonious Monk and Miles Davis records. He started playing guitar and Casio keyboard before studying piano on Saturdays at the Federated Union of Black Arts Academy. "There is no question that music saved my life," he said later. When he graduated in 1987, with a diploma and best student award, he was already working at Kippie's nightclub, where he accompanied internationally-renowned artists including Miriam Makeba and Jonas Gwangwa. In 1988, he joined Hugh Masekela's band and later toured the US with Dorothy Masuka and Julian Bahula. He founded two bands, Brotherhood and Umbongo, in which he played simultaneously and which alternately won awards in 1991 and 1992. He also worked on theatre productions and film soundtracks. In 1994, Robert Trunz, owner of the Melt2000 label, invited him to join other progressive South African musicians for the Outernational Meltdown compilation, to celebrate the diversity and hope of the new South Africa. His first album, Finding Oneself (1995), announced the arrival of a serious innovator in South Africa's ongoing relationship with jazz, continuing the path opened up by Abdulla Ibrahim. The album won two South African Music Awards, for best traditional and best contemporary jazz, and was highly praised in Europe. Molelekwa then spent more than a year recording his second album, Genes And Spirits, of which he said: "I wanted both to reach a wider audience and experiment more." He succeeded on both counts; his musical versatility, eclectic repertoire and suave presentation helped define the new cool. With guests such as the Brazilian singer Flora Purim, Cuban pianist Chuco Valdes and Cameroonian funk drummer Wassy Brice, this CD was less obviously South African, incorporating reggae and drum 'n' bass along with world music input. Genes And Spirits won Molelekwa another South African Music Award, while the high production values of Trunz's label and the slick marketing made the music internationally accessible. He played at the Queen Elizabeth Hall, London, and at the North Sea Jazz Festival in two consecutive years. In 2000, he toured Britain with Joanna MacGregor. Sales of the Genes And Spirits CD have just started to take off in the US, where the video is being shown on cable TV stations. Robert Trunz described Molelekwa as "an extremely talented musician, a very delicate and sensitive person". He had virtually completed a third album of solo piano numbers for MELT2000 and was gigging with a line-up of younger musicians. He had also spread his attentions from jazz to the more commercial and frenetic kwaito scene. He had started producing other artists, including Sibongie Khumalo and TKZee, the biggest selling kwaito group, and had produced the leader Tokolo's new record for BMG. She had previously managed other musicians, including Busi Mhlongo, and was highly regarded in music and cultural circles. webTitle: Coping with being denied access to grandchildren

fields.headline: A year without Jack and Helen
fields.standfirst: Catherine Hemingway  talks about coping with being denied access to her grandchildren
fields.trailText: Catherine Hemingway  talks about coping with being denied access to her grandchildren
fields.body:
I was making the bed and listening to Woman's Hour: we grandparents were being invited to phone in with our experiences. I smiled, knowing I would not call as all I would have to say was that it was pure joy. Our son's little Jack was six, his sister Helen four, as was our daughter's Lydia. We saw them all regularly and being a grandmother seemed a huge and wonderful part of my life.

That morning I listened to callers describing the pleasures and demands, the learning and frustrations, and from some later callers, the heartache. Sad voices told of their children's broken marriages and vanished grandchildren, of relationships with daughters-in-law that went mysteriously wrong, and of failed attempts to gain access to beloved grandchildren. How sad to experience such loss, I thought. How lucky I am.

The following week, it happened to me. That was a year ago, and we have not seen Jack and Helen since.

Derek and I had recently visited our daughter-in-law, Lynn, for a night. At the last minute, our son, Peter, had to go away on business, but he had assured us we would be welcome. It seemed to go well. It was true that the children, clearly missing their dad, were quarrelling more than usual, but we felt encouraged by the fact that Lynn talked to us about it, for she is a reserved person. We emailed Peter, telling him of our happy weekend.

The first we knew that anything was wrong was Lynn's phone call some days later. She was angry and resentful: the weekend had been awful; I was critical, interfering; the Toddler Taming book I had offered an insult. She could usually cope when Peter was around; now it was all too much. She made increasingly wild accusations. Unable to resolve things, I put down the phone in a state of shock.

We and our son have tried to recover the situation, so far without success. The more Derek and I pressed for a reconciliation, the more strain it put on their marriage. Important though grandparents are in children's lives, we felt that for their parents to be together was their anchor. We have sent birthday and Christmas presents, but that is all.

Coping with the loss, the sense of failure and the helplessness, has tested us to the limits. We could not have done it without the support of family and close friends, especially of our daughter. Talking with them has helped me not just to relieve the pain by sharing it, but to seek to make sense of it. I have discovered that tension between mother and daughter-in-law is more common than I had realised. I had not thought of myself as powerful in this sense. My hurt had made me feel a victim, which is a comforting place to be - for a while. But it solves nothing and I have had to do some hard thinking. Offering ideas and supportive advice is one thing with my daughter, who generally finds it useful, and is quite able to tell me when she doesn't. But the relationship with a daughter-in-law is entirely different. We had underestimated the extent to which Lynn felt unable to help us to fit in better with her needs: the pressure built up and the volcano erupted.

I only now recognise that I felt I should be the perfect granny. My own grandmother was hugely important to me as I grew up. My daughter loved my mother in much the same way. They were both great role models for me. Perhaps that desire of mine got in the way of my picking up small signs that could have told us all was not well.

I am learning instead to be a "good enough granny" and I hope this will give everyone more space. In the meantime, the hardest part is knowing how quickly Jack and Helen are growing and changing.

And yet we know we are lucky, too. Our daughter Kate gave birth to Rebecca last Easter. We see the family regularly, watch and listen as Lydia, who has started school, embraces life as only a happy five-year-old can. As I write, Rebecca has learned to crawl and her mum has returned to work. I mark half-terms and holidays in the diary. We are thankful for the joys that come from being active grandparents. But we shall never again take them for granted.

fields.headline: Edith Whetham
fields.standfirst: Understanding agriculture - in Britain and Africa
fields.trailText: Edith Holt Whetham, who has died aged 89, was, unusually for a woman of her time, an agricultural economist. She taught both at Cambridge University and in Africa, and wrote books which looked at agriculture both in this country and the developing world.
fields.body:
Edith Holt Whetham, who has died aged 89, was, unusually for a woman of her time, an agricultural economist. She taught both at Cambridge University and in Africa, and wrote books which looked at agriculture both in this country and the developing world.

Her family was closely connected with Cambridge - her father was an academic and her mother was, in 1889, one of the earliest students at Newnham College. Edith and three of her four sisters continued the tradition. As well as this strong academic background, her family were also associated with agriculture, owning a manor house in Devon and then inheriting a small estate, Hilfield, near Dorchester, in Dorset, where the family spent their holidays.

As a child, Edith spent two years in bed following a fall. She recovered, but her hearing had been damaged and she always remained of tiny stature and with a frail constitution. Educated by a governess in her early years and then at Downe House School, near Newbury, she went to Newnham in 1930. Most unusually, for a woman in that era, she read economics. It was an exciting time. She heard Maynard Keynes lecture as he was starting to develop his great theory. He would, she remembered, often return a week later and say, "I thought again and you should ignore what I said last time."

She started work at a difficult time. While, even in the depression, men with firsts were sure of a good academic job, it was different for a woman. For three years she worked as a resident scholar at the Ministry of Agriculture: this was the beginning of a lifetime's work in agricultural economics. She then took a job at the Economist. The war was spent first at the Ministry of Food and then in the Cabinet Office civil history department. After the war, she returned to agricultural economics and economic history, this time in the academic world. She then returned to Cambridge as Gilbey lecturer in the history and economics of agriculture, and held this post until 1963.

This was when she developed her creative work. Her first major publication, British Farming 1939-1949, came out in 1952. It is a fascinating account of agriculture in Britain at a critical period, when farming switched from a depressed state to playing a major role in feeding the nation.

One of her key jobs was to teach agricultural economics on the land economy or agriculture degree courses. Years later, former students would describe how this tiny woman had lectured to a bunch of hulking students. Edith resigned from her Cambridge job in 1963 and shifted her energies to investigating the developing world.

Despite her constitution, she accepted a job at Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria, Nigeria, as visiting professor of economics and later as professor of economics. She was conscious of the need to address the economic issues that were relevant to what were then rural peasant economies.

During the 1960s she brought out a number of important books. These included A History of British Agriculture, 1846-1914 (in collaboration with Christabel Orwell). There was also work on development issues; a textbook, The Economics of African Countries, in collaboration with myself; and a book on African marketing systems.

In 1966, she was appointed to the executive of the Agricultural Economics Society; in 1971, she was elected president. She continued to research throughout the 1970s, writing the eighth volume of the Cambridge University series Agrarian History of England and Wales (1978).

Edith's life was not confined to academia. She had a strong sense of fun and an indomitable and adventurous spirit. When young, she rode elephants through the jungle in India and, in the early 1930s, rode a horse much of the way between Cambridge and the family estate in Dorset, making use of the neolithic Icknield Way.

There were other adventures by horse, bicycle and, above all, by canoe. The day before she died she reminisced about sailing up the Thames; as she reached Tower Bridge, it had swung open - as if for her benefit.

fields.headline: Lawrence suspect had illegal baton
fields.standfirst: Special report: Stephen Lawrence
fields.trailText: One of the five men questioned by police over the murder of the black teenager Stephen Lawrence has been sentenced to 50 hours' community service for possessing an illegal weapon.
fields.body:
One of the five men questioned by police over the murder of the black teenager Stephen Lawrence has been sentenced to 50 hours' community service for possessing an illegal weapon.

Neil Stuart, who has changed his name from Acourt by deed poll, was stopped by police, who found a police baton - similar to that used in martial arts - on June 14 last year.

He admitted the offence at Canterbury crown court, and was ordered to pay £100 costs by recorder David Mitchell.

Stuart, 25, of Greenwich, south London, had appeared in Folkestone magistrates court in Kent on the day he was stopped, charged with smuggling illegal immigrants.

He was cleared of the charge on Monday.

Stuart was caught by police speeding at 45mph in a 30mph zone in a hire car half a mile from the court.

He appeared before the magistrates that afternoon charged with possessing an extendible ABS police baton, which officers had found in the car.

Nigel Van Der Bijl, prosecuting, said yesterday that Stuart had told police the baton was used to defend himself.

In a statement to police he said: "The baton was there to protect myself and to hit people. It was there for self-defence."

But Stuart insisted he had not needed to use the weapon on any occasion, although he was concerned about repercussions from the publicity of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry.

fields.headline: 'We view people who attack us as legitimate targets'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Shortly after the current intifada began, Colonel Daniel Reisner, head of the Israeli army's international law branch, set out the military's position on assassinations:
fields.body:
Shortly after the current intifada began, Colonel Daniel Reisner, head of the Israeli army's international law branch, set out the military's position on assassinations:

From a legal perspective, classical international law actually only recognises two situations: peace or war. But life isn't as simple as that, and there are lots of terms concerning the in-between: "lower intensity conflict", "limited war", etc.

Be the term what it may, the current situation - the fact that a large percentage of the attacks involve live weapons, that we are facing a Palestinian authority, that we are facing a Palestinian security service which in part is taking active participation in hostilities - has brought us to the conclusion that we are no longer in the realm of peace.

So where are we? While we are not at the end of the spectrum which is war, because war is a conflict between two armies or two states, we are definitely in the area of armed conflict. Call it what you wish, some call it "un-conflict", some call it "active hostilities" ... we have reached the decision that the current situation has more of a semblance of war than of peace.

As a result, we are also applying the principles applicable to warfare to the current situation ...

Up to the current events [starting in October 2000], the rules of engagement of the Israel defence forces in the West Bank and Gaza strip were police rules of engagement. Use of live weapons only in self-defence, or after a warning shot to carry out an arrest.

When this new situation came about, we came to the legal decision that we have crossed the line between the area of peace and the area of active hostility. We therefore looked again at our rules of engagement, because the facts had changed.

Assassination is not a legal term, at least not in international law - assassination is a word which I've heard used in a criminal context.

In international law of warfare, people can be divided into two categories: combatants and non-combatants. You are allowed to target combatants, you are not allowed to target non-combatants. You cannot aim at them. So that's the only relevant question.

In the current situation, people who attack us have been identified by us as combatants. As a result we view them as legitimate targets. That specific individual falls under that category, therefore he was attacked and killed.
