fields.headline: No 1820 Yoshiro Mori
fields.trailText: Who? He's Japan's prime minister.
fields.body:
Who? He's Japan's prime minister.

So he's big in Japan is he? Not exactly. He's not a very popular man at the moment.

Well you can't have your cake and eat it too: you can either be popular or you can be a world leader. True enough, but opinion polls show support for Mr Mori's government is below 20%.

Blimey! What has he done? Banned I Will Survive from the karaoke play list? Got a bit too friendly with Hello Kitty? No, he has committed something of a political faux pas.

We all have our off days. Yes but Mr Mori was having a particularly off day on Saturday.

Oh dear . . . a few too many glasses of sake on Friday night? No, Mr Mori was busy playing golf with some university chums just outside Tokyo on Saturday morning.

I realise that golf is hardly high-speed motor racing, but a penchant for the old irons is surely not reason enough for the opinion polls to droop. No, but halfway through the game the prime minister learned that a Japanese fishing vessel had collided with an American nuclear submarine off Hawaii.

Ah. But Mori continued to enjoy his game for a further two hours before heading back to Tokyo.

Perhaps he was in shock. Or perhaps he was too busy playing at being Nick Faldo. That's understandable. No it isn't. Indeed, the deputy opposition leader, Naoto Kan claimed Mori was "not qualified to handle crisis management".

Well he doesn't exactly sound on the ball. Ah ha ha.

Speaking of which, what was President Bush's response to the incident? Apparently, Mr Bush telephoned Mr Mori on Tuesday to offer an apology for the sinking.

But Mr Mori was too busy playing lawn tennis? I believe it's badminton on Tuesday.

fields.trailText: What an excellent choice George Bush made in appointing squillionaire horse breeder Will Farish to be US ambassador in London. William Stamps Farish III (to give him his full name) managed Bush senior's wealth during his presidency and is a good friend of the Queen, who has stayed four times at his stud farm.

The pair have more than just horses in common: both have embarrassing relatives with too-close-for-comfort connections to the Nazis. Our own dear Queen of course has her uncle the Duke of Windsor, while Mr Farish has his grandfather, William Stamps Farish Sr, who in 1942 pleaded guilty and was fined $5,000 for criminal conspiracy with Nazi Germany. Farish Sr was president and chief executive of Standard Oil New Jersey (which we all now know and love as Exxon), which co-operated with German chemical company IG Farben (well known for its work in Auschwitz) to produce artificial rubber vital to the German war effort, for which Mr Farish's company held the patents.

 Still, that was a long time ago, and this generation's Farish is more interested in horses than dealing with Nazis. A mere $100,000 buys the services of his champion sire Lemon Drop Kid, who also has some amusing and embarrassing ancestors: Gold Digger and Buckpasser, for example (which suggests a sense of irony), and Gay Missile (which suggests something else).

 It is hard to feel sorry for Mervyn King, the iron fist to Sir Eddie George's iron glove at the Bank of England. At yesterday's inflation report press conference Mervyn was under the weather. The official line is that he had a cold, but perhaps poor Mervyn was upset at not getting any Valentine's cards. It all makes sense: the red-rimmed eyes, the sniffles... but press officer Andrew Wardlow was not having any of it when we rang to ask if Mervyn was feeling unloved. "I'm not going to let you walk me down that path," says Andrew. Ooooh, you have seen through my cunning plan. Well, can we send Mervyn some Lemsip? "You're free to do what you like," Andrew rather rashly concedes. A sachet is on its way... and may be the first of many gifts.

 "Timing is everything when you're buying and selling shares," reads the Orange advert on page 29 of yesterday's Times. Readers are free to reflect on the irony of that advice and the miserable showing of Orange's shares since they floated on Tuesday.

 The mobile phone market appears to be reaching saturation, according to Nokia's latest results, but a novel application may give the company a boost. A hospital in Taiwan surgically removed a Nokia mobile from the rectum of a 20-year-old woman, according to the Ananova website, after a sex game went wrong. A hospital spokeswoman said: "We guessed it's because some cellphones have a vibrating function." It brings a new meaning to the term "hands free".

webTitle: Father told he must wait to see in vitro daughter

fields.headline: Father told he must wait to see in vitro daughter
fields.trailText: A man who became the legal father of a child born to his former partner after artificial insemination by an anonymous donor has been told he will not be allowed to see the child for the time being.
fields.body:
A man who became the legal father of a child born to his former partner after artificial insemination by an anonymous donor has been told he will not be allowed to see the child for the time being.

In the first case of its kind, the 38-year-old man, who is infertile as a result of testicular cancer, sought an order allowing him to share parental responsibility. This was even though he has no biological link to the child and the mother had a new partner when the child was conceived.

The man is the one-year-old girl's legal father because he and his partner, who had difficulty conceiving naturally, jointly sought in vitro fertilisation using donated sperm and both were counselled and signed the consent form.

The first attempt at treatment failed and the couple separated, but the woman, by then with a new partner, went for a second course of treatment and became pregnant without telling the hospital she was no longer with her former partner. Under the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act 1990, if treatment is provided jointly for a woman and a man who are not married the law treats the man as the child's father.

Both parties, from Merseyside, signed forms agreeing to the treatment in 1998. A year later the mother, now 34, conceived. The new man in her life wanted to accept the baby as his own and she told her former partner she would not let him have anything to do with the child.

He went to the high court last year seeking an order giving him parental responsibility and the right initially to send cards and presents to the girl with a view to direct contact later. All the parties conceded that he was her legal father, but Judge Mark Hedley adjourned the application for parental responsibility. He ruled that the man should have indirect contact, through cards and presents, but said he would be unlikely to allow direct contact until the girl was at least three.

The judge said: "In every such debate the rights of adults need to be balanced by the consequences on children, not so much when they are young, but when they have to come to terms with where they have come from and who they truly are."

The man went to the court of appeal, where three judges agreed with Judge Hedley's ruling. Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, Lady Justice Hale and Lady Justice Arden, who delivered their judgment on Tuesday, said the case should be reported to the human fertilisation and embryology authority.

Dame Elizabeth, who barred identification of the parties, said the mother had been unable to cope with any direct contact between her former partner and her daughter. "If the father continues to be sensible and reasonable and the mother continues to be sensible, it is not beyond the bounds of possibility that she might agree to let him see the child."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Severed hand fell into tar | £25,000 CJD payouts | Boy, 10, found hanged at home | Young Irish top drink league | Dalek for sale | Arson is cover for murder | Caution for aspirin-takers | Landslide blocks railway | Lottery numbers
fields.body:
Severed hand fell into tar

Surgeons were yesterday trying to save the severed hand of a builder which fell into a vat of molten tar while he worked on a roof at Seaford golf club in East Sussex.

The builder, in his 60s, had his arm caught in an industrial shredder. The hand was recovered and packed in ice. The man was said to be stable in hospital.

£25,000 CJD payouts

Families of victims of variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (vCJD), the human form of mad cow disease, are each to get interim compensation payments of £25,000, the government announced yesterday.

A no-fault compensation package was announced last year after the inquiry by Lord Phillips into the BSE scandal.

Boy, 10, found hanged at home

A 10-year-old boy has been found hanged at his home. Jevan Richardson, from Lewisham, south-east London, was discovered by his father, Oliver, on Tuesday night. Scotland Yard said there was no evidence of crime.

Young Irish top drink league

Young people in Ireland drink more alcohol more frequently than the youth of other European countries, according to research revealed yesterday at the launch of a three-year alcohol awareness campaign by the Irish government.

Dalek for sale

One of Dr Who's most feared enemies - a Dalek - is for sale for £4,000 at the Panorama Bay Motor Company in Poole, Dorset. The Dalek was earlier part-exchanged for an E-Type Jaguar.

MoD consults on naval wrecks

The MoD is consulting divers and fishermen on measures to safeguard naval wrecks. Junior minister Lewis Moonie made the announcement at Scapa Flow in the Orkneys where the Royal Navy is working to stop oil seeping from the battleship Royal Oak, torpedoed in 1939 and the grave of 833 servicemen.

Arson is cover for murder

Two 19-year-olds have been arrested by detectives investigating the murder of Sophie Welcome, a drama student, aged 19. She was found dead on Monday after an arson blaze at her flat in West Bromwich, but detectives said yesterday she died of strangulation.

Caution for aspirin-takers

Healthy people at low risk of heart disease should not take a daily dose of aspirin because of the potentially dangerous side effects, according to the journal Heart; for high or moderate risk, the benefits far outweigh the risks. Up to 10% of the population take the drug to thin their blood.

Landslide blocks railway

A landslide brought down trees as well as earth on the railway between Balcombe and Three Bridges in West Sussex, preventing through trains on the London to Brighton line. Railtrack hoped to have the line clear by yesterday evening, and said that the slip, and others recently in Sussex, were caused by ground being "absolutely saturated" by rain.

Lottery numbers

Winning numbers in last night's lottery were 3, 10, 23, 27, 30, and 32; bonus 19. The jackpot was an estimated £10m. Lottery extra numbers were 3, 12, 19, 27, 28 and 38; estimated jackpot £1.9m.

webTitle: Bush's diplomatic appointment for father's friend

fields.headline: Soft touch for Uncle Sam's envoy
fields.standfirst:
Bush repays father's debt to Texan admirer of the Queen

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Bush repays father's debt to Texan admirer of the Queen, with diplomatic posting as ambassador to the Court of St James.
fields.body:
As William Farish will soon discover, there are tougher diplomatic postings in the new world order than ambassador to the Court of St James.

A Texan horse breeder, investment banker and, most pertinently, a significant contributor to George Bush's presidential campaign war chest, Mr Farish will take office later this year.

He is the latest in a line of political appointees to the London job, traditionally bestowed upon presidents' faithful friends, usually with deep pockets.

Mr Farish was a regular visitor to George Bush Sr's White House, and managed his blind trusts during his term of office. He was tipped to win the London posting in 1989, but in the end it fell to George W Bush to repay the debt.

Officially Mr Farish's role, like that of US ambassadors in other more troubled parts of the world, will be to represent and promote Washington's broad range of interests. He will be responsible for the embassy building in Grosvenor Square, London, which houses the offshoots of seven US state departments.

In theory he will be expected to ensure that when eminent Americans are in town they meet the right people, make sure messages pass through the correct channels, grease the wheels of transatlantic commerce, and present the US in as favourable light as possible. Translated into practice, Mr Farish and his wife Sarah, a member of the Du Pont family, will be hosting an awful lot of parties.

With the special relationship in robust shape, and British and US heads of state increasingly bypassing their diplomatic placemen in favour of personal chats via a hotline, London does not provide the most rigorous examination of diplomatic skills. Given the socialising and schmoozing, Mr Farish's constitution is likely to be more tested than his tact.

The up side of a job first filled by John Adams following the Declaration of Independence, will become obvious when Mr Farish's chauffeured limousine pulls up outside his new home, Winfield House, which sits in Regents Park between the Central London Mosque and London Zoo. It has a permanent staff of 12, and, according to a former resident, everything you need except a change of socks.

Valued at £50m, it boasts 36 rooms (17 of them bedrooms) and 12 acres of what is the second largest private gardens in London. Should Mr Farish wish to see the largest, he need only call on his near neighbour at Buckingham Palace - he and the Queen are old acquaintances.

As a bloodstock agent, polo player and chairman of the executive committee of Breeders Cup Ltd, Mr Furnish has interests that intersect with those of the Queen. They met in 1985 when the Queen stayed at Mr Farish's stud farm, Lanes End near Versailles in Kentucky, and the following year she reciprocated by inviting the Farishes to stay at Windsor during Royal Ascot. She has returned to Lanes End three times since.

"She is a fantastic horsewoman. She knows the sport and she knows horses completely," he said. "She is an expert and can ask very penetrating questions."

Once he has settled in, Mr Farish will have one of the busiest social schedules in the capital. The incumbent, Philip Lader, has been known to host three events a night - drinks, a dinner, and a post-dinner reception - often following a day with a breakfast reception and lunch engagement.

Mr Furnish can expect to collect honorary degrees, deliver speeches and listen to many more, and find himself near the top of many a guest list. But, according to Raymond Seitz, the only career diplomat in recent times to hold the post, there is more to the job than trips to Wimbledon and Windsor.

"Often the press coverage is that it's all parties and receptions (and there's a lot of that) but in the end it is a job of substance ... below the kind of issues that are covered in the papers there is a lot of stuff you don't see."

Recalling a trade dispute that led to sanctions with Britain, Mr Lader said there were pitfalls to the job: "It is unfortunate when representing one's country that one has to be the symbolic whipping boy for differences in policy."

The next four years will not be without matters of weight. President Bush's plans for a national missile defence, the future of Nato, and the prospects of a European defence force will require sensitive handling. Come the 2004 election however, when Mr Farish hands in the traditional ambassador's resignation, his knowledge of canapes is likely to match his understanding of international affairs.

To the White House

 John Adams was the first US ambassador, from 1785 until 1788. His son, John Quincy Adams, held the post in 1815. Both later became president.

 Robert T Lincoln, son of Abraham Lincoln, was ambassador between 1889 and 1893.

 In total, five ambassadors became president - John Adams, James Monroe, John Quincy Adams, Martin Van Buren, and James Buchanan.

 From the ranks of officials and ambassadors who have served in London have also come four vice presidents and 10 secretaries of state.

 Joseph P Kennedy, the father of JF Kennedy, was ambassador from 1938 to1940.

 From 1976 to 1977 Anne Legendre Armstrong was the first, and only, woman to be ambassador.

 The residence of the ambassador, the magnificent Winfeld House in London's Regents Park, dates from the 19th century and with its grounds cover 12 acres. The Woolworth heiress Barbara Hutton gave the house to the US government in 1946 for a token one dollar.

fields.headline: 'Rules ignored for Clinton pardon'
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: A senior US justice department official told an inquiry yesterday that "none of the regular procedures" were followed in Bill Clinton's decision to issue a presidential pardon for the fugitive businessman Marc Rich last month.
fields.body:
A senior US justice department official told an inquiry yesterday that "none of the regular procedures" were followed in Bill Clinton's decision to issue a presidential pardon for the fugitive businessman Marc Rich last month.

Roger Adams, the department's pardon attorney, told the Senate judiciary committee that the White House counsel's office called him at midnight, just hours before Mr Clinton was due to leave office on January 20, and gave him a list of names under consideration for a pardon.

Mr Adams claimed the White House told him only that Mr Rich and commodity trader Pincus Green needed further background checks and that both men "had been living abroad for several years".

Mr Adams also said that his office was so unprepared to conduct inquiries that staff had to call the FBI and trawl the internet for information.

He said that when the FBI confirmed an hour later that Mr Rich was a wanted fugitive he rang an assistant attorney general, Eric Holder, who told him that he knew about the application.

Republicans in Congress yesterday appeared to signal that they will hold Mr Holder responsible for the debacle.

"He did not acquit himself or the justice department well in this case," said Senator Jon Kyl. "There is nothing that justified his inaction."

In his defence, Mr Holder told the committee that "there are things I wish I could have done differently on that night" but he was "extremely busy that day and especially that night" with other tasks, including the security planning for the imminent inauguration of President Bush.

Mr Rich's lawyer, Jack Quinn, himself a former White House lawyer under Mr Clinton, told the inquiry that he had never tried to press his client's case in ways that would circumvent the justice department, as has been alleged ever since the pardon. In particular, Mr Quinn denied that Mr Clinton was encouraged to grant a pardon because Mr Rich's ex-wife Denise was a big donor to Democratic causes, including Mr Clinton's presidential library fund.

Mrs Rich has refused to testify, citing her right to remain silent on the grounds that she might incriminate herself.

webTitle: Microsoft faces new inquiry on competition

fields.headline: Microsoft faces new inquiry on competition
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of Microsoft
fields.trailText: The US department of justice has opened a new inquiry into allegedly anticompetitive business practices at Microsoft.
fields.body:
The US department of justice has opened a new inquiry into allegedly anticompetitive business practices at Microsoft.

Microsoft's $135m(£92.6m) investment in Corel, a loss-making Canadian company, which makes rival office software packages, has raised antitrust concerns at the department of justice.

Corel was a vocal opponent of Microsoft and a supporter of a rival operating system, Linux, before Microsoft bought its 25% non-voting stake in the company last October.

As part of a re-organisation Corel announced plans at the end of last month to spin off its Linux distribution operations, while continuing to develop applications for the system.

It would continue to develop software for Microsoft Office, which controls more than 90% of the market for word processing and other office-based services.

The Corel revamp appears to have coincided with a justice department decision to serve Microsoft with an order three weeks ago to hand over all internal documents related to the Corel investment.

Jim Cullinan, a spokesman for Microsoft, said the group was co-operating with antitrust officials and that the company expected the deal to proceed.

"We think it's very narrow in terms of the information they have requested," he said. The company has no influence over Corel's business decisions.

"When we announced our deal with Corel we said it would in no way impact their ability to do software with other platforms."

A justice department spokeswoman confirmed the investigation but refused to discuss details. "We are looking at the transaction and the competitive effects," she said.

President George Bush is expected to announce the appointment of a new antitrust head at the justice department within days. The most likely contender, Charles James, is said to view antitrust abuses more narrowly than his Clinton-appointed predecessor, who signed the Corel investigation.

Corel was unavailable for comment yesterday. Microsoft is due to appear before the US court of appeal at the end of this month after last year's ruling that it broke US antitrust laws. Microsoft's $135m(£92.6m) investment in Corel, a loss-making Canadian company, which makes rival office software packages, has raised antitrust concerns at the department of justice. Corel was a vocal opponent of Microsoft and a supporter of a rival operating system, Linux, before Microsoft bought its 25% non-voting stake in the company last October. As part of a re-organisation Corel announced plans at the end of last month to spin off its Linux distribution operations, while continuing to develop applications for the system. It would continue to develop software for Microsoft Office, which controls more than 90% of the market for word processing and other office-based services. The Corel revamp appears to have coincided with a justice department decision to serve Microsoft with an order three weeks ago to hand over all internal documents related to the Corel investment. Jim Cullinan, a spokesman for Microsoft, said the group was co-operating with antitrust officials and that the company expected the deal to proceed. "We think it's very narrow in terms of the information they have requested," he said. The company has no influence over Corel's business decisions. webTitle: Victims still entombed in Salvador's adobe towns

fields.headline: Victims still entombed in Salvador's adobe towns
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: Classes had just resumed after the interruption of the January 13 earthquake in the parish school in Candelaria, a remote town of 12,000 people tucked away in the valleys of central El Salvador.
fields.body:
Classes had just resumed after the interruption of the January 13 earthquake in the parish school in Candelaria, a remote town of 12,000 people tucked away in the valleys of central El Salvador.

The infants' teacher, Ana Elizabeth de Chavez, was pleased to be back at work, but had told friends that she was worried about the old adobe school building, damaged by the quake.

In 20 seconds of horror early on Tuesday morning, when the earth shuddered and the building collapsed on her class, her fears came true.

By that evening the bodies of only five of the 22 infants buried alive in the rubble had been recovered. The teacher's body was nowhere to be seen.

In the once-lively town only a few trees were left standing by the quake, whose epicentre was just a few miles away.

El Salvador is mourning again, just four weeks after 1,000 lives were lost in the original earthquake, which measured 7.6 on the Richter scale.

The four central provinces are the worst hit this time. And while the capital, San Salvador, has escaped, callers to local radio stations there yesterday reported "rumbling sounds" from the San Jacinto mountain to the south of the city.

"Hope is the last thing you loose, of course, but it's hard to imagine people still alive 24 hours on," a Red Cross rescue worker said. Even so, the teams say they will carry on digging and searching.

He said that 255 bodies had been counted by yesterday morning, but there will surely be more.

Another 2,260 people are reported to have been injured, and an estimated 12,000 houses destroyed.

Many of those still missing are thought to be buried under the adobe buildings, characteristic of the rural areas, which swayed and collapsed under the power of the quake.

Other victims were caught in mudslides along the provincial highways and side roads.

In the bigger farming towns of San Vicente and Cojutepeque every second house was on the ground.

"The saddest thing is that these houses are all that we had," said one woman looking at the remains of her home.

In both towns the electricity and phones are working again, but not the water supplies. Outlying areas are without any basic services.

To help reach some of the remoter regions, army helicopters from Nicaragua and Guatemala, and US Chinooks, have been called in.

As provincial hospitals have filled up, people have been ferried to San Salvador.

Blood supplies for transfusions are said to be running out.

The epicentre of Tuesday's earthquake was 12 miles south-east of San Salvador.

The first was centred at sea, but a spokesman for the US Geological Survey, Butch Kinerney, said: "It's pretty obvious they're related."

Tremors were felt constantly between the two quakes.

fields.headline: Millionaires attack Bush tax cuts
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: George Bush's massive $1.6 trillion (£1,100bn) tax cut plans are coming under criticism from two groups who would normally be thought of as among his most committed supporters - a number of millionaires and members of the Texas legislature.
fields.body:
George Bush's massive $1.6 trillion (£1,100bn) tax cut plans are coming under criticism from two groups who would normally be thought of as among his most committed supporters - a number of millionaires and members of the Texas legislature.

The anti-tax cut millionaires are headed by some of America's richest and most famous names, including Warren Buffett, George Soros and Bill Gates Sr, the father of the Microsoft billionaire.

The three are among 120 super-wealthy Americans who are backing a drive organised by Mr Gates Sr against Mr Bush's plan to abolish estate (inheritance) taxes that are paid only by the rich.

"Repealing the estate tax would enrich the heirs of America's millionaires and billionaires while hurting families who struggle to make ends meet," a petition drafted by Mr Gates Sr states.

The billions of dollars in lost government revenue as a result of the plan "will inevitably be made up either by increasing taxes on those less able to pay or by cutting social security, Medicare, environmental protection and many other government programmes so important to our nation's continued well-being", it continues.

Mr Buffett, America's fourth richest man, told the New York Times that he had not yet signed the petition, but only because it did not go far enough in defending "the critical role" of the estate tax. Repealing the tax would be "a terrible mistake", he said.

"Without the estate tax, you in effect will have an aristocracy of wealth, which means you pass down the ability to command the resources of the nation based on heredity rather than merit," Mr Buffett said.

Estate tax is assessed on the net worth of an individual at death. At present it is not payable on the first $675,000 of an estate. Above the threshold, estate tax is paid at 37%, rising to 55% on an upper band of $3m and above. Approximately2% of Americans pay estate tax and 4,000 Americans provide half of the amount raised by the tax each year.

Backers of the campaign to keep the tax include many other resonant names in American business history, including David Rockefeller and Steven Rockefeller of the oil-based billionaire family.

The elder Mr Gates said he had not yet asked his son to sign his petition, but he revealed that the Microsoft founder was "sympathetic" to the campaign.

The criticism of Mr Bush from his home state of Texas comes from members of the state legislature who are facing the embarrassing fact that Texas is running short of money as a result of the tax cuts Mr Bush introduced during his last year as governor.

Just over a year ago, Mr Bush pushed a $1.85bn tax cut programme through the Texas legislature at a time when the state's budget was projected to show a $6.4bn surplus. The tax-cut package formed a central plank in Mr Bush's successful bid to defeat John McCain for the Republican presidential nomination and in his campaign to take the White House from Al Gore in November.

Latest budget forecasts for Texas now show that the state will show a $700m deficit during the current year out of a total budget of $101.9bn. The shortfall has been caused by a variety of factors, including the economic downturn, the rising cost of health care and unexpectedly high overheads due to rising fuel costs.

As a result, Texas has to figure out how to make up the shortfall and how to prepare a balanced state budget for the next two years. There is even some discussion of the need for possible new tax increases.

"I don't think it's particularly constructive to look back. We used the best judgment we could at the time," the Republican leader in the Texas senate, Bill Ratliff, said this week.

Other lawmakers took a different view. "Politically, it was the right thing to do. But we should have taken a harder look at it. And so, as a result of the budget priorities of the previous administration, we find ourselves in a difficult hole," said Senator Eddie Lucio.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Strapped hand, big payout
fields.body:
Strapped hand, big payout

A man of 30 was awarded £918,000 damages by the New South Wales supreme court in Sydney yesterday for a school beating 17 years ago.

Paul Hogan sued St Johns College trustees and a former teacher for hitting him eight times on the hand with a leather strap in 1984, permanently damaging his hand and hindering his career.

Reuters, Sydney

Cambodia PM skirts issue

The Cambodian prime minister, Hun Sen, told executives of 5 television channels yesterday to banish violence and women in "short skirts or sexy clothes" from their screens.

Reuters, Phnom Penh

Turkish police net 'manhunter'

Police in Kayseri, central Turkey, have detained a man said to have admitted killing six people and wounding four more after stalking them with a hunting rifle, over a period of three years.

AP, Istanbul

Americans held in Saudi Arabia

Saudi Arabia has detained three unnamed US citizens on suspicion of trafficking in alcohol, the daily al-Hayat reported yesterday.

They were being interrogated about alleged links with an explosion in the eastern city of al-Khobar in December which blinded a man. The US embassy in Riyadh refused to comment.

Reuters, Bahrain

Chechens kill 12 Russian troops

A dozen Russian troops were killed and 24 wounded by rebel hit-and run attacks in Chechnya in a 24-hour period, an official in the regional administration said yesterday.

AP, Nazran'

Oil firms 'agree' Amazon ransom

Oil companies will ransom seven employees held in the Amazon jungle, the Ecuadorean military commander, Admiral Miguel Saona, said. An American hostage was killed two weeks ago. Four US citizens, a Chilean, an Argentine and a New Zealander remain captive.

Reuters, Quito

webTitle: Rail update costs spark franchise row

fields.headline: Rail update costs spark franchise row
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Rail leaders last night suspended the refranchising of a key rail route between London and Scotland to save the government from political embarrassment and the Strategic Rail Authority from further criticism.
fields.body:
Rail leaders last night suspended the refranchising of a key rail route between London and Scotland to save the government from political embarrassment and the Strategic Rail Authority from further criticism.

Railtrack was blamed for the suspension because ministers said that the cost of modernising the east coast main line had doubled from £2bn to £4bn in only a few months.

The SRA, the government's strategic arm, said that the refranchising of the line, would be put on hold while the cost was being reviewed. This will delay a further decision on this key route between north and south until after the election.

Both Great North Eastern Railway, the franchise holder, and Virgin Trains, which is bidding to build a high speed new route through eastern England, capable of carrying trains of up to 200mph, will now have to wait the outcome of the review.

The SRA's decision to blame Railtrack saves it from further embarrassment. Its chairman, Sir Alastair Morton, had originally recommended that GNER got the bid, although Virgin offered more value for money. The government has been forced to move because it wanted to avoid a possible challenge in the courts by Virgin if it approved the GNER bid.

Steve Marshall, Railtrack's chief executive, said he was "deeply angry" at the announcement. He denied that it was the cause of the delay, and said it was still at the pre-feasibility study of costing the upgrade of the east coast line.

He said that there could be no definitive plan for the modernisation until Sir Alastair had produced a strategic plan for the route. Final resolution of the plan was dependent on the requirements of the franchise holder and other users of the route.

The plan was halted on the orders of deputy prime minister John Prescott, who said that the doubling of Railtrack's costs made a rethink imperative. He said that he had asked the SRA to advise him urgently about the sudden rise in costs.

Sir Richard Branson, chairman of the Virgin Group, said that he did not believe that a "risky tilt-train solution" was right for the east coast main line, unlike the west coast route, where tilting trains are due to be introduced next year. It would be a great shame to have to wait another two years to start rebuilding the railway.

His comments came as Britain's first tilting train was trialled yesterday on a track near Melton Mowbray in Leicestershire.

It is the first of 55 Pendolino trains built in Italy which will operate between Euston, Manchester and Scotland from May next year.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: New head for Equitable Life | Shire displays flower power | Baird finance chief quits | Royal Dutch Shell loses bid
fields.body:
New head for Equitable Life

Vanni Treves, chairman of Channel 4, has been appointed to head troubled insurer Equitable Life.

Mr Treves, 60, takes up the position of chairman on March 1 and will succeed John Sclater, who announced in December he would be resigning after a replacement had been found. Mr Treves is also a City solicitor and partner at law firm Macfarlanes.

He said Equitable had offered to pay him £300,000 a year but he had decided this was "too much". Initially the insurer will pay a fee of £60,000 to Macfarlanes for his services. After a year it can pay up to an additional £240,000, depending on his performance.

Shire displays flower power

Shire Pharmaceuticals' pioneering treatment for Alzheimer's disease, which was derived from snowdrops, is likely to be available on the NHS this summer, the company predicted yesterday.

The drug, Reminyl, can slow the onset of memory loss and confusion. Trials have shown it can improve sufferers' language, memory and understanding of events. It is expected to attract annual sales of more than £250m.

Shire's chief executive, Rolf Stahel, said the firm was in the final stage of negotiations to get Reminyl on the official lists of prescription drugs used by NHS doctors.

Shire yesterday announced a 102% surge in annual profits to $138m (£95m). Growth was driven by a 49% increase in sales of Adderall, a treatment for attention deficit disorder.

Baird finance chief quits

William Baird, the textile group, said yesterday its finance director is to step down in the wake of unsuccessful talks with venture capital firm Alchemy about a management buy-out of the business.

In a short statement to the stock exchange, Baird said Brendan Hynes would relinquish responsibilities as finance director immediately and resign at the end of March. A spokesman added that a replacement had not yet been found but a number of people had been approached.

Shares in Baird closed down 1p at 56.5p yesterday.

Royal Dutch Shell loses bid

Royal Dutch Shell has lost out on its bid to become operator of the Kashagan oilfield in the Caspian Sea, regarded as one of the biggest ever discoveries.

The blow was confirmed when Italy's ENI said its Agip subsidiary had been voted as leader of the project by the nine-member Offshore Kazakhstan International Operating Company.

Shell, a member of the consortium, said it could not comment on the situation until the decision had been ratified. This was understood to mean when the Kazakh government gives its final blessing to Agip.

webTitle: Bank hints at more rate cuts

fields.headline: Bank hints at more rate cuts
fields.standfirst: Warning of knock-on effects from a downturn in the US
fields.trailText: The Bank of England yesterday held out the prospect for further cuts in interest rates when it warned that the downturn in the United States could have knock-on effects on both growth and inflation in Britain.
fields.body:
The Bank of England yesterday held out the prospect for further cuts in interest rates when it warned that the downturn in the United States could have knock-on effects on both growth and inflation in Britain.

In its latest quarterly inflation report, the Bank admitted that it would undershoot the government's 2.5% inflation target for a total of four years and that there was a chance that price pressures could turn out to be even weaker than it is anticipating.

The Bank said that last week's quarter-point reduction in base rates to 5.75% had been a pre-emptive strike, even though it believes that the UK economy is in reasonable shape.

However, the Bank added: "The risks to growth and inflation are presently clearly on the downside, stemming in particular from the risk of a deeper or more prolonged slowdown in the US."

The report revealed differences of opinion among the nine-strong monetary policy committee over the prospects for inflation, which has been below 2.5% since the spring of 1999 and is not projected to return to that level until 2003.

One faction on the committee believes that improvements to Britain's supply-side performance and the darkening global outlook mean that inflation could come in up to 0.5 percentage points lower than the Bank's central projection.

Another group is worried about the tightness of the labour market, a concern certain to be exacerbated by yesterday's figures from the office for national statistics showing a larger than expected increase in average earnings and a hefty fall in unemployment.

Data released on Tuesday showed that the government's preferred measure of inflation, which excludes mortgage interest payments, had fallen to a record low of 1.8%. If it should fall to 1.5%, Bank governor Sir Eddie George will be obliged to write a letter to the chancellor explaining what steps the MPC is taking to return inflation to its target. Mervyn King, the Bank's deputy governor, said yesterday that the main reason inflation had undershot its target was the strength of sterling, which the Bank had failed to predict. With interest changes taking time to work, he said there was no point in trying to create "an artificial boom" to make up the inflation shortfall, and then having to rein in the economy again.

He added that the imminence of a general election campaign would not deter the MPC from acting on rates in the coming months. "If we feel the need to make a change we shall do so. That's our remit."

He added that the imminence of a general election campaign would not deter the MPC from acting on rates in the coming months. "If we feel the need to make a change we shall do so. That's our remit."

webTitle: Putin's Trojan horse alarms fortress EU

fields.headline: Putin's Trojan horse alarms fortress EU
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Russia
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Kaliningrad, the 18th century birthplace of Prussia which became a 20th century Red Army garrison, is the focus today of a tussle between Moscow and Brussels about the shape of an expanded European Union.
fields.body:
Kaliningrad, the 18th century birthplace of Prussia which became a 20th century Red Army garrison, is the focus today of a tussle between Moscow and Brussels about the shape of an expanded European Union.

After talks in Moscow the EU's external affairs commissioner, Chris Patten, and the Swedish foreign minister, Anna Lindh, are to reconnoitre Russia's isolated westernmost pocket to try to solve a geographical and historical puzzle produced by the union's EU's forthcoming eastward extension.

"Kaliningrad should not become a bone of contention between Russia and the enlarged EU," Mr Patten said.

The general air of anxiety and uncertainty has been compounded by recent US claims that Moscow has been stationing tactical nuclear weapons in Kaliningrad - claims which the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, has dismissed as "nonsense".

On top of that, rightwing British newspapers have reported that Berlin and Moscow are secretly plotting a German buy-back of the territory. The German government says the allegations are risible, but they have caused paranoia in Russia.

Kaliningrad will find itself physically, if not legally, within the union when the EU takes Poland and Estonia, and then Lithuania and Latvia, into membership later this decade.

"Following enlargement, the Kaliningrad region will become a Russian federation enclave inside the EU," a recent commission study said.

The prospect has alarmed the EU bureaucracy in Brussels, which fears that the poverty-ridden, disease-rich, heavily polluted, and crime-infested province will become a Trojan horse in "Fortress Europe" for illegal immigrants.

The Russians shrug that that is a problem for Brussels, not Moscow.

The Swedish prime minister, Goran Persson, said last month that Kaliningrad was "a severely polluted, ecologically contaminated region burdened with high rates of Aids, tuberculosis and other diseases. We'll have all that then in the middle of Europe".

The EU commission paper reports that "crime is widespread in Kaliningrad".

"Organised crime, trafficking in human beings, drugs, stolen vehicles and illegal migration are all present." So is prostitution, and the smuggling of amber, alcohol and cigarettes.

Crime levels are 20% higher than the Russian average.

As Kaliningrad's neighbours, the Swedes have put these issues near the top of their current EU presidency agenda, Moscow is suspicious and evasive. Many of the enclave's one million people fear they will be locked into greater isolation as Brussels compels the Poles and Lithuanians to subject them to tough visa requirements.

The prospect of a quick agreement is not bright.

"Moscow does not have a clear position and has a negative view of the EU's proposals," the head of the Kaliningrad industrialists' association, Boris Ovchinnikov, said.

It was in Kaliningrad, then east Prussian Königsberg, that the first king of Prussia was crowned 300 years ago last month. Stalin renamed the enclave when the Soviet Union took it from the defeated Third Reich in the spring of 1945. When the Soviet Union disintegrated in 1991, Kaliningrad found itself stranded hundreds of miles from Russia.

Until 1991 it was a Soviet armed camp, housing 200,000 troops. There are now 18,000. According to official statistics, more than 30% of the enclave's inhabitants live below the poverty line.

The province has 90% of the world's amber deposits and almost all of it is smuggled abroad illegally in an economy that is at least 50% "black", the EU says.

To ease its isolation and maintain contacts with Russia proper, Kaliningrad has visa-free travel arrangements with Poland and Lithuania, in a region with some of Europe's busiest cross-border traffic in Europe.

But the EU says that will have to go in the interests of Fortress Europe. Mr Patten also rules out a special "association agreement" between Brussels and Kaliningrad, a suggestion Mr Putin is believed to have made.

"Surrounding us with an iron curtain is not civilised," Vladimir Nikitin, head of the provincial parliament, told a Moscow newspaper yesterday. "If no regional development plan is drafted soon, we will be confronted by an explosion of separatism."

But Mr Putin aims to recentralise Russia rather than devolve greater powers to the regions, and the EU commission says that Moscow's control over Kaliningrad will probably strengthen.

Moscow has just imposed 20% duties on imports from Kaliningrad, despite an attempt in the 1990s to create a free-trade zone or special economic status, sparking half-baked talk of a Baltic Hong Kong.

Anatoly Romashko, a senior Kaliningrad official, says the tax has effectively paralysed industry. "Our firms suddenly can't compete with mainland Russian companies ... If someone wanted to stir up pro-western feelings in the enclave, they couldn't have thought of a better way of doing it."

webTitle: Business: Baglan Bay chemicals plant gets the chop

fields.headline: New blow from BP
fields.standfirst: Baglan Bay chemicals plant gets the chop
fields.trailText: Baglan Bay chemicals plant gets the chop
fields.body:
BP, which this week reported the biggest profits ever made by a UK company, has administered a further blow to employment prospects in south Wales by finalising plans to run down its Baglan Bay chemicals plant.

Nearly 200 skilled staff have been told they will go by the end of the year with the remaining 60 expected to follow by 2005 as the oil and chemicals company switches production to new facilities in Scotland and the north-east of England.

BP, which unveiled profits of £9.7bn on Tuesday, is regarded by many as the best employer in a region reeling from steel sector restructuring announced by Corus.

The group said it had been engaged in extensive consultation with its staff and where possible would try to avoid redundancies.

A BP spokesman said: "By giving a year's notice we hope this should enable staff to plan their futures." He pointed out that BP was engaged in building a gas turbine power plant with General Electric at Baglan Bay. They were creating an energy park around it which should create new jobs.

Baglan Bay is the last leading facility BP operates in Wales, having earlier closed its nearby Llandarcy oil refinery.

The company first announced in November 1998 its planned withdrawal from ethanol production at Baglan Bay "early in the 21st century". But employees not selected to stay with the company said yesterday they were shocked to be told they must leave.

One who asked not to be namedsaid: "These were the premier jobs in south Wales with the average package offering £30,000 a year including share options and non-contributory pension. Where will I find another job like that? Certainly not flipping burgers."

fields.headline: Orange price slides
fields.standfirst: Telecom sector's hopes of lightening debt burden damaged
fields.trailText: Europe's battered telecoms sector took a fresh hammering yesterday as this week's dismal debutant, Orange, fell further adrift of the already cut-price launch offer.
fields.body:
Europe's battered telecoms sector took a fresh hammering yesterday as this week's dismal debutant, Orange, fell further adrift of the already cut-price launch offer.

The asking price for Orange shares had been cut by almost a fifth in the run-up to this week's stock market flotation as institutions made it clear that they were reluctant to buy shares at prices within the initial range.

Yesterday the shares fell from €9.40 (£5.92) to €8.82. That compares with the €10 at which shares were finally offered to institutional investors and the €9.50 for retail buyers. Trading was brisk with some €895m worth of Orange stock changing hands - although that was well down on Tuesday's record-breaking €2.53bn worth of trading.

"It is nasty if you price low and you go still lower. There is terrible selling pressure on the other telecoms and they are such a big percentage of the market," one dealer said.

"There are some companies which are quite good value at these levels, though there are others which are still arguably over valued," said another.

Investors' reluctant reception for the mobile phone company added to existing worries about rising debt levels and put a question mark over future flotations.

Comments from Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan overnight, which were interpreted as suggesting the US central bank might not cut interest rates as aggressively as expected, added to the prevailing gloom.

"It's pretty grotty out there. The selling has been fairly indiscriminate across the sector. I think everyone is looking for a floor," a London-based analyst said. "But there is no reason to suggest any kind of trigger which is going to make people feel more positive."

Among yesterday's big fallers were Orange's parent, France Telecom, which was down 7% at one stage. BT lost more than 7% and Deutsche Telekom saw its share price slip to its lowest level for more than two years.

The telecoms sector is now more than 50% below its peak of last March.

There was speculation, swiftly denied by Deutsche Telekom, that Ron Sommer, its chief executive had resigned. However, analysts believe he remains under pressure because of the fall in the share price.

The outcome of Deutsche Telekom's yet-to-be-completed takeover of VoiceStream in the United States is seen as a crucial factor in determining Mr Sommer's fate.

The market's valuation of Orange - regarded as one of the best companies in the sector - could affect plans by other companies to float parts of their operations.

The likes of BT, Deutsche Telekom and the Dutch group KPN have all been expected to bring subsidiaries to the market as part of their plans to cut heavy debt burdens.

"They may get to the point where they decide it is better to run with higher debt levels and see their debt ratings downgraded than accept the prices they can get. There is a point where that becomes an option if they think valuations are too low," according to one industry watcher.

"However, I think they are more likely to be saying that they are looking at flotations in the second half of the year and that by then the outlook could be more positive. So for the time being they will just wait and see."

webTitle: Business: Bass sale makes Nomura Britain's largest landlord

fields.headline: Bass sale makes Nomura Britain's largest landlord
fields.trailText: Japanese bank Nomura has snatched back the number one slot as Britain's leading pub landlord by purchasing 988 premises from leisure group Bass for £625m.
fields.body:
Japanese bank Nomura has snatched back the number one slot as Britain's leading pub landlord by purchasing 988 premises from leisure group Bass for £625m.

The deal gives Nomura a total estate of 5,585 houses - allowing it to leapfrog the privately owned chain Punch Taverns, which became the market leader two years ago.

Most of the pubs in the deal are small locals, which do not fit with Bass's focus on high street chains such as All Bar One and Harvester.

Nomura intends to lease them on an arms-length basis to landlords. A Nomura spokesman said: "Our experience is that if you take local pubs, hand them over to decent publicans and make them each into mini-businesses, you can actually make a success of them."

The Japanese bank will securitise the rental income from the pubs through a bond issue - something public companies are generally unable to do - giving it capital to invest in other activities.

Nomura's Principal Finance Group, run by powerful City financier Guy Hands, specialises in buying unfashionable businesses. Its past in vestments include William Hill betting shops, 57,000 Ministry of Defence homes and First Quench off-licences.

With fewer than 10% of Britain's 66,000 pubs, Nomura is confident of escaping significant opposition from competition authorities. However, some industry figures have suggested that the Office of Fair Trading should consider the size and income of pubs as well as numbers in determiningmarket dominance.

Bass has been keen to offload the tail-end of its estate for months. A number of buyers were vying for the deal, including Legal & General's venture capital arm, L&G Ventures.

Bass, which recently sold its brewing operations for £2.3bn to the Belgian firm Interbrew, believes it can make more money out of businesses with well known brands.

webTitle: Amanda Matravers talks to women who abuse

fields.headline: Breaking the silence
fields.standfirst:
This week, these men were jailed for being in a paedophile ring. But are all sex offenders male? Amanda Matravers talks to the forgotten criminals: women who abuse

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: This week, these men were jailed for being in a paedophile ring. But are all sex offenders male?  Amanda Matravers talks to the forgotten criminals: women who abuse
fields.body:
My peanut allergy has a deadening effect on dinner party talk. "What happens?" other guests inquire and on hearing the details (breathlessness, blotching, vomiting), push their plates to one side and change the subject.

My research on women sex offenders has a similar effect. In spite of the notoriety of a handful of high-profile female offenders, the world is not ready for a group of individuals whose crimes undermine the image of woman as natural protector. Such offenders also challenge the dearly-held beliefs that women are incapable of sexual aggression and a penis is a prerequisite to abuse. Thus my answer to the inevitable question ("What do they do?") has been the cause of much premature plate-clearing in the years since I began the study.

What they do is, for the most part, what men do, though many fewer of them do it. Estimates based on the work of investigators in Britain and the US indicate that women account for around 10% of child molesters - slightly higher if boys are the victims, lower if girls are. Yet research into women who abuse is sparse.

In the absence of reliable information, attempts to explain why so few women are convicted of sex crimes rely on cultural myths: that women's "natural" passivity precludes their involvement in sexually aggressive acts or that their innate cunning allows them to engage in such acts and evade detection. Rather than take part in fruitless speculation, I wanted to study those female offenders whose existence is undeniable: the tiny group of women in England and Wales serving sentences for sex offences. The Home Office doesn't count female sex offenders as a separate category, but I discovered 18 in prison. To put this in perspective, there are currently 5,000 men in jail for sex offences.

In a three-year study, I gathered information on 30 women - not all of them in prison - whose offences ranged from indecent photography to sexual murder. At the less serious end of the spectrum were women like Rita and Betty, whose offences were, respectively, failure to protect children from an abusive father and allowing indecent photos to be taken of a minor. For Betty, a 60-year-old childminder who had, she said, been "conned" by her male co-offender, conviction constituted a bewildering misunderstanding of her role in the exploitation of a five-year-old. In Rita's case, a failure to act on her daughters' disclosures of abuse by their father led, 15 years later, to her imprisonment on a charge of cruelty.

So what can such a study teach us? As individuals, the women challenged some stereotypes and fulfilled others. For many feminists, Rita and Betty's offences indicate a cultural bias that holds women responsible for the sexual behaviour of men. Neither played an active role in the offences, nor were they considered by professionals to have a sexual interest in their victims. So their offences do not require us to rethink our conception of women as passive in sexual behaviour in general and sex crime in particular.

Not all the women were Ritas and Bettys, however. Four were serving life sentences for offences culminating in murder; others were women who had sexually abused children independently of men, or played leading roles in group offences. Among them were a woman charged with offences against a consenting 15-year-old boy and a 50-year-old factory worker convicted of sexually assaulting her granddaughter. Clearly such women do not fit the popular stereotype of the sexually obsessed, socially inadequate - male - paedophile. But neither were they the coerced accomplices of predatory men.

For the most part, the women do not see themselves as offenders of any kind. The reason lies in wider social attitudes towards sex offenders on the one hand and women offenders on the other. The depth of public feeling against paedophile sex offenders reveals itself in the response to single, tragic incidents, such as the murder last year of Sarah Payne, with the demands for something to be done about the "monsters in our midst". Yet this focus on a minority of obsessive, predatory male strangers acts as a smokescreen not only for the much larger number of men who abuse their own children but also for women. It allows even those found guilty to deny that they are sex offenders and to be supported in this by professionals whose training and experience leads them to see women as victims rather than perpetrators of sexual crime.

Take Kimberly, a 20-year-old convicted of sexually assaulting a 16-year-old girl she suspected was sleeping with her partner. Though she admitted her crime, Kimberly denied it made her a sex offender. "What does my head in is when people think I'm a pervert, going round with little kids and things. I'm not saying it was right what I did, but it wasn't that I just saw this girl and took a fancy to her."

Similarly Susan, convicted of aiding and abetting the rape of her daughter, says: "I don't have any inclination for little children; I'm not one of those people. I mean, I brought five up."

Many of the women claim they were coerced or tricked into taking part in sex offences - and some case files corroborate this - but others seem unable to conceive of themselves as involved, even where there was no question of force being used.Julie, convicted with her partner of indecently assaulting two 12-year-old girls, admits to being present, but no more. "I mean, I was just there. I should have left; even the police said if I'd left I'd only have been charged with knowing about it, not doing it."

Several women claimed they had "done nothing" and their denials, like Julie's, seem to have been accepted, even encouraged, by police officers, psychologists and prison staff. In prison, this may reflect a concern for the women's safety because they are seldom segregated, as men are. One woman bullied by other prisoners says an officer advised her to "deny it to their faces and it'll soon blow over".

This cultural inability to acknowledge women as "real" sex offenders may stop them developing a sense of responsibility for their crimes. On the contrary, their own experience of violence, together with the rhetoric of therapy, often leads them to see themselves as fellow victims. Thus Clare explains how her partner, a known paedophile, took advantage of her: "He was kind to me; he probably got me at a vulnerable point, when I was under a lot of depression, a lot of pressure. He bought me jewellery, a car, so the way I look back at it now, because I've had counselling, I think he used me: he took my vulnerability and he used it to get what he wanted."

The point is not that Clare is wrong to claim she was "used" but that current policy and practice is geared around the male offender. No one knows how much of a risk women like Clare pose to children in the future, nor does her complicated story fit easily into the stereotype of women offenders as pathetic inadequates or mythically evil, "unnatural" individuals. While professionals have decades of research on which to base judgments about male sex offenders, decisions about women are made in the absence of relevant information.

Meanwhile, the police and probation service are left with difficult decisions to make regarding the risk posed by individual offenders. On whom would you target resources: the father of three who abused his step-daughter while her mother was working the night shift; the "loner" who divided his day between downloading child porn and hovering around the school playground; or the woman who held down her daughter while her father penetrated her anally? You decide. Or you may choose to confine yourself to less distasteful topics. Pass the peanuts.

&#`49; Dr Amanda Matravers is a lecturer in criminology at the Institute of Criminology, University of Cambridge.

Four were serving life sentences for offences culminating in murder; others were women who had sexually abused children independently of men, or played leading roles in group offences. Among them were a woman charged with offences against a consenting 15-year-old boy and a 50-year-old factory worker convicted of sexually assaulting her granddaughter. Clearly such women do not fit the popular stereotype of the sexually obsessed, socially inadequate - male - paedophile. But neither were they the coerced accomplices of predatory men. For the most part, the women do not see themselves as offenders of any kind. The reason lies in wider social attitudes towards sex offenders on the one hand and women offenders on the other. The depth of public feeling against paedophile sex offenders reveals itself in the response to single, tragic incidents, such as the murder last year of Sarah Payne, with the demands for something to be done about the "monsters in our midst". Yet this focus on a minority of obsessive, predatory male strangers acts as a smokescreen not only for the much larger number of men who abuse their own children but also for women. It allows even those found guilty to deny that they are sex offenders and to be supported in this by professionals whose training and experience leads them to see women as victims rather than perpetrators of sexual crime. Take Kimberly, a 20-year-old convicted of sexually assaulting a 16-year-old girl she suspected was sleeping with her partner. Though she admitted her crime, Kimberly denied it made her a sex offender. "What does my head in is when people think I'm a pervert, going round with little kids and things. I'm not saying it was right what I did, but it wasn't that I just saw this girl and took a fancy to her." Similarly Susan, convicted of aiding and abetting the rape of her daughter, says: "I don't have any inclination for little children; I'm not one of those people. I mean, I brought five up." Many of the women claim they were coerced or tricked into taking part in sex offences - and some case files corroborate this - but others seem unable to conceive of themselves as involved, even where there was no question of force being used.Julie, convicted with her partner of indecently assaulting two 12-year-old girls, admits to being present, but no more. "I mean, I was just there. I should have left; even the police said if I'd left I'd only have been charged with knowing about it, not doing it." Several women claimed they had "done nothing" and their denials, like Julie's, seem to have been accepted, even encouraged, by police officers, psychologists and prison staff. In prison, this may reflect a concern for the women's safety because they are seldom segregated, as men are. One woman bullied by other prisoners says an officer advised her to "deny it to their faces and it'll soon blow over". This cultural inability to acknowledge women as "real" sex offenders may stop them developing a sense of responsibility for their crimes. On the contrary, their own experience of violence, together with the rhetoric of therapy, often leads them to see themselves as fellow victims. Thus Clare explains how her partner, a known paedophile, took advantage of her: "He was kind to me; he probably got me at a vulnerable point, when I was under a lot of depression, a lot of pressure. He bought me jewellery, a car, so the way I look back at it now, because I've had counselling, I think he used me: he took my vulnerability and he used it to get what he wanted." The point is not that Clare is wrong to claim she was "used" but that current policy and practice is geared around the male offender. No one knows how much of a risk women like Clare pose to children in the future, nor does her complicated story fit easily into the stereotype of women offenders as pathetic inadequates or mythically evil, "unnatural" individuals. While professionals have decades of research on which to base judgments about male sex offenders, decisions about women are made in the absence of relevant information. Meanwhile, the police and probation service are left with difficult decisions to make regarding the risk posed by individual offenders. On whom would you target resources: the father of three who abused his step-daughter while her mother was working the night shift; the "loner" who divided his day between downloading child porn and hovering around the school playground; or the woman who held down her daughter while her father penetrated her anally? You decide. Or you may choose to confine yourself to less distasteful topics. Pass the peanuts. &#`49; Dr Amanda Matravers is a lecturer in criminology at the Institute of Criminology, University of Cambridge.

webTitle: New Nato nuclear trouble in Spain

fields.headline: New Nato nuclear trouble in Spain
fields.trailText: American plans approved by Madrid to transform the Nato docks and airfield at Rota, in Andalucia, into the main US nuclear base for the Mediterranean and north Africa are encountering local hostility.
fields.body:
American plans approved by Madrid to transform the Nato docks and airfield at Rota, in Andalucia, into the main US nuclear base for the Mediterranean and north Africa are encountering local hostility.

Provincial politicians argue that the Pentagon's proposal, "Rota Vision 2010", will damage relations with north African states at a time when concern about radiation hazards has been highlighted by the presence in Gibraltar of a crippled British nuclear submarine.

Last month the Andalucian government wrote to the conservative prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, in protest at his approving the scheme to upgrade base, just outside Cadiz.

Andalucia, with a population of seven million, is Spain's biggest province.The leader of its socialist government, Manuel Chaves, is opposed to an increase in US forces at Rota.

"There is no transparency, nor information respecting the scheme," he has said. It was his party that backed a protest by 60,000 people last month against repairs on the reactor cooling system of the submarine Tireless being carried out in Gibraltar.

"We are concerned Rota will be used as a base for nuclear weapons as well as nuclear-powered submarines," a regional government spokesman in Seville said.

"It may become a handicap for Andalucia in its relations with neighbouring countries [Morocco, Algeria and Portugal] and upset stability in the Mediterranean.

"We probably cannot stop it but we want to participate in strategic decisions. There is a statute [Article 23/1] which says regional governments must be informed about international treaties where they are affected."

Overall, the US has been reducing its military presence in Spain since the end of the cold war. Bases at Torrejon, near Madrid, and Zaragossa, in the north, have closed. Apart from Rota, the only other US site is an air force station nearby at Moron de la Frontera.

Built under the Franco dictatorship in the 1950s, Rota is nominally a Spanish Nato base but the upgrading, expected to cost £120m and take until 2010, will boost its prominence in US defence networks.

Sixteen hangars will be built for the giant C-5 transport planes, and extra jetties added, allowing more submarines from the US Sixth Fleet to dock. Up to 3,000 US troops live on the base, the number limited by the terms of a Spanish-US treaty.

Rota's combined air and naval facilities make it important for Nato or US operations in the Middle East, southern Europe or North Africa.

"Rota is going to be modernised and enhanced but the physical boundaries of the base will not grow," a spokesman at the US embassy in Madrid confirmed.

"It's a Nato base. It will reduce refuelling time for aircraft from two hours to 20 minutes and will become a primary facility.

"There is sensitivity about the plan and objections from the Andalucian government. But Spain is a good Nato partner and it understands Nato's capacity needs."

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Freedom lost | Continent move | Results
fields.body:
 Freedom lost, Britain's largest internet service provider, Freeserve has officially ended its life as an independent company, becoming the UK arm of French parent, Wanadoo. The £1.6bn sale of Freeserve, announced last December, means the ISP's former owner Dixons - will be gradually freed to sell its shares in Wanadoo.

 Continent move London online change of address firm ihavemoved.com yesterday moved into Germany, where one in five Germans are online and about 60% of the population rent homes, so they are likely to move more often, ihavemoved says.

 Results Newly merged French utilities, telecoms and media company Vivendi Universal yesterday posted above-forecast 2000 sales, reaching a provisional €41.7bn (£26bn), an increase of 36.5%, with €26.4bn coming from its utilities activities and €13.6bn from media and communications.

webTitle: Tidemarks  Canaletto helps Venice fight floods

fields.headline: Tidemarks  Canaletto helps Venice fight floods
fields.trailText: Canaletto's 18th century paintings immortalised Venice as perhaps the most beautiful city in the world. Their exquisite precision may now help to save it.
fields.body:
Canaletto's 18th century paintings immortalised Venice as perhaps the most beautiful city in the world. Their exquisite precision may now help to save it.

When depicting palaces rising out of the water, he included lines of green scum - traces of algae - which provide a historical record of the tides.

Scientists from Italy's national research council have started analysing the paintings to chart water levels. By mapping tide dynamics they hope to predict, and prevent, flooding.

"It is very exciting. It fills gaps in our knowledge," Dr Dario Camuffo, who came up with the idea, said. "To predict the future we need to understand the past."

Canaletto's mastery of perspective in his canal scenes made him hugely popular with British aristocrats passing through on their grand tour of Italy.

He had trouble keeping pace with demand, so he increased output with a portable camera obscura - a lens which projects images on to sketch pads. The method was described by Leonardo Da Vinci 250 years earlier, and it enabled Canaletto to reproduce landscapes replete with the green lines left on buildings by high tides.

A 1767 painting of the Piazza San Marco shows algae 34cm lower than today.

Venetians have protested at the authorities' failure to prevent ever more frequent and serious flooding, which is blamed on subsidence and rising sea levels.

Proposed giant flood barriers have been rejected by environmentalists and the authorities now plan to raise the Piazza San Marco.

webTitle: Itinerary to 2003 shows Pope plans to keep going

fields.headline: Itinerary to 2003 shows Pope plans to keep going
fields.trailText: The Pope may be past 80 and ill with Parkinson's disease but the Vatican has demonstrated that he has no plans to slow down by publishing his itinerary to the end of 2003.
fields.body:
The Pope may be past 80 and ill with Parkinson's disease but the Vatican has demonstrated that he has no plans to slow down by publishing his itinerary to the end of 2003.

The most widely travelled, and fifth-longest-reigning, pontiff is planning trips to Toronto and Manila, and hopes to get to Moscow and Beijing before too long as well.

Observers who have seen him at close quarters say he is very bowed, his head sunk against his chest, tremors in his hands, and he walks with a stick. His voice is reduced to an almost inaudible mumble.

There has been periodic speculation that John Paul II may resign - something no pope has done voluntarily since the middle ages. It was thought that the Catholic church's jubilee last year, held every 25 years, might make a suitable culmination to his papacy.

Five years ago the Pope squashed speculation about whether he would step down by saying: "I leave to Christ the decision as to how and when He will release me."

Next week he is due to preside over the largest consistory in history, when the 44 new cardinals named last month are formally appointed, and later in the year he will beatify the largest number of saints too, granting sanctification to victims of Spanish religious persecutions in the 1930s.

This year will take him to Malta and then Syria in May, followed by a visit to Ukraine in June. He may also visit Armenia, which is celebrating its 1,700th anniversary as the first country to accept Christianity as its state religion.

Only Greece seems reluctant to accept a visit. The Greek Orthodox church said he would not be welcome because of disagreements caused by the persistent Catholic attempts to make conversions there.

The Orthodox archbishop Christodoulos told a local radio station recently: "If a visit takes place before these differences are resolved, it will aggravate the situation. Dialogue has been essentially at a standstill for the last decade."

The Pope has already become the first head of the Catholic church to visit an Orthodox country, when he went to Romania and the former Soviet republic of Georgia. The Russian president, Vladimir Putin, is said to be anxious to receive him, asis Beijing, perhaps after he visits Manila in March 2003.

To Vatican watchers, the moment when the chamberlain discreetly approaches the unresponsive pontiff to tap him on the head with a silver hammer - the traditional way of ascertaining whether a pope is dead - seems infinitely delayed.

"Visits seem to energise him," a church spokesman in London said. "It's when he is at his busiest that we are least worried about him."
