webTitle: Glyndebourne is a hit in New York

fields.headline: Brooklyn heights
fields.standfirst: Even without the picnics Glyndebourne is a hit in New York, says  Martin Kettle
fields.trailText: Even without the picnics Glyndebourne is a hit in New York, says Martin Kettle
fields.body:
Glyndebourne opera in Brooklyn ought to have a discordant feel to it, but in fact it doesn't. Certainly on a dark, cold evening in February the Atlantic Avenue subway station feels a world away from July in the Sussex downs, and so it is. If you are expecting picnic hampers and tuxedos, then you have got on the wrong train. But if you are expecting the artistic standards one has come to associate with Glyndebourne, then the Brooklyn Academy of Music is a good place to be.

A lot of Americans come over to Glyndebourne each summer. But until now Glyndebourne has not crossed the Atlantic in the other direction. Last Sunday, however, Sir George Christie and his festival opera took their widely admired production of Janacek's The Makropoulos Case to Brooklyn and delivered what the New York Times critic Anthony Tommasini rightly described as "a riveting evening of musical drama".

If this expensive touring visit had been primarily an opportunity for rich Americans to get a slice of the social side of Glyndebourne, then it would not have come to Brooklyn, says Joe Melillo, the executive producer at the place that everyone round here calls simply BAM.

"There's no snob appeal in Brooklyn," Melillo says. "That's not what this is about at all. We have no green pastures and no cattle here," he says, gesturing out of the window at an unremitting New York cityscape.

"I'm on the same playing field as Glyndebourne in terms of progressive opera. I am in awe of that achievement. That's the bit of Glyndebourne we're interested in. And in that respect we are the perfect partner."

Melillo presides over what he says is America's oldest continually operating performing arts institution. In one way or another, BAM has been here since Abraham Lincoln's time. What makes it important, though, is not its age but its vibrancy. Melillo's arts complex in the increasingly trendy Fort Greene district has been central to the revitalisation of this New York borough.

Across the East river, the gleaming towers of Manhattan house some of the citadels of the arts and cultural world, including the Lincoln Center, Broadway, and a succession of peerless art galleries. But BAMprospers simply by being different, by having a creative edge and a global outlook that increasingly gives the unfashionable district an artistic feel that is more akin to Paris or Berlin than to corporate America.

"I programme artistic work that aims not to duplicate what audiences can experience in Manhattan," Melillo says. "It's not difficult to get here, but you have to give people a reason to come and that's what I do."

Glyndebourne's visit comes in the context of BAM's extraordinary 20-year record of enticing some of the most interesting theatrical talents in the world. BAM is where the Royal Shakespeare Company comes every two years. It's where Robert Wilson works with Lou Reed and Philip Glass. It's where Peter Brook's work is performed, in a nearby theatre remodelled to feel like Brook's Thétre des Bouffes du Nord in Paris. It's where Ingmar Bergman will bring Strindberg later this year. It's where Jonathan Miller will revive his staging of the St Matthew Passion.

In this framework, the arrival of Nikolaus Lehnhoff's production of Makropoulos makes good sense. Lehnhoff himself agrees. As he sips tea in his Brooklyn hotel, the German director says that bringing this show to New York is a completely different exercise from reviving the standard international "shared production" on which so many opera houses now rely, not least to share costs.

"The impetus of the Glyndebourne working conditions remains when we present this work elsewhere," Lehnhoff says. "The impetus comes from the fact that it's not just the singers, but some of the stage crew who have come over, so the Glyndebourne mark is always present. I do not have to start from scratch with new people."

There was no mistaking the tautness of the Makropoulos production as it was unveiled to the American audience. The impact of Lehnhoff's version of Janacek's life-affirming story about a 337-year-old opera singer was every bit as great in Brooklyn as it was six years ago, when it was first performed in Sussex. And if Lehnhoff at times sounded giddily enthusiastic about the successful transatlantic translation, then he surely had some right to be.

"The Glyndebourne production conditions are perfect now," Lehnhoff says. "I've worked in Bayreuth and Salzburg, but at Glyndebourne you get what you do not get anywhere else. Above all you get time. The productions have an intensity which I have not been able to match anywhere else. If I could do so, I would only like to work at Glyndebourne, absolutely ideal. To get paid for this is extraordinary. A year without Glyndebourne is for me a lost year."

Lehnhoff will return to Sussex in 2002 to direct the festival's first ever Wagner staging, Tristan und Isolde. For Anja Silja, on the other hand, whose performance as Janacek's aged heroine Emilia Marty grows ever more powerful as she herself ages, this summer's Makropoulos revival could be her last appearance at the festival. Considering that Silja has been described by the New York Times as "the Callas of the German repertory", that makes this summer's revival particularly poignant.

"I didn't like it at Glyndebourne at first," Silja says. "I thought it was very snobbish. I didn't like the picnics and all that side. But the work atmosphere was very nice and the work conditions were very good. Then I got to know the Christies better and now I go basically just because of them."

Silja leaves one in no doubt that Glyndebourne matters to her for artistic and personal reasons. "It's to do with the progressive approach," she says. "Coming to New York it would have been impossible to go to the Met with this work. It is perfect here in Brooklyn. It emphasises the primacy of the artistic."

At a reception after the first-night performance, Sir George Christie said that this week's American performances were the realisation of a "lifetime ambition" to take his company across the Atlantic. But the visit may turn out to be a one-off.

"Touring presents three hazards," Sir George explains as Silja and the rest of the company settle in for a night of hard partying. "First, we don't want to compromise our standards. Second, we need to ration and retain our allure. And third, it can be a distraction. My mind is really much more focused on this summer's festival."

webTitle: Arthur Smith: The death of British art

fields.headline: The death of British art
fields.trailText: We like our artists skint, drunk and, if possible, deranged.
fields.body:
We like our artists skint, drunk and, if possible, deranged. Van Gogh - now there was a man who led a proper painterly life, wandering round Europe, failing to sell his work, slurping absinthe and finally going mad and doing a Tyson on his own ear. We don't like these modern types who have grown plump and succulent on the Saatchi wodge.

As I sat on the tube en route to Michael Landy's show, Break Down, I noticed a cartoon in Private Eye in which a young British artist describes Picasso, Braque and Modigliani in Paris, "producing world-shattering art without a sou to their names". He and his friend agree how depressing this is and resolve to go to Mauritius again this Easter. The implication is that any artist worth his salt should not be able to afford such a trip.

The cliché of the starving artist is one of the many ideas that Landy has tossed into the air by publicly destroying everything he owns. This destruction is taking place in Oxford Street at what was, until recently, C&A (not, as I initially misread on the invite, the ICA). In this failed temple of capitalism he is feeding his clothes, furniture, love letters, car, artwork, passport, etc, into an industrial granulator. Since the artist is present but not naked, one must question the purity of his endeavour, but I found it most enlivening.

It certainly engenders a good debate in the pub afterwards. One mover in the art world told me: "We've just seen the death of British art." Another person mentioned sadhus in India, who give up everything and go begging. It was pointed out that the integrity of the work was undermined by being sponsored by the Times (proprietor: R Murdoch). A radical woman in experimental tights said Landy ought, technically, to kill himself at the end of the event.

I came to the conclusion that I must have a bit of a clear-out myself - I've got a biography of Van Gogh and some Guardian columns I'm keen to get shot of.

fields.headline: The prodigal daughter
fields.standfirst: LeAnn Rimes has grown up, writes  Michael Ellison . To prove it, she's got a raunchy new image and is suing her dad
fields.trailText: LeAnn Rimes has grown up, writes Michael Ellison . To prove it, she's got a raunchy new image and is suing her dad
fields.body:
Right from the off, there was something unsettling about the Mississippi-born country singer LeAnn Rimes. It wasn't the name, nor her generic soft-rock country style. It was more to do with lyrics such as: "No one else is gonna feel his touch, he's gonna drive me crazy . . . Makes me feel like a natural woman, I know he's the only one who can."

Regulation fare, perhaps, but sung by a 13-year-old? Only the unaware, devotees of the cutesy and those who take their pleasure in illegality could buy into her 1996 debut album, Blue, and keep their self-respect.

Still, she became a star. And now, five years later, Rimes has worked a new twist on an ancient affliction of popular music enterprises: she has fallen out with her record company because of musical differences.

Specifically, Rimes would like it to be made known that she does not approve of her new CD, I Need You. "This album was made without my creative input," she says in a message to fans. "It consists largely of unfinished material and songs that didn't make other albums. I have not heard the album, so I cannot tell you my opinion on it."

Not that this stops her. "I want to make abundantly clear to you that this album is not a reflection of myself as an artist, but is solely the conception of Curb Records, and for that I am truly and deeply sorry."

She stops short of asking people to desist from buying the CD, and the faithful propelled it to number 10 on the Billboard chart in its first week. For their money, they got two songs that had appeared already on the soundtrack to the movie Coyote Ugly, one that was used in the CBS miniseries Jesus, a duet with Elton John from Aïda and a few songs they had not heard previously.

They also received a cover shot showing that, at 18, Rimes has made the final transformation into an altogether foxier proposition, baring her teeth and giving it some shoulder from out of a little black number. Whether this is also unrepresentative of Rimes as an artist is less likely, but what is certain is that she is not the only one giving I Need You the shoulder, and a cold one at that. "To not give LeAnn any artistic input is terribly unfair . . . LeAnn is a maturing adult with her eyes wide open to being a responsible individual and artist," says her manager, Tom Ross. Rimes has not always worked in such harmony with her managerial staff. She is suing her father Wilbur - don't worry, she says she still loves him - and her former co-manager, Lyle Walker, alleging that they siphoned off $7m of her money.

The singer, who had a number one single in the United Kingdom last year and has sold more than 20m albums, is also suing to get out of the contract with Curb that her parents signed on her behalf when she was 12.

Wilbur, whose little girl has two Grammys and three Academy of Country Music Awards among her many trophies, is having none of it. He has filed a counter-suit saying that his daughter's company owes him a 3% producer's fee as part of a deal he struck with his wife Belinda. Or, rather, his ex-wife: they divorced in 1997.

"At the heart of the lawsuit is a teenage daughter who resisted her father's attempts to exert parental control," says Wilbur's attorney, Brad Rhorer. "One of the acts of rebellion was refusing to honour her father's role generally in her career and specifically in producing her records."

As an indication of just how out of control the songbird had become, Wilbur alleges that she wrecked a $350,000 Bentley, bought booze with her credit card and fell into the arms of another country singer at the age of 15. Or, put another way, she is a teenager with bigger toys and boys than most.

Curb Records have declined to comment but then, when a child star grows up, there is hardly any need to do so. All anyone has to do is to look at today's 18-year-old star and then refer back to the sleeve notes she wrote for Blue. "Thanks to: Mom and Dad for helping me to reach my dreams. Mike Curb for believing in me and giving me the chance of a lifetime."

 I Need You is out on Curb Records.

fields.headline: Another blow for troubled Bookham
fields.trailText: For a brief period last summer Bookham Technologies, a company that very few in the City had heard of prior to its April flotation, was in a stratosphere all of its own.
fields.body:
For a brief period last summer Bookham Technologies, a company that very few in the City had heard of prior to its April flotation, was in a stratosphere all of its own. The optical processor specialist was valued in excess of £6bn, more than the entire Sainsbury group - despite having an annual turnover less than one of the supermarket's stores.

Yet investors were strong believers that Bookham's products would play a crucial role in internet growth and backed it with their wallets.

It thrust Andrew Rickman, who had founded the firm in a room above his garage 12 years ago, into the limelight. The 25% stake that he and his wife Nichola owned was valued at £2bn and, in a crazy market where every management consultant was trying to float a technology firm and dreaming of making millions, it was too good a tale to ignore.

Ten months on Dr Rickman was trying to explain the reasons for Bookham's second disappointing trading update in less than one month. The shares have now fallen 80% from their one-time high.

Based on last night's closing price, Bookham is now valued at £863m and the Rickman family has looked on as the value of their shares has fallen by £1.8bn. Dr Rickman was dogged in his defence of the firm which he believes will still become a global player.

He will have been able to take some comfort from the fact that five months after the company floated, and when the shares were trading at around £33, he and other managers and founder shareholders at Bookham had dis posed of some of their stake. They only sold a tiny percentage of their overall holdings to satisfy demand from other investor. The sale netted the Rickmans £40m.

Shares in Bookham fell 12% to close at 691p yesterday after the Abingdon, Oxfordshire- based firm warned that full-year revenues for 2001 would be approximately £15m less than expected.

It said: "Bookham is expecting a marked downturn in demand for its mini-dual inline [DIL] products. The company expects that this will impact on the first half of the year, resulting in slower top line growth."

The loss for the quarter came in at £8.5m, while revenues jumped 49% to £11.5m, in line with expectations that had been lowered following last month's profits warning. Lower than hoped for orders from Nortel Networks - which accounts for more than 50% of Bookham's revenues - had forced the initial caution.

Analysts said further unexpected bad news so soon after the initial profit warning had hit Bookham's already damaged credibility among City investors.

"In this business consistency wins you your best friends but Bookham has been consistently inconsistent," said Navdeep Sheera, an analyst at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney who is moving his "speculate" recommendation on the stock down to the equivalent of a "sell".

Mr Sheera emphasised, however, that with £226m cash in the bank Bookham still had enough money to see it through the next 18 months to two years, by which time it hopes to make a profit.

Analysts at Credit Suisse First Boston also rate the stock a "sell" and say it is overvalued compared to US competitors.

Bookham is without a finance director after the previous holder of the post was forced to retire due to ill-health at the end of last year.

Dr Rickman said he was optimistic that much of the revenue shortfall for the year would be made up through better sales of other products which he believes are unique and will be in strong demand from customers. He disagreed with analysts who fear that future sales could be affected by the financial difficulties experienced by key customers like Lucent, which account for 10% of revenues.

Dr Rickman added that the work done building new manufacturing facilities, buying overseas rivals and recruiting new engineers since the company floated, placed it in "an extremely good position", a global star in the optical networking space.

Whether the share price will likewise regain its former sparkle is another matter.

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.trailText: Piers Henru, editor of lads' mag Front, on the Anna Kournikova email virus, Express
fields.body:
"She's undeniably the most attractive in a field famed for unattractive women. And any good-looking woman whose career involves lots of sweaty endeavour, those short skirts, tennis balls in the knickers and images of women's changing rooms, has definitely got something . . . Email is essentially a laddish thing, isn't it? If you're the first to pass on a naked picture of Anna Kournikova, you've got real kudos with the boys. Women? Well they read books for that sort of stuff, don't they?"

Piers Henru, editor of lads' mag Front, on the Anna Kournikova email virus, Express

"Our message to computer users is simple - think with your brain, not your groin"

Technology consultant Graham Cluley on the very same virus, Daily Telegraph

"I felt I was kind of de-sexed. I'd done all these movies and all of a sudden I was like someone's wife and that image had gone completely. I'm 32, I'm a woman now and I feel it's right, I feel it's empowering. I don't feel vulnerable or like I'm being exploited in any way. I feel that I'm actually very in control of it"

Patsy Kensit on why she posed naked, Arena

"The first few were all right, but then there was a shoot where all I had was a bit of fur wrapped around me. It was really tacky and I thought: 'That's not you. What are you doing?' "

Anna Friel on posing for lads' mags, Elle

"Funny, isn't it? Whenever a high-earning woman keeps a spouse at home, he's always called her manager. And when a high-earning man does exactly the same thing, she's always called his wife"

Carol Sarler's response to recent coverage of Anne Robinson's American TV deal, Express

"A foetus is a foetus, not an unborn child. People who support the availability of legal abortion are pro-choice, not pro-abortion, and those who oppose it are anti-abortion, not pro-life (none of us is anti-life, for goodness sake)"

Jenni Murray, Eve

"I've been on a diet for over 20 years. The trouble is, dieting wrecks the skin. It used to be 'great body, crap face'. Not any more. Botox has redressed the balance"

Ella, 33-year-old Botox party host, Evening Standard

webTitle: What rights of access do grandparents have?

fields.headline: Lost generation
fields.standfirst: When grandparents are denied access to their grandchildren it can be unbearably painful - but what rights do they have, asks  Natasha Joffe .
fields.trailText: When grandparents are denied access to their grandchildren it can be unbearably painful - but what rights do they have, asks Natasha Joffe .
fields.body:
When families fragment, the law steps in to determine the rights and res-ponsibilities of mothers and fathers in relation to children. But what happens to the grandparents when a family breaks up? All too often, especially if the split has been acrimonious, one or both parents may deny them access to the grandchildren.

The 1989 Children Act enabled grandparents and other extended family members to seek contact orders, but there is no automatic right to apply for an order. In most circumstances, grandparents must first obtain permission from the court. This extra hurdle - and extra expense (few grandparents are eligible for legal aid in such circumstances) - discourages many; the Grandparents Federation, a charity which works to maintain contact between grandparents and grandchildren, would like to see it removed. Most of those concerned agree that recourse to the courts should be a last resort. Approximately 40% of callers to the federation's helpline are looking for advice on contact. According to its director, Lynn Chesterman: "If anyone phones us here, the first thing we say is don't litigate. Even before you get to mediation, try to calm down. Take a deep breath."

The best solution in most cases may be a letter from the grandparent to the parent, apologising: "Even if you are not sure what you are apologising for . . . We try to get families to remember that a family feud is a feud between adults and not between children."

Jenny Johnson and her husband, Don, have spent more than £5,000 of their retirement savings on litigation to maintain contact with the children of Jenny's dead son. After long months of proceedings, Jenny was allowed to see the children for two hours every three months at a contact centre 170 miles away. "I actually walked out after one hour because I couldn't bear to see my grandchildren in that situation," she says. "It's worse than being on death row with someone watching you from every corner of the room and the children's mother there. My grandson was whispering, 'I love you,' so his mummy couldn't hear."

But what if informal solutions don't work? The government has been pushing mediation rather than litigation when families break down. But grandparents tend to be left out in the cold. "There's very little mediation for grandparents," says Chesterman. "I don't think there are enough resources in family mediation services to deal with the extended family." Andrea Rivers, a family law barrister and mediator, says: "The usual model at the moment is a couple who have split up amica bly and want some help sorting out money and children."

The situation is tougher still for people whose grandchildren are fostered or adopted. Although it is possible for a contact order in favour of grandparents to be made at the same time as an adoption order, Alison Richards, legal adviser at the Family Rights Group, knows of no case in which such an order has been made: "Generally, there's a belief in this country that contact with the birth family is a bad thing . . . if a parent has done wrong, the grandparent is implicated."

The problem seems to be our tradition of "closed" adoption. Although most children taken into care are not adopted as babies, it is still usual for previous family ties to be severed. Yet research since the 70s has shown the value of maintaining links. Where grandparents are permitted contact, Richards says, it may just mean that they can send Christmas cards but are not allowed to sign them "Granny" or "Granddad".

Where a child is taken into care, the local authority has a duty to promote contact, as long as it is consistent with the child's welfare. But, as Rivers points out, contact with grandparents is rarely seen as a priority by social services departments which have to give first consideration to parents, and are often anxious not to alienate foster families.

Further problems arise where parents are opposed to the grandparents seeing the children. Jean Stogdon, co-chairwoman of the new campaigning organisation Grandpar ents Plus, would like to see more training for social workers on working with the extended family.

Janet's story shows how ingenuity can triumph even against this bleak background. Her grandson, Ben, was taken into care as a baby (before the 1989 Children Act), and social workers severed contact with Janet and her husband, Arthur. "We would hang around the shops when we knew the foster parents would be around. They didn't object to us bumping into them at the shops."

On the day Ben was adopted by his foster parents (when he was five), Janet and Arthur waited outside the court. A few weeks later, the adoptive parents rang to ask whether they would like to visit.

Twelve years on, Janet and Arthur, who now provide a home for Ben's two sisters, have an excellent relationship with Ben and his adoptive parents and he has a relationship with his sisters. Janet is understandably critical of social services, although it is fair to say that government guidance and regulation in relation to family contact with children in care has improved since Ben entered the system. Children such as Ben, she points out, "come with a lot of baggage and are going to ask questions eventually. They are going to wonder where they come from."

Chesterman is emphatic that the interests of the child must come first; the federation is not suggesting that every grandparent is an apple-cheeked, cake-baking paragon, or that the law should be relaxed in any way which might expose children to risk. None the less, it is hard to escape the sense that as a society we are too often failing the grand- parents and the children.

As Stogdon says: "Family life is so diverse at the moment, and the voice of the older generation is so weak."

 Some names have been changed

Where a child is taken into care, the local authority has a duty to promote contact, as long as it is consistent with the child's welfare. But, as Rivers points out, contact with grandparents is rarely seen as a priority by social services departments which have to give first consideration to parents, and are often anxious not to alienate foster families. Further problems arise where parents are opposed to the grandparents seeing the children. Jean Stogdon, co-chairwoman of the new campaigning organisation Grandpar ents Plus, would like to see more training for social workers on working with the extended family. Janet's story shows how ingenuity can triumph even against this bleak background. Her grandson, Ben, was taken into care as a baby (before the 1989 Children Act), and social workers severed contact with Janet and her husband, Arthur. "We would hang around the shops when we knew the foster parents would be around. They didn't object to us bumping into them at the shops." On the day Ben was adopted by his foster parents (when he was five), Janet and Arthur waited outside the court. A few weeks later, the adoptive parents rang to ask whether they would like to visit. Twelve years on, Janet and Arthur, who now provide a home for Ben's two sisters, have an excellent relationship with Ben and his adoptive parents and he has a relationship with his sisters. Janet is understandably critical of social services, although it is fair to say that government guidance and regulation in relation to family contact with children in care has improved since Ben entered the system. Children such as Ben, she points out, "come with a lot of baggage and are going to ask questions eventually. They are going to wonder where they come from." Chesterman is emphatic that the interests of the child must come first; the federation is not suggesting that every grandparent is an apple-cheeked, cake-baking paragon, or that the law should be relaxed in any way which might expose children to risk. None the less, it is hard to escape the sense that as a society we are too often failing the grand- parents and the children. As Stogdon says: "Family life is so diverse at the moment, and the voice of the older generation is so weak."  Some names have been changed

webTitle: Sunk Japanese boat: Survivors tell their story

fields.headline: 'I saw something; I thought it was a whale'
fields.standfirst: Survivors recount the horror of being sunk by a surfacing US nuclear submarine
fields.trailText: The political fallout from the sinking of the Japanese fisheries training ship Ehime Maru continued to grow yesterday as angry survivors told of the horror of seeing a US nuclear submarine rip through its hull.
fields.body:
The political fallout from the sinking of the Japanese fisheries training ship Ehime Maru continued to grow yesterday as angry survivors told of the horror of seeing a US nuclear submarine rip through its hull.

Speaking at a press conference in Honolulu before flying back to Tokyo, members of the Ehime Maru's crew accused sailors in the USS Greeneville of "unforgivable" laxness in allowing civilians to handle its controls at the time of the accident.

Nine people, including four 17-year-old students, have been missing, believed dead, since Friday, when the 110-metre (360ft) Greeneville carried out an emergency surfacing drill almost immediately below the 53-metre Ehime Maru.

The ship was carrying a party of 13 students and two teachers from the Uwajima fisheries high school on a study tour to catch swordfish, tuna and shark. The school picked the busy sea lanes around Hawaii because they were considered safe.

They were anything but safe on Friday afternoon, when the Greeneville's crew blew the main ballast tank, executing an emergency procedure which sent the 6,900-tonne submarine shooting up wards at an angle of 30 degrees. As the submarine sped towards the surface, most of the training ship's students and 20 crew were below decks.

Second engineer Sakichi Atsuta said he was taking medication in the bathroom. Takashi Nakamura, a young deckhand, was washing his clothes. Tetsuo Hama was eating lunch. Others were resting in their cabins. Some of the students were tidying away the dishes after a meal.

Impact

Moments later they were jolted by a double impact. The lights died and they heard the screech of metal tearing through metal. Within seconds water gushed in through a huge hole in the hull.

"Everyone was in a panic," said Shukuo Nakamura, a deck hand. "'Everyone go up!' someone was shouting. 'Go up because the waves are coming.'

"And then a big wave crashed against us and I was thrown into the water."

Hideo Okayama rushed out in time to see the menacingly dark profile of the submarine break surface. "I saw something come up and I thought it was a whale," he said.

As water flooded through the lower decks, the senior officers ordered every one to climb to the top of the ship. "We were already at the top of the ship and all I heard was someone screaming 'Danger! Danger!'" Mr Okayama said.

Within minutes the bulk of the ship was submerged. Many could not recall how they made it to the life rafts in the ensuing chaos.

"It was total panic," the first mate, Ryoichi Miya, said.

Mr Nakamura was among those who helped students to one of the three liferafts, where they huddled in diesel-polluted water for nearly 50 minutes while the submarine prowled nearby. Fortunately the sea was warm and fairly calm.

Twenty-six of the 35 people on board were saved. The rest are believed to have been trapped in the ship as it plunged 550 metres to the floor of the Pacific, nine miles from Honolulu.

The survivors blamed the crew of the Greeneville after hearing that guests had been trying out the controls of the submarine.

"A civilian wouldn't know what to do," Mr Miya said."It's absolutely unforgivable if a civilian was operating it."

As the first survivors returned home, Japanese news programmes broadcast extensive coverage of the shocked coastal community of Uwajima, in western Japan.

Yoshiko Kamado, whose 16-year-old son Atsushi was rescued, told reporters that she believed the surfacing drill had been performed to impress the civilian guests.

"I sense laxness. I am all the more annoyed since I heard that the area is mostly crowded with training vessels and cruise ships. I just cannot stand it," she told the Kyodo news wire.

As increasingly angry editorials appear in the Japanese media, Washington and Tokyo have attempted to minimise the damage to relations between the two countries. President George Bush has apologised, and compensation has been promised. But explanations have been slow in coming. The US has confirmed that two civilian guests were at the controls but has refused to say what they were doing.

Washington has been reluctant to grant Japanese requests for the ship to be salvaged so that the bodies can be retrieved. Officials admit that recovering it would be technically difficult and expensive.

The US has begun using a deep sea robot to locate the wreckage and assess the possibility of a salvage operation.

webTitle: Pepsi pulls out of Premiership race

fields.headline: Pepsi pulls out of Premiership race
fields.trailText: Pepsi withdrew last night from the race to sponsor the Premier League, leaving only two companies bidding to back English football's elite competition.
fields.body:
Pepsi withdrew last night from the race to sponsor the Premier League, leaving only two companies bidding to back English football's elite competition.

Officials refused to say who the two were but an announcement is expected over the next few days once the sale of overseas television rights has been completed.

A Pepsi spokesman said: "While the Premier League is a great property, we are not involved in bidding. We are already well covered in that sector by our partnership with Manchester United and our association with global stars like David Beckham."

Any company that eventually wins the rights to sponsor the Premier League will have its name associated with the competition around the world. Carling, which previously sponsored the league but recently withdrew from nego tiations, was named as sponsor only in United Kingdom broadcasts. Overseas the competition was known as the FA Premier League.

Budweiser also announced recently that it was withdrawing from the bidding.

A Premier League spokesman said: "There can only be one winner for the total sponsorship and, as negotiations progress, the process will inevitably get refined until we are left with the organisation that has won the rights to sponsor the FA Premier League."

Premier League officials are keen to find a global sponsor not associated with alcohol, in an attempt to transform football's image.

Carling paid £27m to sponsor the league four years ago but the new backer will be expected to pay considerably more. The Premier League is broadcast in 127 countries and is reckoned to be the most watched domestic football competition in the world.

fields.headline: United take a firm grip in the wet
fields.standfirst:
The English champions are one win away from the quarter-finals
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: For all Valencia's attacking flair, last year's beaten finalists could not apply the finishing touch and a supremely efficient away performance by Alex Ferguson's men left them one win away from the quarter-finals.
fields.byline: David Lacey  at the Mestalla stadium
fields.body:
Manchester United trod water with supreme efficiency here last night to force their second successive scoreless draw in the Mestalla stadium and leave themselves a win away from reaching the last eight of the Champions League. With Jaap Stam, Wes Brown and Roy Keane outstanding, Sir Alex Ferguson's side saw off a remodelled Valencia attack which for all its ingenuity and imagination failed to apply a finishing touch.

Last season a goalless game satisfied both sides since each needed a point to go through. All the more credit to United then for belying their earlier erratic defending away from home in this season's tournament to leave Valencia rather more frustrated than they were last March.

United knew that by this time next week they could be virtually assured of a quarter-final place. Four points from their two encounters with Valencia, who come to Old Trafford on Tuesday, would be enough; now United need only the other three.

Yet this game may have been as much about mutual pride in performance. Valencia had not lost at home in Europe for eight years while the English champions needed to restore some kudos abroad after first-round defeats by PSV in Eindhoven and Anderlecht in Brussels.

With the ball stopping on a pitch saturated by a day of heavy rain, neither team were likely to make that fluent a statement about their footballing qualities.

Stam and Brown stood to be tested by the combination of John Carew, Valencia's Norwegian striker, and the sharp Argentine skills of Pablo Aimar, their £14m buy from River Plate. Working in tandem, the pair splashed into dangerous situations early on, with Gaizka Mendieta prodding and probing around them, but later the ability of Kily Gonzalez to set things up from the right posed a greater threat.

Ryan Giggs, tormenting Jocelyn Angloma with his speed and persistence, was United's most dangerous attacker. Generally, though, they were content to let Teddy Sheringham and Andy Cole conjure what they could without pressing forward in numbers.

After 20 minutes Sheringham set up Giggs for a centre which found David Beckham sprinting towards the far post and failing to meet it by a whisker, but such moments were rare. Largely it was a matter of Stam and Keane maintaining their authority, although Mendieta should have done better when he overelaborated in the box.

For all Valencia's threatening gestures and Manchester United's counter-punches, neither goalkeeper had to make a serious save in the first half. Fabien Barthez's worst moment came when he failed to cut out a centre from Kily and was rescued by the alertness of Brown.

This state of affairs suited United but increasingly frustrated Valencia, who were finding it difficult to launch Carew or Aimar beyond the long-legged reach of Stam. Equally Mauricio Pellegrino offered Cole few glimpses of goal, and Amedeo Carboni's policy of lay ing up tight on Beckham restricted his supply of centres and saw him replaced by Nicky Butt for the last 15 minutes.

The more Valencia strained for a win the more they were likely to expose themselves to counter-attacks but, unless the Spanish side scored, United were not going to change a pattern which always looked like bringing them the contentment of a draw.

With 20 minutes left Kily sent up Carew for a close-range shot which, though it was blocked by Barthez, could have brought Valencia a goal had Aimar been better placed for the rebound. After that the game drifted towards its barren conclusion.

The result was prearranged only to the extent that Ferguson had largely planned it that way. Last night, for United's progress in the Champions League, a clean sheet was as good as a muddy blanket.

 Second-half goals from Mario Haas and Tomica Kocijan gave Sturm Graz their 2-0 win against Panathinaikos and moved them up to third place. In Group B, 10-man Milan were held to 1-1 by Paris St-Germain, who equalised through Nicolas Anelka. Galatasaray lead the way by two points thanks to Suat Kaya's early winner against Deportivo La Coruna.

Valencia : Canizares; Angloma, Ayala, Pellegrino, Carboni; Angulo, Mendieta, Baraja, Kily Gonzalez; Aimar, Carew (Alonso, 75min).

Manchester United : Barthez; G Neville, Stam, Brown, Silvestre; Beckham (Butt, 75), Keane, Scholes, Giggs; Sheringham, Cole (Solskjaer, 85).

Referee : D Jol (Netherlands).

webTitle: Sugar article was 'an honestly expressed opinion'

fields.headline: Sugar article was 'an honestly expressed opinion'
fields.trailText: The Daily Mail's article that called Sir Alan Sugar "miserly" in his running of Tottenham was an honestly expressed opinion based on fact, the high court was told yesterday.
fields.body:
The Daily Mail's article that called Sir Alan Sugar "miserly" in his running of Tottenham was an honestly expressed opinion based on fact, the high court was told yesterday.

Victoria Sharp, counsel for the newspaper, said the reporter Jeff Powell was entitled to comment on the state of affairs at the club. "You should be free to express your opinions about football, and so should Mr Powell," she said. "The facts speak for themselves and the facts support the comment that was in the article."

Powell, who with Associated Newspapers is pleading fair comment in defence against Sugar's libel action, contended that the December 1999 article headlined "Why miserly Sugar must come out of his counting house and give George [Graham] the money" was about a "matter of great public controversy" at the time.

Powell agreed there was no doubt that Sugar had put the club on a sound financial footing but said he considered that the chairman's response to Graham's team winning the League Cup the previous season had been "miserly".

"I felt that that achievement had given Tottenham a platform from which to build. Here they were with a flying start to the season, the glitch had come and they had to decide which way to go.

"I just felt George Graham deserved an injection of cash and if two terrific players were brought in there could have been a transformation."

The hearing continues.

Dennis Bergkamp has dismissed as "total rubbish" suggestions that he did not travel to Lyon for Arsenal's Champions League game on Tuesday because he was afraid of trains. "I know that Mr Wenger was asked whether I'm scared of travelling by train and he reportedly fell a little short of denying that I have such a fear," the striker said on his website.

"I'm a little bit disappointed that he didn't consult me. It seems a little odd because Mr Wenger knows I have no problem with trains." The Dutchman added that the manager had simply chosen to rest him.

Airdrie's owner Steve Archibald and his players were locked out of their ground by the liquidator KPMG yesterday. KPMG took the action because it did not believe the former striker had the money to fund the £2m rescue deal he has been promising since July.

"We could cease trading at any point in time," said the liquidator Blair Nimmo. "But it is also a football club and we are trying to recognise that."

Internet sales of tickets for the 2002 World Cup have been delayed in Japan and South Korea for up to three days because of technical problems. Fifa wanted to take applications on its website (www.fifaworldcup.com) but fans in the two host countries can still apply in writing. Allocations will be decided by a draw.

fields.headline: European transfer deal in sight
fields.standfirst: Fifa president hails a 'historic' compromise but key issues are unresolved
fields.trailText: Fifa president Sepp Blatter yesterday hailed a 'historic' compromise over the future of transfers despite key issues being left unresolved.
fields.body:
Hopes rose yesterday that football's seemingly interminable wrangle about the future of transfers will finally be settled tomorrow after the world and European governing bodies reached agreement with the European Commission on a number of key issues.

At a meeting in Brussels between the Fifa president Sepp Blatter and his Uefa counterpart Lennart Johansson and the commission all parties agreed that there would be two transfer windows in the European football season, one in the winter and another in the summer, and that players' contracts would be for a minimum of one year and a maximum of five years.

The agreement means footballers will have greater powers to change clubs and will almost certainly lead to a significant increase in their earnings with clubs spending more on wages than transfers.

However, other crucial areas have still to be agreed, such as the minimum length of time players have to honour contracts and what penalties players who unilaterally break contracts should face.

Fifa and Uefa say such players should be banned for at least a year; the commission feels this is too harsh, although it accepts there should be some sort of punishment.

Following yesterday's three-hour meeting in Brussels, both sides expressed satisfaction and said they were confident that agreement on the outstanding issues could be reached tomorrow at another meeting in Brussels.

Blatter said that for the first time the commission had accepted the need for "stability of contracts". It had initially stated that players should be allowed to break contracts after three months.

Blatter said: "I am sure that this was a historic day today. There is now a full agreement by Fifa and Uefa that we are near to a solution which will be beneficial to the whole world of football and which ... will enhance the quality of the game."

Uefa's director of communications Mike Lee said: "It's very positive . The need for stability of contracts has been accepted and understood."

Football and commission officials have been locked in negotiation for the past six months following demands that the transfer system be changed to comply with European Union labour laws, giving players freedom of movement across the continent.

Fifa and Uefa yesterday met the EU commissioners Mario Monti, Viviane Reding and Anna Diamantopoulou. Monti, the competition commissioner, later read a joint statement stating that the political commitment existed to finding a solution and that a final deal would be announced before the end of February.

Monti added: "One must find a balance between the legitimate need for stability of contracts - an aim, it [the commission] believes, is supported by clubs, players and fans alike - and freedom of movement which is one of the fundamental rights.

"The presidents of Fifa and Uefa agreed to reflect on an appropriate solution."

Tomorrow's meeting will also be attended by representatives of G14, the group of elite European clubs, and Fifpro, the international players' union.

However, despite optimism expressed by commission and football officials, Fifpro remains concerned. It is opposed to the Fifa/Uefa recommendation of making players honour contracts for a minimum three years and is at odds with them also over how the compensation figure for a player should be reached.

Uefa has told Fifpro that it is willing to go it alone in negotiations and will submit its own proposals to the commission if agreement cannot be reached.

Fifpro is to meet Fifa and Uefa officials today to try to achieve a united position from the football family, as the commission has demanded.

Gordon Taylor, president of Fifpro, said: "The two key areas not finalised ... are stability of contracts and the size of compensation.

 Contracts will last between one and five years, effectively meaning that a player cannot move twice in one season.

 An arbitration panel will decide how much compensation a club losing a player should receive.

 How to protect players aged 18 and under.

Fifa and Uefa say such players should be banned for at least a year; the commission feels this is too harsh, although it accepts there should be some sort of punishment. fields.headline: Love's Labour's Lost
fields.standfirst:
Lowry
Salford
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Lowry
Salford
Rating: **
fields.body:
Will setting Love's Labour's Lost in an office lobby give Shakespeare's most earth-bound comedy a lift? English Touring Theatre's update has an air-conditioned elevator ambience, the Kingdom of Navarre becomes a barbed world of office politics where muzak is the food of love.

Director Stephen Unwin makes a bold attempt to explain certain circumlocutory aspects of a play that frequently trots out spin rather than substance. Love's Labour's Lost often feels like an extended linguistic conceit demonstrating endless ways of saying very little. Unwin interprets this arch loquacity as postmodernism before its time, suggesting that if the young bucks of Navarre become a clutch of trendy PR-types we will be better able to comprehend their superficiality.

It's a nice touch, but for all the brushed aluminium and slick tailoring of Neil Warmington and Mark Bouman's designs, Love's Labour's Lost is never going to be transformed into Sex and the City. Incongruities such as Berowne the merry madcap marketing executive we can live with; the deeper problem is that so much of the dialogue is simply incomprehensible. The young cast is far more comfortable with their ravishing outfits than the paradoxes and conundrums they are obliged to come out with.

The danger with designer-Shakespeare is that it becomes so cool as to freeze out what little warmth remains in this most charmless of the early comedies. The incessant digs at funny foreigners, brainless yokels and doddering pedants seem to exhibit Shakespeare at his least compassionate, while his mocking of the young men's intellectual pretensions hardly disguises the fact that he's really one of the lads.

It is the women who emerge with the greatest dignity: the scenes with the Princess of France and her companions are the most watchable. Kirsten Parker's Princess has a sprightly authority and Syan Blake's Rosaline offers an excellent foil to Nick Fletcher's rather monotone Berowne.

That the plot concludes with the most improbable instance of coitus interruptus in the canon sums up the manifold frustrations of this play. After an effortful expenditure of words, everyone agrees to a three-year moratorium on love. But if falling in love is such a laborious business as this, maybe that isn't such a bad idea.

 Ends Saturday. Box office: 0161-876 2000. Then tours to Bury St Edmonds, Brighton, Darlington and around Britain until April 28.

webTitle: Business: Abbey tells Lloyds to up its bid

fields.headline: Abbey tells Lloyds to up its bid
fields.trailText: Abbey National's management issued a strong defence of its track record yesterday as it called upon Lloyds TSB to increase its £20bn bid if it was serious about taking it over.
fields.body:
Abbey National's management issued a strong defence of its track record yesterday as it called upon Lloyds TSB to increase its £20bn bid if it was serious about taking it over.

Publishing pre-tax profits for last year of £1.9bn a week early, Lord Tugendhat, Abbey's chairman, said: "If anyone wants to buy us the price will have to reflect the considerable achievements we are delivering now." He appeared to suggest that Lloyds TSB needed to increase the 260p cash component of its offer, the remainder of which is 1.5 Lloyds TSB shares.

Yesterday the Lloyds offer valued each Abbey share at £13.26, above last night's £12.30 close, which was up 5p on the day.

Lord Tugendhat made it clear that a takeover by Lloyds TSB was not Abbey's "preferred option". He said Abbey had a strong future on its own or with Bank of Scotland, with which it had been trying to merge when Lloyds TSB waded in with its offer.

Abbey accompanied news of the 11% rise in pre-tax profits for 2000 with a pledge to accelerate its commitment to derive 65% of profits from outside its core mortgage and savings business, bringing it forward to next year instead of 2003.

webTitle: Pop review: Frank Black and the Catholics

fields.headline: Frank Black and the Catholics
fields.standfirst:
Cockpit
Leeds
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Cockpit
Leeds
Rating: ***
fields.body:
The huge, scary bald man with tattoos is jumping up and down, gesticulating wildly and looking like he might be about to crush someone's skull. It's not Frank Black, it's a Frank Black fan. And he's thoroughly enjoying himself. Black is on stage, looking increasingly like a cross between a baby and a bouncer, grinning affably and trying to ignore the bellows of his rabid alter-ego in the sweating throng. As some familiar chords ring out, one fan turns to his mate and beams: "I can't believe he's playing this!" The song is the Pixies' Where Is My Mind, and its presence indicates that Black has reconciled himself with his past as an American indie figurehead.

His band, the Catholics, sock the oldies to us with fierce determination. The jerky stomp of Nimrod's Son, complete with Black's unsavoury screams, is counterpointed by the sluggishly menacing Monkey Gone to Heaven, a spine-tingling reminder of what an inventive songwriter "Black Francis" was in his heyday.

There are a few rather more turgid Pixie and solo-Frank retreads, so it's a good job we have plenty of offerings from the Catholics' fine new album Dog in the Sand. Blast-Off, the gig's opening track, is as good a place as any to get a handle on Black's new direction. Chugging Keith Richards guitar, boogie piano, and sing-along chorus are pumped out at deafening volume. But it's not until the windswept, piano dominated I'll Be Blue that we hear the plaintive pedal-steel guitar that adds colour to much of the new album's world-weary melancholy.

What with the pedal steel, the emotional lyrics and the increasingly wistful melody writing, it's tempting to wonder how good Frank could be if he followed his heart and applied all his energy to carving out his new identity. Unfortunately, about a third of the show was drowning in a muddy puddle of retro-indie noise.

 At Liverpool University (0151-794 4158) tonight, then touring.

fields.headline: Ligeti delivers a double triumph
fields.standfirst:
Ligeti premieres
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Ligeti premieres
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
One new work by Gyorgy Ligeti would be treat enough, but there were two in the London Sinfonietta's concert, conducted by George Benjamin. As well as the British premiere of his horn concerto, the Hamburgisches Konzert, first performed two weeks ago in Hamburg, there was a chance for London to catch up with an even more recent piece, Sippal, Dobbal, Nadimegeduvel, a song cycle to poems by Sandor Weores, finished last year.

Ligeti's tribute to his fellow countryman - he describes Weores as "Hungary's Mozart" - is typically wry and playful. The seven little settings pit a mezzo-soprano (the spell-binding Katalin Karolyi) against four percussionists, who as well as having to strike and stroke the usual range of instruments, have to play harmonicas and swanee whistles. Unaccountably, the Sinfonietta's programme included no translations of the texts, but the diverse ways in which they are delivered - as guttural exclamations, a patter song, a lilting lullaby - suggest that all human life is contained in the poems, while the percussionists create ever-changing webs of colour around them. The result is typically unclassifiable; if Ligeti ever gets around to writing the second opera he has contemplated now for more than 20 years (based on Alice in Wonderland), it might, one suspects, sound a bit like this.

What is unexpected about the Hamburgisches Konzert, though, is how it harks back to the world of Ligeti's earlier works. Harmonically everything may have changed - one of the points of the new concerto, in which the solo horn is accompanied by four natural horns in the chamber orchestra, is the exploration of tunings and harmonies outside the conventional western system.

But the shifting textures of the first of the six tiny movements look back to Ligeti's musical cloudscapes of the 1960s, while the frantic canon for the orchestra that ends the fourth recalls the manic clockworks of a few years later. Elsewhere, there are long, sinuous melodies and echo effects between the soloist and his four siblings that conjure up the forest images so deeply embedded in central European folklore.

Somehow all these disparate miniatures add up to a substantial experience. Ligeti challenges the performers in new ways, without resorting to cheap effects: the horn part is ferociously difficult - Michael Thompson seemed to have mastered it consummately - and the writing for the orchestra isn't far behind. Further performances, no doubt, will bring even more rewards.

webTitle: Theatre review: A View from the Bridge

fields.headline: Unspeakable love in Edinburgh
fields.standfirst:
A View from the Bridge
Royal Lyceum Theatre
Edinburgh
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
A View from the Bridge
Royal Lyceum Theatre
Edinburgh
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The last time Arthur Miller's A View from the Bridge was performed at the Royal Lyceum, in 1989, Kenny Ireland played Eddie Carbone. Ireland now directs Matt Costello in the part; he, in turn, played Eddie while at drama college with his partner, Kathryn Howden, playing Beatrice. The couple are repeating that experience in this production, now at about the right age. Confused? You won't be.

For Miller's writing is about all our lives, and remains so despite social change and alleged progress. The setting for A View from the Bridge might be the Sicilian-American area of Brooklyn in the 1950s, but in its portrayal of how communities, from individual families upwards, deal with the presence of outsiders, the play still resonates.

The Italian immigrants being sheltered by close-knit communities in the tenement blocks can't help but make us think of asylum-seekers across Europe: the furious vitriol meted out to them from some quarters, the lack of communities ready to welcome them. When Carbone yells his anguished, broken plea, "I want my name", it articulates all the insecurity that forms tabloid fury now.

But Miller never tackles issues without a human dimension to them. Here it's the fate of Carbone, the working man who has taken in his wife's niece and raised her as his own. His unspeakable and unspoken love for her scars the family interactions - every meal, every edgy exchange between him and Beatrice. When love arrives for her in the form of Rodolpho, a family drama becomes the stuff of classic tragedy, "a high visible arc moving in full view to a single explosion" as Miller once described the play.

Ireland's production is very nearly perfect, with only a few uneven accents and a slightly cool and underwhelming first act detracting from an otherwise compelling evening. Costello and Howden shine as Eddie and Beatrice, their lives ready to snap into dysfunction at any moment. If anything, Howden's Beatrice, the long-suffering and self- deluding broken woman, has the edge. In the second act especially, her every move - to clear the table or to make love to Eddie - has palpable tragedy running through it.

When a production of the play gets the central couple right, as this does, then it's the smaller details that make the difference between a perfunctory and memorable performance. The music here is perfect, all aching, impending menace, while Saul Radomsky's set of the house's interior, with its openness and yet hidden, interior depths, is powerfully suggestive. Everything is lit as if Edward Hopper was directing an episode of Happy Days. The result is the American Dream gone more badly wrong than we have words to say.

 Until 10 March. Box office: 0131-248 4848.

fields.headline: Credible Witness
fields.standfirst:
Royal Court Theatre Upstairs
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Royal Court Theatre Upstairs
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
The asylum debate has moved into the theatre. Alongside Kay Adshead's impassioned The Bogus Woman at the Bush, we have a new 90-minute play from Timberlake Wertenbaker that takes us into the same terrain of detention centres and hunger strikes. But where Adshead's play is brutally shocking, Wertenbaker's raises questions about nationhood, identity and history.

Wertenbaker approaches her subject obliquely but the nub of the issue is this. Alexander, a Macedonian teacher, has escaped persecution and made it to Britain; three years later his indomitable mother, Petra, arrives at Heathrow in search of him. Alexander has disappeared into a world of community work and street-cleaning: the proud and institutionally detained Petra goes on hunger-strike until the authorities find her son. Eventually they meet in a confrontation of irreconcilable attitudes: the one embodies an intransigent Macedonian nationalism, the other the necessary assimilation of the exile.

As always, Wertenbaker is not afraid to tackle big issues: above all, she attacks the idea of historical paralysis. Britain, she argues, is locked into a notion of itself as an island fortress destined to repel unwanted boarders. Other nations equally are walled in by their oppressive past: to that end she shows even Petra's chauvinism crumbling. Behind the play lurks a vision of a world where we are not all defined by nationhood and where the free passage of peoples is a sustainable ideal.

Wertenbaker's ideas are fascinating, even if their dramatic resolution is not always plausible. The big mother-son confrontation packs the right emotional punch. But Wertenbaker also invents a harrassed immigration official rather too symbolically named Simon Le Britten. And, while he effectively embodies the arbitrary power and rash certainty of the bureaucrat, the scene where he winds up in a detention centre on New Year's Eve to sort out Petra's case defies belief.

There is a knockdown performance from Olympia Dukakis as Petra, a superb embodiment of maternal and nationalistic pride. Adam Kotz as her son persuasively stands for exiled absorption and there is good work from Clive Merrison as the emotionally involved desk-wallah. Even if you feel Wertenbaker manipulates the dramatic situation to suit the argument, her play adds weight to the growing canon of asylum dramas.

 Until March 10. Box office: 020-7565 5000. A version of this review appeared in later editions of yesterday's paper.

Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Those who arrived at the South Bank expecting something from John Cale's classical or soundtrack portfolio were in for a disappointment. This was strictly Cale's post-Velvet Underground back pages, the singer alone (self-accompanied on acoustic guitar and piano), or with the occasional swoony daub of 21st-century pedal steel from BJ Cole, who looked like a bemused Open University lecturer. Cale has one of the finest, most underrated catalogues in rock, but you might have come away thinking that £19.50 for a virtual busk of a performance (no staging, little in the way of between-songs chat) was taking the unplugged piss.

Once you'd admired Cale's groovy leather trews there was nothing in the way of any visual dynamic - this from a man whose fondness for ski masks and enacted psychosis once marked him out as the thinking person's Ozzy Osbourne. But Cale does know his masks, and it's hard to tell if this was just his take on the ultimate mask: acting natural.

This performance was one of bland reserve, with just the occasional chill to remind us that the alien still lurks in his gut. After a breezy, acoustic skip through a few songs old and new, hopes were raised that he might be about to essay something more innovative. A burst of radio static, a skippety computerised heartbeat, treated noise squalls from Cole, and a slightly askew piano motif from Cale ... But this dip into crackly electronica proved literally to be a one-off, and the rest of the set was played decidedly safe.

The acoustic treatment did suit songs such as the ghost-filled Ballad of Cable Hogue - one of Cale's many tales of lost prairies and road-movie regrets. But even here he managed to spoil things by taking too many of his best songs at the same brisk clip. The melancholy Chinese Envoy (surely the only rock song to namecheck Cardinal Richelieu?) was revved up a notch or two to no good effect.

This is essentially the same show I saw Cale do seven years ago (as commemorated on the peerless live resume Fragments of a Rainy Season), when his subtle grasp of theatrics had me on the edge of my seat. Now, by comparison, he was poised, polished, but not much more than chirpily proficient. Songs such as Paris 1919 and Thoughtless Kind cry out for some kind of chamber orchestra treatment; I can't have been alone in assuming this was why the Queen Elizabeth Hall had been chosen as the venue. You may have come away with the impression that all Cale songs sound similar - nothing could be further from the truth.

webTitle: David Walker and Polly Toynbee's top 10 books about politics

fields.headline: David Walker and Polly Toynbee's top 10 books about politics
fields.trailText: Political commentators Polly Toynbee and David Walker are the authors of Did Things Get Better? (Penguin), in which they explore the performance of Tony Blair's first administration. Here they choose the essential books to read if you want to understand New Labour, and some favourite political novels.
fields.body:
Political commentators Polly Toynbee and David Walker (left) are the authors of Did Things Get Better? (Penguin), in which they explore the performance of Tony Blair's first administration. Here they choose the essential books to read if you want to understand New Labour, and some favourite political novels.
Read extracts from Did Things Get Better?
Read Polly Toynbee and David Walker's online discussion
Buy Did Things Get Better? at Amazon.co.uk

David Walker
1. The Cunning of Unreason by John Dunn
A subtle, pessimistic book about democracy by an original mind. Read Dunn and the future of elective self-government looks bleak.

2. Mandelson and the Making of New Labour by Donald MacIntyre
More than just a biography of the prince of darkness, Don MacIntyre brilliantly conveys how Labour's defeats in 1983, 1987 and 1992 felt. This remains the great source book on why Mandelson and Gordon Brown fell out.

3. Primary Colors by Anonymous (Joe Klein)
This is still the best book about Bill Clinton - and Monica and Hillary - and the sheer exhilaration of running for national office in the USA. Of course it's a novel, but it speaks truth about power.

4. Politics and the Pound by Philip Stephens
The essential book about the John Major premiership and the ERM debacle. Money is the mother's milk of politics, they say; sterling's fate was John Major's and may yet be Tony Blair's.

5. The Life of William Ewart Gladstone by John Morley (Greenwood Press, ISBN: 0837105765)
Morley was himself a Liberal MP, and brings to the monumental task of describing the tree-chopping, prostitute-rescuing, three-hour-speechifying Victorian a shared love of the business of winning and using power for public purpose.

Polly Toynbee
6. Sovereign Virtue: The Theory and Practice of Equality by Ronald Dworkin
Liberty, fraternity, equality: the greatest of the three is equality, and Ronald proves it with rigour. He is the kind of author who makes his readers feel cleverer.

7. Felix Holt: The Radical by George Eliot
Modern political novels never come close. Through her characters Eliot managed to explain class and (unfashionable idea these days but all too present in 1832) class conflict

8. The Prime Minister by Peter Hennessy
Throughout the country politicians are making speeches using bons mots and stories culled from this set of portraits of premiers since Attlee. Is Blair Boney? Hennessy reminds us that the historians will remember Blair as a successful war leader.

9. Paying for Progress by the Commission on Taxation and Citizenship (Fabian Society)
Here, in one place, all the arguments for and against income and indirect taxes, with handy charts and some passionate pleas for higher spending, too.

10. Phineas Finn by Anthony Trollope
An Irish adventurer rises in the Commons then comes a cropper. If only real politics was this witty and exciting.

webTitle: Business: Stand by for battle of the banks

fields.headline: Stand by for battle of the banks
fields.standfirst: Notebook: Bidders regroup as Byers ponders
fields.trailText: Notebook: Ian Harley, the chief executive of Abbey National, insisted yesterday that the bank he has run for the past three years was not up for sale.
fields.body:
Ian Harley, the chief executive of Abbey National, insisted yesterday that the bank he has run for the past three years was not up for sale. Indeed, a casual flick through the lengthy documentation accompanying the bank's year-end figures showed no reason to disbelieve him.

The detailed analysis of Abbey's profits (close to £2bn at the pre-tax level) made no reference to the planned merger with Bank of Scotland or the unwanted approach by Lloyds TSB.

Yet, gleaming as the figures may have been, Abbey's near-term trading performance is no longer of any interest to the financial community.

The issue is simply about who is going to own this bank and, unwittingly or otherwise, the impression that came across during yesterday's briefings in the City is that Abbey is now ready to talk to Lloyds - so long as it radically improves the terms on offer. (A figure of 400p a share in cash against the 260p on the table has been whispered.)

By implication, this suggests Mr Harley believes the planned merger with BoS is all but unattainable.

There is a big "but" to all this: what Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, will decide to do with the huge dossier sitting on his desk containing the office of fair trading's advice on whether a combined Lloyds TSB and Abbey poses competition risks.

Referring the bid to the competition commission would involve a review that could take six months. A decision, which must be publicised by February 23, to give it the all-clear means the stalling willhave to end.

Abbey is going to talk to its shareholders, more than 70 of whom have already received visits from Lloyds TSB - a bank whose own copy book is far from clean, having abandoned its much-vaunted cost-income ratio targets and failed to get anywhere near a promised deal in Europe. Shareholders will demand a hard fight and look certain get one. Mr Byers is the only reason for the truce.

Research gap

There was a display of tack-spitting at the Canary Wharf offices of investment bankers Credit Suisse First Boston yesterday morning, after news in these pages that one of its analysts had been caught sending out a hard-nosed research note on the software and controls group Invensys, advising institutional clients to sell the stock, when the bank was telling everyone else (including Invensys) that it believed the shares were a raging "buy".

The whole issue of what information analysts glean when they talk to companies and how it is distributed is an ultra-sensitive one. Written guidance on the matter is likely to pop out of the regulator, the financial services authority, in a couple of months' time.

For CSFB, the Invensys affair is no more than an embarrassment. The bank does not have a corporate finance relationship with the company and there is no evidence that its analyst received special access to information on trading at Invensys.

But the equity market as a whole has to get some clarity and transparency into the system of investment banking research. As things stand, there is a dreadful lack of trust.

Company chairmen and chief executives, fretting about their share prices, can be accused of being anxious. But just because they are paranoid it does not mean the City is not after them.

Sweet nothings

Strange as it may seem, the British are losing their appetite for sweets, according to Cadbury Schweppes.

The eclipse of Ye Olde Sweet Shop by the megastore has taken the fun out of selecting a handful of gobstoppers. Supermarket chains are more interested in surrounding till points with glossy advertising magazines than confectionery, so the last-minute purchase of a Kit-Kat is becoming a rarity.

Cadbury Schweppes yesterday let slip its latest ruse to win back the sweet toothed. The firm has come up with the concept Cafe Cadbury.

The concept of a chocolate-dominated meal may sound peculiar but on reflection Cafe Cadbury has some commercial sense. The past few years have seen an explosion in the popularity of coffee, with lattes and moccacinos available on every high street. Hot chocolate is yet to become trendy but there is no reason why it should not appeal to the same espresso-sipping crowd.

According to market research firm AC Nielsen, sales at confectionery and tobacco stores fell 12% between 1996 and 1999. Cadbury will need to be imaginative to maintain its growth rate.

Among its suggestions is the installation of vending machines at hospitals and pubs - two locations where people tend to be at their weakest. Britain's dentists should beware.

fields.headline: A tap-dancing drum and bass steam train
fields.standfirst:
Tap Dogs
Sadler's Wells
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Tap Dogs
Sadler's Wells
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
The six dancers in Tap Dogs work impressively hard to convince us that they would never stoop to anything as sissy as a warm-up before they come on stage. Probably they just break into a couple of six packs with their teeth. These are the hard lads of the international dance circuit, the dancers who have forged their image out of Levi jeans, dockers' biceps, Desperate Dan jaw lines and metal-tapped Blundstone boots. Ever since Tap Dogs first took Sydney Theatre Festival by the scruff of its neck in 1995, the show has apparently been on a mission to prove that dancing isn't just for wimps and girlies.

The resulting testosterone-fest would be comical if the act were any less slick. Tap Dogs is danced on a stage that famously looks more like a construction site or a steelyard than the orchid-festooned ballrooms in which Fred Astaire used to rattle around. The dancers swing from scaffolding, teeter on planks and crash against corrugated iron, working up a seriously macho sweat. All of the visual jokes and puns are emphatically boysie - like the routine in which they pound out the rhythm of a steam train in a cloud of dry ice, dodge between blowtorches, or pretend to take a piss between their tapping toes. At frequent intervals they get out screwdrivers to adjust the screws on their metal taps - a deliberately far cry from dancers retying their satin ribbons or pulling up their tights.

The tap style which the dancers favour is also heavy duty. Though it's partly an illusion created by the amplification of the floor, the muscular heft of the dancers and the heavy percussion of the music, it seems that every step bears down hard into the ground. Compared to Astaire, who could seem as light as a water boatman, his witty feet splintering the dance phrase into staccato beats, these guys are all drum and bass.

But there's an arch self commentary going on too, which allows the dancers to mock their own toughness and occasionally play with a lighter palette of movement. As the show is building to its climax, two of the men swill buckets of water into a shallow trough and the others, clad in rubber boots, make ready to jump boisterously into it. The audience in the front rows flinch back from the expected soaking but of course the dancers place their boots in the water as delicately as ballerinas and perform a sweet splashy quartet. Elsewhere, too, they will stall the racket and skim the ground in lazy syncopation, giving us a chance to listen to nuances of rhythm and phrase.

But these are only brief interludes in the big, noisy picture. At 75 minutes, Tap Dogs does what it does with expert style. Any longer and the show would become a crashing bore.

 Until March 3. Box office: 020-7863 8000.
